First Edlltl©ini
Counselling is an act of assistance. When a person is in difficulty and seeks out
someone in whom he has confidence for advice and guidance, a situation exists
for counselling. It is very common situation in everyday life. Younger persons
seek the advice of older persons; less successful persons seek the advice of more
successful persons. In a situation like this, where one seeks the guidance of
another in sorting out one's problems, there is usually an assumption, which is not
always correct, that the guide who gives advice understands the problem of the
person who seeks advice, and that the solution given as a piece of advice is the
best possible solution. In other words, although the situation for counselling,
where one person seeks the advice of another person, is very common, the expertise
for giving appropriate advice is not common. It requires the special knowledge,
skill and competence of a counsellor in order to understand the problem of the
other person in the perspective of the other person and then to lead the person,
through a process of discovery to a solution or alternative solutions which are not
only feasible but also acceptable to the person. Htus, although persons have been
giving advice since time immemorial, counselling, as it has developed in scientific
psychology, has been of more recent development. Counselling is not just an act
of advising or guiding another person, a common function performed by parents,
teachers, doctors and others in our society. The art of counselling depends so
much on the specific knowledge, understanding, skill, attitudes and values of the
counsellor that it has become a specialised job for which one requires professional
training.
Towards the middle of the nineteenth century, when psychology staned emerging
as a science, one of its directions of growth was through rigorous experimentation
and research of a quantitative variety, giving rise to rapid developments in the
field of measurement of individual differences as well as of scientific phenomena
like perception, learning, intelligence tests, etc. This type of psychology came to
be known as experimental psychology, where laboratory techniques of observation
and measurement and the development of proper instrumentation became very
important. About the same time, however, developments were taking place in the
medical field and particularly in the treatment and care of mental patients. The
progress in this field was more in the matter of techniques to help the patient to
recover, which came to be identified as psychoanalysis and psychotherapy. These
two important directions of development, one emphasizing more the understanding
of the phenomenon under observation in the laboratory, and the other emphasizing


--- PAGE 6 ---
vUl Foreword to the First Edition
understanding of the person in controlled conditions, indicate the academic as
well as the practical aspects of psychology as a science. In trying to develop this
ait of healing the mentally sick person; there were developments in theories and
techniques which led to the development of a branch of psychology concerned
with personality. Later on, the two trends converged so that our understanding of
the dimensions and depth of the human personality increased considerably.
Historically speaking, counselling psychology is rooted in this praxis aspect of
modem psychology. The counsellor's ultimate concern is not with a theory or a
methodology, but with a person who has to be helped to solve his or her problems.
After the First World War, when child guidance clinics started working in the
USA, one of the challenges which a psychologist had to face was to devise tools
and techniques of understanding children. The tests which were available at that
time were concCTned only with intelligence. Later on, achievement tests came and
tests to measiue the progress of the child in development were also available. But
to understand a child as a person and particularly the child facing problems of
adjustment required something more than just tests. Techniques had to be developed
in order to help such children. Gradually, with increasing school enrolment,
adolescent boys and girls began to demand more attention from the psychologists.
The problems were not just educational.
Problems of adolescents, as in India, are more complex. They arise out of the
adolescent's total interaction with the environment, which has various aspects,
namely, educational, social, cultural, economic, religious and so on. To face these
practical problems of helping the youngsters, teachers in schools had to understand
the psychology of the child and the adolescent. Whereas in earlier times, the
teacher in India performed the role of a gimi, which included counselling, it is no
longer possible in the present times. Hence, there arose a need for establishing
trained counsellors for the schools, and counselling psychology is the scientific
basis of this particular kind of helping act.
In order to understand a person, it is necessary to have a good knowledge of
the psychology of the child, the adolescent and the adult It is necessary to understand
the nature of verbal communication, the communication that is usually observable
in any interactional process that takes place between the parents and the children,
the teachers and the students, the employer and the employees, and so on. Any
counselling situation is also a social situation because there are two persons
interacting in a counselling situation. For the counsellor, therefore, it is necessary
to have a'knowledge of social psychology and particularly of the processes of
interaction and the dynamics of a dyadic relationship. In order to help a person,
and particularly a person who has problems of adjustment and has, therefore,
come to seek guidance from an expert, it is necessary to understand the structure,
functions and the dynamics of personality. This is because more often than not
superficial problems are rooted in personality, and superficial solutions to deep-
rooted problems do more harm than good. The task of a specialist is really to
judge in a given case the severity of the problem and its roots.
In the teaching of young students and the teachers who want to be counsellors,
it is necessary to give a thorough understanding of the process of counselling,
apart from a knowledge of the techniques and methods of evaluation. There should


--- PAGE 7 ---
Foreword to the First Edition I*
be some practical experience available to the prospective counsellor becausecounselling psychology cannot be theoretical, although there is a theory whjcneeds to be mastered. One can only master it properly through actual work with a
variety of situations and clients of counselling.
There is a dearth of good books on counselling psychology in India. Here we
have an age-old tradition and culture of counselling as an acceptable m(^® °
human relationship, but we have yet to acquire the modem scientific tradition
professionally trained counsellors. It is, therefore, necessary for a book on counsellmS
psychology to present theories, methodologies, concepts, and such other matters
of counselling psychology in such a manner that this branch of knowledge an
practice can become assimilated into the newly emerging scientific and profession
culture. I am sure that a book like this one, which has been vkritten by Professor
Narayana Rao, whose competence in this field is of a very high order, should no
only help students of this branch of knowledge, but also others like teacher educators,
employers, managers, etc. because they also need to understand and master sotne
of the subjects tmd techniques of dealing with people, which have been dealt wi
here. I should think that this book is a useful addition to the earlier books on o
subject, and Indian students particularly will find it worthwhile.
S.K.Mttba

The fiist edition of this book which was published under the title Counselling
Psychology was written to meet the need for a quality Indian text fulfllling the
requirements of post-graduate students of psychology and education, and those
pursuing diploma courses in counselling and guidance. It was also designed to
serve as a reference book to counsellors, psychiatrists and other professional
workers. The furst edition was extensively used in most universities in India and
in some abroad. Several other non-teacMng institutions/agencies also used the
book. Suggestions from the users—students, teachers and practitioners—^were
received. This revised second edition. Counselling and Guidance incorporates most
of the suggestions received. Practically all universities in India onering coiu'se in
psychology and education offer counselling and guidance as an integrated course
with the exception of a couple of universities which offer a course in counselling
psychology. In order to meet the need for a comprehensive book in counselling
and guidance, modifications have been made, wherever necessary, in addition to
elaborating the section on 'Counselling and Related Fields'. New material concerning
'Educational Guidance' has also been added. Special areas in counselling are
discussed in greater detail adding new sub-sections such as 'Counselling of Weaker
Sections', 'Counselling Drug Addicts', etc.
The book in its present form is expected to adequately meet the basic objective
of providing a clear and concise account of the different aspects of counselling
and guidance.
Any one who has had the experience of writing a book knows the disappointment
of not being able to thank adequately the people who helped and contributed
significantly to complete the woric. I thank Dr Suijlta Sangamitra, Associate ProfesscH*
of Education and S.K.N. Rao for all their help.
S Narayana Rao

First Edition
This book has emerged from my experience as a teacher of counselling psychology
for over a decade, and the award of the University Grants Commission's Fellowship
to write it. Writing a textbook on Counselling Psychology is a formidable task. In
recent years there has been tremendous expansion of the scope of counselling and
of research dealing with different aspects of counselling. What prompted me in
this venture is the non-availabili^ of all the required information for students of
counselling in a single book. There are pioneering books, like Elahn and McLean's
Counselling Psychology, Pepinsky and Pepinsky's Counselling: Theory andPraciice,
and Bordin's Psychological Counselling, which follow different lines of approach.
A student is likely to be confused by these.
In 1964, Fr Fuster, SJ., and more recently, in 1976, Pasricha have published
Psychological Counselling in India, and Guidance and Counselling in Indian
Education, respectively. The two books have largely concentrated on guidance,
especially in the educational setting.
The basic objective of this book is to provide a clear but concise account of the
different aspects of counselling psychology. The term 'counselling' is variously
interpreted and understood.
An attempt is made here to set out counselling psychology as a distinct field of
specialization. For this purpose. Chapters 1 and 2 as well as Chapter 14 are
designed to present a succinct account qf the emergence and development of
counselling and its relation to other kihdred fields. The term counselling is confused
not only with guidance, but also with psychotherapy. Chapter 2 strives to define
the field of counselling as distinct from psychotherapy. Chapter 3 portrays the
developmental characteristics and the precipitating problems of youth in the
educational context in India, which need sympathetic understanding and assistance.
The underlying theme is that counselling is one of the helping professions, and in
this context, counseU'ees, parents, teachers, administrators and the public in general,
expect counselling to help them with their problems and difficulties. Their
expectations may often be contradictory to one another. It would therefore be
useful to state the goals of counselling at the outset such that there is no confusion
regarding the expectations. Chapter 4 sets out the counselling goals and discusses
them in the light of expectations of different individuals and agencies in relation
to the objectives or goals of counselling.
Counselling, as a helping profession, desires to bring about changes in knowledge,
attitudes •• and behaviour of individuals employing different approaches. These are


--- PAGE 12 ---
xlv Preface to tfie First Editfon
discussed in Chapter 5. No pretention is made to present the theories of counselling
in any great det^ or depth. Only representative theories are considered in their
essential outlines. Chapters 6 through 9 describe the counselling process at some
length. The use of psychological tests is discussed in passing, and not as a central
theme. More attention is paid to the counselling interview. Counselling, which
was understood essentially as a face-to-face and one-to-one interaction, had to be
extended to group situations to meet the exigencies of time. Group counselling is
outlined in Chapter 9. Chapter 10 specifically focusses on counselling in the
educational setting which includes both educational and vocational guidance.
A helping profession always has demands made on it for which it may not be
prepared at the outset. But a counsellor cannot ignore and be indifferent to the
need to assuage and alleviate human suffo'ing in different situations and under
different conditions. Chapter 11 discusses some of the special areas in which the
counsellor may be called upon the function. The special areas described are by no
means exhaustive; only a few are selected for presentation. In recent times,
counselling is becoming progressively specialized such that sub-specialities are
fast developing. This chapter deals with a few of them briefly.
In a praxeological science, there is a need for evaluation of outcomes. Counselling,
as a praxeological science, cannot ignore this vital aspect. A counsellee makes an
appointment with the counsellor and goes through the counselling process normally
until the relationship is terminated. Naturally, the question whether the counsellee
has benefitt^ or not from counselling is important. This calls for evaluation.
Evaluation is dependent on several criteria. Chapter 12 discusses briefly the problems
of evaluation and considers relevant critoia.
Chapter 13 has, for its theme, counsellor preparation, as counselling is fast
becoming a professional field of activity. A professional field must pay attention
to four requisites, viz., selection, training, certification and professional ethics or a
code of conduct of its members. This chapter briefly discusses the above issues.
The last but one chapter is devoted to the consideration of modem trends. It is
undoubtedly hazardous and foolhardy to predict the future especially when one
does not have all the necessary information to base one's predictions. The chapter
describes a model of counselling which could be of practical and heiuistic value.
The three-dimensional model discusses the target of intervention, the purpose of
intervention and the method or means of intervention in helping counsellees with
problems. This scheme hopes to provide the much needed theoretical model for
counselling. The last chapter gives a brief account of the status of counselling in
India. The appendix presents the ethical standards as set out by the National
Vocational and Educational Guidance Association.
It is thus seen that the attempt is to cover the field of counselling psychology
as broadly as possible, without entering into the polemics, and details could have
several lacunae.
The primary objective, however, has been to provide students of counselling
psychology with a simple and comprehensive book covering all the important
aspects of the field. The labour and the time ^nt in writing this book on counselling
psychology has been on the whole a rewarding experience.
Anyone who has written a book knows the disappointment of not being able to

INTRODUCTION
When we take a look at the world around, we are instantly struck by its complexi^.
What is significant is that this state of affairs is man's own making. Throughout
history man has pitted his strength against the world in a struggle for survival.
Unlike other living creatures, though similar to them in many respects, human
beings have brought about changes of far-reaching consequences in their
environment. The process by which organisms attempt to meet the demands made
upon them by (heir own nature and by their environment is called adjustment. Living
creatures never cease to adjust. Adjustive behaviour may be more or less successful
in terms of how it meets external demands and satisfies the needs of the organism.
This is a continuous process and is as basic to life as breathing is which itself is
a form of adjustive functioning. Man has not only adapted himself to the world and
its conditions—as he must for survival—he has, to a large extent, successfully
modified the environment to suit his needs. He differs from other living creatures
in this aspect
A significant result of this interaction between man and environment is the
series of material changes brought about in the world. These changes favourably
affect the living conditions and comprise civilization. In his interaction with other
human beings, man has developed a number of conventions, customs, rules of
social conduct and values which comprise his culture. Thus growth, which is a
product of man's interaction with his physical and social environment, has two
aspects that are not always clearly distinguishable—civilization and culture.
Civilization is becoming more complex, requiring concerted efforts on the part of
man to cope with life. The rapid advance of modem science and technology has led
to tremendous progress as well as unprecedented problems. Man has never before
possessed such a fascinating opportunity for self-determination to pursue unexplored
avenues and for enjoying life to its fullest potentialities. Paradoxically, the same
scientific and technologic^ advances that have made our present age progress at a
rapid pace, have also posed many problems and threats which make it an age of


--- PAGE 22 ---
2  Counselling And Guidance
anxiety. The problems of living must be solved first if we are to survive and move
forward. For this reason, the period of one's dependence on adult members during
the early part of one's life is getting progressively extended. A hundred years ago,
men and women were able to enter the mainstream of life in their early teens.
Although in some advanced countries such as USA, many adolescents become
economically independent, they are not considered mature enough for taking up
adult responsibilities. Thus today, most societies both in the developed and developing
countries, characterize adolescence with immaturity and perceive the need for
guidance to make adolescents responsible members of the community. Numerous
forces, often apparently contradictory in nature, influence the speed of change. And
change, as we have already observed, brings into operation a number of forces that
create problems of adjustmenL Some of these forces can be identified as:
1. Developments in science and technology
2. Better communication avenues
3. Economic interdependency
4. Search for a meaning in life.
As people become increasingly enmeshed in the lifestyle accruing from the
scientific age, the psychological consequences and behaviour become more complex.
As people begin to realize the potential for a fuller life that modem technology can
provide, they also become aware of the inadequacies of many existing institutions
and practices, beliefs and codes of conduct accepted by themselves and their
forefathers at an earlier age. As a consequence, while more people hope for a better
life, there is simultaneously a feeling of frustration and anxiety that they themselves
may not be able to experience this better lift which they feel should be available
to them. They search for new anchors, new guidelines for plans of action that hold
promise for realizing some of their dreams and aspirations.
FACTORS CONTRIBUTING TO THE EMERGENCE OF COUNSELLING
Technological changes have made a major impact upon people's lives and work.
Industrialization has resulted in social and vocational mobility. It has affected child-
rearing practices also. One of the important ways in which man tried to cope with
the rapidly changing world around him was to start the guidance movement The
guidance movement later led to the growth of counselling psychology in the first
decade of the twentieth century, based on man's concern for his fellow men and
their well-being, particularly the younger members of society.
Counselling must have existed in one form or another since the very beginning
of human civilization. Man must have sought comfort, help and solace from family
and close associates. However, it is only in the recent past that counselling emerged
as a distinct branch of psychology. As part of the broader field of psychology,
couselling, has of necessity, been influenced by the developments within it But it
is, in several respects, a unique field.
Modem counselling is a product of the educational system—more especially of
the American educational system. It has deep roots in the concern for an individual's


--- PAGE 23 ---
Emeigen^ and Growth ofCuldiuics and Counselllr^PsyehoIosy ®
freedom, rights, dignity and worth as a human being. The development of counselling
psychology can best be appreciated by analyzing the various issues that affected
and influenced its development The issues basically stem from man's conception
of human nature. Unfortunately there are several mutually opposed conceptions of
basic human nature. Is human natiue inherently evil, or good, or neuual? When we
refer to a characteristic which is inherited by all members of a species, that is, it
is innate and not learnt, it comprises its nature.
Human nature has been viewed as essentially evil. This view has its origin in
the Biblical teaching that man is bom in sin. Genesis (8 : 21) tells us, "The
imagination of man's heart is evil from his youth." In the early and middle ages,
the idea that human nature was basically evil gained ascendency. According to this
view, whatever the individual desired or longed for was considered evil. Man was,
therefore, not permitted to follow the course of his individual desires. It was,
therefore, the concern of the state, society and community to contain man's evil
nature. Society was seen to have the responsibility to reduce, if not check, it by
means of constant vigil, vigorous disciplinary measures and deterrent action.
As opposed to this view, the Reformation and Renaissance movements propagated
the view that human nature was essentially good. This view drew inspiration from
the conception of God. If God existed. He could not but be good. No religion has
depicted God as being evil. If God made man, man is ipso facto good because he
is fashioned by God, the incarnation of goodness. A great exponent of this view
was Jean Jacques Rousseau (1712-78). He held that man was essentially good and
that it was his environment that corrupted him. Therefore, in Emile, published in
1762, he maintained that the child should be protected from the corrupting influence
of society.
Pestalozzi (1746-1827) and Froebel (1782-1852), the great German educational
innovators, put this view into practice. According to this view, the innate goodness
in man should be drawn out and helped to bloom by removing obstacles that
hinder its growthNThis view is criticized on the ground that if man is by nature
really good, how^n his evil aspects, such as deceit, avarice, crime and so on be
explained?
Many thinkers hold the view that man's essential nature is neither good nor evil,
but is neutral. The modem scientific attitude favours this view. According to die
empiricist and objective standpoint, man is neither good nor bad by nature, but has
potentialities to develop in either direction. When circumstances arc favourable, the
individual is likely to behave in 'good' ways, and when they are adverse, he may
leam to behave in undesirable or 'bad' ways. If man's essential nature is neither
good nor bad, depending on the prevailing conditions and circumstances, man's
actions take the flavom- of goodness or become tainted with evil. Man can be a Dr.
Jekyll or a Mr. Hyde. If suitably helped he can become a creative and constructive
individual and, if misdirected, he can become dangerous to society.
The second dimension of human nature concerns its 'active-passive* aspect Is
man basically an active agent, always seeking new avenues and dtting on his own,
or is he passive, only reacting to the stimulations from the enViixmment? According
to the former view, the individual acts on his own accord; The latter holds that man
acts only when he is compelled to by the environment, because he is characterized


--- PAGE 24 ---
4  Counsellingand Guidance
by inertia and acts only when he must on stimulation. This view has many far-
reaching implications that lead to an essentially deterministic position. The standpoint
that man is an active agent also has very important implications that provide for
freedom, choice and self-determination.
Man acts in.his day-to-day life with the implicit belief that he is free to act in
accordance with his desires and choices. He believes that in choosing and deciding
he weighs the pros and cons and several possible alternative courses of action open
to him, implying thereby that he is free to pursue any course of action he desires
to choose. While this view of himself as a freely choosing individual is self-
comforting, several thinkers discount it and hold that man's belief in freedom of
action or free will is illusory and unreal. They argue that man's actions are actually
determined by forces beyond his control. Indian thought, which has been described
as fatalistic, has from ancient days explained human actions in terms of the doctrine
of Karma. Even in the early Greek thought there is much evidence to show that
they believed in a kind of unrelenting, pre-ordained destiny, from the dispensations
of which none could ever escape. Classical Greek dramatists such as Sophocles
have depicted the inevitability of the pre-ordained end from which there is no
escape. Man is only a pawn in the hands of fate. This theme is brought out in the
legendary story of Oedipus Rex. In the middle ages, also this view prevailed in
some schools of Christian thought. The Calvinist doctrine of prc-destinaiion, for
instance, is a good example of religious determinism. According to it, man at the
time of birth has already been marked for salvation or damnation both inescapable.
In the Persian thought of approximately the same period, Omar Khayyam, in his
Rubaiyat, says:
"Where destiny with Men for pieces plays:
Hither and thither moves, and mates and slays,
And one by one back in the closet lays" (XLDC)
"Thft Moving Finger writes, and, having writ.
Moves on: nor all thy Piety nor Wit
Shall lure it back to cancel half a Line,
Nor all thy Tears wash out a Word of it" (LI).
In contrast to this type of fatalistic determinism, modem science has made
positive cause-effect determinism its cornerstone. According to it, all natural activity,
including human behaviour or action, is lawful. Nothing is without cause. Every
action, however simple and insignificant, must have its necessary and sufiicient
cause. If the causes of behaviour are known in full detail, it should be possible to
explain and predict behaviour. This view is based on the concept of the model of
reactive man. According to B.F. Skinner, the hypothesis that man is not fi^ is
essential for the application of the scientific method to the study of human behaviour.
If carried to its logical end, scientific determinism is essentially pre-determinism,
i.e. all events are determined by what has happened before. The view that man's
behaviour is determined by external factors, if accepted, frees him from the
responsibility of the consequences of his action, as he is like any other lower
organism which is compelled to act in one way or the other (fropistic behaviour)
by external conditions.


--- PAGE 25 ---
Emergence and Growth of Guidance andCounselUiig Psychology S
Rejecting the above positions, the view that human nature could more
appropriately be explained as inieractionist is favoured by many thinkers.
Closely related to this view is the assumption of tlie rationality of man's behaviour.
This cannot be sustained without the acceptance of freedom or free-will in his
actions. For, without fieedom there can be no accountability for one's actions. In
the course of the history of man in the West, belief in reason had suffered several
setbacks. But it emerged as a basic postulate to provide democracy a solid base.
This position assumes that man is capable of directing his own affairs and those of
his society wisely and responsibly.
The conception of man's innate rationally is seriously questioned and deprecated.
Man, it is pointed out, has not been unbiased and unprejudiced in his beliefs,
attitudes and actions. Irrefutable evidence has been obtained to show that social
culmral, emotional and motivational conditions can distort and in fact have distorted
man's thinking and led him to act irrationally. Within the domain of psychological
thought, psychoanalysis and behaviourism have discounted the idea of the innate
rationality of man. While psychoanalysis explains the unconscious id as the major
source of man's actions, behaviourism looks upon man in terms of the mechanistic
model and explains that man is acted upon by environmental stimulations.
Notwithstanding the evidence put forward by them to deprecate man's rationality
which helps him determine his actions, there is sound evidence to suggest that man
is rational in his pursuits. This can be gleaned from man's scientific achievements
which underline rational systematic pursuits in unravelling the secrets of nature.
For, without freedom there can be no accountability for one's actions. This apparently
irreconcilable paradox of determinism versus fiee-will remains one of the perennial
problenrs of philosophy defying easy solution.
The conflicting views concerning human nature suggest that man is capable of
both good and evil, rationality and irrationality and exhibits active to interactive
behaviour within limits. The behavioural patterns need not be mutually exclusive,
for man can be both good and bad, mostly rational but occasionally irrational and
has the capaciy to choose freely in most situations, but occasionally may be forced
to act against his free-will by certain environmental factors and circumstances.
Thus no individual is always good and acts rationally and fieely all the time and
under all circumstances. Yet there can be discerned a pattern of behaviour or style
of life for the individual who tends towards one extreme or other depending upon
the nature of his past experiences. The diverse views of human nature as evil, good
or neutral, have important implications. If man is by nature selfish and destructive,
i.e., evil, society must sh^ him into a law-abiding, useful social being. If man's
natural tendencies are fiiendly, cooperative and constructive, then society has to
promote them by encouraging spontaneity, naturalness and self-direction. Strategies
of restriction and control are to be substituted by the encouragement and fulfilment
of inner potentialities. Belief in the growth potential of the individual is stressed
upon by modon educational philosophies. "The psychologist believes in the dignity
and worth of the individual human being. He is committed to increasing man's
understanding of himself and others."'
^Ethical Standards of Psychologists American Psychological Association, Washington,
D.C., 1963, p.p. 5-6.

MORAL AND PHILOSOPMCAL ISSUES
In a highly traditional and conventional society children are expected to follow the
course or way of life traditionally pursued by their forefathers. The individual has
no freedom to choose his vocation, his place of residence, his partner, and so on.
With the development of society, with enlightenment, scientific innovation,
industrialization and urbanization, some, if not most, of the traditional conventions
and values have come to be seriously challenged. They have been bitterly criticised
and opposed by sizeable sections of the society. This is, of course, not without
purpose. In the modem world, old ways of doing things are no longer useful or
even practicable. The growth of liberalism since the Renaissance and the Re
formation has blossomed into what has come to be identified in the twentieth
century as the movement for democratic values. These values are based on the
concept of individual freedom.
ECONOMIC CHANGES AND CHALLENGES
Early man was a food gatherer. As he became civilized, he also became a food
product. With agriculture as the basic industry, man's economic system started on
its long and steady course of development. Today we And that the occupations an
individual can choose from are legion. New occupations are continuously emerging
while some traditional ones are dying out. Consequently, there is a changing pattern
in employment trends. Industrialization and automation have led to increased
productivity. These and similar factors often confuse young men and women about
to enter the job market. Under such circumstances we cannot expiect them to make
appropriate choices without assistance.
EDUCATIONAL ASPECTS
In order to be able to direct one's behaviour efficiently, it is important for one to
understand oneself and the world outside. People must understand their needs,
potential, rational and irrational urges, and other factors of their own nature so as
to obtain a realistic self-image. One's view of the self and the world, whether
accurate or inaccurate, is a primary determinant of behaviour. Coping with personal
and social problems and carving out a good future is not simply a matter of acquiring
information and developing competence. One must also understand the question as
to why one should act one way or the other. A comprehensive value system guides
a person's choices and leads to adjustive behavioiu". This helps us understand the
'Why?' of our behaviour.
Man is the only living creature who finds his own existence a problem which
he has to solve and from which he cannot escape (Fromm, 1955). Human beings
are basically evaluative. Irrespective of their habitat, they are always found to say,
'This is Go<xl', 'This is Bad', and so on. Psychological problems centring around
meaning and values interfere and complicate the adjustive process. Valuing processes


--- PAGE 27 ---
£meigenceandCmwthofCu!danixandO}unseHlngPqKhology 7
ultimately constitutes everything that we feel or think. Every experience, from
satisfying hunger to sloving a mathematical problem, is one such valuing process.
The question of value judgements is crucial to our well-being. If we choose values
that are inconsistent with either the needs of our own nature or the realities of the
world, they only drive us to work towards our destruction.
Our problems largely concern self-direction, our need to solve the uniquely
human problems of understanding both 'Know how' and 'Know why*. Finding
answers to questions such as 'Who am I?', 'Where am I going?* and 'Why?* deal
with one*s self-concept, life plans, value patterns—in essence, with self-knowledge,
goals, competencies and value judgements involved in self-direction. It is an
interesting fact of the educational system that makes us study almost everything
else before getting around to studying ourselves. Yet we must live with ourselves
and our resources in order to be productive and find satisfaction. At the psychological
level, there are equally good reasons for the need for adequate self-knowledge.
Failure to understand the irrational forces in our make-up can play havoc with us.
For many of us, living is a matter of muddling through, rather than u.sing the
knowledge and resources that human history and modem science have opened up
for us. We go through life making many costly and needless mistakes ancf wasting
much of our potential for self-fulfilment Even today, literally millions of people
let their lives be.guided by superstidous assumpUons and common nodons of
human nature that science has already proved false. They are in the wrong
occupations, choose incompatible mates, bring up children by adopting questionable
methods. Beneath the facade of confidence that they present to the world, feelings
of inadequacy and unhappiness often lie deep-seated.
In response to the demands of modem existence many educational innovatimis-
have been adopted. The demand for professional and technical skills has given rise
to different curricular programmes and a veriety of specialized courses are now
being offered. A student needs guidance in the choice of a useful curriculum to suit
his capabilities and aspirations.
mental MEASUREMENT
Modem psychology has been fundamentally affected by the rapid growth of the
scientific spirit, resulting from the acceptance of Darwin's theory of evolution,
Machianism (positivism) and Galtonism (quantitative outlook). From this point of
view, hiunan beings are seqn to be no different from any other organisms. The same
concepts are employed in the explanation of the complexity of human behaviour as
that of the other living organisms. Like all Other living organisms, human beings
react to environmental changes or situations. They are as much a part of nature as
any other living being. Human behaviour, though complex, is predictable and
explainable as our present state is caused and determined by the past factors—a
simple response to simple pressures. A close examination of this explanation reveals
several lacunae in the logic. The idea that 'Human beings are reactive' does not
seem adequate. So it is revised to ihean 'Human beings are reactive in depth' as
a result of the influence of psychoanalysis. There have been several theories proposed


--- PAGE 28 ---
g  Counsellingand Guidance
for the explanation of human nature not merely as one of depth phenomenon, that
is not merely as reactivity in depth but human nature as a process of becoming.
The difference between the two approaches can be illustrated in terms of Aristotle's
quesUon- 'What is the place of man in nature?' and Sl Augustine's quesUon: '
Who am IT The first question refers to 'Man' as a natural being as in natural
phenomena Hie second concerns 'Man' in the process of becoming, man not justmuddled with his past but who is moving out to realize his 'being', his potenUal.
Knowing the true nature of man has been an eternal philosophical question: 'Man
know thyselF. . . .
Towards the end of the seventeenth century, psychologists started evincing interest
in the individual differences among people.. Daring the eighteenth and early
nineteenth centuries the study of individual differences received great impetus. In
the early ykrs this study was concerned with psychophysical functions like sensory
activity motor speed and reaction time. Francis Galton (1822 - 1911) brought
psychological phenomena like imagery into the laboratory for measurement. James
McKeen Cattell (1860-1944). a student of Wilhelm B. Wundi (1832 - 1920),
introduced the study of individual differences in the USA. But the most significant
development in mental measurement took place in France in the first decade of the
twentieth century. Alfred Binet, in collaboration with Theodore Simon, developed
his test of intelligence in 1904. This led to the enthusiastic study of intelligence and
several adaptations and innovations were made in the measurement of human
intelligence. Hugo Munsterberg (1863 - 1916) introduced the concept of applied
psychology in 1912 and this led to the study of aptitudes. Aptitude testing became
very popular after the publication of Walter V. Bingham s (1880 - 1952) epoch-
making book, Aptitude and Aptitude Testing, in 1937. This new ^d fascinating
movement of psychological measurement started by Francis Galton in England and
Alfred Binet in France opened new vistas. With improved techniques of increasing
the reliability, validity and objectivity of psychological measurement, the possibility
of guiding young men and women more effectively and appropriately has become
feasible.
THE MENTAL HYGIENE MOVEMENT
The terms 'adjustment' and 'adaptation' pervade our thinking about mental health.
Tlie society's concept of mental health is reflected in the ideas of school children.
In a study, several thousand children in many countries were asked to write
imaginative stories about men and animals with divergent characteristics. It was
found that the most common theme was that of conformity. In other words, to be
considered mentally healthy one must conform to the behavioural nornis of the
society. Another concept of mental health is that of ^ell=founded personality. The
pressures of society for developing a well-rounded personality are quite relentless.
By the time children reach class three they have been taught to equate divergence
with mental illness or delinquency, hfeny highly creative children apparently seem
odd. They feel their parents and teachers do not understand them. Many societies
abide by rigid concepts of masculinity and femininity (Mead, 1935) and those


--- PAGE 29 ---
Emeisence and Growth ofGuidance and Counselling Psychology 9
whose behaviour does not conform to these norms are considered mentally ill or
delinquent
Wilie (1940) argues that concepts of abnormality vary according to the frame of
reference. Individuals, families, societies and nations go by different frames of
reference. A person may be considered quite healthy according to one frame of
reference and mentally ill according to another. Jahoda (1958) argues that the
criterion for normality both in terms of statistics and in the way people behave is
of little or no use in explaining mental health. To define mental health as the
absence of mental disease is not tenable as there is little agreement amongst specialists
about both mental disease and mental health. A feeling of well-being cannot be
counted as a dependable criterion of mental health. Individuals may be happy imder
different conditions. But to explain their cheerfulness as mental health is not always
valid. Similarly, individuals may feel unpleasant owing to depression or misfortune—
this cannot be considered as an indicator of poor mental health.
Jahoda suggests that mental health, may be considered in terms of the following
aspects of an individual:
1. Attitude towards oneself
2. Growth, development and self-actualization
3. Integration
4. Autonomy
5. Perception of reality, and
6. Environmental mastery.
The individual's altitude towards the self includes self-acceptance, self-confidence,
self-reliance, self-dependence and initiative. One's own ideas and feelings are
available to one's consciousness (and are not repressed and inaccessible). It is
important to see oneself realistically and objectively and accept oneself as 'oneself
is' without distortions, hiding or concealing one's ideas from oneself. Crucial to
this perception of self is identity, i.e. self-regard. Many personality theorists such
as Rogers, Froram, Maslow and Allport stress that man strives to realize his own
potentialities and the realization of these potentialities is self-actualization. A mentally
healthy person has a positive self-concept and is motivated to strive for self-
actualization. He is integrated, i.e. there is a balance of psychic forces in the
individual. He has a unifying outlook on life and has a reasonable capacity to resist
stress. He exhibits a sense of autonomy in relation to the environment and with
regard to decision making. He exhibits a healthy and objective perception of reality,
free frrom distortion and displaying social sensitivity.
Another important cirterion is the individual's ability and success in mastering
the environment. This comprises the following:
1. Ability to love (psychoanalysis)
2. Adequacy in inter-personal relations (Sullivan)
3. Capacity for adaptation and adjustment (Hartman)
4. Efficiency in problem-solving (Humanistics)
Mental health is necessary for the complete functioning of the mind? It is a basic
condition for the growth of mind. Mental illness renders a person incapable of


--- PAGE 30 ---
10 Counselling and (Midanee
coping with reality and robs him of the zest for life and the desire to learn. Mental
health is mandatory in order to be able to respond constructively to stress and
change and not merely to adjust to these factors. Constructive behaviour is a prime
criterion of mental health and should be a major objective of education.
The mental hygiene movement started by Clifford W. Beers in 1909 had a
favourable effect on guidance. Lighmer Witmer (1867-1956) an alumnus of Leipzig
University started the first ever known psychological clinic in 1907 at the
psychological laboratory in the University of Pennsylvania. He also introduced
what he called the clinical method whose avowed aim was to aid and assist the
learning of school-going pupils. In his clinic he successfully treated a number of
retarded children. The work of a number of similar clinics led to the recognition
of the importance of emotional needs in the process of growth as well as in learning
and adjustment. An unfavourable emodonal atmosphere is now recognized as one
of the foremost factors in inhibiting learning and motivation and hampering social
adjustment
PROGRESS IN PSYCHOTHERAPY
The advent of psychoanalysis has had tremendous impact on psychotherapy. This
has led to the need for, understanding the causative factors of psychological
(functional) disorders."!S^ore the formulation of psychoanalysis by Sigmund Freud
the field of psychotherapy was dominated by the medical model, according to
which a disorder is caused by a lesion in the brain, or an injury leading to destruction
of the brain tissue, or by parasitical invasion and destruction of brain cells. All
mental disorders were explained to be caused by organic factors explained as above.
But the medical model used in the treatment of psychological disorders was found
to be inadequate and it was increasingly being recognized that the prognosis of a
mental disorder depended a great deal on attending to the psychological factors.
SOQAL THEORIES
About this time, sociologists and anthropologists such as Margaret Mead, Ruth
Benedict, Malinowski and Boas were studying different societies and their cultures
and had begun to realize the need for understanding the social milieu in explaining
human behaviour. What was considered abnormal in one culture was not so in
another, and it became essential for the psychotherapist to understand the social
mUieu sufffciently while interpreting the symptoms and diagnosis of psychological
problems.
The course of the development of counselling psychology was deeply influenced
by these trends. Thus the counselling movement started with the efforts of a few
dedicated individuals, each of whom was touched by the spectacle of human suffering
and misery arising from wrong or inappropriate choices made by individuals, and
the need to mitigate their suffering by providing suitable help.

lAAPORTANT PERIODS IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF COUNSELLING
The historical development of counselling may conveniently be classified into three
periods.
1. 1850-1900
During the latter part of the nineteenth century far-reaching innovations in the field
of psychology were made. This period saw the founding of the first psychological
laboratory at Leipzig by Wilhelm Wundt in 1879. Stanley Hall (1844-1924) started
the first psychological laboratory in the USA in 1883. In 1895 George Merrill
established the first systematic vocational programme in San Francisco. Lightner
Witmer heralded the beginning of the counselling movement by founding the first
psychological clinic in 1896. J.B. Miner established and directed the free clinic in
mental development at the University of Minnesota in 1909. However, it was Jesse
B. Davis who first used the term 'counselling'. He set up the educational career
counselling centre in Detroit in 1898. The guidance movement assumed, by the turn
of the century, such importance that the President of Chicago UniversiQf, William
Rainey Harper, stressed the importance of guidance in his annual addre^ in 1899.
Z. 1900-1930
During the fust few years of the twentieth century several significant events took
place. They were:
1. The first convention of the International Congress of Psychoanalysis was
held at Salzberg.
2. Stanley Hall invited Carl Gustav Jung to lecture at the Clark University.
3. Clifford Beers launched the 'Mental Hygiene Movement' with his epoch-
making book. The Mind that Found Itself.
4. The use of psychological principles was advocated in pastoral counselling
by Rev. Elwood Worcester.
5. lite Vocational Guidance Movement was started on a modest scale by
Samuel Frank Parsons and Eli Weaver in Boston and Brooklyn respectively.
6. Guidance was introduced by Wheatly and Boyden in Wes^it and Jessie
Davis in Detroit
7. Binet-Simon tests of intelligence were adapted to American conditions about
this time.
8. The Progressive Education Movement was initiated by John Dewey with his
epoch-making book, How We Think.
9. The School of Social Work started by Mrs. Adolf Myer between case work
and psychiatry.
These movements boosted the efforts to develop knowledge and services in
order to assist individuals in need of help without which they would have wasted
away. In the years that followed, these movements converged pointing to the need
for the application of psychological insights for obtaining and providing a meaningful
base and sense of direction for the efforts to become fhiitful and rewarding.

12 Counselling emd Guidance
Unfortunately, there is a wrong impression that counselling is a poor man's
psychotherapy. It is hoped that with a greater degree of professionalization many
of the prejudices and misconceptions concerning counselling will be dispelled.
The first decade of the present century saw the popularization of the guidance
movement. Eli Weaver published Choosing a Career in 1906. Frank Parsons started
the vocational bureau of Boston in 1908 and published his book. Choosing a
Vocation, in 1909. The state of Michigan started the first city-wide guidance
movement in Grand Rapids in 1912. The National Vocational Guidance Association
(NVGA) was founded in Grand Rapids in the following year. Thus it can be seen
that the vocational guidance movement grew out of voluntaiy efforts in educational,
civic and social work. These events not only signified growing public interest but
2^o concern for the future welfare of the youth. Educationists and administratorstegan to recognize that it was hazardous to leave pupils to fend for themselves.

that had also to be taken into account in Hnding suitable jobs. All these factors
afforded ample opportunities for the development of the guidance movement There
was a great need for its services and the movement braced itself to meet the

3. 1930-1940
In catering to guidance needs, guidance workers looked around for suitable tools
and techniques. The psychometric movement, with its fascinating and interesting
tests of mental functions and abilities, attitudes, interests, etc. began to attract
attention. They took advantage of the new innovations and pressed them into service
with great success. The guidance movement thus developed a vocational bias. It
came to be recognized as the vocational guidance movement as distinct from
vocational selection. In the vocational guidance movement the subjects were to be
apprised of their assets and liabilities (their abilities and skills) so that they would
have a fuller and healthier appreciation of themselves and choose occupations that
were congruent with their abilities. It was appreciated that vocational maladjustment
resulted firom an inappropriate choice of jobs in the absence of a proper and adequate
understanding of one's own capacities and potentialities. Donald Paterson (1930)
of Minnesota remarked that when Parsons launched his vocational bureau he found
his psychological cupboard bare, that is, there were no psychological tests he could
have readily used in guidance work. This was owing to the obvious fact that
the influence of psychometry was not yet appreciably felt. There were very
few psychological tests available and few persons were trained to use them at
that time. Consequently, Parsons had to be content with providing only the
occupational information basic to proper vocational choice. Thus, in the first few
decades, the guidance movement was aimed at providing educational and vocational
guidance.
The post-war situation remarkably changed the character of the guidance
movement The period, 1918-1939, firom the end of World War I to the outbreak
of World War II, saw the publication of books and important psychological tests,
such as Harry Kitson's Psychology ofVocational Adjustment (192^, Qark L. Hull's.
Aptitude Testing (1927) and E.K. Strong Jr.'s Strong Vocational Interest Blank
(SVIB) (1943). The National Vocational Guidance Association (NVGA), founded
in 1913, formed the American Council of Guidance and Personnel Association in
1934, which, later merged with NVGA to become the American Personnel Guidance
Association (APGA). Robert Hoppock, a former Secretary of NVGA published his
book. Job Satisfaction, in 1935. With Hoppock's (1935) work, the guidance
movement ^ded to become more psychologically oriented, unlike the earlier period
in which it was more concerned with school location and provision of career
information. Another milestone in the progress of the guidance movement in this
direction was marked by the publicatidn of L.L. Thurstone's (1887-1955) Tests of
Primary Mental Abilities in 1938. The following year (1939) saw the publication
of the Dictionary of Occupational Titles (DOT) which listed 18,000 jobs. The
guidance movement made tremendous progress in the hands of Donald Paterson
and E.G. Williamson during 1930-1940 at the University of Minnesota. Their work
was largely concerned with the objective assessment of the individual's abilities, to

This conclusively established counselling psychology as a specialized field or

There has been a growing awareness of the need for professionalism. For a long
time the medical men and general public had serious reservations about the credibility
of psychological techniques of therapy. Mesmfer's (1734-1815) work had two-foldeffects: while it popularized mesmerism, it also raised serious doubts in some
circles. Since then the need has been felt for a sound professional basis for
psychotherapy. In course of time, the need for improving the efficiency of training
led to scientific selection procedures. To exercise healthy supervision, a scheme ocertification or licensing was introduced as in other professional fields like medicme.
law, accountancy, etc.
Over the past five decades counsellors have gained overwhelming accept^from society; consequently, a large number of sub-specialities have developed
serve in settings such as schools, mental health clinics, rehabilitation centr .

community agencies, college personnel services, etc. Hiey incorporate the important
findings of the personality theory, social psychology, counselling psychology and
therapeutic techniques.
The early innovators were mostly preoccupied with practice and were impatient
for practical results. Perhaps because of their preoccupation with results they adopted
a pragmatic approach in the first two to three decades after inception of the guidance
movement Little effort was made towards theory building. When the early guidance
movement, which was pragmadc-in its outlook, developed into a powerful-counselling
movement, the importance and need for a sound theory came to be acutely felt.
Therefore, the attention of counsellors was naturally drawn to this lacuna. The
different approaches adopted by guidance workers and counsellors have led to
different approaches to counselling. Psychoanalysis, as a theory of human personality,
was like a Copemican revolution in psychology and was perhaps the first systematic
attempt to explain human behaviour—normal and abnormal. Theory building in
counselling began with the adoption of the psychoanalytic approach to counselling
needs. However, the different views concerning human nature and man's philosophic
concerns significantly influenced theory building. Thus several theoretical approaches
to counselling are in vogue today.
PHILOSOPHIC CONC£RNS
Counselling as a discipline depends on certain concepts, values and purposes which
together make its philosophy. Without this philosophy, or a kind of theoretical
framework, counselling would be shallow. Philosophy, to a layman, is an exercise
in futility. He considers it to be far removed from reality. He views persons called
philosophers as strange fellows wrapped in abstruse matters of no relevance to
problems of day-to-day life. The famed literary figure, Jonathan Swift (1667-
174S), described philosophers to be engaged in "creating certain edifices in the air"
(Tfl/e of a Tub). But philosophy is essentially concerned with man and his conduct
in its several facets. Philosophy in its true sense can help find a-sense of unity and
purpose in the life of every individual. Understood in this sense, philosophy can be
no more than one's 'way of life' as determined by one's sense of values, ideas of
right and wrong, what is evil and good, desirable and undesirable and so on. There
fore, thinkers such as Aldous Huxley (1894-1963) held that there was no question
of philosophy or no philosophy, what we need is a good philosophy, which would
provide us with a sense of direction and purpose to our actions. Thus an individual's
actions, behaviour, expectations and aspirations all comprise his view of the universe.
All human beings have a unique conception of the universe and of themselves—
this is reflected in decisions taken and choices made in everyday life.
The fundamental problems of counselling "are in the domain of philosophy—
because the very basis of guidance, its raison d'etre, is to be found in a cardinal
philosophical issue: concem for the individual" (Mortensen and Schmuller, 1976).^
®D.Q. Mortensen and A.M. Schmuller, Guidance in Today's Schools. New York. Wiley,
1976, 3rd ed. p. 56.

The.vhutnanistic viewj emphasizes the uniqueness of the individual and his
potentialities. The existential model of man is akin to the humanistic view in many
respects. The signiHcant point in this view is that it does not place too much
emphasis on man's past as do the psychoanalytic and the behaviouristic approaches.
The existential approach is very much concerned with man's present and with his
predicament It is disillusioned with traditional values and institutions. The
depersonalization of man, according to the existentialist view, has destructive
consequences in leading to a loss of meaning in human existence. It is imperative
that man makes his existence meaningful in terms of his uniqueness. According to
this view man's existence is 'given'. But what he (man) makes of it (the existence
as given) is up to him. It is his essence. Thus it is man's responsibility to give shape
to the kind of person he is to become and to live a meaningful life.
It is not easy for individuals to make life meaningful arid fulHlling in a fast
changing social and cultural world. Conflicts, therefore, are bound to surface in this
age of rapid change in which traditional values no longer appear to be valid and
new or emerging substitute values do not seem capable of guiding an individual's
behaviour. Estrangement with the older people, values and culture, and
depersonalization certainly make man's life in the contemporary world confusing.
This situation gives rise to the existendal predicament which is a challenge to make
living worthwhile. Thus living implies and involves the making of choices. Man is
a choosing agent, he cannot help choosing all his life. He is a free agent, free to
set the goals of his life and he is a responsible agent, personally accountable for
his free choices as they come to be revealed through the manner in which he
conducts his life (Morris, 1966).^ Freedom is the core of living and ipso facto the
source of an agonizing but inescapable burden. Effective life does not consist in
evading or running away from the responsibility of choosing and deciding, and
naturally must bear the burden of responsible freedom. Thus freedom to be is the
real freedom and the individual must pay the price for this.
Man would be able to live more fully if he lived in the present rather than in
the past or future which he could do by not exercising his freedom to choose. If
man were predominantly absorbed with the past, he would be leading a wasteful
life, since what is gone is irretrievable. Too much involvement with the past would
mean running away from the reality of today. On the other hand, an individual may
live for the future. His plight would be no better. A few take advantage of the
lessons of the past to anticipate the possibilities of the future. The life we live today
should profit ftom our past experiences and must be adapted to the possible demand
of the future.
Affecdo'n, Cognition and Conation
There is a strange and unnatural tendency to underplay emotion and to overemphasize
cognitive aspects. But feelings are an integral part of life. Man may learn to live
by suppressing his feelings and developing his intellect. But this would be a lopsided
and an unnatural life. Feeling and intellect are of equal importance and a harmonious

blend of the two helps one lead a full life. Man is capable of development and can
reach the stage of self-actualization if he harmonizes all the aspects—affection,
congnition and conation.
Sovereignty
The next important philosophic issue concerns the sovereignty of man. Is man
subservient to his culture or to his society? Should his needs, ideas and values be
sacrificed when thty clash with those of his society or culture? Should they be
subordinated to those of his society? With the rise of nationalism in the western
world, man was relegated to the background. Political theorists extolled the
supremacy of the state over the individual. After the New World was discovered,
people who cherished individual freedom emigrated to the New World in the face
of danger and despair, and struggled to fashion a society based on the inalienable
rights of liberty, freedom and sovereignty of the individual.
Modem counselling is based on the basic posuilates of individual freedom,
lib^ty and sovereignty. It is rooted in the democratic values of life.
From what has preceded, it follows that the counsellor should not take
responsibility for the client's choices and behaviour. This is firmly grounded in the
belief that the client is as intelligent as the counsellor, and that given proper assistance,
will be able to make rational choices and responsible decisions. In other
words, counselling does not assume to be omniscient and infallible. By taking
daisions for the client, the counsellor would be assuming responsibility for the
client s behaviour and would in effect be treating him (the client) as an incapable,and therefore, inferior being. Such a position would to a lack of regard for the
self respect of the client
Values
It follows that the counsellor has a deep sense of respect for the individual (client)
Md his values and does not in any way take him for granted and make him feel
inferior or insulted. He exhibits regard for the client He does so by respecting the
client s values, his religious beliefs, customs, etc. Counselling aims at enhancing
the client s sense of self-regard- The question of non-interference with the client's
value system concerns the counsellor's view of life. If the counsellor were to accept
a democratic view of life, it would follow by implication that his behaviour would
be modelled on. it namely, the principle of equality. This would ensure that the
counsellor does not look down upon the client's values and beliefs.
Counselling is committed to self-actualization as a basic human virtue. It accepts
the weaknesses of man and the reality of individual differences not as a handicap
or liability but as an opportunity for man to live a more productive and creative life.
Human values are not sacrosanct They are fashioned by man, a product of human
culture, hfen is not a victim of his culture. He is its maker, however, minimal his
part may be as an individual.fashioning the values. All individuals are characterized
by the common motivation of striving towards self-actualization. The concem for
human dignity occupies the central place in the counsellor's system of values. The
first is human frreedom, perhaps a God-given right of each individual to lead his


--- PAGE 39 ---
Emergence and Growth of Guidance and Counselling Psychology 19
own life, to choose whatever he finds desirable and good, and to follow his chosen
path. The second, namely human dignity, is something that man gives to himself
or earns for himself. He maintains his self-regard and integrity, however trying the
circumstances may be. In this, education has a vital role to play. It has to kindle
the urge for preserving one's dignity. This cannot exist where there is no fireedom,
where there is no self-regard and where there is no rationality.
Thus during the last five decades of this century counselling has developed into
an important concern of psychologists and has become a vital part of the educational
system at all levels. Further, it has found its way into such diverse setdngs as
employment bureaux, rehabilitation centres, hospitals and industry. The counselling
movement has permeated into several avenues of our society and institudons. In the
first few years the major thrust of the movement was actuarial, that is, assessing the
individuals' potendalides and capacides by using objecdve psychometric devices
and comparing the same with the expected norms for different categories of
individuals. On the basis of such comparisons the individual's probable success, or
otherwise, was determined. This data were also used to provide necessary informadon
to individuals for their self-understanding. Later, the emphasis shifted to the clinical
approach and this marked the growth of counselling as an important
psychotherapeudc technique. The emphasis thus shifted from guidance, which largely
consisted of providing informadon, to counselling, which comprises aiding the
personality growth of the client.
SUMMARY
Throughout hlstoiy men have been providing succour to their fellow men—
healing their pt^slcal ailments and dispelling their anxieties and fears. The
earliest known healers were the Shaman or religious men and witch doctors of
primitive societies. Gradually, following the growth of modem medicine,
beginning with the work of Hippocrates, the medical profession emerged as the
foremost among the helping professions. Correspondingly, the diverse
psychotheiapeudc techniques employed by healers differed from culture to culture
and from one sodety to another. In the latter part of the nineteenth century
more Interest was directed to p^chologlcal £illments and the explanation for
their causation was sought In p^chologlcal rather than in organic factors. The
work of Freud gave the psychotherapeutlc movement great Impetus. Freud's
depth p^cholo^ tried to explain the cause of several p^choneurotlc disorders.
Along with dils movement was a growing Interest In Individual dlflerences and
their objecttve assessment. In th USA James fAcKeen Cattell Introduced
p^chomotor tests for the measurement of Individual dlfiierences. BInet and
Simon's work In the testing of Intelligence was received with great enftiuslasm.
Attempts were made In different parts of the world to adopt Blnet—Simon
tests. The guidance movement which started at this time, took advantage of fte
p^chologlcal and psychomotor tests of Individual differences. The two world
wars gave a tremendous boost to the progress of the guidance movement.
The world wars brought In their wake several problems of
adjustment of the war veterans, requiring psychological Intervention.

20 Counsellingand Guidance
There was a tremendous demand for p^chlatilceind dlnlcal assistance. This was
not met owing to a severe dearth of trained personnei. Until about this time it
was believed that p^chotherapy was an exclusive preserve of the psychiatrists.
In 1942 Carl Rogers published his epoch-making book. Counseling and
P.^chot/]erapy, and convincingly ar^ed that the distinction between counselling
and p^chotherapy was arhflda], arbitrary and mateiicdiy untenable. The two
fields, according to Rogers, belonged to the same category of the helping
profession. This position appeared plausible as a result of the work of Freud
whose psychoanalytic technique was recognized as a very important
ps>'chotherapeutic technique and was employed by analysts both with and
without medical training. The following years saw the development of other
p^chotherapeutic techniques which were independent of p^chiatry leading to
the dariflcatlon of the scope of different professional fields like psychiatry,
counselling, guidance, etc
During the last five decades counselling has made a significant advance,
though among the several helping professions it Is the youngest. Naturally,
problems of deHnition, aims, roles and boundaries assume much importance.
Counselling as a fleld of knowledge Is diffuse. On the one hand it is invoh/ed
in fonctions bordering on guidance activities like Informadon giving and, on the
other, it is Involved In providing therapeutic assistance to Individuals to help
them gain insight Into their personalities so that they are able to resolve their
problems. Counselling as an activity Is pursued by both anrateur and professional
workers. As an occupation, counselling Is found In a variety of situations, such
as schools, colleges, hospitals, guidance centres, rehabilitation agendas. Industries,
homes etc If past performance is any guide, it can be reasonably stated that
counselling heis to play an Increasingly important role in the future.
It is not only undesirable and wasteful but also a dangerous practice to
improvise 'from crisis to crisis'. Human suffering can be mitigated If timely
assistance Is provided to individuals to help adjust diemsetves better and resolve
their problems before they reach explosive proportions. Counselling, therefore,
has a role to perform. It is very necessary to help Individuals escape Impending
CTlses by resolving their problems through the process of better and more
effective self-understanding, self-direction, self-realization and self-actualization.

INTRODUCnON
The traditional approach of defining the subject at the outset to help identify the
scope of the field, while useful in a sense, may prove to be a stumbling block.
Therefore, no attempt is made to define counselling at this stage. However, to
provide the beginner with some guidelines, a woddng definition is given.
'Counselling', like the terms 'personality' and 'intelligence', has acquired different
shades of meaning. This difficulty is due to the confusion between popular
understanding of the term and technical and professional meanings of it To counsel
is to advise. Individuals seek advice in a variety of situations. It is evident that from
the earliest times man has turned to his fellow beings for advice, encouragement,
sympathy, comfort and understanding. He has been able to survive his hostile and
hazardous environment only because of the innate concem.of his fellow beings -for
him.
(jhe goal of counselling is to help indiv'«'t"«'ig overcome many of their future
problems. In recent times, nq)id social change caused by industrialization and
urbanizatitHi has led to varied and perplexing problemsJ For most people the pace
of change is simply too fast and creates serious problems of adjustment>This means
that counselling should start early in rchool and should continue in order to enable
individuals to meet vocational and personal problems of adjustment in later life.
Naturally, counselling has to minister to a varied of problems, such as educational,
vocational, marital, parental and personal.'
Parents, teachers, friends, ministers, doctors, nuises, social workers, personnel
officers, lawyers as well as a host of other people give counsel. Their purposes,
methods and training vary enormously. Some give advice and some supply
information. Some help the individual understand himself and his environment, to
meet his needs and to deal with his problems effectively. Some are trained
counsellors, others have had virtually no training. Nonetheless, all of them are
concerned with helping people solve their various problems, ^ince problems can
arise at any time in life, counselling must necessarily be a continuing process
concerning p»sons of all age levels and placed in different life situations.^
*The tnajor objective of all counselling is to help individuals become self-sufficient,
self-dependent, self-directed and to adjust themselves efficiently to the demands of

a better and meaningful life. Individuals are provided assistance to enhance their
personal, social, emotional and intellectual devclopmenL Therefore, the counsellor's
services are preventive, developmental and therapeutic in nature. In order to assist
the clients the counsellor must understand their needs, motives, perceptions, defenses,
etc. In this sense, counselling could be deHned as a therapeutic experience for
otherwise reasonably healthy persons faced with problems. Recording to Rogers
(1942), "Effective counselling consists of a definitely structured permissive
relationship which allows the client to gain an understanding of himself to a degree
which enables him to take positive steps in the light of his new orientation."®

him to help others reach solutions to various types of personal difficulties" (Hahn

employs psychological methods based on systematic knowledge of the human
personality in attempting to improve the mental health of the latter.""

yprom a careful reading of the several definitions quoted above, it can be seen
that the emphasis placed on the various aspects of counselling by different authors
is not the same. The early concern was with cognitive factors; later this was widened
to include the affective aspects as well. The counselling process was also viewed
as a one-to-one process and in more recent years the relationship is increasingly
becoming less restricted to a dyadic relationship and the scope is teing widened to
refer to more than one client
Practically all the definitions concur with the view that counselling is a process
which involves bringing about sequential changes over a period of time leading to
a set goal. These definitions stress that the counsellor-counsellee relationship is not
casuaH, matter-of-fact and business-like but that it is characterized by warmth,
responsiveness and understanding.

3. Influencing the client's values, attitudes, ^liefs, interests, decisions, etc.,
with or without any threat or admonition.
4. Interviewing clients.

make the suitable choice. "The client alone is responsible for the decisions or the
