PSYCHOTHERAPY
Psychothoapy is concerned with the alleviation of human suffering. Medicine is
the earliest known science which was concerned with human suffering. The sciences,
as we understand them, can be broadly classified into three categories; formal
sciences, empirical sciences and praxeological sciences. Formal sciences arc those
which concern themselves with what 'ought to be* rather than with 'what is*.
Formal sciences, such as mathematics, logic, ethics, axiology are concerned with
non-empirical data. Ihcy are also known as perfect sciences as they are concerned
with the basic postulates and axioms. The empirical sciences are concerned with
the natmal phenomena, that is, the happenings or events in the world. The empirical
sciences are subdivided into experimental and non-experimental sciences. The
sciences, both formal and empirical, are essentially concerned with truth. The third
category of sciences, namely, praxeological sciences are concerned with the practical
application of the findings of the empirical sciences. Under this category may be
considered medicine, nursing, education, psychotherapy and the like. Belonging to
this category of science psychotherapy represents a body of knowledge that gathers
its data from a number of related professions all of which are basically concerned
with the helping function.
Human ailments arc broadly classified into two categories. Though this
classification is crude and does not stand close scrutiny, it is helpful in the
undersinding of ailments. They are (1) organic or somatogenic diseases or ailments,
and (2) non-organic or functional ailments. It has been the traditional preserve of
the medical profession to treat individuals suffering from ailments caused by organic
factors. For a long time in the history of medicine the functional diseases were not
recognized as such. In the dmes of the ancient Greek civilization some of the
functional diseases were looked upon with great awe and admiration. A person with
an epileptic fit was considered to be in communication with God. However, in the
middle ages, functional diseases came to be looked upon as instances of transactions
with Satan. They were supposed to be caused by evil spirits or the devil and the
victims were treated inhumanly. Often they were burnt at the stake. After the
Renaissance and the growth of the spirit of humanism, this attitude towards victims
of functional disorders slowly but steadily changed. It look over ten centuries for
people to recognize that an insane person is essentially a sick person deserving
sympathy and humane treaUnent Philippe Pinel (1745-1826) in France, Benjamin
Rush (1745-1813) and Dorothia Dix (1802-1887) in the USA. William Tuke (1732-
1823) in England and several others stand out in the annals of history as leaders
of this movement With the recognition that bizarre and unusual symptoms were a
'type* of disease, the medical profession took upon itself the responsibility to treat
them. But it did not take much time for doctors to realize the futility of.their
methods. The work of Franz Anton Mesmer (1734-1815) in Prussia and later in
France swept the people off their feet and Mesmerism came into vogue. However,


--- PAGE 45 ---
Counselling and Related Fields 25
it was soon disgraced with the appointment of the French Royal Commission to
investigate the 'cures' and Mesmerism no longer remained a force. About this time,
James Braid (1843), a British physician presented before the Royal Society a paper
on Neurhypnohgy or the Rationale of Nervous Sleep (Allen, 1949).
This ushered in hypnosis as a therapeutic technique. Dr James Esdaile was
known to have carried out not less than 300 major amputations in Calcutta employing
hypnosis. The discovery of chloroform and cocaine have today dispensed with
hypnosis in our operation theatres. The work of Josef Breucr (1895), a famous
neurologist in Vienna, and the discovery of psychoanalysis by Sigmund Freud
opened up new vistas in psychotherapy. Today, the highly specialized branch of
medicine, namely, psychiatry, which is concerned with the treaunent of psychological
disorders has become respectable and monetarily rewarding.
Towards the end of the last century and in the Hrst two decades of the present
century, a new Held of specialization emerged as a link between psychiatry and
psychology. This is the field of clinical psychology. Much later in the history of
psychology, counselling emerged as a specialized discipline.
The term 'psychotherapy', on closer examination, appears to be vague. On the
one hand, it refers to what is patent—the psychological form of therapy. On the
other hand, it refers to a host of psychological therapies, the broad spectrum of
which has hypnosis at its one extreme and counselling at the other. Counselling
thus is a form of psychotherapy.
Robinson (1950) holds that counselling is concerned with aiding normal people
to achieve better adjustment skills which manifest themselves in increased maturity,
independence, an integrated personality and responsibility. Thome (1950) is of the
opinion that counselling is a special type of psychotherapy adaptable to problems
of normal people. Bios (1946) considers that "counselling deals with relatively non-
imbedded proijlem cases, that is, with those persons who have not developed rigid
neurotic patterns, but arc primarily pressurized from the outside environment".*^
Psychotherapy, according to the more orthodox view, is concerned with the
reconstruction of the individual at both the conscious and unconscious levels. Unlike
counselling, psychotherapy is more concerned with alleviating pathological
conditions. Counselling lays stress on rational planning to solve problems of
adjustment. In brief, psychotherapy utilizes psycho-analysis, hypnosis, and such
other psychological approaches for therapeutic purposes. In psychiatry, in addition
to the above, physical and chemotherapy are employed. Counselling, in contrast to
the above, is almost always concerned with such problems as learning difficulties,
minor conflicts involving feelings of anxiety, hostility, etc.
COUNSELLING AND PSYCHOTHERAPY
We have alluded to'Carl Rogers' book Counselling and Psychotherapy (1942). Few
books in the field of psychology have had such a far-reaching impact on the course
'^P. Bios, "Psychological counselling of college studcnis", American Journal of
Orthopsychiatry, 1946.16. pp. 371-580.


--- PAGE 46 ---
26 Counselling and Guidance
of the development of counselling. Rogers was a psychotherapist with a difference.
He had no medical background. He was a clinical psychologist with some training
in ministry. Until his time it was commonly believed that a psychotherapist should
necessarily have a medical background. Rogers exploded this myth. "He destroyed
the gap between counselling and psychotherapy by denying that any difference
existed" (Lewis, 1970). In Counselling and Psychotherapy, Rogers holds that both
counselling and psychotherapy are exactly the same. Modern counselling
psychologists owe a great deal to him for his positive contribution to the technique
of counselling. However, we do not endrely agree with his posidon. We believe
that Rogers has created some confusion in the minds of counsellors and others and
that psychotherapy is a much wider field that embraces counselling in its fold. The
reladon between counselling and psychotherapy has been ambiguous as a result of
the fact that the terms are amorphously defined and loosely used. There arc at least
two reasons for this confusion:
1. The habit of the representatives of the medical profession to include
psychotherapy under the legal definidon of the practice of medicine. Persons
with a medical'background hold that psychotherapy is a concern of the
medical field. Medical jurisprudence has lent considerable weightage to the
posidon that psychotherapy is a medical process.
2. The semandc characterisdcs of the words psychotherapy and counselling
are not strictly the same. For example, the latter is not concerned with the
restructuring of personality. There are other points of difference which would
be of interest. Many pracddoners, medically trained, are obviously at a great
disadvantage owing to their ignorance of the theory and facts concerning
personality change. Psychotherapy is usually concerned with severely
disturbed persons who have to be entrusted to insdtutional care. But on the
other hand, as in the medical field, minor disorders do not require any
insdtutionalizadon. Persons with such disorders are treated as oui-padenis.
Coimselling is a service performed in many sctdng by different kinds of persons
with varying backgrounds. They all represent people with a common interest, viz.
to assist those in need of help to overcome problems concerning adjustment to
various situations in life. This poses some important questions: 'What is the difference
between psychotherapy and counselling? 'Can they be theoretically distinguished
as discrete fields?' A clear appreciation of this issue will help clarify several issues
concerning .the problems of training, practice and special policy in both these
fields. So far clear demarcation between the two has not been made possibly due
to practical difficulties. Neither do we have satisfactory definitions of psychotherapy
or counselling. Attempts to compare one with the other have only tended to present
biased accounts of each to make each appear exclusive of the other. A superficial
comparison made in terms of institutional setting or the function or the training has "
not been particularly useful either.
A close examination of the work of a psychotherapist and a psychological
counsellor reveals that the former sometimes docs what the latter does most of the
time and vice versa. However, tfiere is a significant difference in the nature of the
work that each does. The psychotherapist and psychological counsellor are


--- PAGE 47 ---
Counselling and Relatsd FleJds 27
characteristically concerned with different aspects of the continuum of some
dimensions of individual functioning.
Psychotherapy developed as a therapeutic technique in the treatment of illness
in the traditional model. Later it came to be recognized as an important method of
rehabilitation. Counselling developed in this tradition and psychotherapy initially
aimed at helping those who were very ill and unable to adjust to the demands of
life. Counsellors were seen in this context as those who helped the sick back to
normalcy. In this sense, medicine, psychotherapy, counselling and other similar
fields were cast in the role of protectors and supporters of human well-being.
It is only in the recent times that the role of counselling as an instrument of self-
actualization has come to be recognized. It began to be seen as a means to help
people realize their potential. This is essentially similar to the role of education
which calls for a far more creative role for the counsellor than a merely curative
or restorative one. The common man's stereotype perception of psychiatrists and
psychother^ists as a 'headshrinker' came to be extended to the counsellor also.
This 'headshrinker' notion is not descriptive of a teacher's function. In fact, the
teacher's role is contrary to this notion of headshrinking.
Teaching has also passed through the phases of performing, disciplining,
instructing and supporting functions to the modem view of encouraging and
promoting pupils b^ome more self-reliant and creative. There is a striking similarity
between counselling and teaching; both are supportive and stimulating services.
'~The counsellor, like the teacher, is more than a facilitator. He is an active agent
teaching and helping the client become more self-actualized by gaining deeper
insight into his existence.
In order to be effective, a counsellor cannot function as a mere professional
worker who mechanically applies certain rules-of-thumb methods. He has to be
actively involved as a catalytic agent, helping the client gain the meaning of his
existence. In this process of counselling, the counsellor's behaviour produces the
experience that facilitates the understanding of the significance of the client's
existence. The counsellor employs his knowledge and resources to help the client
solve his problems on his own. Becoming a counsellor is not a matter of learning
how to counsel. Counselling involves understanding of the concept of 'self as
instrument' and regards 'becoming' as essential to it This implies that the focus is
on persons rather than competencies and offers a challenge to creative persons
enable of rising to the demands of individual situations. There cannot be a fixed
pattern of approach to clients.
The concept of teaching generally degenerates into the traditional role of
dispensing advice and maintaining order and siatus quo. Teaching raises the question
'Teaching what?' If counselling is considered similar to leaching, the question:
'What is the role of counselling?* has to be answered. The basic goal of counselling
is self-actualization in the client. The cousellor cannot achieve 'self-actualization'
in the counsellee by a one-sided effort The counsellee has to realize it himself. The
counsellor helps the counsellee in this process. The conception of self-actualization
is fairly new and unfamiliar in the psychotherapeutic context. Adjustment has long
been regarded as a goal of psychotherapy and counselling. A well adjusted individual
was considered a normal individual and a normal individual as an average person.


--- PAGE 48 ---
28 Counselling and Guidance
However, equating adjustment with being average is not exactly welcome. Merely
being average does not make one 'something'. An individual longs to become
'something', achieve something and attain something that would be self-rewarding,
self-satisfying and self-comforting. Maslow has suggested that to be a self-actualized
person one should be a 'fully functioning individual'. Other personality theorists
such as Snygg and Combs referred to 'adequate personalify', Allport to 'self-
folfilment', and Mead to 'self-realization'. The key is that all these theories are
concerned about transcending the static and status quo levels of personality-
functioning. Self-actualization involves positive ways of thinking, feeling and acting
about oneself and in relation to others. Such an individual believes that he is liked,
wanted and accepted, and is able, worthy and dlgnifled. On the other hand,
psychologically sick people, see themselves as being unwanted, disliked,
unacceptable, unable, unworthy and undignified. The coimsellor should aim to
initiate positive thought and action in the counsellee. This depends on the self-
assurance of the counsellor. Thus he cannot be content with merely playing a
supportive role or showing warmth and sympathetic attitude towards the counsellee.
These refer to the initiative of the counsellor, i.e. what he does and not what the
counsellee does. Does the counsellor help the counsellee become independent, self-
supportive and self-reliant, growing or emanating from the 'ego-strength' of the
counsellee? Contributing to the counsellee's positive view of himself goes beyond
the supportive function of the counsellor. A positive view of self is a source of
strength and power. The fundamental goal of counselling is to produce a more
positive self and every act of the counsellor must contribute to this. A counsellor
cannot produce such actions unless he believes in them. For example, we cannot
teach another person that he is able through his own actions unless he finds himself
able. This experience directly contributes to the belief in one's 'ability'.
Change has been and continues to be the basic paradigm of progress, both in the
individual as well as in the society. The notion that an effective teacher should be
an agent of change also applies to the counsellor. Schools must promote excellence,
candidness, innovation, creativity and dynamism among other positive things, in
pupils and help them become responsible, responsive citizens. Schools have often
been criticized for becoming dismal and dreary, stultifying and dehumanizing pupils
and demanding conformi^ from them. Counselling must stimulate the development
of positive ideas and feelings and prevent the growth of negative factors in
educational environments. Schools should be enabling, but not inhibiting, agencies.
There, perhaps, continues to be the mistaken impression that counselling is
•poor man's psychotherapy'. This attitude unfortunately persists in some quarters.
We have only to hope that with a greater degree of professionalizalion much of the
prejudice and misconception concerning counselling will be dispelled.
It appears desirable that the practicality of the situation be considered with some
care. AU clients will not obviously need the same type of treatment The question
arises whether it is in the best interests of the patients and clients in the long run
to invest in a single professional group-the responsibility for the psychotherapy of
different levels of psychological disorders. Much of the confusion regarding the
scope of counselling is a result of the usage of the term in a less professional
connotation. From the earliest times, religious counselling was practised and the


--- PAGE 49 ---
Counselling and Related Helds 29
counsellor was the minister of the congregation to which the individual belonged.
The minister did not strictly restrict himself to questions of religion and faith. He
usually helped the individual with words of comfort and sympathy. In western
society, owing to the nature of their social customs and milieu, marit^ counselling
was found necessary to help assist in the resolution of emotional tensions and
problems. Many marriages were saved from going to the rocks by marital counsellors.
The marital counsellor not only functioned as a source of information on what a
young couple contemplating marriage should know but handled emotional problems
as well. He tried to reduce the conflicts and points of discord which could become
the cause of marital unhappiness. The field of the marital counsellor thus became
specialized.
For those involved in the field of education (teachers, parents, administrators) a
counsellor was one who provided the necessary assistance to pupils. He helped
resolve pupils* emotional problems and identify the cause for underachievement
and failure. He strove to diagnose specific leaning difficulties and helped provide
remedies. Thus counselling has had very close ties with education. Both share the
common goal of contributing to the personality growth and development of
individuals.
In considering the kind of assistance that a person needs, it is necessary to focus
on the personalify role problems along the dimension of intensity of the internal
disturbance. These difficulties may stem from any psychic factor or from emotional
difficulties requiring special learning. The psychotherapist is largely concerned
with the areas of moderate to intense intra-personal disturbances. His primary concern
is with the individual's point of contact with the external world. For the
psychotherapist, the role problems of his clients are of interest because they throw
light on the inner conflicts. The counsellor is concerned with his client's resources
to use them as teaching tools and his most characteristic work need not depend on
the events of 'transference'. He is concerned with areas of minimal to moderate
personal disturbance in relation to some particular problem area. This does not
mean that the counsellor is not concerned with intense disturbances. Both the
psychotherapist and the counsellor are concerned with the client's difficulty in the
role areas. This situation gives counselling its characteristic triadic rather than
dyadic character—the client, the counsellor and the role problem. The psychotherapist
is basically concerned with the felt presence of a problem involving deeper dynamics.
The counsellor is concerned with the interpretation of the client's psychodynamics.
The difference is best expressed by saying that counselling looks more often towards
interpretation and development of the personalify in the characteristic of a specific
role problem. Psychotherapy looks more towards re-interpretation and re-organization
of malignant, conflictual elements within the personalify through the relation with
the therapist. The distinguishing processes are:
1. Ego integration and analysis of infantile conflicts or impulses; attention to
conscious material as against unconscious or repressed material; and
2. Attention to the present as against the pasL
Counselling generally deals with the future: What shall I do with my problems?
Psychotherapy deals with the present: What am I doing that creates my problems?


--- PAGE 50 ---
30 Counselling and Guidance
Psychotherapy and counselling exist because of the need for them in our society
which has become highly complex, multi-valued and multi-roled. Additionally,
society is characterized by great economic and moral changes. This has brought
about serious problems of adjustment for everyone in playing different roles at the
same time or at different times. The situation of having to cope with the multiplicity
of roles and with value conflicts need attention. Counselling and psychotherapy
have developed to help individuals find appropriate strategies to function in relation
to their personalides and the roies they are called upon to play. Personality and
roles are often antagonistic but they go along. The roles are reasonably broad
culQual patterns or forms through which individuality is expressed. This freedom
to create an Identity through individual integration in playing the available roles
also integrates them uniquely and characteristically. Overt behavioural or action
patterns are the manifestations of personality. The interaction of personality and
situational demands generates and confirms the individual's sense of self-hood.
When problems arise, psychotherapy and counselling become useful.
Problems may arise in the developmental process of personality or in the failure
of personality to cope with the demands of role performance. They may arise owing
to the transition from one role to another, from role choice, or from conflicts among
different roles, or in the role expectadon due to the complexity and fluidity of
social environment Counselling, or psychotherapy are conceived as assisdng or
helping processes to provide optimal conditions in which individuals are required
to deal with problems of personality growth. A clash of roles in the individual's
psychodynamics leads to intra-personal conflicts and problems such as ambivalences,
guilt feelings, inhibidons and so on.. The problem could also be caused by fixaUons
at different levels of' psychic development Specific learning problems resulting
from inoblems such as vocadonal choices and marital adjustment also need to be
resolved. Conflicts may vary in intensity depending on varying degrees of intra-
psychic conflicts which may be independent of the immediate environmental
conditions. What usually determines how well a person uses his potential in resolving
problems or how rapitUy he learns or integrates, is the extent to which he is free
from <»• is afflicted by disrupting internal tendencies.
Psychotherapy is the treatment of problems of an emotional nature by
ptychological means. Counselling also treats such problems by psychological means,
the difference being that in counselling, the emphasis is on the individual. The
treatment is started with the establishment of a professional relationship between
the therapist/counsellor and the patient/client. The object of this relationship is to
remove, modify or retard (lessen) the existing symptoms and promote positive
personality growth. Though there are no differences between psychotherapy and
coimselling, certain distinctions are made and these need to be examined at some
length. The distinctions are made on the basis of:
1. Individuals receiving help.
2. Persons giving help.
3. Severity of the problems concerned.
4. Setting in which help is rendered.
In psychotherapy, it is customary to designate the person receiving help as


--- PAGE 51 ---
Counselling and Related Fields ^
•patient* and in counselling as 'client' although this distinction is only superficial.
Further, in some institutions, both psychotherapy and counselling could be carried
out simultaneously. For instance, a patient discharged from a mental hospital may
still receive psychotherapy and rehabilitation counselling.
The persons who undertake psychotherapeulic treatment are usually called
psychiatrists, while those who counsel are not included in this group. Psychotherapy
can be further distinguished from counselling on the basis of the training of personnel.
There is a basic difference in the training of psychiatrists and counselling
psychologists. The psychiatrist has a basic medical background while the counselling
psychologist has no such training. In the same way the psychiatrist may not require
the kind of training in the psychological field that a counselling psychologist would
have to receive. In recent times more emphasis is being placed on professionalism
in counselling. The learning theory, personality theory, principles of psychological
measurement, psychodiagnostics, etc., are not basic to the training of a psychiatrist.
These are of vital significance only to the counsellor.
A distinction could be made in terms of specific goals and the manner in which
they are achieved. In psychotherapy the goal is to overcome certain weaknesses by
any practical means, including psycho-surgery. The counsellor, on the other hand,
is concerned with the identification and development of positive strengths in the
individual. This is done by helping the client b^ome a 'fully fimctioning person*.
The techniques employed in the two fields may be disparate. In psychiatric
psychotherapy the treatment is physical, that is, it is either through the administration
of drugs, electro-convulsive therapy or psycho-surgery largely on the organic basis,
in terms of the medical model of ueatmenL On the other hand, in counselling,
results or objectives such as ego enhancement, self-integration and self-direction
are secured through the psychological techniques of establishing rapport and
providing warmth and support to the client to help him gain insight into himself.
The counselling process is essentially a learning process.
According to Patterson (1973), the two disciplines overlap greatly. Both draw
their inspiration from the same personality theories. If we were to examine the
definitions of each, we would notice the following similarities:
1. The specific kind of relationship between the therapist/counsellor and the
client.
2. The techniques employed by both of them.
3. Their objective which is essentially to assist the patieni/client.
Tyler (1958) attempts to distinguish counselling from psychotherapy on the
basis of the ^pe of ailments treated by them. She states that it is ncft the job of
counsellors to remove physical or mental handicaps. According to her, such disorders
fall in the domain of psychotherapy. However, viewed in the light of the American
Psychological Association's statement (1956) on the scope of counselling
psychology—^"to help individuals toward overcoming obstacles to their personal
growth, wherever these may be encountered, and toward achieving optimal
development of their personal resources"—^it is seen that the functions of counselling
are practically the same as those of psychotherapy. Hence Tyler's distinction appears
far-fetched. Another distinction very frequently made is in terms of the nature of


--- PAGE 52 ---
^2 Couns^lns snd Guidance
the clients treated by the two. Oiunselling is said to deal with normal individuals
whose problems are related to the developnient of their potentialities. On the otherhand, psychotherqiy is supposed to handle clients who are "deficient in some
respect" (Vance and Volsky, 1962). The distinction obviously cannot be sustained
on closCT scrutiny. Both the clients in counselling and the patients in psychotherapy
could be said to be deficient in some respect, that is, they have adjustment problems.
In Patterson's (1973) view the term psychother^y is used for the treatment employed
to remedy the patient of his emotional distuit^ces of a deep-lying and seriousnature. On the other hand, when the disturbances are not serious enough to
incapacitate a patient but are like the problems of a normal person which interfere
with the development of his potential, it is called 'counselling*. Patterson remarks
that "the so called counsellors practiced psychotherapy while psychotherapists
practiced counselling". The counsellor need not and often cannot limit himself to
working with 'normal clients*. The distinction made on the basis that the counsellor
works in a non-medical setting while the psychotherapist works in a medical setting
is superficial and cannot be sustained. Ibe clients in counselling are supposed to
be 'reality oriented', that is, their problems, are conscious. Most of the problems
dealt with by counsellors, it is claimed, are concerned with making educational and
vocational choices. Psychotherapy, on the other hand, is said to be exclusively
concerned with problems emanating fiom the personality of the clients and are
primly related to the unconscious. This distinction cannot be sustained on close
examination. According to mostauthorities, counselling deals with all the dimensions
or domains of the client's personality—cognitive, affective and conative. Hence
coimselling approaches psychotherapy very closely when it handles affective
problems. However, when- no affective problems are involved, counselling is
^owedly most differentiated from psychotherapy. If this were true, it could perhapsbe at best information giving or discussing, but not counselling.

RELATED FIELDS
{ Several terms have come to be used along with, and often synonymously with, the
^brm 'counselling*. For example, we sometimes speak of guidance and in certain
special contexts we use the expression 'counselling and guidance*. In the same way
we may use 'student advising* interchangeably with 'guidance of the students*. It
is necessary to examine these terms before we can give a proper definition of
counselling.
Advising
It is nattual for human beings to have problems. In most problematic situations,
individuals seek the assistance of others. Sometimes this assistance may be merely
material in nature. One could be in great need of money and approach another
individual for monetary help: Obviously we would not c^l this advising. On the
other hand, an individual may face the problem of taking a decision or making a
choice. In this event, he may approach another individual for assistance. This
situation has several important features:
1. There is an element of voluntariness.
2. There is a belief (right or otherwise) that the other person has the necessary
experience, wisdom and ability to advise.
3. The advice is sought for consensual validation.
4. The advice given is not binding on the person who seeks it, that is, the
person may reject it and approach another person for assistance which in
turn may be rejected if found tmsuitable.
Advising has no psychological implication regarding individu^ development. A
person in difficulty may seek advice on the problem confinonting him at the moment
He may receive help towards the solution of his problem and thus solve the problem.
But on a future occasion, in a similar predicament, he may not be able to resolve
his problem without any outside assistance. The individual may have to seek outside
assistance every time he is faced with a problem. Thus each piece of advice is
helpful only in a particular situation, that is, it has a very limited role to play. There
is another sense in which advising is sometimes used. On several campuses of
American universities, academic advising is a common feature—in fact it is a


--- PAGE 54 ---
34 Coims^lng and Guidance
characteristic feature of the Amttican system of education. Academic advising is
concerned with the specific relationship between a faculty adviser and a prospective
student
Parents and teachers often give advice. They suggest solutions that seem
appropriate to them. Often, parents appear heartbrokM and teachers resentful that
their advice goes unheeded. This attitude is psychologically inappropriate and
stultifies the very process of psychological growth or maturation as it makes children
dependent, anxious and inadequate.^
Guidance
juiSance, another popular term, has been defined in many ways. While there are
fferences among them, there is broad agreement that the objective of guidance is
essentially to render help. Sometimes it is used synonymously with the term
counselling. But more often it is used with the preposition 'and', as in 'guidance
and counselling'. Guidance is the assistance given to individuals in making intelligent
choices and adjustments. It is based on the conception that it is the duty and the
right of every individual to choose his/her own way of life as long as his/her choice
does not interfere with or infringe on the rights of others. It is based on the belief
that the ability to make such (intelligent) choices is not innate but like other abilities
must be developed. Every individual is potentially capable of achieving his goals.
But from childhood he is continuously hampered by internal conflicts or external
barriers. He has to learn to overcome the internal obstacles and fiw his latent
creative power. This can eliminate wastage and destructiveness arising out of internal
conflicts. The internal conflicts indicate that human beings are essentially emotional
creatures. The intellect is only a minor portion of the total personality. Higher
levels of achievement can be enormously enhanced by a constructive combination
of feeling and intelligence. The importance of this aspect of emotion and feeling
has long been stressed by great thinkers and teachers. They have also emphasized
the TOi»rtance of developing appropriate attitudes towards society and its problems.
One s likes and dislikes, one's longings and aversions really determine one's strivings
and manner of progress. The truly professional contribution to human welfare is in
the area of emotion. -The guidance counsellor has a unique opportunity to help
clanfy the role of emotions both in their positive and negative aspects. With his
grwt potential, an individual can achieve within limits, whatever his perceptions of
self allow him to. He can rise to the challenge of becoming a productive person in
fulfilrhent of potential for becoming—a life-long task.Guidance is essentially a helping process that comprises providing material or
non-matenal assist^ce to solve a problem which an individual may be facing at
a given time. Although help from an external intervention or source may help
overcome a i^oblem here and now, however, it does not guarantee or obviate the
occurrence of problems in future. Guidance in its psychological connotation is
more tiiM mere provision of help for the solution of the problem on hand.. It
consists in helping the individual help himself without having to depend on others.
In other words, it helps make the individual self-dependent and self-directed. The
helping process, psychologically speaking, is broadly of two types:


--- PAGE 55 ---
Counselling and Related Fields 35
1. It promotes the utilization of one's own potential; .
2. It helps the onset of change in one's persoanlity for desirable adjustment.\
Guidance is concerned with the former, viz. helping to bring about the best possible
utilization of the individual's capacities and the available environmental resources.
Counselling is concerned with the latter, viz. change. Therapy is its goal. Personalia
change in a small or big way contributes to personality growth and development'
of the individual. Understanding the difference between change and utilization is
important. A guidance counsellor helps facilitate education^ and occupational
choices. This can best be explained as utilization of available capacities and resources
rather than change in the individual's personality. On the other hand, when the
client has a personality problem the aim is to bring about a change in the client.
This is normally referred to as therapy. Of course, there is some ambiguity in the
use of the term 'therapy'. In counselling, some kind of change is brought about in
the client which is essentially therapeutic. It is commonly believed that therapy
should aim at bringing about as much personality change as possible. This notion
owM its influence to psychoanalysis which has personality re-organization as its
go^■in contrast, what is attempted in counselling is often a minimum change in
personality. The guidance counsellor tries to help the counsellee discover for himself
some blocked path, the clearance of which enables him to move forward. To be
more specific, the change sought to be brought about through guidance is one of
direction rather than quantity. By facilitating a change, the direction is sought to be
changed. The distinction to te borne in mind is that in psychopathology, the client's
weaknesses are diagnosed and the necessary therapy made available. In guidance,
however, the attempt is to discover the counsellee's strengths. A person who knows
his real strengths can choose and act according to them, leading to healthy adjustment
Guidance helps the client discover his personality and decide how best he can use
his assets and overcome the obstacles in his path.
Another important aspect in guidance is the manner in which the situation is
structured for the client, taking into account his expectations and goals as well as
the counsellor's. For example, an individual may be profoundly dissatisfied with
life. He may really be looking for a good change. Therefore, what may be actually
necessary is a small shift in direction rather than major changes. However, the
client may not be satisfied with this suggestion. The counsellor has to persuade the
client to discover for himself what his personality is like in terms of his interests,
attitudes, etc. and decide for himself how he can overcome his obstacles and move
forward. The next important feature is the use of counselling relationship to reduce
the client's anxiety. What the client needs is support, not shallow reassurance and
encouragement of dependence. Support is the act of lending the counsellor's strength
to the client to help him make the appropriate choices. The basie premise of this
kind of help to be provided through guidance comes from the psychology of
development and individual differences rather than from psychopathology and
psychology of adjustment. The assumption is that there are many different ways of
living and it would be best for the individual to make his own choices on the basis
of knowledge of self and situation. He has to choose such that he can live life in
his own way. Guidance thus has basic respect for the counsellee (unconditional


--- PAGE 56 ---
36 Counselling and Guidance
self-regarcO and views the help he provides as enhancing the counsellee s freedomof choice, responsibility and commitment to his choice.
The guidance counsellor should have in his mind a model for guidance. Different
guidance counseUors have different models depending on personaUly, preparation
and goals. However, there are some common features. AUport outlined three common
models of guidance:
1. Hie first views man as a 'reacdve being'. In psychological terms, this could
include naturalism, positivism, behaviouiism, operadonism, physicalism—
all included under sciendflc psychology.
2. The second model views man as a 'reacdve being in depth*. This would
include psychoanalysis, psychodynamics and the like. This view ignores the
possibility of creative or cognitive development or transformed personhood.
3. The third model views man as a 'being-in-the-process-of-becoming*. This
view is held by several theorists with different backgrounds. From the
psychoanalydc tradidon, Adler, Jung, Hartman, Homey, Erikson and Fromm
have expressed this view. Goldstein, Maslow, Rogers, White and others
emphasized this view as an essenUal characteristic of human nature. The
guidance counsellor following this point of view strives to develop an atdludeof tentadveness of outlook. Modem science has convincingly demonstrated
that there is uncertainty in the phenomena of nature, (Heisenberg's 'Principle
of indeterminacy*). If the growing individual cultivates the outlook of
lentedveness, he can fearlessly and cridcally examine all dogmas—cultural,
social, religious, etc. for what they are worth. It creates a posidve view of
the world and of one's own capacides. In this process, one may lose but also
gain equally. Loss or gain can never be a matter of absolute certainty.
William Jarnes stressed in the beginning of the present centiur how uncertainour founttodons of values are. Like Cardinal Newman, James recognized the
constructive power of commitmenL Any ideal that leads to long-range
Mnstrucdve consequences is pragmadcally true and psychologically sound.
Tentadveness and commitment represent disintegradve and integradveaspects. A sound blend of these leads to an appropriate perspecdve. This
can be helped to develop through guidance.
Gtiidance is a friendly concern to help an individual strive to develop a posidve
outlook.
The three models are important for guidance. The concepdon of man as a 'reactive
bemg may be e3q>lained in terms of stimulus and rt^nse (S —> R) behaviour. Different aspects^in the enviromnent stimulate the individual who responds to them.
Understood In this way, a human being is no different from any other organism,
simple or complex, which may be studied biologically. A few concepts and principles
^wn from a careful study of organisms can explain any complex type of behaviour,
including that of the human beings.' The question, 'What does it mean to be a
human being?' needs no special answer other than that a human being is a more
complex organism and his behaviour reflects this complexity. It is predictable in
principle as all behaviour can be explained in cause and effect relations. While the
S -> R position may explain most of human behaviour, it does not and cannot
explain all of it, because it does not consider a human being's consciousness as a


--- PAGE 57 ---
Counselling and Related Fields 37
determining principle. A critical examination of human behaviour reveals the
shallowness or inadequacy of the principle of man conceived as 'reactive being* to
explain human activity. Often the parent, the teacher, or the administrator finds the
child or the pupil or the individual behaving in a manner that baffles his expectations
and understanding.
Further, in terms of this conception, human nature is viewed essentially as
passive and dependent on external factors. The model of man as a reactive being
in depth explains behaviour in terms of principles such as regression, reaction
formation, and the like—all based on the psychoanalytic view that individual's
reactions are also caused by internal forces usually unconscious in nature.
Psychoanalytic causation explains in terms of the past history of the individual as
the 'conditioned response' for behaviourists is the explanatory principle. On the
basis of the model of 'reactive being indepth', the principles of recall and recovery
are central to guidance. Accordingly, guidance and counselling are carried out by
unearthing and disclosing to the client the troublesome, repressed traiuna. There is
no place for an individual's capacity to disregard his past or reshape himself freely.
As 'id' by nature does not change, the future can at best be 'redirected' and not
transformed. In other words, what one becomes is what one is, and what one was.
In Freudian terms, an individual seems never to be truly pro-active or even active.
Almost all the time he is reacting to some fixations and unconscious complexes,
One of the prime functions of education is to provide opportunities for the wholesome
development of such abilities among pupils. Guidance, in this sense, is an integral
part of education.
It is customary to use guidance as an important service in an education system.
The process of academic advising referred to earlier can be considered as an example
of guidance. Guidance essentially consists of giving information. The pupil or
individual seeking guidance is expected to make his own choices. The person
giving guidance does not choose but helps in choosing the more desirable or most
appropriate course of action. It is aptly said that 'guidance helps individuals to help
themselves'. It helps them make their own choices in such a way as to promote or
stimulate the gradual development of the ability to make decisions independently
without having to take assistance from others. The essential function of guidance
is to help make individuals respon.sible. Traditional education concerned itself with
the 'three Rs', reading, writing and arithmetic. Modem education, in contrast, is
concerned with 'four Rs', the fourth being responsibility. Individuals in a free
society which cherishes democratic values are free. They are ipsofacto req)onsible
for their actions—good, bad or indifferent. Guidance as a service believes that
individuals of average intelligence should be able to choose the right and discern
the wrong. They should act voluntarily and not out of compulsion.
Guidance thus comprises the giving of information. The housewife needs to
know the daily prices of provisions, the investor about the stock exchange rates, the
marketing manager the consumer trends, and so on. Different pec^le require different
types of information at different times. The information required may be as simple
as the arrival and' departure timings of a particular train or as complex as the
information required in making a vocational choice. Guidance thus, in its simplest
sense, is to render help, to those who seek it by providing reliable and dependable
information.

CUNICAL PSYCHOLOGY
Clinical psychology is concerned with the description, classification, diagnosis and
prognosis of psychological illnesses. The clinical psychologist usually functions in
a clinical setting, in a hospital. Usually the clinical psychologist is found working
in close association with the psychiatrisL We may, therefore, subsume it under
psychiatry which is usually concerned with the treatment of severe psychological
disorders like psychoses and neuroses. The clinical psychologist aids and provides
assistance to the psychiatrist usually in the diagnosis and evaluation of psychological
disorders.
The number of clinical psychologists, though large, is still very inadequate to
meet the demands of the growing population. In ideal circumstances the ratio of
counselling psychologists to the population must be much higher than it is in the
case of clinical psychologists or psychiatrists. Psychiatry is concerned with severe
psychological disorders requiring institutional care. The psychotherapist deals with
less severe psychological disorders that do not require hospitalization but which
seriously or adversely affect ease of adjustment Apart from these two categories
we have normal individuals exhibiting transient problems of maladjustment of a
less severe nature.

concerned with hygiology than, with psycho-pathology of behaviour. According to

The figures presented above speak for themselves. There is a compelling need

resorted to in order to provide the necessary help.
The psychiatrist, the clinical psychologist and the counselling psychologist are
all concerned with psychotherapy. But they function at different levels. The
counselling psychologist is almost always concerned with normal individuals who
experience conflicts of different degrees of complexity, experience anxiety, are
unable to decide and are subject to spells of vacillation. Indecision in matters of
conflict-resolution or choice of goals or paths of action is painful. The psychiatrist
and the clinical psychologist are concerned with pathological cases involving serious
emotional disturbances.
The importance of counselling in modem times cannot be overemphasized. It
can become almost mdispensable owing to such factors as rapid industrialization,increased knowledge, population explosion, urbanization, economic upheavals,
technological innovations, ecological imbalances, excessive competition, impersonal
bureaucracy, rapid rate of consumption of resources, impending threat of an atomic
holocaust, etc.

COUNSELLING AS A HELPING RELATIONSHIP
(Counselling is in its essence a 'helping relationship*. AH of us seek to satisfy our
personal needs. More often than not, in trying to gratify our needs, we find ourselves
in conflicting situations in which our interests clash with those of oth^. But
through the process of socialization in childhood, and later through education, we
learn to moderate our desires such that there is no open clash. We may learn to
suppress a few desires and inhibit other needs so long as our happiness is not
endangered. In addition to human suffering caused by physical handicaps and clash
of interests, a major source of suffering is to be found in one's own personality.
Often a sense of personal inadequacy and inferiority leads to lack of self-conHdence,
withdrawal and lack of desire for achievement Even if the individual has the desire
or motivation, he is hindered by subjective and environmental factors. The
psychological conflicts, namely those of goals, values, interests and the like, cause
an ebbing of human enthusiasm and zest for life. The counselling psychologist
alleviates this suffering by establishing a helping relationship. In the words of
Rogers, a helping relationship is one "in which one of the participants intends that
there should come about, in one or both parties, more appreciation of, more
expression of, more functional use of the latent inner resoiuces of the individual".
The commonly observed relationships such as those between the teacher and pupil,
husband and wife, mother and child, counsellor and counsellee, could all be
considered helping relationships.
A helping relationship is characterized by certain essential features. According
to Shertzer and Stone (1968), the helping relationship:
1. Is meaningful because it is personal and intimate.
2. Is affective in nature involving mild to strong emotional relationships.
3. Involves the integrity of the helper and the helped and is sustained voluntarily.
4. Involves the mutual consent of the counsellor and the counsellee either
explicitly stated or implicitly to be inferred.
5. Takes place because the individual in need of help is aware of his own
limitations and inadequacies.
6. Involves confidence reposed in the helper.
7. Is often achieved and maintained through communication and interaction; it
ihvolves give and take, that is, it is not a one-way process.
8. Involves a certain amount of 'structure'. The situation is either vaguely or
clearly defined.
9. Is marked by the desire for change in the existing condition of the client,
that is, it is concerned with the improvement of the client.
While most human relationships may involve the rendering or receiving of
help, over the years, importance has come to be attached to providing help
effectively and efficiently. In other words, helping has become professional
in nature. According to McCully (1966), "a helping profession is defined as
one which, based upon its specialized knowledge, applies an intellectual
technique to the existential affairs of others toward the end of enabling them to
cope more effectively with the dilemmas and paradoxes that characterize the human


--- PAGE 62 ---
4Z CounseUIngand Guidance
condition."*® In short a helping profession involves^pecialized knowledge, trained
skills and the desire to provide comfort to others^)
COUNSELLING AS A SOLUTION TO HUMAN PROBLEMS
Counselling aims at helping the clients understand and accept themselves "as they
-are", such that they are able to work towards realizing their potential. Often this
requires modification of attitudes, outlook and behaviour. The nature of the
counselling process depends on the setting or the situation. The counsellor accepts
his clients and has unconditional regard for their personality or self or self-worth;
Naturally, counselling involves the feelings of clients. It is often because the feelings
run strong that the counselling function becomes a highly delicate and specialized
function. In addition to the concern for the feelings of the clients, counselling has
a cognitive dimension through which a behavioural change (conation) is sought to
be achieved. The client is received without any reservations and he is helped to
state his problems and explore the possible solutions. The counsellor does not try
to solve the client's problems or make choices that could reduce his emotional
conflicts. Instead, through counselling, the client is helped to discover for himself
his strengths and weaknesses. The self-understanding that is sought to be reached
is often through the use of objective psychological instruments. It is generally
recognized that an individual has the ability to resolve one's own problems. What
is supposed to prevent the individual from making suitable choices is a lack of
proper or adequate self-understanding and understanding of the environment The
counsellor aims at making the client act independently in a mature and responsible
manner and with full understanding of the consequences. This is what is meant by
personality development, A child or an adolescent is not able to act independently-
He is not prepared to face the consequences of his actions. Hence, he is considered
immature. A mature person, on the other hand, is expected to function efficiently,
make desirable adjustments when he has the necessary understanding of his capacities
and liabilities as well as the environmental conditions—physical, social and cultural-—
in tCTms of which he has to act. Counselling aims at helping individuals reach a
stage or state of self-autonomy through self-understanding, self-direction and self-
motivation. Such an individual suffers from the minimum of inhibitions, conflicts
and anxieties. He is a 'fully-functioning person'N
