INTRODUCTION
Most human problems arise from life situations and significantly affect the
development of individuals. From the psychoanalytic point of view, problems of
adjustment are explained to be the result of the nature of the psycho-sexual
development of the individual. According to this view, complexes arise when
the libido is blocked or fixated or even tarried at any particular stage. Such
fixations in unfavourable circumstances may precipitate personality problems
and lead to problems of adjustment While the psychoanalytic position of Freud
deserves attention for its clinical insights, there are other points of view which try
to explain the reasons for adjustmental problems with or without employing Freudian
concepts.
DEVELOPMENTAL TASKS
Havighurst (1953) explains that individuals must acquire certain competencies and
skills as they grow from infancy to adulthood. He calls these competencies
•developmental tasks', which he defines as the tasks which arise at or about certain
periods in the life of the individual in relation to his environment. A successful
achievement of the tasks contributes to the individual's happiness and also to his
success in dealing with later tasks, while failure could cause unhappiness and result
in social disapproval as well as difficulty in the performance of later tasks. '
Developmental tasks, like biological growth, follow a pattern and are hierarchictoy
related. They are determined by biological, physiological and cultural factors We
expect a child of two years, for example, to walk without help. If the child c^not
walk, he cannot perform the developmental task which is expected to be mastered
by the age of two years. The chUd is considered to have a problem and this may


--- PAGE 64 ---
44 Counsellingand Guidance
interfere with the acquisition of other motor skills. It could adversely affect the
development of the child's personality. The ability to walk is biologically determined.
It results from the maturational process. In Samoa, for example, children at the age
of Hve or six are expected to be able to swim well and they actually do so. In the
Indian society the acquisition of this skill is not considered important at such an
early age and hence is almost absent at this age. This skill, therefore, is culturally
determined. Certain other tasks are psychologically determined. For example, an
individual is expected to evince interest and exhibit concern in achieving a masculine
or feminine role as the case may be, striving to find self-identity, accepting one's
physique and using the body effectively, etc. If a little boy were to exhibit a mature
sex interest we would consider it an aberration, while if an adult failed to show this
interest, he would be considered to have a psychological or psycho-psysiological
problem.
ADOLESCENCE
Development in the early stages is determined by inborn forces (inherited factors)
and reflects what human beings have in common with animals. However, the later
stages of development raise human beings above animals and make them distinctively
human. For Hall, the vague evolutionary principle of recapitulation governed the
unfolding of the human life cycle. For Freud 'sexuality' was the guiding force in
life and the ultimate source of all energy. This later stage of development, Hall
holds, corresponds to the stage of adolescence. It is during this stage that the
individual becomes aware of most of the forces or institutions that shape his adult
life. For Hall, adolescence was a particularly vital period in perpetuating nature's
evolutionary scheme for mankind. Adolescence has a kind of dual significance. On
the one hand, it represents the 'recapitulative' stage—the bridge between the primitive
and the civilized. On the other hand, it is a period during which the individual
becomes more sensitive to the cultural atmosphere that surrounds him. This increased
sensitivity, awareness and flexibility marte a kind of second birth. He would,
during this time, contribute to changing and promoting the institutions. Adolescence
sustains the society in its march towards progress. A hundred years before Hall,
Rousseau described adolescence as a kind of rebirth. It was described as a period
of great complexity that marks a vital stage in human development. This stage has
a particularly decisive impact on adult personality. Hall described this period as one
of 'storm and stress' (strum und rfrong). The imperiousness of adolescent sexuality
is responsible for making adolescence a period of emotional turbulence and
instability. There is increased reactivity and the normal adolescent is susceptible to
abrupt shifts in mood—high spirits at one moment and depths of despair in the
next This tendency to extreme and unpredictable behaviour presents society with
one of its greatest challenges. Hall's characterization of adolescence as a period of
storm and stress corresponds to the commonly held view of the teenage. He
emphasized the importance of adolescence as a period of development, during
which various elements of personality get integrated, resulting in the emergence of
a sense of individuality.


--- PAGE 65 ---
Developmental Characteristics ofYouth 45
Anna Freud describes adolescence as an exclusively egoistic stage. However, in
later life adolescents are capable of forming the most passionate love relations, self-
sacrifice and devotion. They are materialistic and selfish and at the same time, full
of lofty idealism. The growing individual cannot remain forever in the complicated
emotional tangle he had got himself into. The ambivalences have to be sorted out
and removed from the path of development. While relegating adolescence to a
lesser role, Anna Freud was broadly in agreement with Hall's portrayal of adolescence
as a period of emotional turbulence.Tt is a stage during which both the desirable
and the undesirable, that is the good and the bad aspects of human nature often tend
to be simultaneously revealed. The later neo-psychoanalytic theories, while not
accepting the emphasis attached to sexuality, also neglected the role of social and
cultural factors in affecting the course of human development.
Sullivan stressed the importance of the satisfaction of two inter-personal needs—
the need for security and the need for emotional support. These needs exist co-
terminously with life. Psychoanalytic tenets stress the immutability of the 'id' and
the mutability of the 'ego*. In other words, they hold that the basic human drives
change very little throughout life. Only the ability to handle them changes. Thus
the psychoanalytic theories view the human existence as an inner struggle between
the 'id' and the 'ego' under the watchful eye of an overseeing 'super-ego'.
Irrespective of the level of civilization that human beings may have achieved, there
is an inherent primitive tendency in them, craving for release. This reductionist's
account of personality development is the basic theme of the constant threat of the
'return of the repressed'. However, Sullivan views human development less as an
internal struggle and more as an attainment of certain crucial relationships with
other people, that is, securing certain 'inter-personal needs'. According to Sullivan,
what begins in infancy as a global, vague and diffused need for security, is
progressively refined to be fulfilled by one's close friends. What was once amorphous
and uncritical has bwome increasingly differentiated and selective. This explanation
of human development emphasizes significantly, inter-personal needs rather than
'libido' as a driving force in life. The motivating principle of human behaviour
involves the concept of tension reduction, which is similar to the psychoanalytic
explanation. Certain needs arise within the individual, which impel him to engage
in various activities for obtaining some gratification and relief. Sullivan holds that
it is the need to be free of anxiety that provides a key to all human motivation.
Classical psychoanalysis also stresses the importance of anxiety which, of course,
is caused by the 'id' impulses. They are the prime movers, although it is apparently
anxiety that appears to have caused the activity or behaviour. Hall, Anna Freud and
Sullivan regard adolescence as a period of turmoil, although the emphasis varies.
Heinz Hartmann stressed that the human infant is more than a bundle of drives
at birth and is bom with inborn capacities or 'ego apparatuses'. Therefore, even at
birth the human infant is made to respond, however primitively, to changes in his
environment. In other words, the human infant is born pre-adapted to the
environment. Radical shifts in his surroundings and inconsistent handling should
make it difficult for the child's adaptive skills to develop normally. Erickson was
deeply influenced by Hartmann, though his orientation was basically psychoanalytic.
Erickson s theory contains all the basic elements of the theories of Hall, Anna


--- PAGE 66 ---
46 Counsellingand Guidance
fteud and Sullivan. He portrays adolescence as a pivotal period in personality
development and provides an alternate solution to the 'storm and stress' phenomenwi
and presents an inclusive conceptual theory, explaining the many facts of adolescent
development, both normal and abnormal. If we describe psychoanalytic theory as
'mechanistic', Erickson's theory may appropriately be called 'organic'. In
psychoanalytic theory, there was too much ^phasis on the pathological and
defensive aspects of human nature, while ad^tive and creative aspects of human
nature have not been given due importance. Erickson explains that personality
results from the continuous interaction of the three great systems—the biological,
social, and individual—and these systems are inseparable and mutually
interdependent
Erickson agrees with psychoanalysis that at birth the human infant is invested
with a powerful set of drives and impulses. He is in agreement with Hanmann who
holds that the infant is bom pre>adapted to an 'average expectable environment*.
To this basic description, he adds the need for continuity of experience. He explains
that human development occurs in a more or less predictable sequence and that it
is governed to some extent by innate mechanism or maturational factors. This sort
of mechanism underlies all organic development—human and animal. The epigenetic
principle implies that anything that grows has a ground plan and out of this, parts
arise, each part having its time of special ascendency, until all the parts have arisen
to a form of functioning whole. (1968 p. 92). But the unfoldmeni cannot take place
in a vacuum. At least in the case of human beings who are bom with a physical
state of great helplessness and dependency, the biological dimension by itself cannot
achieve anything without the social dimension. The infant's drives cannot be satisfied,
his sense of order and consistency cannot be maintained and sustained, his peculiar
potentialities cannot become manifest, in the absence of other people who serveto stimulate, nurture, sustain and reward them. If he is to survive, he has to be
cared for. Development of potentialities involves social interaction. The child has
to toake several adjustments to the rest of the family if he has to grow into a
civilized humM being just as he has to leam about his own demands and theirs.
This social dimension in personality development involves a series of mutual
accommodations.
"Hie precise nature of accommodations varies from culture to culture. There are
obvious outer limits which are determined by the infant's needs and vulnerabilities.
He cannot be starved and cannot be severely abused. Between these outer limits,
each family is permitted to adapt its modes of treatment, popularly called child-
reanng practices and styles which not only differ from one culture to another,
but also from one family to another. This explains why no two persons ever
develop into identical personalities, though all are bdm with a need to categorize
and organize experience. No two persons are bom with precisely the same equipment
(physical, social and cultural). Each individual will perceive and respond to the
situation and the world differently. Consequently, even identictd twins do not have
precisely the same experiences and no two persons can integrate those experiences
precisely in the same way. This underlies the importance of the individual or
'ego-element' in personality development-in addition to biological and social
dimensions.


--- PAGE 67 ---
Developmental Characteristics of Youth 47
The proper co-ordination of biological, social and individual factors will help
develop a healthy person, who actively masters the environment and shows uniQ'
of personality, and is able to perceive the world and himself correctly. These three
systems are inseparable and are responsible for the development of the concept of
identity. A healthy individual develops the capacity to place himself in an ego-
space-time experience. This is responsible for the individual's recognition of himself
as a unique person with a particular past, present and future, within a specific
society. Those who can integrate their experiences are unified and those who cannot
are not. If the breakdown in ego synthesis is serious enough, individuals can
become severely disorganized. The development of a sense of identity is essential
to human evolution. As civilization advanced, each tribe and community conceived
of itself as being unique in order to make sense of all the differences that had
emerged in habit, custom and appearance. What is true of a group is true of the
individual; thus each develops the need to feel special or unique within the group.
Erickson's explanations of 'identiQ^* are somewhat unclear, a little vague and even
ambiguous. Howev^, we can understand the sense of 'identity' in its 'psychological
perspective' to include:
1. A conscious sense of individual uniqueness
2. An unconscious striving for continuity of experience
3. A solidarity with group ideals (Erickson, 1968, p. 208).
Identity, like personality development, has a biological, a social and an individual
or ego dimension. This helps us understand how a person manages to construct an
identity, how each individual has a need to feel ^)ecial, perhaps arising out of the
'unconscious striving for continuity of experience'. But this cannot happen in the
absence of a culture, for culture provides the care and consistency necessary for the
development of ego and formation of identity which is not only vital but central to
the ego-space-time experience.
All human existence revolves around the need to maintain a certain 'equilibrium'.
Erickson stresses the importance of 'continuity of experience' as a critical variable
in personality development. He describes the challenge of development as 'normative
crisis' or 'nuclear conflicts' and had identified eight such crises or challenges that
need to be resolved between the period of birth and death. No one, however, can
successfully and completely gratify or resolve these challenges and hence no one
is free from anxiety. Conflicts remain unresolved and each leaves a mark upon the
individual and upon society. Every human being, even as a child, seeks to formulate
a sense of self, or of the kind of person he is, and to obtain relief from an 'uncanny
feeling of dread' that the human being is beset with soon after birth. Tlie impressions
the child forms both of the world and of himself may be found to be considerably
at variance with those of others, once he interacts with adults other than his parents
and with other children.
Personality development is a process that continues from infancy to old age.
Erickson desigriates adolescence as a particularly crucial period for identity formation.
What happens in adolescence is of course, in many ways determined by what went
before, but that in turn determines much that follows. Thus adolescence occupies
a pivotal position. Adolescents differ from children in that they act and look more
like adults but they are not adults and are not treated as such. This discrepancy is


--- PAGE 68 ---
48 CounselHr^and Guidance
tied up with sexual development. The adolescent is described as beginning
progressively to-experience a sense of alienation from parents and other adults.
Sp.Tiifll conflicts and turmoil are only a part of the portrait of adolescence, as seen
in expressions such as 'adolescent rebellion*, 'gen^tion gap', and so on.
As the child grows and reaches puberty a psychological metamorphosis takes
place. Volumes have been written about adolescence. It is a fascinating area of
research for the psychologist Adolescence is a developmental period during which
a growing pason makes a transition from childhood to adulthood. It is a lime of
striking change and is considered a unique period. It creates problems for the
individuals themselves, besides being a source of perplexity and irritation to adults.
In most cultures this period has been institutionalize into one of several years*
duration during which individuals are no longer viewed as children but nonetheless
are considered to be too immature to be treated as adults. In this period youth are
expected to attain physical, mental and emotional maturity. They are required to
make serious efforts to assume vocational and civic responsibilities. The most
remarkable characteristic of adolescence is change. The change is physiological,
psychological and sociological. The sociological significance of adolescent
charactCTistics is of considerable importance. The biological development of human
beings is always paralleled by sociological development Changes in social attitudes
parallel changes in physiological stnictare.
Most wiitos have described adolescence as a period of storm and stress. However,
Margaret Mead's (1949, 1953) studies of Samoan youth have demonstrated that
adolescence is not by nature necessarily a period of turmoil and stress. The social
considerations determining patterns of thou^t and behaviour in the western societiesne^ not necessarily hold good in other societies in which the transition from
chilt^ood to adulthood is smooth and passes off without being recognized as a
special period. Studies of non-westem cultures by sociologists and cultural
anthropologists have given credende to the view that adolescence is a 'cultural
invention'.
Adolescence is a rather trying period, during which the fulfilment of adult desires
IS Relayed. Adult members do not accept adolescents as men and women and often
believe that they have to be directed and commanded. Yet the youth are expected
to have developed new interests and a new sense of personality. At one moment
the adolescent is treated as an adult and expected to act like one. At the next
moment he may be forced to act like a child. Thus in modem societies there is an
implicit conflict between the attitudes, values and ideologies of adults and
adolescents. The adolescents naturally experience much difficulty in defining their
roles. Uncertainty regarding their roles creates ambiguity in their motivations which
in its turn leads to emotional instability. The basic nature of the society within
which they find themselves causes many conflicts. What the youth learn from
books and from adults about what is desirable and good and what should be
accomplished is full of contradictions. One is told as a boy that 'honesQ^ is the best
policy", "truth is virtue", and so on. But he finds himself surrounded by adults who
often pay scant respect to what they profess and preach. Some of the adult practices
are diametrically opposed to what adults profess to be correct Adolescents exposed
to such conflicting experiences become estranged and alienated from their society.


--- PAGE 69 ---
Developmental Characteristics ofYouth 49
During this period there is a significant growth of self-awareness in the
adolescents. This involves the thinking of such questions as who he is and what sort
of a person he is, and he is very much aware of himself. Often he experiences
agonies of self-consciousness as he grapples with, and attempts to come to terms
with new values and ideologies.
The most important aspect of adolescents' adjustment concerns their emotional
problems. The impact of adolescence varies from individual to individual, family
to family, culture to culture, country to country, generation to generation (Honrocks,
1976).
It is necessary to bear in mind that there are bound to be individual variations.
The important points of difference could be when:
1. The adolescent becomes increasingly aware of himself and strives to test the
conception of himself against reality. Consequently he learns to fit into
personal and social roles which suit his self-concept as well as his concept
of others.
2. The adolescent seeks status as an individual, he resents parental authori^
and the close supervision of his activities by parents. In most cases
adolescence is a period of emerging vocational interests and striving for
economic independence.
3. The adolescent seeks status and recognition from his age-mates. He also
strives to conform to the standards of his peers.
4. The adolescent finds himself confronted with an emerging heterosexual
interest and frequently this may cause emotional conflicts.
5. Adolescence is important as a period in the development and evaluation of
the individual's value-system. These determine the central values which
serve to integrate his life. The adolescent has ideals which may conflict with
reality. Therefore, it is frequently said that adolescence is a period of conflict
between immature idealism and reality.
These points indicate the areas in which there is an anxiety-producing
developmental process. Sometimes adolescents may exhibit alienation which is a
syndrome comprising attitudes of ego-centricity, distrust, pessimism, anxiety,
meaninglessness, powerlessness and normlessness. Often this results in a state of
estrangement between the self and the objective world. The individual who feels
alienated also feels lonely, unwanted, uncared for and unvalued. The feeling of
alienation during adolescence may be a transitory phenomenon and represents a
normative condition. It could assume, under exceptional conditions, deviant patterns
of behaviour. Some psychologists consider alienation as an inevitable and necessary
state experienced by all individuals passing through adolescence. It is resolved
satisfactorily before adulthood is reached but it could cause misery and agony to
the adolescents.
Adolescence can also be marked by inter-generation conflicts arising from the
generation gap. The causes for inter-generation conflicts are legion. The most
significant among them are the incorrect perceptions that adolescents and adults
have of each other. This situation is exacerbated by the lack of adequate and proper
communication between them. These and such other factors cause much anxiety


--- PAGE 70 ---
50 Counselling and Guidance
and tension which could be leduced, if not eliminated, by providing suitable
assistance.
Another important aspect of the adolescent's personality is his conception of
self, which, by its very nature, is the least tangible. Nevertheless, it is necessary and
has a central place in the individual's personality. Adolescence marks a vital stage
in the development of the self-concept of an individual. Several adolescents
experience difficult in developing an integrated self-concept which is consistent
and is able to stand the test of reality. Self-concept is not present at birth and
evolves essentially through learning which in actuality consists of the individual's
conception of his several identities. The self-concept slowly develops, following
the inception of ability to think symbolically. The self-concept which develops
during adolescence becomes stable in later years.
ERICKSON'S THEORY OF PSYCHOLOGICAL DEVELOPMENT
Along with the psycho-sexual development as explmned by Freud, are corresponding
psycho-social stages of ego-development as adumbrated by Erickson (1950).
Following the psychoanalytical model, Erickson has outlined a sequence of psycho-
social development in which each preceding stage of development is a preparatory
phase for the subsequent one. Erickson's theory stresses the epigenic principle. .
According to this, the development of new properties which were not contained in
the original situation develop as a result of environmental influences and the
interaction between the former (original situation) and the latter (environmental
factors). Thus at each stage of development the individual encounters new situations
to which he may or may not be ready to adjust himself, depending on whether he
has an appropriate plan to enable him to find his identity. Sometimes the situation
that he encounters may lead to a crisis owing to its own problems and conflicts.
Erickson emphasizes the problems unique to adolescents and adults and has
contributed towards rectifying the one-sided explanations concerning childhood as
the prime source of all adjustmental problems as described by Freudian
psychoanalyas. He argues that personality development does not stop at adolescence,but continues throughout the life of the individual.
Ego QMalities
Erickson explains that the individual has ego qualities which emerge dunng thecritical periods of his development
The first age of an individual is characterized by a'normauve
conflict between trust and mistrust according to Erickson.
first ego quality. This conflict is an interpersonal one asperiod, Wancy'^U.ecluldhastobegiven so™

--- PAGE 71 ---
I
feelings of mistrust. In early childhood, the individual learns to count or not to
count on other people. His interactions provide, aileast in part, the basis for his
identity. This basic trust versus mistrust is the first of the ego qualities. By 'basic'
is meant that it is not essentially conscious but is an underlying feeling of which
the individual has a vague sense. Trust implies that one leams to ^pect a certain
behaviour from others which is consistent. When this ego quality is not well
developed, the individual has a sense of mistrust and is wary of trusting others and
anticipates unpleasantness in his dealings with others. Infants never quite resolve
the conflict between trust and mistrust, neither do adults. The need to trust in a
higher power (God) is generally found among adults. The sense of trust underlies
the virtue of faith in adults.
The second ego quality is autonomy versus shame and doubt. Erickson's expla
nation of this stage combines psychoanalytic, interpersonal and anthropological
elements. Having progressed beyond the passive receptiveness of the first stage, the
child is concerned with 'holding on' and letting go* in general. The child has
advanced considerably by this stage, but is still highly dependent and wants to
assert himself. Almost inevitably he finds himself at odds with his parents. Through
interaction with them the child can hope to achieve a successful equilibrium between
autonomy and self-doubt This stage has a lasting impact both on society and
human nature. It is at this stage that the individual's autonomous will and his desire
to do things his way become apparent Erickson traces the origin of will or 'will
power' in adulthood to this stage. It is also at this stage that 'control' and 'regulations*
first enter the picture and a parallel can be drawn between parent-child conflict and
the institutions of law and-order.
As the child grows he progressively becomes self-dependent and experiences a
sense of autonomy. When he fails to experience a sense of autonomy, he feels a
sense of shame. This stage of development is a decisive one in the development of
love, cooperation, willingness and freedom of self-expression. A thwarting of this
quality leads to hate, non-cooperaticm, unwillingness and suppression of self-
expression.
The third ego quality is initiative versus guilt. A child who experiences autonomy
is able to take initiative. An individual who has not experienced autonomy may
develop a sense of guilt Around the age of four to five years, a child is able to use
his locomotory organs and move about freely to explore his immediate environment.
Simultaneously he leams to speak. Using locomotion and language, he expands his
imagination. This stage plays a crucial part in the development of his conscience.
The fourth ego quality is industry versus inferiority. This fourth phase differs
from the preceding three in that it is not a swing from an 'inner upheaval to a new
mastery*. This stage encompasses the child's elementary school years and emphasizes
the impact that education can have during thes6 years. In all cultures, the
channelization and direction of a child's energies form an important part at this
stage. The problem of channelling human energies originates in childhood but
continues to remain a vital issue for adults and every culture must lay down certain
guidelines for productive adult activity. Children must begin to feel and adults
should retain the feeling that the actions serve some purpose. The child acquires the
skills needed to work within his particular society. Learning these skills requires


--- PAGE 72 ---
52 Counsellingand Guidance
some discipline. Consequenily, this stage involves transformation of the sense of
initimive into a sense of industry. The child's sense of industry always competes
with a sense of inferiority. Therefore, some guidance, gentle and unobtrusive, is
necessary. The trend towards 'sensitiveness' may not only lead to no learning but
also to ideas of procrastination and evasion of responsibili^. If a balance is struck
between industry and inferiority the child emerges from this stage with his self-
esteem intact and a sense of industry, which develops into competence. The child
learns about the kinds of work his society considers valuable and he develops ideas
of fitting himself harmoniously into the occupational hierarchy.
The growing child is explorative and manipulates his environment. He tries to
change and adapt to his environmenL In his desire to be a constructive person he
believes that he can do several things and he actually tries to carry out his plans.
Failure in this expectation results in feelings of inferiority. Success prods him on
to -further work and makes him industrious.
The fifth ego quality is identity versus role diffiision. This stage corresponds to
the adolescent years and is a critical period in the personality development of the
individual. Since the individual ego has been set upon a certain course during the
previous four stages, the events of this period are partially determined, i.e. they
must in some sense follow the course the ego has so far followed. The child has
continued to nurture and assimilate the customs and values of his culture and in the
process he has begun to formulate an identity. This complex process of identity
formation, is a continuous series of back-and-forth manoeuvres.
Adolescence is a crucial period for identity-formation and depends on the
capacities of the adolescent age. For this one must be able to entertain a number
of different alternatives. One must be able to examine one's existence from a
-historical perspective, evaluating the sort of Individual one is at present and the sort
of person one can become in future. The adolescent, besides possessing the necessary
skills to decide upon an identity, is also faced with certain pressures to do so. He
can build upon the identification of the past in this endeavour of the feelings of
trust, autonomy, initiative and industry that have hopefully resulted from his attempts
to cope with other normative crises. He must look ahead to the conflicts of adulthood
as well as develop his own strategies for meeting them in the midst of so many
things around him at once or simultaneously. Since the adolescent must take many
decisions about himself not merely on the basis of what he has become but also
upon his best assumption of what he is likely to become, there is considerable
potential for indecision. Erickson, therefore, describes this core conflict Of
adolescence as 'idendty versus diffusion (confusion)'.
According to Erickson, the core conflict of adolescents is idenliQ' versus identity-
diffusion and several other adolescent conflicts could be subsumed under it. As
puberty approaches, there is a certain amount of confusion in an individual regarding
his own role and that of the expectations of others. Aidtudes towards people and
actions change. The adolescent who is able to successfully resolve his idendty
crisis re-groups his childhood identificadons and tests a new idendty in which he
has confidence. Adolescents who are unsuccessful in the resolution of this identity
crisis become ego-diffused. There is a kind of role differendadon which one has to
learn as one grows—because one is a boy/girl, one does or does not do certain

Developmental Characteristics of YouOi 53
kinds of things. The roles are not clear and well defined. There is an enormous
amount of role confusion and role diffusion, that is, there is inabiliQ' to decide
about the kind of person one wants or desires to be. Either because of social
circumstances or family upbringing the youth may fail to attain a sense of personal
identic and a desirable concept of one's self. This could lead to a sense of not
being able to know 'what one is' or 'where one belongs' or' to whom one belongs'.
Such confusion could lead to delinquencies. A few seek 'negative identity', that is,
one which is contradictory to the expected or socially approved norm. But this
should not be construed as a 'lost' case. Adolescents who fail to establish a clear
sense of personal identic could improve with sympathetic assistance.
One who has attained a 'working sense of ego-identity' cannot aHbrd to be
complacent One will of necessity encounter challenges and threats to this identic
in future siuiations, for the solving of problems at one stage is no guarantee against
the cropping up of new problems which could jeopardize one's adjustment
The sixth ego quality is intimacy versus isolation. Erickson considers social
interaction as an unavoidable and fundamental influence on personally development
He believes that a stiu-dy self image is necessary and it helps develop intimate
relations. Identity is the prerequisite of all interpersonal relationships. Successful
young persons must be able to express warmth and affection for others and they
must be able to distinguish friends from enemies. One must be secure about oneself
to endure and even enjoy being by oneself. The major.preoccupations of adulthood,
love and work, require a balance between these two trends. A normal person has
to love and work (lieben und arbeiten) to be a balanced healthy individual. The
individual who fears closeness may withdraw from others and use his work as a
protective shield. But the person who cannot bear to be alone, who can never shut
out others, can never work. This 'age of man' with his emphasis on love and
productivity is characterized by a broadening of social horizons. In early adulthood,
the individual has critically moved beyond the confines of the parental home into
a larger and more variegated community. In the young adult this new sense of
participation encourages a fellow-feeling and solidarity that did not exist before.
A successful search for identiy leads to a willingness to seek and obtain satisfying
companionship. The individual is ready to commit himself to affiliations or
partnerships. An avoidance of this leads to the painful state of isolation and self-
absorption. This stage is arrived at in adulthood in the life-stage development of the
individual. The human life process is not only one of growth and development, but
also of assimilation and accommodation, leading to a progressive differentiation of
functions and roles which, in course of further development, are synthesized or
integrated into mature roles and personal identities. The growing person seeks to
find his identity which determines the feeling of acceptance of self and a sense of
integrity and belonging. A lack of sense of identiy could lead to feelings of distress.
The life sequence of individuals includes two important periods in which negativism
could be a major tendency of expression. One of these appears early in childhood
and the other later in adolescence. Negativism may result from the blocking of the
mastery motive by the environmental factors. It may also arise from the difficulty
encountered by the individual in testing reality in terms of his feelings of self-
identity. During adolescence one has to deal with self-esteem in terms of which


--- PAGE 74 ---
54 Counsellingand Guidance
one's choices, self-evaluation and self-perceptions are made. Self-attitudes of
individuals differ in content, direction, importance, consistency, stability and clarity.
The adolescent judges and classifies himself on the basis of these self-attitudes.
Generally the self-attitudes are favourable but when they become negativistic they
have seriotis consequences. They determine not only how the individual will react
in any given situation but also how he will be reacted to. In considering self-
esteem, it is necessary to distinguish between self-evaluation and self-worth. The
latter is more fundamental than the former as it is more intra-situational.
The seventh ego quality is generativity versus stagnation. Generativity incorpo
rates productivity and creativity. The individual is concerned with his offspring and
also with altruistic actions. Regression from generativity often leads to pseudo-
intimacy and to the impoverishment of relationships. The consequence of this may
not be desirable and the individual is either able to experience or miss the most
creative part of his life.
An adolescent's world is more complicated than that of a child as it has many
more possibilities and alternatives to sift through. Role experimentation during
adolescence helps him discover where his true talents and tastes lie. One of the
most important choices to be weighed and tested during adolescence has to do with
work—the concern is to produce something worthwhile. Occupations chosen
constitute a rather critical element in the youngster's emerging identity. Stagnation
is the negative counterpart to generativity. It is the fear of stagnation that helps
keep people productive. Generativity is itself a driving power in human organization.
The last but equally important ego quality is integrity versus despair. This state
is characterized by belief and faith in onself. Having successfully established identity
and intimacy, the individual experiences a sense of fulfilment.
A number of apparendy maladjustive reaction patterns are described by Erickson
in the role diffusion that accompanies identity crises, including labile and
unpredictable b^aviour, lack of commitment, deviant behaviour, and so on that are
indicative of psychopathology when they occur in adults but are near-normal in
healthy adolescence.
According to Erickson, one of the paramount needs of human existence is to
Hnd meaning and continuity in experience. This is most evident in the eighth and
final stage of man. In most cultures in which work and self-sufficiency are valued,
this final stage is challenging and often brings images of despair to mind. If a
person can believe that he has met the crises of the previous stages with good grace
and reasonable success, and that he has found a unique and worthwhile destiny for
himself, a sense of integrity may predominate. A grown-up individual who has
taken care of things and people and has adapted himself to success and
disappointments with equanimity finds the seven stages maturing to integrity. This
stage is the acceptance of 'oneself as one is, and does not need to seek any
institutional help for adjustment It is the acceptance of one's life as one's own
responsibility.
Erickson designates wisdom as the enduring human virtue of the final stages of
human life. His persistent theme is that human nature, social institutions and the
survival of the human race are all mutually interdependent From the various stages
of life, such dispositions of faith, will power, purposefulness, competence, fidelity.

love, care, wisdom—all characteristics of the individual strength—flow into the life
of institutions. Without these, social institutions falter.
Development of Personality
Erickson explains that each stage has a positive as well as a negative aspect. If the
ego qualities in the preceding stages have been negative the final stage may be one
of despair. This life cycle outlined by Erickson represents a normative sequence of
psychological growth corresponding to physiological growth and maturation. There
is much similarity between Havighurst's and Erickson's explanations of the
development of human personality.
Zaccaria (1965) identifies a number of concepts with which Havighurst, Erickson
and Super are in broad agreement. They are:
1. Individual growth is a continuous process.
2. This process could be conveniently divided into periods or life-stages.
3. Each life stage is characterized by certain general characteristics which
individuals have in common.
4. In a given culture most individuals pass through similar developmental
stages.
5. The society imposes responsibilities and makes certain demands on the
individual during these stages.
6. The demands of the society are uniform for all its members.
7. The demands differ form one stage to another as the individual progresses
through the developmental process.
8. Developmental crisis occurs when individuals fail to perceive the need to
adjust to different situations.
9. Through successfully meeting the developmental crises the individual moves
from one stage of maturity to the next, that is, a given tasks must be
mastered and the crises overcome before he can successfully move from
one developed stage to the other.
10. The developmental task appears explicitly at its corresponding stage.
11. The preparation for meeting the developmental crises or tasks occurs in the
preceding life stage.
12. The developmental crisis may arise during a later phase in the life of the
individual in a somewhat different form.
13. Meeting a crisis successfully leads to social approval and happiness.
14. Failure to meet the task lea^ to disapproval and unhappiness.^^
In early infancy there is an amorphous and undifferentiated feeling which slowly
gets differentiated and is expressed and responded to individually. With maturity,
development and a wider range of emotional experiences there is a further
differentiation of these feelings. One of the important problems in early and late
childhood is differentiadon versus non-differentiation when the child fails to control

and differentiate feelings as a part of development towards maturity. The failure to
leam to express certain feelings In accordance with the accepted norms and to
control the expression of certain other feelings would comprise serious problems of
development and behaviour. Such failures may result from adult ambivalence. If
ambivalent experiences are repeated often enough, the child may become anxious.
Another mechanism of adjustment concerns 'acting out*. Children leam to act in
certain ways, for example, crying loudly or exhibiting temper-tantrums because
they know by experience that by resorting to this method their needs are satisfied.
This pattern of ^haviour, when repeated often, becomes set. As children grow,
these sets orpauems of behaviour are slowly modified. Education plays an important
role in this by making children slowly give up irrational ways in preference to
rational modes of thinking, feeling and behaving. The family and cultural factors
of course play a crucial role apart from the individual's own experiences. Often
distortions are noticed in the expression of feelings and impulses. A common
example of such distortion is the expression of anger. An individual learns that
unrestrained expression of anger is destmctive and, therefore, can be indulged in
only at one's own peril. When actually confronted with a situation one may resort
to substitute mechanisms—some desirable and others undesirable.
SOaO-CULTURAL FACTORS
The essential nature of human life is its incompleteness and this is a blessing. If
it were otherwise, there would be very little room or scope for change and without
change th«e would be no progress. Growing up is a process in which one gives
as well as receives. One learns to do things for others in order to get affection, to
gratify one's needs, to be secure, etc. In this context, it would be helpful to view
counselling as a special type of assistance provided for the progress of the
developmental process and for advice on changes a client needs by which he can
become a 'fully-functioning person*.
The nature of the developmental process, outlined above, often creates problems
for the adolescents. It is the responsibility of adults to help solve them. Modem
youth lives in an unenviable situation. Proficiency in different kinds of skills,
mature understanding and major adjustments are required from today's youth and,
moreover, these demands are forever increasing. Rapid industrialization, urbanization,
technological progress, knowledge explosion, exposure to alien ideas and cultures,
increasing dependency and unemployment place the modem youth at a serious
disadvantage. There is no sure guide to successful living in this tumultuous age.
The man of today is a product of his own time. What is more distressing is the spate
of anxieties which man is subject to.
Adult Dependence
Today dependency does not imply physical helplessness but economic dependence.
Today it is inconceivable and illegal for a child of ten to work. Hence, the period
of dependency of modem youth is getting progressively lengthened. The more
civilized we are, the longer is the period of dependency of the youth. Besides the


--- PAGE 77 ---
Developmental Characteristics of Youth 57
usual stresses experienced by youth there are certain special problems created by
our society which youth encounters. These may be concerned with learning in
school, stagnation, delinquency, drug abuse and the like. The problem-ridden youth
requires understanding and sympathetic help for the resolution of such problems.
Youth and h$ Concems
Youth, in contemporary times, is exposed to several conflicdng, distracdng, difficult
and stressful situadons. In the past, young people generally tended to rely on the
advice, wisdom and judgement of their elders. In modem times, owing to their
exposure to other cultural milieu through mass media, books, travel and to some
extent through personal contacts with others, they arc often tempted to imitate and
emulate other modes and patterns of behaviour. Such influence someUmes creates
distressing problems of adjustment They appear to be increasingly groping for a
meaning in life consonant with their ideas and expectadons. Owing to several
socio-economic and polidcal factors, a significant secdon of youth is becoming
estranged and alienated from society. The growth of radical youth movements all
over the world is an illustradon of this phenomenon. Youth is getdng increasingly
involved in revoldng against tradidonal, social, polidcal and racial injusdces. Other
forms of expression of youth revolt may be found in their resort to drug abuse,
espousal of the hippie culture, etc. These are only extreme examples of protest
resorted to by some youth. Fortunately, however, the vast muldtude of young men
and women are only confronted with common issues that have to resolved
sadsfactorily for normal adjustment to the demands of growing up. First of all these
young people growing into adults have to learn to relate themselves to the adult
members of their society. This apparently matter-of-fact issue is not as simple as
it appears to be, for it involves the transidon from dependence to independence.
They have to become independent in different spheres of life—economic,
occupational, social, etc. Becoming self-dependent or independent would ipsofacto
mean becoming responsible for one's own decisions and acdons. This could be a
highly stressful and somedmes even a painful experience for young people.
Individuals cannot live in isolation. The very nature of social life involves
interdependence which could also pose problems for youth.
The other related issues comprise making normal sex adjustments, finding a
vocation that will be absorbing, inspiring and satisfying and obtairung a desirable
social status. Last, but not the least, is the issue of finding a meaning in life; in
other words, having a sound philosophy of life. In regard to all these issues, youth
is called upon to make choices from a welter of disconcerting alternatives. It is
through this process of making choices that development takes place.
According to Tyler (1953), making choices is a major aspect of development
Therefore, the function of counselling is to help clarify alternatives so as to make
the right decisions. In making the right choice, one cannot only follow one's
inclinations. Then one can strive to convert some possibilities into actualities. For
Tyler, therefore, counselling is non-therapeutic. Her view of counselling relates
mainly to developmental and not to pathological problems.
Youth exhibits a robust sense of optimism. Their time orientations are not the
same as the adult modes of looking at reality. Remoteness in time does not overly


--- PAGE 78 ---
58 Counselllnssnd Guidance
concern the youth. Jhey lend to be swayed by considerations of the present or the
immediate future in preference to the demands of the distant future. Their over-
optimism is often followed by. painful disillusionment They also tend to identify
themselves very closely with some persons, while being unable to deal with others
in a reasonable manner. These difficulties arise largely from their limited experience
with reality. One reason may be that many are over-protected at home and, therefore,
have not had occasion to make an independent choice.
Adolescence is also characterized by fantasy and day-dreaming. Erickson
introduced the phrase 'identic crisis' about four decades ago to explain the adolescent
period of internal stress. Most adolescents suffer from an identity crisis. Society no
longo' considers them young enough to be created as children nor is it prepared to
treat them as adults and entrust them with adult responsibilities. This amorphous
position causes the identic crisis and feelings of alienation. Their emotional turmoil
makes them anxious and most youth become emotionally brittle and highly strung.
They exhibit different degrees of nervousness and appear to lack confidence in
themselves and to some extent in others as well.
Thus youth, in such an unenviable situation, can be expected to experience
several problems which could be debilitating. The problems of youth broadly fall
under three categories:
1. Emotional problms which include anxiety, hyperscnsitivity, impulsiveness,
moodiness, immaturi^, withdrawal, etc.
2. Motivational problems which include lack of ambition, low aspirational
level, feelings of frustration, negative attitudes, lack of interests, etc.
3. Moral problems which include feelings of guilt, sense of being lost, confused
ideas of right and wrong, delinquencies such as lying, .stealing, unruly
behaviour, etc.
Adolescents who are beset with such problems are not able to function efficiently
in any sphere of activity. Their academic life leaves much to be desired. Their
performance is adversely affected. It is thus obvious that youth, not only as an
important section of the community but also as the future hope of society, require
counselling assistance. Studies made in India by Riddle (1962), Rao (1962,1965,
1967,1974) and others emphasize the need for counselling our youth.
PROBLEMS IN THE INDIAN EDUCATIONAL CONTEXT
The twin problems plaguing the Indian educational scene are: (1) stagnation and (2)
wastage. Stagnation is concerned with the failure of students in examinations. The
Indian educational system has an unparalleled record of over 70% failures at annual
examinations. Efforts made to redeem the situation have not yet been successful.
The Indian population ranks among the second highest in the world. This factor
alone has been nullifying most of the efforts made to solve many of its social
problems. Consequendy a significant section of the populadon (around 40%) is
living below the poverty line and many school and college-going students are
compelled to quit their academic careers to earn a living and add their earnings to.


--- PAGE 79 ---
Developmental Characteristics of Yourii 59
the paltry family income. This contributes to educational wastage. Those who
graduate face the problem of unemployment and this is in spite of the efforts made
by the governments at both the state and central levels.
The problems so far outlined refer to the problems of students in the post-
adolescent and pre-adulthood period. A few resort to crime and delinquency and
the upper-middle and rich among them may resort to drugs and alcohol. An effective
programme of counselling could help clarify feelings and motivate students by
increasing their self-awareness and self-understanding. This is best achieved by
clarifying goals which serve to bridge motivation and thinking.
Collegiate environments'tend to emphasize cognitive pursuits and academic
excellence at the cost of other aspects of student life and needs. Most of the college
students perhaps live for the first time away from their parents and homes. There
is no doubt that for freshmen at college, adjustment poses a host of problems. For
one thing, the freshman arrives on the campus during a critical phase -of his
personality development, namely, adolescence. Adolescence is a deeply internal as
well as environmental crisis, for the adolescent has to adjust himself to rapid
physiological changes taking place within his body as well as the problems that
arise from tlte environment or situations as a consequence of the b^ily changes
that have taken place. He is suddenly left to his own devices to adjust himself to
the demands of the new situation. He has to pick and choose his friends from the
many who join college with him without any outside assistance. He may err and
become a member of an undesirable group. The highly academic and often
unemotional atmosphere of the institution, the severance from home life and the
uncertainties of the hostel or dormitory are some of the situations which could
create acute problems of adjustment for the freshman. Some are successful in
making new friends and discovering new interests, are adequately motivated and
develop a thirst for knowledge. They accept their teachers and fellow students with
confidence. Others are less fortunate, a few become home sick and emotionally
brittle and question the value of the examination system. Others become listless and
seek various forms of retreat like day-dreaming, loafing, etc. (Rao 1963, 1967).
To determine the nature and extent of the problems of students in the Sri
Venkateswara University area and also to sensitize faculty members to students'
needs and problems, a Problem Check List (PCL) was administered to a sample of
2338 male students enrolled in degree classes during 1964—1965 (Rao, 1967).
The data obtained point to an unenviable picture of the situation in which the
students in- India in general, and those of the S.V. University area in particular,
were placed. Of all the problems reported, those in the area of finance were most
important. The students seem to be put to several hardships owing to the meagre
financial resources available to them. The presence of a large percentage of first
generation students in educational institutions today, who have had no necessaiy
guidance with regard to proper and efficient methods of study, was highlighted by
the findings of the study. This makes it imperative for the institution to assume the
(additional) responsibilities of providing guidance and making available the necessaiy
facilities for acquiring desirable study habits and skills. Most teachers and
administrators seemed to be under the mistaken impression that the students would
"somehow acquire the necessary study skills and practices as a matter of natural


--- PAGE 80 ---
50 Counsellingand Guidance
development". Unfortunately this does not seem to be true as a very large percentage
of students reported difficulties in this area. The students also reported problems in
the area of personal adjustment The provision of necessary assistance may go a
long way in easing emotional tensions and anxieties which contribute to the
debilitation and dissipation of student energies. The results show that it is
fundamentally wrong for the teachers and administrators to delude themselves with
the idea that the Indian student is irresponsible and apathetic. The fact that they
(students) are conscious of and are concerned about their parents' anxieties and
worries is sufficient indication of their seriousness of purpose.
The disruption of orderly student life on campuses in India is not a result of the
irresponsibility of students. It is a symptom of a deep-rooted complex of
maladjustment, which is enhanced by feelings of personal insecurity, inadequate
facilities for work and recreation, growing incertitude about the future, lack of an
optimum level of personal efficiency, etc.
If academic standards are to be raised and student unrest minimized, it is
imperative that we.provide sound values through relevant and stimulating education.
Students often acquire unworthy and inappropriate values through associating and
being influenced by undesirable groups. If a healthy change in the value system is
desired it may be accomplished through situations which provide a desirable feed
back. In this regard hostel mates and faculty members can help engender desirable
changes in the students* value system. Students could be encouraged to establish
a relaxed intellectual relationship with a member of the faculty. Such contacts
would help promote intellectual excellence. Counselling would help mitigate the
adjustmental problems and check the growing cynicism and psychological inertia
in students in India (Rao, 1967),
The child guidance centre, the school psychologist, the counselling centre and
other such agencies are increasingly being called upon to shoulder the responsibilities
of giving succour to alleviate the avoidable suffering caused by developmental
hazards and tensions. No society can afford to ignore the basic need to render help
to the youth.

A young man calls at the student counselling centre. He Is tense and anxious. He
calls at the centre because he has some problem or difTicuI^. Another young man
calls as he has heard £rom his hiends that psychological tests are administered at

may be unfulfilled causing frustration, and clients may want to find techniques or
methods of resolving their conflicts and fulfllling their needs.
Thus individuals se^ the help of others in a varies of situations. The assistance
sought may be as simple as asking for a small piece of information or as complex
as asking for assistance for solving some cmcial problem. The latter ^pe of problem
is encountered as frequently as the former. When the problems are adjudged to be
too difHcult to be tackled without outside help, one can approach different individuals
and agencies depending on the nature of the problem one is facing. For example,
individuals approach lawyers, physicians, psychiatrists, psychologists, clergymen,
social workers, teachers and others for assistance to help solve different kinds of
problems.
Counselling and psychotherapy developed as methods of rehabilitqUon. The
concern was to help those considered 'off the track' and unable to adjust to life.
This popularized the view that psychotherapists and counsellors were persons who
helped individuals return to normal. Gradually the counselling process came to be
understood as a means of prevention as much as treatment More recently counselling
has come to be viewed as an instrument or technique of self-actualization. It is
no longer enough for an individual to be 'well' and 'unsick', it is necessary
that he becomes the best he is capable of and counselling must help him in this
process. This offers a challenging and creative role for the counsellor. It is not
enough to maintain staius quo, counselling should go further to help the client
transcend the status quo.
