The three fundamental qualities that a counsellor should have, as emphasized by
Rogers, are: genuineness of feeling and interest, understanding, and unconditional
acceptance of the counsellee. The counsellor's interest in the counsellee cannot be
artificial. He is not to put on an act or merely do role-playing. His response has to
be genuine, warm and sympathetic. His understanding should not be confined to
mere intellectual or rational appreciation of what the counsellee says or does. It
involves reaching out with warmth and empathizing with the counsellee's situation.
EXPERfENONG OF RESPONSIBILITY vX
Once the client discovers that he is responsible for himself and his experiences,
various feelings may result, varying from unpleasant to pleasant No purpose is
served by distorting or rejecting an experience when one is responsible for it Thus"
the first step is to experience responsibility. As the counselling relationship becomes
stable the client freely explores his feelings and attitudes. He is now able to
experience both fear and positive interest towards his perceptions. Inconsistencies
and contradictions discovered in his self no longer upset or embarrass him. As the
process progresses as a result of exploration, negative attitudes are experienced and
perceived as freely as are the positive auitudes. When the client is able to experience
feelings and attitudes which were so far distorted he is no longer anxious about
experiencing these perceptions. The client thus reaches a stage at which he is ready
to reorganize his self.
essential CONDmONS FOR PERSONALITY CHANGE
According to Rogers (1957), the conditions necessaiy for a personality change to
take place are:
1. The counsellee and the counsellor are in psychological contact with each
other.
2. The counseUee is in a state of incongruence and hence is vulnerable and
anxious (vulnerabili^ is .the condition of the individual whose experience is
discordant with his self-structure and thus capable of creating tension and
psychological disorganization).
3. The counsellor is congruent and integrated, that is, he is free fix)m anxie^^
and tension. His relationship with the counsellee is genuine and does not
cause any disharmony in him.
4. The counsellor has unconditional positive regard for the counsellee. (TTie
counsellor does not have any reservations. He accepts the counsellee as he
is and does not impose any preconditions.)
5. The counsellor experiences an empathic understanding of the counsellee's
internal frame of reference and tries to communicate his experience to the


--- PAGE 104 ---
84 Counselling and Guidance
counsellee. (By internal frame of reference is meant the subjective world of
the individual which is available to himself and to none else.)
6. The counsellor exhibits empathy and warmth of acceptance of the counsellee
andhe (counsellee) appreciates and understands the counsellor's unconditional
positive regard towa^ him to a reasonable extent. (The client has some
understanding of the counsellor's position.)
Rogers (1961) describes the counselling process in seven steps or stages which
form a continuum.
^AGES IN THE COUNSELLING PROCESS
Stage I
1. There is an unwillingness to communicate about the self; communication,
if any, is only about exiemals, such as experiences which have no deep
significance for himself.
2. Feelings and meaningful personal experiences are neither recognized nor
accepted.
3. Client's personal constructs are extremely rigiii
4. Close and communicative relationships are often viewed as dangerous and
interpreted likewise.
5. The client does not recognize or perceive any problems.
6. Owing to blockage of internal communication (non-perception of
incongruence) there is no desire to change the experiential field.
7. Individuals at this stage do not recognize the need for counselling and do
not come voluntarily for help.
Stage II
1. In this stage the client begins to express his feelings about non-self objects.
The client may speak about other filings which are remote in relation to his
self.
2. Problems, if perceived, are looked upon as external to the self.
3. There is no sense of personal responsibility in problems.
4. Feelings may be exhibited or repressed as unrelated to himself and are not
owned.
5. Ways of experiencing generally follow past tendencies as distorted by the
self-structure acquired in the pasL
6. Client's personal constructs are rigid. Feelings may be shown but are not
recognized or owned. There is little differentiation of personal meanings
and recognition of contradictions.
Clients may begin therapy at this stage.
Stage III
1. The client feels free to express , his feelings. The process started in the
previous stage continues more freely.'Another significant improvement is
&


--- PAGE 105 ---
Approaches to Counselling 85
that the client talks about the self as an object. Past feelings and personal
feelings which are usually negative are expressed. However, the client does
not accept them. For most part, the feelings are revealed as something
shameful, bad or abnormal or unaccq}table in other ways. Certain experiences
are described as in the past or as somewhat remote from the self.
2. Personal constructs, though rigid, are recognized.
3. Differentiation of feelings and meanings is better and less general There is
some recognition of contradictions in experience.
4. The client is able to see his personal choices as ineffective but not in their
proper perspective.
Stage IV
1. The client describes more intense feelings experienced in the past and does
not refer to the feelings in. the present.
2. The client is able to overcome his defenses occasionally and express his
feelings as experienced in the present.
3. The tendency towards experiencing feelings in the immediate present is
dominant but there is distrust and fear of experiencing.
4. The client does not show open acceptance of feelings though occasionally
this is exhibited.
5. The client is able to express his experience as expeiienced in the present
and is less bound by the past self-structure and is less remote.
6. Acceptance, understanding and empathy enable the client to move smoothly
in the direction of therapy.
7. There is a realization about contradictions and incongruence between
experience and self.
8. The client shows feelings of self-responsibility in problems but there is a
tendency to vacillate.
9. The client is still wary about close relationships.
Stage V
1. Feelings are expressed freely in the present.
2. Feelings are very close to being fully experienced though fear, distnist and
lack of clarity are still present
3. Self-feelings are increasingly owned and accepted.
4. Responsibility for problems is accepted.
5. The client is increasingly able to accept contradictions and incongruencies
in experiences.
6. There is an increase in free dialogue within the self and improvement in
reducing blockage of internal communication.
Stage VI
1. The client who was previously inhibiting a feeling is able to experience the
same with immediacy and without any difficulty.
2. Feelings are freely experienced and expressed. The immediacy of


--- PAGE 106 ---
86 CounseUlngand Guidance
experiencing and the feeling which constitutes its content are accepted and
not denied, feared and/or struggled against In other words, negatives give
place to positives.
3. Self as an object tends to disq^pear.
4. The incongruence between experience and awareness is vividly experienced
as it disappears into congruence, that is, incongruence becomes congruence.
In this stage there are no longer any problems—external or internal.
Physiological concomitants of a loosening, relaxing nature—tears, sighs,
muscular relaxation, improved circulation, etc.—are present
Stage Vll
New feelings are experienced with immediacy and richness of detail. Changing
feelings are accepted and owned. There is a feeling of trust in the total organismic
process. All the elements of his experiences are now available to awareness and
there is experiencing of real and effective choice in new ways of being. The
counsellee becomes a 'fully-functioning person', by which is meant that each
individual has an innate tendency toward actualizing himself, that is, realizing his
inherent capacities and potentialities.
In brief the counselling process involves:
1. A loosening of feelings.
2. A change in the manner of experiencing.
3. A shift from incongruence to congruence.
4. A change in the manner and extent to which the individual is willing and
able to communicate himself in a receptive climate.
5. A widening of the cognitive maps of experience and a breaking of rigid
boundaries.
6. A change in the individual's manner of relating himself to others and to his
own experiences.
7. A change in the individual's reactions to his problems. .<>5^
The major shortcomings of client-centered therapy are:
1. This approach emphasizes the affective determinants of behaviour, ignoring
the importance of intellectual, cognitive and rational aspects of human nature.
2. It totally ignores the usefulness of providing information which may be of
value to the counsellees.
3. It has the same goal for all the clients, namely, maximizing, that is, making
them self-actualizing individuals. Hiis gener^ goal does not take into account
the individual needs of clients.
4. As a client-centered approach it claims to give freedom to the client to set
the goal, but more often than not, counselling goals emerge from the 'setting'
in which the counsellee and counsellor work.
5. It does not consider the category of individuals who accept little responsibility
for their problems.
6. In this aproach the counsellor is expected to be neutral and not communicate
his own values to the client. But in natural, inter-personal relations it is
difficult to conceive of neutral, value free and bland relations.


--- PAGE 107 ---
Approaches to Counselling 87
The positive contribudons of this approach are:
1. It successfully drives home the point that the coiinsellee rather than the
counsellor is the centre or focus of the counselling process, that is, it is for
the counsellee to take the inidative and overcome his problems.
2. It emphasizes the importance of the counselling reladonship in facilitating
personality change.
3. It stresses the importance of the counsellor's attitudes rather than his
techniques in effecting the counselling relaUonships.
4. It emphasizes the importance of the affecdve domain in the counselling
process and holds that counselling should concern itself with emodons and
feelings.
BEHAVIOURISnC APPROACH TO COUNSELLING
(counselling and psychotherapy are concerned with behaviour change and, therefore,
according to some theorists, must involve the applicadons of the principles of
learning or learning theory. Learning here is understood as changes in behaviour
which are relatively long lasting and which are not diie to maturation or to
physiological factors like fatigue, effect of drugs, etc. However, counselling, by and
large, has developed outside the learning theory. It is only in recent times that the
principles of learning theory have been sought to be applied in the counselling
technique.
The learning approach employed in the behaviouristic model could be either the
classical conditioning or the operani conditioning model. While it is not necessary
to go into the details of conditioning, it is essential that the basic principles be
grasped. From the behaviouristic point of view, all behaviour—adjustive or
maladjustive—is primarily learnt in the same manner. Hence it should be modifiable
by employing suitable learning principles. All behaviour of organisms, including
human beings, ranging from simple to complex behaviour, is learnt. Four basic
principles (DCRR) are involved in all types of learning. The first is drive or
motivation which impels the organism to act. The drives could be primary (tissue
needs) or'secondary (learnt). Without drive there can be no action; consequently,
no learning can occur. The second principle is cue or stimulus. For instance, an
organism is hungry and is stimulated by a variety of different objects, including
food. The stimulation by food would be elective while the other stimulations in
this situation would not be effective. Thus, drive and cue together determine the
response of the organism. The third principle of all learning is response. Stimulation
leads to responses. The relevance of a response to a situation at a given time is
determined by its survival value or its serviceability or usefulness to the organism.
For example, the ringing of a bell elicits different responses like the turning of the
head in the direction of the sound, the pricking of ears, salivation, and so on.
Among these, salivatioit is the relevant response because it has survival value. If
there is danger, then running or flight would be the relevant response. Usually the
relevant responses are reinforced. Reinforcement is the fourth principle of learning.


--- PAGE 108 ---
88 Counsdllng and Guidance
It is of the nature of a reward. A response that is reinforced or rewarded is acquired,
wt^e a response that is not rewarded is not acquired^{^e behaviouristic approach to counselling employs the four principles of learning,
namely, drive, cue, response and reinforcement. Every response is considered
modifiable by the use of an appropriate system of reinforcemenL The behavioiuistic
approach differs from the psychoanalytic and medical approaches with regard to its
attitude towards maladaptive or maladjusted behaviour. In psychoanalysis or clinical
approaches the concern is with the past, that is, as to how a particular symptom or
syndrome tias been caused. The therapist delves deep into the life history or case
history of the client to identify the causes. The dispelling of these causes is expected
to rid the client of the undesirable symptom(s). In sharp contrast to this view, the
behaviour therapist is least concerned with the past He is not interested in knowing
what caused the symptom. He is concerned with the symptom here and now. The
past for him is something which cannot be changed. It is irrelevant. But the future
can be modified. Past, however, is not existent and, therefore, unmodifiable.
Therefore, the behaviour therapist is not concerned with the case history and the
past There is no need for delving into the past life history of the client It serves
no real purpose. Therapy essentially consists of several simple steps: (1) identifying
the undesirable, unwanted, maladjusted and maladaptive behaviour, (2) careful
analysis of the maladaptive behaviour into small units, and (3) each unit is eliminated
by an appropriate technique involving an operant conditioning procedure. There are
different approxhes stressing different aspects of the learning theory.\
Dollard and Miller's (1950) reinforcement theory is a thought provoking approach.
They define neurosis as learned behaviour. What is more interesting is that, xcording
to them, neurotic conflicts are taught by parents and learnt by children. Thus,
unwanted and maladjusted behaviour is acquired or learnt This includes phobias,
compulsions, hysterical symptoms, regression, reaction formation, alcoholism, etc.
In the long run many behavioural reactions become maladaptive. They comprise
the techniques by which the responsibility for action is evaded. They increase the
misery though in the beginning the results appear favourable. In the treatment of
clients therapy involves the creation of a new type of social situation which is the
opposite of that responsible for inducing repression. The new social situation provides
for gradually overcoming the repressions under permissive social conditions. The
therapeutic situation is characterized by permissiveness which leads to the removal
of repression. Rogers (1951) underlines the importance of the permissiveness of the
counselling situation. The therapeutic process is a slow and difficult one because
fear and anxiety xcompany the repressed ideas and even though the therapist is
permissive and neutral, the client cannot help experiencing these unpleasant emotions.
The clients are encouraged to verbalize their experiences, that is, talk about
themselves and in this process the client gives vent to his emotions. In psychodrama
a similar principle is employed. Much of our learning makes use of labels. This is,
based on principles of generalization and transference. The fear of one object, by
association, leads us to fear several other objects. We label them all as dangerous
so that even a neutral object may arouse anxiety and fear owing to generalization.
In therapy this principle of labelling is used to overcome a client's own fears by
learning to label appropriately. Effective learning involves making proper choices.


--- PAGE 109 ---
Approaches to CounseJIIrjg 99
If an individual were lo wrongly identify and choose objects, he would perhaps
encounter unpleasant experiences. Labelling as a technique is used by the therapist
to help the client acquire certain desirable behavioural tendencies or eliminate
undesirable behavioural tendencies.
^In the implementation of therapy the client is provided with a permissive social
environment where he is free to talk and express his feelings no matter how shocking
or horrifying they may be. The therapist obtains relevant information from such
talk. Gaps are filled by suitable questioning. In this process, the client starts with
relatively unimportant material and progresses to express more stressful and
emotionally-upsetting material. The therapist suitably rewards the free expression
or free-association (talking) of the client The simplest rewarding technique is to
give exclusive attention to what the client is saying. The second kind of reward is
to accept what the client says without condemning him or giving critical comments.
A third reward is to recount to llie client what he has mentioned earlier. Yet another
type of reward is not to cross-examine the client.
The next step in therapy consists in the handling of transference. Through this
the therapist gains information about the client. He has to identify the transferred-
responses and clarify them by questioning and identifying the origin and the person
from whom it is transferred. Transferred responses are learned responses. They can,
therefore, be modified and even unlearned.
The reinforcement theory of Dollard and Miller (1950) is an integration of
psychoanalytic concepts with behaviourisdc techniques. Since the two belong to
endrely different domains, there are bound to be some gaps and inconsistencies.
But the approach has been very useful in stimuladng other thinkers and therapists
to explore the use of the learning approach in counselling^
RECIPROCAL INtOBinON TCCHNIQ.UE
In the reciprocal inhibidon technique, Wolpe (1964) tries to free himself from
psychoanalydc concepts and move towards the behaviourisdc approach. According
to him, all behaviour conforms to causal laws. Changes in the behaviour of any
organism are caused by (1) growth (maturadon), (2) lesions (injury, damage and
disease) and (3) learning. Here we are concerned with those changes in behaviour
which are caused by learning. According to Wolpe, learning is assumed to have
occurred "if a response has been evoked in temporal condguity with a given sensory
sdmulus and it is subsequenUy found that the stimulus can evoke the response
although it could not have done so before". If the sdmulus earlier evoked the
response but subsequently evokes it more strongly, then, too, learning may be said
to have occurred. The strengthening of the relation between the stimulus and the
response is called reinforcement. Reinforcement is strengthened by several factors,
such as an optimal interval between the unconditioned and conditioned stimulus,
the interval between the response and the reinforcement and the nature of
reinforcement When a conditioned stimulus is repeatedly presented without
reinforcement the conditioned response disappears. Sometimes the conditioned
response does not appear for reasons such as fatigue, dissipation of energy, etc.


--- PAGE 110 ---
90 Counsdilngand Guidance
Wolpe is a protagonist of reciproca] inhibition as a therapeutic device. According
to him, reciprocal inhibition eliminates or weakens an old response by the substitution
of new ones. "When a response is inhibited by an incompatible response and if a
major drive reduction follows a significant amount of conditioned inhibition of the
response will be developed." The technique as initiated by Wolpe is quite simple
and in therapy this process follows from the basic assumption, namely, that neurotic
behaviour is a learned behaviour. It is a persistent habit of unadaptive behaviour
acquired by learning in a physiologically normal organism. Anxiety is the important
constituent of maladaptive bdtaviour. Anxiety is unpleasant and may often interfere
with performance. The unlearned anxiety or fear is a normal response to dangerous
stimuli. Neurotic anxiety is evoked by harmless stimuli as a result of conditioning.
Anxiety is the central component of most neuroses. Free-floating anxiety is evoked
by a number of stimuli in the environment such that there is no clearly defined
stimulus. In reciprocal inhibition the client is helped to overcome anxiety by inhibiting
it. The therapy is essendally a conditioning therapy and is of three types:
1. Counter-conditioning—^The principle involved is that a response inhibitory
of anxiety can be made to occur in the presence of anxiety-evoking stimuli.
It will weaken the bond between these stimuli and the anxiety (Wolpe). In
this technique, anxiety is eliminated by a competing response by means of
a reciprocal inhibition. This principle is also the basis for aversive therapy.
2. Positive reconditioning—^This is a technique of establishing new behaviour
patterns. Operant conditioning principles are employed such that a response
is rewarded every time it is omitted and a response which is sought to be
eliminated is not rewarded every time it appears.
3. Experimental extinction—This procedure consists of continued non-
reinforcement of a habit such that it is progressively weakened and disappears.
Wolpe has suggested the implementation of a type of therapy which involves
(1) systematic relaxation, (2) systematic desensitization and (3) assertive
training.
Systematic relaxation—^The client is asked to practice relaxing his body muscles.
Some.ldnd of training is given to the clients in learning to relax the muscles. Mental
relaxation in addition to muscular relaxation is also obtained through respiratory
refuses which comprise simple breathing exercises. Anxiety-ridden clients are
helped by letting them inhale a mixture of carbon dioxide and oxygen. Not more
than foiu' such inhalations are permitted in a single session.
Systematic desensitizadon—^The client is assisted to prepare a list of stimulus
siUiations starting with the least anxiety-evoking to the most intensely anxiety-
evoking stimulus situation. The client is then asked to read the items in a hierarchical
order. Clients go through the items in different sessions one by one till they get
adapted to each one of them without expaiencing the least amount of anxiety. If
the case warrants, the client of either sex is encouraged to think of sexual responses
without experiencing any anxiety.
Assertive training—This involves leaming to make assertive responses. These
assertive responses enable the overcoming of anxieties arising out of inter-personal
relationships. This technique is similar to psychodiama.

Approaches to Counselling 91
BEHAVIOURAL MODIHCATION
Behavioural modification is a technique or group of techniques that employ the
learning theory. As far as behavioural counsellors are concerned, behaviour results
from the interaction of heredity and environment Behavioural counsellors are usually
concemed with observable behaviour, though implicit behaviour is as much a result
of the interaction of heredity and environment. They stress five tenets:
1. Most, if not all, human behaviour is learnt (excluding maturation). Hence
it is changeable or modifiable.
2. Changes in the environment can alter behaviour. Counselling therapists seek
to bring about relevant changes in client behaviour by altering the
environment suitably.
3. Social learning principles are of value in efiecting behavioural change. The
common social learning principles employed are social reinforcement,
modelling, labelling, etc.
4. The counselling effectiveness can be assessed in terms of actual outcomes
in behavioural change.
5. The counselling technique or procedure cannot be a predetermined fixed
process. It has to be designed to suit each client's specific needs.
The most important central principle of behavioural counselling is reinforcement.
Reinforcement could be positive, negative or neutral. Behavioural change is alierapted
to be brought about by first identifying the behaviour to be changed and defining
the objective (nature of change sought).
The principles of reward (R), aversion (A), omission (0) and punishment (P) or
RAOP are employed either individually or in combination as required in specific
cases. If the client makes a response which is in the desired direction, it is positively
reinforced. The client may also be shown a model and the behaviour of the client
is sought to be modelled by suitable reinforcement. For instance, if smoking is to
be eliminated, every time the client makes a response in the direction of smoking,
such as reaching for the cigarette case or taking a cigarette, an aversive reinforcement
is given. A common aversive technique used in overcoming alcoholism is that
when the client consumes alcohol he immediately feels sick and vomits. Thus
consumption of alcohol is associated with aversive vomiting behaviour. Another
technique to eliminate a behaviour is to ignore iL No reinforcement is given in this
technique. This corresponds to deconditioning or extinction. Punishment is
administered as a negative reinforcement whenever quick results are sought But
punishment by itself may not be useful because it may harden the organism, that
is, the client may develop negative adaptation. Behavioural counselling has a very
significant application in schools and early childhood behaviour. Whether it would
be useful with adults, and if useful, what the permanency of such a change would
be, are questions which have not been satisfactorily answered.
Criticisms of behavioural counselling generally stress the meaninglessness of
the mechanistic view of human behaviour. It is also questioned as to whether the
manipulation of client behaviour in a cold, impersonal fashion is justifiable. The
major criticism appears to centre round the issues of the infringement of human
freedom and choice.


--- PAGE 112 ---
92 Counselllngand Guidance
The principles of cybernetics are also sought to be employed in the field of
counselling. Phillips and Winer (1966) have explained that individuals acquire a
chain of reactions in which each reacdon serves as a feed-back to the individual.
If the outcomes are positive, that is, desirable and satisfying they form an amplifying
positive loop. The undesirable or dissatisfying reacdon chain forms into a negative
counteracting loop. The therapist has to introduce a 'change plan' and implement
it padently to break the hold of the self-defeadng counteracdng negadve loops on
the behaviour of the counsellee. For instance, a highly modvated student offers a
challenging course and obtains high grades; he is sadsfied and his self-confidence
is boosted. This modvates him further and he moves forward. Another student may
offer similar courses and spend more dme and energy to secure good grades and
this need of spending more time makes him feel Ixired and his efficiency may
suffer as a consequence. He may obtain low grades and this outcome may create
a sense of dlssadsfacdon in him and he may avoid taking challenging courses ever
afterwards. The diagram below illustrates the amplifying positive loops and
counteracdng negadve loops:

THE EXISTENTIAL POINT OF VIEW
Existential thinking approaches the quesdon of understanding man's 'being', i.e.,
man as he 'really is' in the spirit of St Augustine's quesdon: 'Who am I?' rather
than with the sciendfic understanding of a human being following the Aristotelian
quesdon: 'What is the place of man in nature?' Existentialism developed as a
reacdon to the menacing growth of materialism. Human life was fast becoming
mechanical, losing its freedom and ability for self-transcendence. Philosophers from
ancient times have been striving to find fte meaning of human existence, glorifying
rationalism as an unfailing guide. However, all attempts to gain insight into human


--- PAGE 113 ---
Approaches to Counselllr^g 93
nature and existence proved shallow. Existentialism developed as a powerful
movement and as a reaction to excessive rationalism in war-ravaged Europe. Human
life in the post-war Europe was becoming meaninglessly compartmentalized.
'Humanness' seemed to be getting lost Rigid compartmentalization resulted in
business devoid of ethics and daily life estranged from religion. All irrational
activity or behaviour was described as evil and undesirable. Reason came to be
increasingly emphasized at the cost of feeling and experience. It was claimed that
reason helped man act objectively instead of emotionally. Brushing aside the
interfering emotions, it was argued, helps man act rationally. Such compartmentalized
individuals with will divorced from reason did not fit well into the fast developing
industrial society. Individuals devoid of will were either manipulated like machines
or they manipulated themselves. Thus human beings came to be viewed as marketable
commodities and market conditions determined the value of human existence. In
this situation, men surrendered their self-awareness to insulate themselves as
necessary protection against reality and paid the price dearly—in terms of anxiety,
compulsions and despair. This unenviable predicament of human life loomed large
in the post-war technological world. The true predicament was, in reality, that
human beings lost the love and confidence in one another, and perhaps the will to
be human.
In the last hundred odd years there has been an undesirable change in peoples
attitudes to religion and religious values. This is due to the rise of movements such
as liberalism, enlightenment and social revolution that led to the serious erosion, if
not breakdown, of religious traditions in the name of scientific rationalism. Religion
lost relevance for the young, the old, the educated and the uneducated, all alike.
Against this background, the existential movement was started as a corrective measure
revolting against excessive rationalism. It substantially affected contemporary
thought. However, in USA owing to the influence of British empiricism, the impact
and import of existentialism was not appreciated for a long time. The hold of
empiricism was further accentuated by the rise of positivism, behaviourism,
operationism and associationism. There was apparently no enthusiasm to grapple
with the concept of 'being' and it was dismissed as a puerile and distant abstraction.
However, the writings of Angyal, Lecky, Goldstein, Rogers and Maslow emphasized
varying degrees of self-actualization. Though they were not existential thinkers,
they stressed the basic motive of life, namely, maintaining and actualizing the self.
Scientific advances which apparently led to mastery of power over nature could not
help understanding man's being. There was growing despair resulting from the split
between subject and object which not only resulted in man's estrangement from
nature but also to his estrangement from himself. Oriental thought has approached
this issue with greater success. The question, 'What does it mean to be human?'
cannot be answered in terms of any materialistic science. Ancient oriental thinkers
were of the opinion, as Lao Tze in the Way of Life states, that 'existence is beyond
the power of words to define'. Existence is infinite.
In spite of the several changes that have resulted from scientific and-technological
advances, the way 'to do' and 'to be' remained enigmatic. There was evidently a
lack of direction, causing deep concern in all sections of society. The assumption
that success in other realms owing to scientific reasoning will unravel the inner


--- PAGE 114 ---
94 Counselllngand Guidance
world which characterizes man's existence turned out to be hollow. This is umwelt
which is the world around. We all live at the same time in the world and have
interpersonal relations which differ from one individual .to another. This world of
personal and interpersonal relationships is the mitwelt, a world within. We live with
this world. Further, we live in a third world, the intimate personal world, which is
not adequately understood. This is the eigenwelt. It induces self-awareness, self-
relatedness and self-transcendence, possessed only by human beings. While attention
has been paid to the unwell and the mitwelt, the eigenwelt remains enigmatic. It
comprises the unique personal experiences. For example, one may say: Tt is a
beautiful sunset*. This statement is empty and carries no significance unless it is
related to one's experience. Thus while it is a beautiful sunset for one, it may not
be so for another. Any attempt to objectify and look for an index of truthfulness
is futile. An experience irrelevant and meaningless to one may be immediate,
concrete and real for another.
In existential counselling, we are concerned with the eigenwelt. The basic concepts
arising from this for existential counselling are:
1. To 'know the counsellee is to relate to him in his totality, to grasp his
being'. This is not the same as knowing him. All psychological test data,
however valuable and comprehensive, do not help one learn of him. It only
'tells' about him. Therefore, it is not knowing the other person as a person.
2. The sense of being is real. A thing of experience cannot be reduced to
quantification in scientific terminology. The experience of 'being' can be
grasped only through experience. A number of measures that are carefully
and painfully gathered do not help comprehend the 'being'. 'Being' is not
static. It cannot be measured at one time and dealt with later. 'Being' is
'becoming'. Therefore, what was good yesterday may not be good either
today or tomorrow. A human being has the unique capacity to be aware of
himself and be responsible for himself. He can also become aware of 'non-
being*. His choices and actions determine his 'being' and 'non-being'. Each
time he chooses he also rejects. 'Being' and 'non-being' invariably follow
one's affirmation, i.e., choice. The counsellor in his relationship can help
create the conditions in which the counsellee feels accepted. This feeling of
acceptance implies trust If there is unconditional acceptance it enables a
person to experience his own 'being*.
3. To contemporary man, modem life is' a picture of complete cultural
disintegration. This is especially true of the younger generation. Contemporary
life is characterized by four feelings: fear, uncertainty, loneliness and
meaninglessness.
4. Existentialism tries to re-establish the possibility of meaning. For this it
holds that man is related to his world. An individual and the world must be
understood as one. When we think of an individual in his home, or in his
office, we mistakenly think of the spatial relationship, but much more than
this is implied. The basic theme is that it is necessary for counsellors to
assume that they cannot arrive at an adequate understanding of the
counsellee's behaviour from a study of environment alone. Each one lives
in his own world which may be similar to others but also uniquely different.


--- PAGE 115 ---
Approaches to CounseHlng 9S
'World* and 'being in ihe world' have a specific meaning for existendalists.
The world comprises an individual's unique structure of meaningful
relationships in which he participates. The counsellor should know the
counsellee's environment. But this is possible only when the meaning of the
environment of the counsell^ is understood.
The counsellee's world consists of experiences of past events and a variety
of external influences, but their meaning derives fiom how he relates to
them. The counsellee is continuously using what he selects fiom the world
of intimate personal experiences, shaping, forming and building it into his
relations with them. Self-awareness is an ongoing process which is open to
all experiences. This openness is not identifiable with culture.
5. Ego and being are different. Counsellors unwittingly confuse the function
of the ego with 'authentic being'. Ego is traditionally conceived as a passive
agent derived from modifications imposed upon it from the external world;
and it represents the external world, i.e., the ego is a reflection of the outside
world. Its strength and weakness depend upon the approval/disapproval of
people and forces outside the person. In this subject, object ^chotomy,
'ego' is the subject, but 'being' is prior to this dichotomy. It is in one's own
experience of existence. It is not derived from the outside forces. The sense
of being is knowing that I am the one who initiates what is occurring. One's
knowing includes one's capacity to be so. Lack of understanding 'being'
misleads counsellors into viewing adjustment as a goal of counselling.
Therefore, they assume that ego is primary and acceptable satisfaction of
ego demands the end result. This view assumes the individual to be the
passive recipient of forces upon him.
6. Fact of 'non-being'. It is easy to think of life in terms of 'being' and
'becoming'. Yet all these things come to an end. 'Non-being' is the end. It
is real. Every new experience threatens our-being. We can choose to escape
this 'denial' through rationalization and thus deny 'being* within us. We do
not consciously create being. It takes place incidentally as we choose to
pursue it in the future. 'Being' and 'non-being' are the opposite poles of
existence. One cannot and does not have meaning without the other.
7. Ontological perspective of anxiety. Most counsellors deal with anxie^ that
is common, namely 'normal* anxiety, which arises from a real fear of
helplessness, frt addition to normal anxiety, there is 'neurotic anxiety' arising
out of fear of something that is vague and ambiguous. It is not a concrete
thing or object or event and the consequent feeling of helplessness gives rise
to neurotic anxiety. Another type is called 'existential anxiety. Existentialists
call it urangsi which underlies the feeling that in the ultimate sense we are
finite, helpless and doomed to meet our end some day. This does not imply
hostility or provoke inner conflict leading to neurotic defensive measures.
We can escape this anxie^ by detachment and conformity. The counsellee
in this situation does not escape the threat of anxiety and emptiness. The
counsellor is not engaged to free the counsellee from anxiety. He sees
anxiety as an opportunity for growth. So he is interested in helping the
counsellee to accept anxiety as a constituent of life.


--- PAGE 116 ---
96 Counselllns^d Guidance
8. Ontological perception of guilt. One feels 'functional guilt' when one behaves
in a manner unacceptable to society. For example, lifting small articles from
a shop results in functional guilt owing to cultural factors. This may also be
called 'societal guilt'. Another is 'ontological guilt' which originates in
one's own world. It differs from other forms of guilt as its source is not
culture or introjection of authority figures. It is also different from neurotic
guilt
BASC ASSUMFnONS OF EXISTENTIAL COUNSELLING
Existential counselling is a radically diHercnt approach to the counsellee and
counselling. The basic principles are:
(i) Technique follows understanding. It is commonly believed that the simple
can be understood only in terms of the complex. This is not true in existential
counselling. This approach places emphasis on the context in which counselling
occurs. The counsellee is not viewed as an object. He is seen as a person who is
choosing, committing and orienting himself toward something out of the present.
(ii) In order to obtain a more realistic image of man and his potential we have
to revise our current theories of learning which are inadequate and can best explain
animal learning and perhaps, to some extent, learning in young children. The theories
of growth have stressed physical maturation to the neglect of psychological
development. Allport stresses the importance of functional autonomy in place of
firmly structured personality. Human nature is explained by most theories as a
quasi-closed system shaped by past factors. Mercifully, human personality is a
wide-open system, oriented to the future which is responsive to tangible and
intangible cultural forces.
Existential psychological counselling has its ori^ in early philosophical thinking.
It may be traced to the ideas that preceded Freud's psychoanalytical theory. The
existential view is a complex one arising from theology, literature, philosophy,
psychology, psychiatry and other such areas of human interest. The basic theme is
concerned with the understanding of human nature in general and human behaviour
and emotions in particular. Existential therapists hold that man is more than 'an
intellect' and that counselling should, therefore, be psychological rather than logical.
Existential philosophy is concerned with the nature of man. The individual is not
a mere substance or mechanism, but is becoming or emerging. The proponents of
the existential view are fix)m outside the psychological stream of thought. The
father figure of this movement is Soren A. Kierkegaard (1813-1855). Among the
other thinkers are Paul Tillich (1886-1965), Martin Heidegger (1889), Jean Paul
Sartre (1905-1980), Eugene Minkowski 0). 1885), Ludwig Binswanger (b. 1881),
Roilo May (b. 19(^) and Viktor E. Frankl (b. 1906). Most of the thinkers are
literary figures and who have not distinguished themselves either as psychologists
or psychiatrists. The last two, namely. May and Frankl have contributed to
psychotherapy and counselling.
Existentialism centres around the concepts of 'being' and 'non-being'. Man is


--- PAGE 117 ---
Approaches to Counselling 97
deeply concerned with the question of defining himself. Both in the East as well
as in the West, philosophers from time immemorial have stressed the importance
of the dictum, 'know thy self. What is man? Man is what he makes of himself. He
has perfect freedom to fashion himself in any way he likes'. But after having made
a choice he is responsible for the consequences. He cannot disown them. But man
tries to evade responsibility. To accept responsibility is extremely painful. The
existentialists use the word 'dread' to signify man's reaction to his responsibility.
Because of his dread he tries to evade responsibility and in the bargain forfeits his
freedom. This awareness causes anguish. This is man's existential predicament We
want to be free but we are a&aid of responsibility. So we avoid the responsibili^
and, therefore, we become unhappy.
The existential conception of man is simple yet all-encompassing. The view
of man is stated in a set of the foUowing propositions: (1) Every man who
is mentally not incompetent is responsible for his actions. (2) Man can do little
to change the physical universe. It is better for him to face reality and learn to
live with it. (3) Man is alone in this world. Therefore he must aim at making
his fellow beings happy. (4) Man creates his own world, that is, his own natiue
by his own free choice. Man should act towards others as he would want them
to act towards himself. When making decisions man first asks—What will
their effects be on humanity? He must treat human beings with dignity just as
he believes himself to have dignity. Man is not just a physical entity existing
in a physical universe which functions on the principle of determinism. This
principle of determinism does not apply to human beings as their essential
nature is freedom. To be firee means to be responsible to oneself for one's own
actions. Man needs counselling help because no man in this world can solve
ell his problems alone. Counselling helps man to understand himself in his proper
perspective as a human being. Existential thinking places enormous emphasis on
the concept of freedom. It sees man not as 'being' but as 'becoming'. A free man
has limitless opportunities not only to make a free culture but also to transcend it
Concept of anxiety and guilt—Tliere is an opposition between 'being' and 'non-
being' such as between life and death. This is the existential anxiety which grows
out of man's concern for himself. The second kind of anxiety is called normal
anxiety which we experience when we feel helpless in a specific situation. It is
natural for every one to experience existential anxiety and normal anxiety, unlike
neurotic anxiety which stems from deeper maladjustments. It is man's inability to
act responsibly chat leads him to experience guilL In existential counselling the
client is helped to gain knowledge and insight into his situation, that is, he experiences
a sense of commitment. When a client is able to determine the implications of his
commitment he will be prepared to take responsibility for actions that have emanated
from his own choice and £ree will.
The existential point of view has rightly focussed on the basic conflict of human
nature, the kind of ambivalence that results in inaction or renunciation of freedom.
In practice, existential counselling does not appear to ^ply to the common conflicting
problems of human beings.

THE MINNESOTA POINT OF VIEW
The irait-and-fxtor ^proach has developed fiom the vocational guidance movement
which advocated guidance for educational and vocational adjustment TTiis movement
was started by the pioneering efforts of people like Hi Weaver who wrote Choosing
a Career in 1907, Frank Parsons who started the Vocational Bureau of Boston in
1908, Jesse B. Davis (1898) who started Educational Career Counselling in Detroit
and William Rainey Harper of University of Chicago who stressed the importance
of guidance in 1899, a decade before Frank Parsons. Donald Patersoii and his
colleagues continued this work at the University of Minnesota. This blossomed into
a school of thought in the woric of Williamson, Berdie and others who did a great
deal of work at the Student Counselling Bureau, University of Minnesota. The
directive point of view has developed with the recognition of and the concern for
problems not necessarily restricted to educational and vocational areas. However,
the important point of distinction is that the Minnesota school does not consider
psychotherapy to be the same as counselling. To quote Williamson (1950),
"Psychotherapy in the past has centered attention ^ost exclusively and somewhat
narrowly upon the pathology and medical treatment of emotional disruptions, traumas
and anxieties". Williamson emphasizes the developing nature of counselling. There
is an element of change in the development Hence, Williamson has never claimed
to have stated the principles of directive counselling in their fmal form.
One of the foremost tenets of counselling, according to the directive approach,
is that the goals of counselling and education are the same. This view is called
'personalism*. The function of counselling is to enable the student to profit optimally
firom instruction. Psychotherapy has often restricted itself to the emotional aspects
of personality development. Counselling, on the other hand, has a much broader
scope. It is concerned with the interaction of the personaliQ^ with the surrounding
culture. Thus counselling is not psychotherapy but a different concept which embraces
and integrates vocational and ^ucational guidance with personality dynamics and
inter-personal relationships.
The directive approach explains the nature of man in terms of five propositions:
1. Human nature is always capable of accomplishment, often through education.
Therefore, coimsellors must help the counsellees learn to utilize their abilities
most efficiently.
2. The second proposition concerns human development Though man has the
potentiality for fiiU development, he often does not thieve this. Self-
actualization requires the assistance of other people. Williamson (1965)
emphasizes Herberg's statement "the human self emerges only in the
community and has no real existence apart from it"
3. There is the question of 'what is good?" This has been a problem through
the ages and this question cannot be answered with finaliQ^. Self-actualization
is thus the best possible and the most 'good' form of human nature.
4. Who determines what is good? There is once again much controversy
regarding this and what appears apt is that the search for self actualization
itself will prove to be a good life.
5. What is the natiue of the universe and what is man's relationship to the


--- PAGE 119 ---
Approaches to Counselling 99
universe? The counsellor has to help the counsellee formulate the best
conception of his personal cosmology.
The acrimony between the directive and non-directive counselling theories has
mercifully subsided. The orthodoxies of the 1950s have apparently run their course.
As counselling sought recognition as a profession, the question of explaining the
functions and describing the procedures elicited vague answers which were not
quite convincing. Non-directive counselling theory became too broad and led to the
emphasis of therapy at the expense of counselling. So long as counselling and
therapy were not distinguished, any distinction was thought irrelevant Non-directive
theory was apparently in the leading position, but this led to blurring the distinction
between counselling as an educative agent and counselling as a therapeutic agent.
Client-centred counselling therapy attempted to become the definition of guidance
theory. The directive model assumed that the counsellor possessed information,
content and facts that he provided to his clients. An informational deficit was, in
reality, a problem which could be quickly and effectively solved. The concept of
guidance is superficial if imparting of information is a major objective of guidance.
It is as disjunctive to the gods of guidance as is the classroom teacher who functions
merely as a presenter of content This implies the avoidance of a major educational
goal—the process of disciplined enquiry in the classroom and the process of learning
to be able to make one's own decisions as in the case of counselling. These two
aspects of the process of education become the major educational goals once the
complementary roles of teaching and guidance are recognized. From the point of
view of teaching this would mean the growth of individual autonomy in the use of
ideas, facts, questions and content in the various subject disciplines.
NATURE OF COUNSEUING
Counselling, according to Williamson (1950), is "one of the personalized and
individual processes designed to aid the individual to learn school subject matter,
citizenship traits, social and personal values and habits, and all other habits, skills,
attitudes and beliefs which go to make up a normally adjusting being." In other
words, the function of counselling is to assist the counsellee at school or college
to learn effective ways of achieving desired and desirable goals. Counselling is thus
personalized, permissive assistance to develop self-understanding and self-direction.
The directive approach is also called the trait-and-factor approach by which is
meant that the counselling process consists of analysing and identifying personality
traits or factors which could best be matched with the demands of different kinds
of situations—educational, vocational, personal, etc. The counselling process consists
of six steps—analysis, synthesis, diagnosis, prognosis, counselling and follow-up
(ASDPC^. In this approach there is a strong analogy to the medical model. The
first step in analysis is to obtain as full and complete an understanding of the client
as possible from cumulative records, autobiographies, anecdotal records,
psychological tests and interviews. A trained counsellor will not necessarily limit
himself to any particular approach. He tries to secure as much information as
practicable from different tools or techniques. The information thus obtained has to


--- PAGE 120 ---
100 Counsellingand Guidance
be synthesized. Synthesis esswitially consists of ordering and arranging the data so
that it helps in dhignosis.
Diagnosis as a method in counselling is disfavoured in client-centered therapy.
According to Rogers, in diagnozing, the client is treated as an object The locus of
responsibility is shifted to the counsellor. Gathering diagnostic information produces
no change in the client Further there is a danger of the counsellor becoming
committed to his diagnosis and, therefore, failing to see significant new attitudes
in" the client Diagnosis is, therefore, considered inimical to client-centered
counselling. However, in the trait-and-factor approach it is considered to be the
necessary first step in counselling. Diagnosis consists of the interpretation of data
in terms of the problems indicated, the assets and liabilities and the strengths and
weaknesses of the counsellee. It is arrived at by a logical process of inference.
Diagnosis involves: (1) identifying the problem and (2) determining the causes, that
is searching for relationships, past, present and future, which may help in the
understanding of the causes of the symptoms.
Diagnosis is always of the nature of a hypothesis and, therefore, should be open
to modification. Diagnosis is primarily the function of the counsellor. This does not
however mean that the counsellor can do his work without the active cooperation
of the counsellee in the process. The next step after diagnosis is prognosis. Diagnosis
and prognosis are both relevant to the goals the counsellee strives to achieve. While
diagnosis is concerned with the past and the present, prognosis is concerned with
the future.
The next step in the treatment is counselling proper. This is effected through
counselling sessions or interviews in which the counsellee is helped to try different
solutions without fear of ridicule or criticism. There are no limitations imposed on
the client regarding the number of solutions he may try. He is free to try as many
as he likes till he is able to reach an optimal solution.
The last step, usually neglected but most important, is the follow up. This
concerns the counsellor's continued interest in the counsellee and includes the
assistance the counsellor gives to deal with new problems of a recurring nature.
HOW COUNSELLING IS IMPLEMENTCD
The directive approach outlines five techniques in the implementation of counselling.
These are: (1) forcing conformity, (2) changing the environment, (3) selecting the
appropriate environment, (4) learning the needed skills and (5) changing attitudes,
lite counsellor establishes rapport with the client and helps him to achieve self-
understanding. If the client is unable to do this, the counsellor forces conformity
or resorts to the other techniques listed above. In forcing conformiQ' the counsellor
may use direct advising, that is, talk frankly and state his own position in clear and
unambiguous terms. Next, he may employ the persuasive method. The counsellor
collects the relevant evidence and explains logically the course of action and
persuades the client to try it.
The explanatory method is often considered most desirable. In this the counsellor
patiently explains the diagnosdc data and points to the different ways in which the
counsellee can utilize his potendalities and environmental resources.


--- PAGE 121 ---
Approaches to CounseJIIng 101
When a reasonable course of action has emerged the counsellor may assist the
counsellee in its implementation. For example, if some learning deficiencies are
diagnozcd, the counsellor may work out a remedial programme which would help
the client (in this case, the student) to overcome them. If the counsellor is confronted
with problems he is unable to cope with he has to make referrals to specialized
agencies for assistance.
The Minnesota approach stresses the use of measurement and prediction. It
seeks out objective and dependable data about the client and helps him to make an
appropriate choice or decision in the resolution of his problem. Obviously this
approach is a rational, problem-solving one though the importance of emotions
cannot be ignored. This approach stresses that human individuals are rational and
are, therefore, capable of making proper choices or finding solutions to their
problems. What hinders in this process is ignorance or lack of information regarding
the individual himself or the environment or both. If the necessary information is
made available, the client being rational, should be able to solve his problems. In
this approach there is an element of direction which, of course, is not authoritarian
but is a kind of cognitive direction or explanation. In this the didactic technique is
used by the counsellor to help the client understand his assets and liabilities and his
potentialities for growth. With such self-knowledge the counsellee should be able
to make proper choices in educational and vocational Helds or find solutions to
problems of a personal nature.
The limitations of this approach are:
1. The trait-and-factor approach has been developed in an educational setting
concerning adolescents and early adults. The nature of the clientele and the
setting are such that the problems encountered cannot help having an
educational and/or vocational flavour.
2. This approach overemphasizes rationality or reason and does not give
adequate attention to affective elements.
3. It places too much reliance on objective data. It is a moot point that
psychological test data are often claimed to lack objectivity. No test can be
valid in all simations and for all persons. And it is impossible to individualize
the test and yet claim objectivi^.
THE ECLECTIC APmOACH
There is no gainsaying the fact that counsellors, like medical men, adopt variations
of their theoretical positions in actual practice. This kind of variation becomes
necessary to suit diflerent individuals and specific situations. From a strictly
theoretical point of view it may be argued that it is unscientific to stray away from
wy given theory no matter by how small a degree. It is argued with equ^ vehemence
that puritanical rigidity may be counter-productive and that if one wishes to succeed,
one must appreciate the realistic aspects and variations in clients' backgrounds,
experiences, expectations and goals on the one hand, and situational differences on
the other. Most pracdtioners in actual practice adopt minor to major variations in
their theoretical orientations. They adopt different view points which are consistently


--- PAGE 122 ---
IQ2 Counselling and Guidance
combined into a working theory. This trend in practiUoners' approach towardstheory is often described as 'emerging eclecticism'. Each counseUor must sooner
or later develop a point of view which may be called uniquely his own. Thedivergencies in current theories of personality also point to the reason why no one
theory or method of approach is fully adequate for any counsellor, for different
types of clients and for different kinds of situations. Such a pragmatic approach is
likely to exhibit several theoretical inconsistencies. But it should be realized that
developing a unique view encompassing all the variations and incorporating alt the
salient feamres of all the theories is a very demanding and lifelong task. A practitioner
cannot afford to await the development of such an all-encompassing point of view
before he takes on the pressing task of helping others. The preceding lines imply
that there could be as many different ^es of eclecticism as there are practicing
counsellors. There may be some who refuse to identify themselves with any particular
theoretical system, such as psycho-analysis or existentialism or behaviourism. Some,
it will be seen, under-emphasize the importance of theory. They contend that it is
wasteful, if not dangerous, to be drawn into the vortex of academic controversy
over the issue of theories when there are raging differences in the points of view
and approaches of the extant theories. Instead they believe that it is best to draw
firom all theories and not be bogged down by the limitations of any particular
theory. This would give them the freedom to choose from lime to time the principles
and ideas that would best suit their current specific needs. Some counsellors go to
the extent of claiming to be non-theoretically oriented, stating that what they are
really concerned with is to provide relief to the client, here, and now, and not to
enter into the polemics of theories. They declare that they are least concerned with
theory building.
Even though some counsellors disclaim interest in the theoretical aspects of
counselling, each one has some conception of the underlying structure and dynamics
of his client's personality. He may not be able to adequately verbalize his ideas and
argue about its strengths and weaJoiesses. His is a case of practice first and perhaps
theory later. But others claim that "in practice, a consistent frame of reference is
desirable" (Patterson, 1973).
English and English (1958) define eclecticism in theory building as the selection
and orderly combination of compatible features from diverse sources and of
incompatible theories and systems into a harmonious whole. The resultant system
is open to constant revision even in its major outlines. Eclecticism is to be
distinguished from unsystematic and uncritical combination of things. The eclectic
seeks consistency as far as possible. The formalist sees the eclectic's position as too
loose and uncritical. The eclectic finds the schools (theories) too formal, dogmatic
and rigid. The newer concept of eclecticism is not a theoretical. The recognition
that no one theoretical orientation is adequate to deal with the complexities of a
variety of individuals suggests the need for an integrated, comprehensive and
pragmatic approach.
Brammer (1969) explains that eclecticism in counselling refers to selecting, or
choosing from various systems or theories. What is selected, presumably, is the
best of each system. The question, 'what is best?' is seldom explained satisfactorily.
The matter of choosing what is 'best' from each system is left to the counsellor to


--- PAGE 123 ---
Approaches to Counselling 103
decide under the given circumstances, and this can lead to much avoidable
controversy. It is explained that the choices of principles are never made in advance
but arc made as and when they are found to be expedient in working with the
counsellees. It is, therefore, not practicable to predict what an eclectist will do in
a given situation. This suggests that the position of every eclectic counsellor will
naturally differ from every other eclectician, making the position impossible to
define or describe. Carkhuff and Berenson (1967) call this approach an 'eclectic
stance' which they believe is systematic. They claim the 'openness' of this approach
to be an advantage.
According to an important protagonist of the eclectic point of view, Thome
(1950), eclecticism is the most practicable and apt approach to counselling. He
points to the fact that there are wide personalia differences and no single theory
of personality can justifiably encompass all phenomena. Similarly, the problems of
individuals vary both in content and intensity and an approach suitable to one
individual need not necessarily suit another individual. Tlierefore, it is necessary
that the therapy be individualized. It must be such that it is relevant to the problem
and the client. This suggests an approach of robust common sense utilizing the
contributions of all recognized systems and schools of psychotherapy according to
their indications and contra-indications.
Thome calls this 'integrative psychology' and claims that it provides systematic
theoretical foundations for eclectic clinical practice. Brammer (1969) is critical
about "choosing bits and pieces from a wide spectrum of counselling theories and
methods" and holds that it is a "hodge-podge of contradictory assumptions and
incompatible techniques". He instead suggests the need for developing a
comprehensive, consistent and systematic synthesis "incorporating all valid
knowledge about behaviour". In support of this position. Woods (1964) states, "if
there were no theoretical positions, there would be no eclecticism".
The therapeutic implications of integrative psychology arc:
1. All psychopathological or disturbed conditions are examples of disorders of
integrations and the goal of all methods of psychological counselling is to
strengthen and improve the quality of the integrative process, thus fostering
higher levels of self-actualizations. The specific goal of all therapeutic
counselling is to alter the existing psychological state. The counsellor's
focus is, therefore, the person in the present situation: "The psychological
state of the person running the business of his life in the world".
2. The therapist has to assess whether the client has the necessary resources to
take on the responsibilities of his life.
3. If the therapist is satisfied, he gives the client the responsibility of taking on
some routine tasks to start with.
4. Therapy involves the training and re-education of the client in acquiring the
controls necessary for self-regulation.
Thome prefers the term 'psychological case handling' to 'psychotherapy* for the
reason that the effectiveness of the psychotherapeutic methods has so far not been
convincingly demonstrated. The former terra is broader and more comprehensive
and includes all activities not necessarily confined to psychotherapy alone.


--- PAGE 124 ---
104 Counsellingand Guidance
The steps in psychological case handling are:
1. Making a diagnosis systematically to obtain a complete picture of the client's
problem.
2. Understanding the methods completely, including their strengths and
weaknesses, their limitadons and contra-indications, which could be employed
in the treatment
3. Concentrating on the basic or underlying causes rather than treating the
superficial symptoms.
4. Choosing a speciflc method suited to the needs of the client
5. Evaluating the method on the basis of the results obtained, (in this the
therapist must recognize that there can never be universally applicable
methods.)
6. Scientifically analysing the data and evaluating the results.
According to Thome (1968), the major objectives of psychological case handling
are: (1) precluding and halting the aggravation of the problem or condition, (2)
rectifying etiological factors to prevent a recurrence of the problem, (3) mitigating
suffering through systematic support, (4) facilitating personality growth through the
removal of obstacles and re-education, (5) helping expression and clarifying
emotional attitudes, (6) resolving conflicts and inconsistencies and thus promoting
maturation and growth, (7) enabling the individual to accept what cannot be
changed—'endure what cannot be cured' and (8) changing attitudes and maximizing
resources to catalyze self-actualization by improving integrational status.
Case handling should be based on an individual appraisal of each case. The plan
should include suitable measures for beginning the relationship and unearthing and
identifying the problem for dealing with the psychopathological symptoms and
related etiological factors. The therapist may utilize ^1 available methods for an
early termination of the case.
Counselling is defined as a face-lo-face relationship in which the counsellor, a
person competently trained in psychological science, consciously attempts by means
of attitudes and speech to help others solve problems of life in which personality
factors are the primary etiologic agents. Thome holds that a client seeks counselling
assistance because he has problems with which he is unable to cope with alone.
Consequently the counselling relationship, no matter how non-directive it may be,
assumes a dominance-submission, relationship. The direction of counselling depends
on the assistance that is sought and the client's potentialities for effective self-
regulation. Thome believes that human nature or personality is reflected in the
manner in which the individual interacts with his environment. There are a series
of drives which activate the individual, like the drive for higher organization, the
drive to achieve and maintain stability and the drive to integrate opposing functions
so as to avoid imbalance. Human nature exhibits a constant striving for unity
manifesting itself in efforts to consistently maintain integrity and organization of
the self.
s From the eclectic point of view, personality development is regarded as a struggle
to transcend affective, impulsive and unconscious determinants of behaviour by
learning and perfecting rational, logical and voluntary control of behaviour. An


--- PAGE 125 ---
Approaches to Counselling 105
individual's life style shows distinctive on'ensive-defensive strategies for satisfying
needs and coping with reali^ by the use of various mechanisms and expressive
styles. The self develops in consciousness around feelings of personal identity and
by experiencing what is happening to oneself. The self-image is the self one thinks
oneself to be. Thus, the self is able to regulate the whole organism and to even
cause it to do things that are against its own interests. In an abnormal state the self
may not be aware of itself and hence may not be able to control cotain functionings.
The self-concept is crucial since it operates as the functional core of being. Personality
development is affected by constitutional, biological and cultural factors as well as
by the drive for self-actualization. The drive for self-actualization is a powerful
drive which motivates human beings towards improvement or perfection. The
awareness of alternatives and the possibility of decision-making imply freedom
iiom mechanistic determination. The need for making choices introduces the need
to have a value system and to be responsible for one's actions. Human life reaches
its most outstanding heights in moments of highest self-actualization and self-
transcendence. llie striving or working towards it constitutes positive mental health.
Garfield (1969) summarizes Thome's system as one which is comprehensive
and organized and which has brought together a varieQ' of methods though it still
remains essentially a loosely gathered system.
SUMMARY
Some of the representative approaches to counselling have been outlined In
brief. Several lacunae are evident In the approaches. These approaches difh^
with regard to the importance they attach to rationality in human behaviour. At
one extreme the behavioural approach to counselling tends to view human
behaviour as simply reactive and as entirely determined by the environment.
The p^choanalytical view takes a dim view of human rationality and explains
human behaviour eis mostly unconsciously caused by irrational forces. They
believe that the environment exerts little. If any, ellect on the unconsdous. This
negattvlstic view of man presents a pessimistic and unedl^rlng view of human
nature. The client-centered approach places a great premium on man's goodness
and makes it the focal theme. The existential view-point views man as purposeful,
seeking the meaning of life and striving to determine his own destiny. The trait-
and-factor approach believes In the indtvlduai's capacity to act rationally and
purposefully, provided he Is ^en the necessary assistance to use his innate
resources. The eclecticapproach, we have seen tries to combine into a consistent
^stem the positive aspects of all the systems. All the approaches aim at reducing
man's suffering and increasing his efficiency, productivity and happiness. Ford
and Urban (1963) explain that there are differences in the view of human nature
held by different approaches to counselling. Some tiieorles, they hold, consider
man as a pilot steering his course and others consider him as a mere robot,
automatlcdiy controlled by suitable manipulations of the environment by the
counsellor. The behavlouilstic approaches take a mechanistic view and explain
human behaviour to result fiom suitable operations of environmental stimulations.
Notwithstanding this partial, limited and dismal view of man taken by many
theories, much faith is reposed In the view that human nature is modifiable.


--- PAGE 126 ---
106 CaunseUIng and Guidance
Nothing Is ever unredeemable. Given ttie patience and facilities man's apparently
chaotic and destructive life could be directed tov/ards more meaningful
worttiwhile goals and towards gaining self-actuallzatlon through re-education.
There Is agreement concerning the importance of recognizing man's
Individuality, freedom and responsibility. It Is also the consensus that It is desirable
to enhance ttiese Individual 'rights'. Behavioural approaches, though apparendy
concerned with symptom-relief, aim at enabling the Individual to function better,
or In other words, to achieve Increasing expression.
In terms of techniques, tfie major approaches also show some Important
differences, aient-centered, tr^t-and-factor. existential and p^choarailytlcal
approaches look upon providing Insight as a major technique of therapy.
these the Individual Is given heedom and encouraged to talk openly. It Is
through the 'talklng-out' process ttiat the IncUvldual gains Insight Into himself
and understands the significance of the symptoms underlying his difficulties. The
gaining of In^ght either dispels the difficulties or helps In their elimination.
Behavlourally-orlented approaches are concerned with symptoms, behaviour
and actions which they seek to eliminate, modify and change by suitably
manipulating the environmental stimulations and reinforcements.
Counsellor education and training stress the need for developing a plairslble
and consistent approach which is meaningful In terms of one's values and
expectations. The counsellor's own experience, his personality and his view of
man, all affect his 'personalized' approach to counselling. No counsellor would
accept the view points of all the approaches fer the simple reason that they are
at variance with one another. Therefore, he has obviously to pick and choose
only those Ideas, principles, techniques and methods that appeal' to him as
being meaningful, useful and practicable. As a professional worker, he has to
develop a style of functioning which Is uniquely his own. In the course of his
professional practice, he may gain new Insights which enable him to re-evaluate
his Ideas, principles, methods and techniques and perhaps modl^ some of
them slightly, change a few significantly and abandon a few others for the one's
he believes to be more meaningful and purposeful In the context of his present
situation (client's problem). It would be a grave error If one were to believe that
a counsellor could function without a theoretical basis. No one can operate in a
vacuum. However Inexperienced a counsellor may be. he Implicitly operates on
the basis of some theory. This he Is perfectly free to modify, clwige or even
abandon on the basis of his experience for another point of view which he
considers more benefldal.

INTRODUCTION
The term 'counselling' is used by individuals engaged in different occupational
fields like school counselling, employment counselling, marriage'counselling, and
so on. They (the professional counsellors) have much in common as th^ are all
concerned with helping others. Counsellor's efforts whether crisis based or
developmental based have a clear focus on the counsellee's future. An essential
aspect of all counselling relationships is to help the counsellee focus on his/her
personal future, explore the desirable possibilities and their feasibility to develop
plans that would lead to a desirable Fesolution of the problem situation(s). In trying
to help the counsellee reach this goal, the counsellor has to inspire feelings of trust,
credlbili^ and confidence. This is done through communicating to the counsellee
his caring attitude and his positive regard for him, irrespective of his position. The
counsellor strives to understand rather than judge the behaviour of the people he
is trying to help. Before thinking about how to accomplish something he has to
clarify what is to be accomplished. Counselling emphasizes growth and enhancement
as an important goal. It is necessary that we imderstand and distinguish between
growth that is healthy and growth that is not. Rogers (1961), Blocher (1966), Ellis
(1967), Erikson (1968), Maslow (1968), White (1973), Jourard (1974) have referred
to the different aspects of 'desirable growth' in individuals. A person with healthy
growth will show an increasing tendency to behave confidently and make decisions,
exhibit commitment to appropriate goals, reveal self-control, be capable of impartially
appraising a situation and acting rationally and effectively. He will be willing to
learn from his mistakes and use his ingenuity to deal with each new crisis. He will
be clear about his motivations, beliefs, feelings, assumptions and values.
Counselling can best be described as a nmcess. This implies an identifiable
sequenc€~tif~evenis taking place over a period of time. Successful and effective
counselling may take as little as thirty minutes, it may take a few sessions or it may
take months, lite sequence of events, the dynamics involved and the nature and
extent of exploration differ with each individual counsellee. However, the stages in
the process are broadly similarjfor most individuals. The stages usually include:initial appointment, (^"^re-counselliitg s^sionjpvolving art exploi^on of^e client's concern(s), (•3y"ftSv«To5rr'"^t "l' a'ffleilitanve r^tifl&b^
