achievement, (6»'^valuation of results, .^termination of relationship and (8)foUow-up. ,
"Outcome goals are the intended results of the counselling process. They reter ^
what the counsellee desires to achieve with the assistance of a counsellor. Process
goals are those future events which the counsellor considers helpful or instrumen^in bringing about outcome goals. Process goals are often described in terms of th®counsellor actions and also in terms of the effects to be experienced by the client.
For example, a counsellor may say to himself, "in order to help the counsellee,
must understand his attitudes and the way he behaves towards others, I rnus
understand the circumstances which have led to the present situation and ihos®
which are reinforcing the counsellee's behaviour".
PREPARATION FOR COUNSELLING
Readiness
The initial step in counselling is readiness on the pan of a potential counsellee to
be help^. For instance, many people smoke. Even though they are aware that
is undesirable and injurious they persist in the habit From among them a few may
desire to give up smoking and are ready to seek assistance to gel rid of the habit-
Yet others may not bother themselves about this and will naturally make no efToiis
to give up the habit Thus readiness is the first step in the counselling process. It
is this that makes the client seek the assistance of the counsellor.
There are a number of factors affecting readiness. The first among them
ignorance. Individuals may persist in certain kinds of habits without having th®
least idea that such habits are undesirable. Therefore, there is no question of tryinS
to give them up. The second factor is the common psychological phenomenon-
called resistance. Individuals tend to be apathetic owing to an innate resistance (ot
change. The third factor is lack of motivation. An individual may be aware that a
particular habit is undesirable but he may not be sufficiently motivated to do
something about it The points enumerated above are serious obstacles to readiness
and are subjective or client-centered. Apart from this, readiness may be lacking
owing to situational problems, such as non-availability of competent assistance. In
otho- words, while the individual may desire a change, he is helpless because h®
does not know whom to approach or does not have the time or other resources to
seek help. Readiness is partly determined by the subjective feelings of the individual
and partly by the situational obstacles. Most of these obstacles can be overcome by
providing the necessary information to potential clients who may, in addition to
other things, have false notions regarding the costs. But the basic obstacle, namely*
attitude, is not easily ameijable to change. For example, many people may belief®
that consulting a counsellor is socially damaging. One of the important services of
counselling is concerned with preparing clients for counselling. There are a number
of referral agencies. For example, a teacher at school may identify a pupil's problen»
and ask the parents of the pupil to obtain the necessary assistance. If there is 8
helping agency like a school psychologist or a counselling centre available the
teacher could refer the case to them. This has certain advantages. The agency


--- PAGE 129 ---
Counselling Process 109
would take the initiative and contact the potendal clienL It could overcome the
resistance and shyness of the prospective client and ultimately succeed in bringing
the client to the counselling centre. If this were to fail, the agency could meet the
parents of the pupils and Impress upon them the need for intervention. If this were
also to fail the agency could resort to disciplinary measures. But as a rule counselling
services do not visi^ize employing disciplinary action for counselling purposes.
The best method of bringing about client readiness Is through dissemination of
informatiCHi. Meeting the subjects individually as well as in groups to discuss the
need to seek assistance could be helpful. The other method is to give the prospective
client as complete an information as possible. This helps to draw the attention of
the client to his problems which he may not have initially been aware of.
Administering problem checklists or asking subjects to fill an adjustment inventory
would be of value.
Usually clients fall under two broad categories: (1) The first category consists
of those who voluntarily seek assistance. Such persons are aware of their problems.
They feel uneasy and want to be relieved of their suffering. (2) The other category
of clients is usually referred to the counsellor by school autfiorities, parents, civic
authorities (police) or courts. The clients in this category may again be further
classified into two categories: those who want to profit from counselling and improve
themselves and those who resent it This category of people are not ready for
counselling and usually do not cooperate with the counsellor.
Pre-counselling Interview
When once the client has reached the stage of readiness the next stage Is the pre-
cotmselling interview or the Initial interview. The pre-counselling interview has
very simple objectives. It is meant to apprise the client of his responsibilities, the
modus operandi o^ihe counselling service, the frequency and the time of the
counselling sessions and also the amount of fees (if charged). The pre-counselling
interview must also concern itself with obtaining personal data and other such basic
information regarding the client The counsellor on his part tries to establish an
initial contact which could go a long way in establishing rapport and a healthy
counselling.relatiCHiship. While the counselling expectations cannot be fully discui^sed
at this stage the client must be given some idea of it
From the material obtained in the pre-counselling interview the counsellor can
fmmulate his strategies as how best to proceed with the client Usually the pre-
counselling interview is followed by a couple of counselling sessions during which
the counsellor strives to obtain as clear a picture as is practicable of the client's
problems. If the counsellee is less communicative, more sessions may be needed.
Simultaneously the counsellor tries to inform himself about the client as completely
and fi^y as p^ible by reswting to anecdotal records, case history, autobiographical
and biographical reports and other such sources.
Brammer and Shostrom (1960) discuss the importance of readiness during the
interview. In this the importance of motivating the clients is stressed for a client
may not return after having called once, or even if he were to return, may wear a
facade and may mislead the counsellor through unconscious devices of resistance.
The client may fluently report much simpler problems like difficult in

remembering things, not knowing how to study, and so on. There is a distinct
possibility for the counsellor to get caught with these apparent problems. Anexperienced counseUor would be able to see through this facade in a short whUe

Case History
In the preparation for counselling the importance of the case history of the client
cannot be overemphasized. "A case history is a syslerriadc collection of facts about
the client's current and past life" (Brammer and Shostrom, 1960). Counsellors with
different orientations place different degrees of emphasis on case history and use
different kinds of materials. A psychoanalytically-oriented counsellor m*ay look for
important childhood experiences while a counsellor trained in a different tradition
(social wori:) may emphasize the environmental circumstances of the client A
vocational counseUor would naturally look for items having a direct bearing on the
vocational choice, and an educational counseUor would look for relevant facts in
school and the early training period for the difficulties encountered by the cUeht
with his academic work at present
Process of Counselling
The process of counselling is set in motion with the making of an appointment by
the cUeni. This is foUowed by the actual caUing of the client. The client brings with
him his attitudes and feelings towards himself, towards the counsellor and towards
the very concq)t of counselUng. The client may have problems such as the choice
of a career, self-acceptance, or adjusunent to the kind of work that is required at
school or coUege. The more meaningful the problem is, the more strongly will he
feel about his difficulty. Each cUeni reacts to the first interview in a unique mannen
The counsellor knows that most people experience difficulty in not only asking for
help but also in accepting help. Often they are reluctant to face the consequences
of change. To some people receiving help means other things as well. Some view
it as an admission of inadequacy or faUure. A few take the attitude that they eitho"
need no assistance or cannot be helped. Such an attitude often results from fear of
personal involvement that may be demanded in a counselUng situation. Thus there
is an ambivalence of motives and the opting for help represents a culmination in
the struggle between the desire to seek help and the negative feeUngs that prevent
one firom asking for help. The decision to seek help is regarded by counsellors as
a positive stq) as it necessarily impUes the counsellee's acceptance of hisftter
responsibilities. Freud recognizes this psychological ambivalence as basic to aU
feelings and actionSi Rank (1945) terms it the 'counter wiU* which is the negative
component to every positive endeavour.

Reasons for Maldng an Appointment
A formal statement of why a client goes to the counsellor frequently tells very little
about the real nature of the situation. By requesting the client to elaborate on
cotain aspects of the problem the counsellor gives the client an opportunity to
crystallize and to organize his own ideas, thoughts and feelings regarding the issues
that concern him. At this stage of discussion a great deal of latent anxiety comes
to the surface. The client may realize that his problem is more serious or more
compelling than he had imagined jt to be at the outset. It is also sometimes found
that the latent anxiety comes to the surface accompanied by a great deal of feeling.
This marks a very important position which indicates that the client has moved
from an almost impersonal request for an appointment to a point where he is able
to share with the counsellor some aspect of his problem.
Referral
The other type of clients who call on the counsellor perhaps not on their own
initiative but at the suggestion of others, may be worried parents, troubled relatives,
perplexed friends, discouraged teachers or dissatisfied employers. Usually this
category of individuals comprise the majori^ of clients.
The question of referral is not quite as simple as it appears. The counsellor has
to consider several important and very closely related aspects, such as:
1. Why a person is referred.
2. Who the referral is made by.
3. How the referral is structured.
4. How the client perceives the referral, etc.
The reasons why clients ^ referred to a counsellor or a counselling agency
depend on a number of ^tors. Most referrals originate not fiom the client's desire
to obtain expert help but from the referral agency's/individual's experience of the
client's failure to function adequately in one or more endeavours. Therefore, quite
often counsellors Hnd their clients calling on them with a nonchalant attitude.
Nothing in the situation suggests that the referrants want new experiences. The
clients almost always ask no questions, answer in monosyllables and appear to be
very much relieved at the termination of the interview. There is an important matter
of social significance that might account for this atdtude. Our society seems to
attach some kind of stigma to seeking counselling help. This is because a large
number of people do not understand ^e objectives of counselling. The fear of
social ostracization may prevent potential clients from readily seeking counselling
assistance.
It is necessary that the counsellor understands why. the client has been referred
to him and whether he can provide the kind of assistance required. Gales (1949)
holds that sometimes several sessions are required to enable the client to come face
to face with his own problems. It is important to know who made the referral,.for
this can throw considerable light on the purpose of the referral. Referrals made by
professional people deserve particular consideration. Making a referral invariably
entails responsibility. For a referral to be effective it is necessary that the client


--- PAGE 132 ---
112 Counselling and Guidance
shares responsibility. UsuaUy the client is not clear as to how the counsellor can
help him and sometimes may even be labouring under a misapprehension. Whaievw
the client's position may be, the counsellor always begins with the reality as it
appears to the client Misconceptions arising from ignorance can be handled without
much harm to the client
The structure of the referral is another issue of considerable importance. The
client should be u>ld that he may have to take a few psychological tests or be asked
a few questions. Although the structuring of the referral is not usually crucial to the
outcome of the counselling process, it can certainly help or hinder the progress of
the cotuiselling process, at least in the initial stages. A client who comes to the
counsellor to seek advice may view the counsellor as an expert and hence take no
responsibility in the decision-making process and may not play his real part in the
counselling relationship. An exasperated teacher may send a student to the counsellor
who may find that the concern^ student views him with suspicion and hostility.
The student may not be disposed to think of the counsellor as a professionally
trained person capable of assisting him to solve his problems.
The way the client perceives the referral and his counsellor are equally important
in the counselling process. This is determined largely by his basic personality
structure and his understanding of his situation. This, in turn, will determine what
the counsellor says to the client and what the tests (if given) reveal. It is postulated
that the more immature the client, the greater will be the extent of appercepiive
distortion.
Anxiety
Anxiety is another important factor which impels people to seek assistance. When
examined carefully it represents the conflicts between opposing needs, motives or
desues in the educational and vocational areas or personal life that motivate the
client to seek professional assistance. Unless the client feels anxious or unsure of
his plans or ambivalent about some choice, he does not need the help of a counsellor.
The very essence of counselling lies in helping the client to recognize the conflicting
feelings inherent in most problems and to accept them as a part of his real self.
There can be no counselling without the client experiencing some anxiety.
It is not unusual for the counsellor to once in a while come across clients who
are aware that something is a miss or wrong with them but are incapable of going
through the coimselling process. They either have no time or patience or are afraid
of facing facts. There are also a few clients who are otherwise psychologically
soimd but develop anxiety in response to an environmental difficulty, such as the
loss of one's job or a loved person. Anxieties engendered by a particular predicament
can be ameliorated if the client mobilizes his own resources and faces his problems
squarely. This requires support which is likely to express itself as a desire for
reassurance which the counsellor can provide.
The First Interview
The counselling process, generally speaking, consists of three parts: the request for
assistance (intake), the counselling proper (counselling) and the termination of the


--- PAGE 133 ---
CounselllrigProcess 113
relationship (termination). The first interview is the beginning of the actual contact
between (he client and the counsellor. Usually the client approaches the counsellor
cautiously. He is unsure of what is going to happen. Thus much of what takes place
during the first interview is concerned with the probing and, if possible, with the
identification of the problem. Either the client or the counsellor may open the
discussion. There are no rigid rules about who should start talking first. The client-
counsellor relationship is usually established during the initial interview. The fees,
if any, duration and frequency of interviews, kinds of psychological tests to be
administered, if necessary, and other related issues are discussed. The client is
made to understand that he has to function within a system or structure and that it
is up to him to make whatever use he can of counselling. Also, he is informed of
the limitations of the situation and the counselling process so that he docs not
harbour any misconceptions or false expectations.
Reassurance
By reassurance is meant the assuaging of anxiety. Thus it plays a significant part
in counselling situations. Reassurance is considered as one of the important functions
of the counselling interview. Usually the need for support and reassurance is thought
of as an expression of emotional conflict. Like the other aspects of the helping
process, reassurance is usually structured and does not connote a uniform meaning
to all people as do other psychological phenomena. The need to be reassured stems
from an inner anxiety. As the termination of the counselling relationship approaches,
the client experiences and may even express new fears. This indicates that the client
has not overcome all his fears and doubts.
Wiming Confidence
The counselling relationship is a face-to.-face and often one-to-one relationship in
which the client is encouraged to express himself without any apprehension or
hesitation and without any fear of ridicule or criticism. Therefore, it is necessary
that the counsellor wins the confidence of the client. There are no sure techniques
of achieving this. But a professionally trained counsellor has no difficulty in
establishing warm and friendly relationships which help win the confidence of his
clients. This would, in turn, help establish rapport which is the essence of the
counselling relationship. It is possible that the counsellor may subtly cajole and
persuade the client to share with him his ideas and thoughts. Distrust on the part
of the client has to be met and handled as a part of the reality of the counselling
situation. There is no reason for the client to trust the counsellor. He may well be
within his rights in not trusting him. But this adversely affects the counselling
process. A counsellor has to learn to "view lack of trust on the part of a client as
a part of the working reality. Lack of trust is often an expression of a fundamentally
insecure individual. Such clients may often resort to the escape mechanism of
submissiveness, silence and maintaining a 'you know the best' attitude, and are ^
naturally difficult to manage, but it is the counsellor's responsibility to help his
client urespecdve of these several limitations.


--- PAGE 134 ---
114 Counselling and Guidance
Advising
Advising is most often mistaken for counselling. In guidance situations sometimes
advice may be given, this cannot be taken to form part of either guidance or
counselling. Jones (1945) holds, "it is never safe to give advice except when you
know that the other fellow will not follow it". Advising is undesirable for more
reasons than one. Firstly, it makes the client dependent, secondly, it assumes that
the client is incapable of acting on his own and thirdly, it assumes that the client
does not have the necessary ability to take decisions. This runs counter to one of
the basic postulates of counselling, namely, that the client is rational and has the
necessary ability to take care of himself if given the opportunity of doing so.
Advice giving is faulty because of the implicit assumption that the counsellor
knows what is best for the client It is easy for the client to follow tlie advice for
then he need not be responsible for the outcome. Psychologically speaking, advice
giving is an act of imposition of the counsellor's ideas upon the client Offering
advice is professionally not an accqjiable practice.
COUNSEIUNG RELATIONSHIP
The core of the counselling process is the reladonship established between the
counsellor and the client We had occasion to examine how the attitudes of both
the counsellor and the client affect the relationship. It is by means of this relationship^t the counsellor elicits and recognizes the significant feelings and ideas that^t^ine the behaviour of the client It also helps the client to recognize thesefeelings and ideas. This determines th^quality of the relationship and affects theprogress of the counselling process. (Relatjonship' has immense significance inc^n^ing. It acts as a curative agent ft its oira right Most clients do not have

Uniqueness-commonness comprises an important dimension of the counsellingrelationship. counsellor understands him and derives from this feeling a sense of suppoi^It isnot uncommon for a few of the clients to perceive the involvement of the couns^or

Existential encounters are basically of two types: self-self encounter and self-
other encounter. In the former type the individual must understand himself both as
a subject and object The other encounter, that is, encounter with others involves
affection, fnendship, empathy' and eros. In most human encounters these four kinds
of emotional relationship receive emphasis. In this kind of relationship the counsellor
may get'emotionally involved to make the client similarly involved with him. The
basic concern underlying this is a keen interest to help the client overcome negative
feelings of rejection or anxiety.
The other dimension of the counselling relationship is cognitive-conative. The
cognitive aspects concern the exchanging of information and understanding the
implications of various courses of action. The conative elements refer to the
expression of feelings. There is need for the counsellor to interpret the client's
problem rationally. At the same time the counsellor realizes that action without
knowledge would be of little value. Therefore, he has to encourage an understanding
of feelings. Thus balance has to be maintained between the cognitive and conative
aspects.
Ambiguity
When a stimulus situation is vague and is capable of eliciting different responses
from several subjects, it is called an ambiguous situation. Bordin (1968) stresses the
importance of ambiguity for its therapeutic implications. According to him, in
many ways the counselling relationship appears vague and ambiguous to the client.
The counsellor generally structures the situation. The degree of clarification that the
client obtains is of profound importance. Ambiguity allows for projection which is
a very important defense mechanism. The client is able to project his feelings with
a little more abandon in an ambiguous (counselling) situation. This process of
projection of feelings has been recognized to be of great therapeutic value. Yet too
much ambiguity may lead to anxiety on the part of the clients who seek secure and
Structured relationships. Ambiguity is significant for another reason. It provides for
'transference' which is an important psychoanalytic concept. Transference is the
unconscious transfer of the love-hate affective relationship to the counsellor. The
ambiguity of the relationship helps in understanding the problem of emotional


--- PAGE 136 ---
116 Counselllngand Guidance
distance. Greater ambiguity may place the client in a rather vague position of not
knowing how pOTitissive the situation is and how close he can get to the councilor.
This has other professional implications. Most counsellors consider it unwise to
socialize with their clients. Th^ prefer to keep the two worlds—professional and
social—as far apart as possible. It is desirable that such a rigid position should not
be adopted in dealing with human relationships.
ResponslbDity
Responsibility is yet another characteristic of the counselling relationship. How
much responsibili^ should the counsellor accept for the outcomes of counselling?
How far should the counsellor share the client's troubles? Should counselling be
viewed as a very serious business in which the counsellor endeavours to play his
rightful part? Counsellors differ in their interpretation of what they expect from the
clients in terms of responsibility. While it can be stated without fear of contradiction
that no counsellor should ever take the responsibility of running the client's life,
that is, selecting the goals for him, all counsellors accept the importance or need
of providing sound advice. Counsellors may even have to assume certain liabilities
for the possible outcome of the counselling relationship for the simple reason that
the outcome is influenced by their own personality in addition to that of the
counsellee's. The amount of responsibility that a client is asked to shoulder or that
a counsellor should be willing to share depends on a variety of factors, such as the
client's age, ability, background and type of problem. It would suffice to state that
mutual responsibilities have to be worked out in each case, taking all the factors
into account

pie several theories examined in the preceding section all Indicate that counsellingIS a complex function which aims at changing the outlook of a counsellee from one
m^k^ by anxiety, pain and suffering to one of self-understanding, self-assurance

Setting
Counseling can best be carried out under certain optimal conditions which includethe physical setting. The physical setting, that is, the room in which counselling is
rendered must be free from outside disturbances. The room should be simple but
tastefully furnished, should give a feeling of warmth, and should be comfortable,
with lighting that is neither too flashy and bright nor too dull and depressing. It


--- PAGE 137 ---
CounseJUngProcess 117
should , have good ventilation. In short, it should be comfortable such that a
relaxed atmosphere is provided in which the counseliee can talk in a relaxed mood-
There is a danger of taking the physical setting for granted and, more often than
not, it is neglected to such an extent that it seriously interferes with the counselling
process.
Privacy
The essence of counselling and, for that matter, of all professional relationships, is
privacy—not only physical privacy but also psychological privacy. The question of
privacy is very intricately connected with that of recording counselling interviews.
Much controversy centres on the question of whether or not to record the counsellee's
responses. One view is that any attempt at recording may interfere with the v^
process of counselling and harm the rapport established. It is also argued that the
counseliee may become defensive and inhibit his responses. The idea is that any
suggestion of recording could have adverse effects. Those who are in favour of
recording feel that it is necessary. They argue that the counsellor should have
m^rial to go over as many times as he desires for understanding and appreciating
what the counseliee has said. Without such a record the counsellor is forced to rely
upon his memory which is known to be faulty and which can introduce new
elaborations and distortions. Exclusive reliance on memory is thus certainly
undesirable. It is further argued that if. a healthy rapport has been established it
should not be difficult for the client to overcome any hesitation or uneasiness in a
short while, when the counsellor explains the purpose of the recording. There are
others who hold that recording could be done unobtrusively using gadgets such as
camouflaged tape recorders and concealed microphones. Such devices, it is argued,
do not embarrass the clienL The client then will have no reason to feel any hesitancy.
The antagonists of recording hold that it is imethical to keep the client ignorant of
tlte recording when it is actually being done. Those who are in favour of recording
argue that no client would object if the piuposes of recording are made sufficiently
clear to him. In any medical setting several such records are made and at no time
does the client resent or oppose showing his physician the records or results of
biochemical tests. By the same token, in the counselling setting also, the client
should have no objection. However, there is an important difference between the
two settings. The counselling setting is purely psychological and it cannot be
compared with a medical setting though there too privaqy is importanL
The recording of counselling sessions is a very important and nec^sary device
in training counsellors. Therefore, for training purposes at least recordings should
be made available. However, tliese need not 'real'. They could be records of
simulated counselling sessions. The controversy boils down to two factors: the
infringement on clients' rights and, second, the need for their privacy. As far as the
first is concerned, the rights of the clients are to be accepted and without tfa^
ccHisent recordings should never be attempted. As regards the second tiiere need not
be any serious problems because all counselling, wheth^ recorded or not, is expected
to ensure privacy with all its ethical and professional obligations.

Value, Belief and Attitude Change
Counselling is a one-to-one relationship in which the counsellor provides a friendly
and warm environment for the counsellee to verbalize his problems and consider
the appropriate solutions. In this subtle relationship it is suggested that the counsellor
may unwittingly modify the altitudes, values and beliefs of the counsellee. This is
a highly sensitive issue. However, it is expected that the counsellor will take an
objective altitude and not allow his subjective attitudes to influence his professional
re^tionshlps. There are still some other questions, such as those regarding beliefs.
The counsellor is not opposed to criticize or exhibit an attitude of derision towards
the beliefs of the client. Such an attitude is not expected from any cultured individual,
let alone a counsellor. Therefore, this is not a serious problem. But there is the other
problem, namely, the modification of the client's beliefs. Should a counsellor do
anything in this direction? Is he justified in intervening and effecting a change in
the counsellee's beliefs? This is a very intricate and ticklish question though it may
superficially appear to be naive and innocent For example, what about the false
beliefs, such as the superstitions of the client? Should the counsellor have a stand
offish attitude? The counsellor would be perfectly within his rights if he were to
modify the false or wrong beliefs of the client But when these beliefs concern the
basic philosophy of life, or the essential culture of sociefy, or the religion of the
client, the counsellor is expected to adopt a neutral attiUide. Most civilized societies
today accept the individual's right of faith and the counsellor cannot have extra-
constitutional powers to interfere with the fundamental rights.
Value Orientations
The next issue concerns the value system or orientation of the client Following
Spi^ger's types of men, we could conceive the major value orientations of
i^viduals—theoretical, economic, political, social, religious and aesthetic. In most
situations clients are often plagued by value conflicts. Against this background
what is the counsellor expected to do? There is no question of the counsellor
forcing his value system on the client This is an outright unethical practice. However,
when there are value conflicts the counsellor should help resolve them by clarifying
the issues, overcoming the confusions of the client and adopting an attitude of
unreserved acceptance.
Acceptance
Rogers (1961) attaches great importance to the principle of acceptance. The nature
of a counselling relationship is defined and set by this principle of the counsellor
regarding the client unconditionally as a person of self-worth. Sometimes we have
conditional acceptance which no social relationship can escape. The counselling
relationship is also a kind of social relationship'and the parties, namely, the counsellor
and the client, may approach each other with different degrees of acceptance. This
is not a healthy counselling relationship.-An ideal counselling relationship is one
in which acceptance is unconditional. Complete acceptance does not involve
normative or judgemental attitudes. But it is deeply concerned with alleviating the
misery of another person. A counselling situation reveals acceptance by words.


--- PAGE 139 ---
CounsellingProcess 119
gestures, postures and the counsellee's as well as the counsellor's experience of the
feeling of being unconditionally liked, respected and understood. In this sense,
acceptance is the essence of a counselling situation.
Understanding
One of the basic needs of an individual is the need to be understood. This touches
the deepest feelings of the individual. To be understood is to be loved, liked and
accepted. To be not understood is to be treated as an alien. Understanding others
in a social situation as well as understanding oneself have been the prune concern
of human beings of all ages. Understanding is essentially the perception of another's
attitudes, meanings and feelings. To understand is to clearly grasp what is sought
to be understood—a person, object, event, idea or word. In a counselling situation
understanding has two connotations. First, it refers to the client's understanding of
himself and his situation or environment and, second, to the understanding of the
counsellor of the client's position or siuiation. The counsellor is able to understand
the feelings of the client and consequently the counsellor is able to follow the
client's mode of thought Gendlln (1961) has identified certain factors as important
characteristics of understanding:
1. Experiencing is felt rather than thought about and verbalized.
2. Experiencing occurs in the immediate present
3. Experiencing can be directly referred to by the individual.
4. Experiencing guides conceptualization.
5. Experiencing is implicitly meaningful.
The above categorization suggests different levels of understanding. Usually
four levels of understanding are identiGed. The fnst concerns knowledge about the
individual, thing, event, and so on. The second level consists of verbal and/or
operadonal understanding. The third concerns the understanding of one's own
perceptions, experiences, likes and dislikes. The fourth concerns self-understanding
and it may or may not be with the assistance of either internal or external perceptions.
Rapport
So far we have discussed factors or aspects that are external and also factors which
are largely influenced by the counsellor and his orientation philosophy and value
system. Apart from these, much of the success of counselling depends on counselling
skills or counsellor skiUs such as establishing rapport and empathy. Counselling is
a helping relationship that is carried on in a face-to-face and usually one-to-one
relationship. Rapport is an essential step in such a siuiation, which is more commonly
called the counselling interview. Rapport is a warm, friendly and understanding
conditioii which is essential for an effective relationship between the interviewer
and the interviewee. It is a relation that cannot be secu^ by force. It grows out
of the warmth of relationships and the desire on the part of the counsellor to
sympathetically understand the counsellee and the coimselIee*s cooperation in trying
to help the counsellor achieve a warm, friendly and trusting relationship. Rapport
is not one-sided. It is mutual and grows out of a cooperative effort It is often


--- PAGE 140 ---
120 CounsellingandGuidance
wrongly felt that ilie counsellor has a 'bag of tricks' which he uses to obtain
rapport Rapport determines the success or otherwise of an interview. It has not
•only to be secured but also sustained throughout the counselling process. The
sustenance of rapport is as important as its initial establishment. It is sustained
through the regard and trust the counsellee has for the counsellor. Even a small
feeling of doubt can mar the entire relationship. While most psychological phenomena
are measurable on some kind of psychological scale, rapport cannot stand scrutiny
on any scale of measuremenL Attempting to measure rapport would be like catching
a spinning top to feel what its motion is like. The very act of trying to feel the
motion puts an end to it If attention is drawn towards rapport, the counsellee can
become self-conscious or the counsellor can become embarrassed and rapport would
be lost. How then is one to establish and sustain rapport? This question has naturally
been a problem to counsellors. While no'thumb rules can be sensibly suggested we
can suggest certain positive factors that could help secure and maintain rapport.
Some of these factors are: (1) warmth of relationship, (2) communication of this
sense of warmth to the counseUee (not necessarily through verbal or such other
direct modes of communication), and (3) feelings of trust which grow out of
unconditicmal acceptance. Gestures, such as moving out to receive the client, greeting
him warmly, putting him at ease and directing his attention away from the problem,
are some of the basic techniques of establishing rapport Sensitiveness to the
counsellee's needs and moods can help to sustain rapport
Communication and Empathy
^unselling is, in a sense, reaching out into the psychological world of the client.The client may not be willing^ and even if willing, may not be able to communicateor give a glimpse of his psychological world to tJje counsellor. The counsellor has
not only to to reach out to tlie heart of the client but should also be able to
understand his deeper feelings. The method by which this can best be done is
through einpathy. Apathy is the capaciQ' to feel 'into* while sympathy is to feel
1^' understood by seeing how a mother feels when her.child is ill.The above statements suggest that empathy is an inier-relationship between two
people and this intcr-relationship borders on a sort of saaed relationship. According
to Rogers Q961), empathy is a necessary condition in counselling. Empathy, in his
words, is "to sense the client's private world as if it were your own, but without
ever losing the 'as if quality—this is empathy, and this seems essential to therapy.
To sense the client's anger, few, or confusion as it were your own, yet without your
own anger, fear, or confusion getting bound upon it, is the condition we are trying
to describe". From this descriptipni it will be seen that Rogers emphasizes
transposition. Empathy is not imitaiion. One does not do "exactly what the other
person does, yet one makes him.aware that one understands his thoughts, feelings,
and actions" (Shenzer and Stone, 1968).
Buchheimer identifies five dimensions of empathy. They are: (1) tone—the
expressive and non-verbal dimension conveying harmony and unity, (2) pace—the
appropriate timing of counsellor leads, (3) flexibility—the ability of the counsellor
to adapt himself to the counsellee's isituation, (4) perception of counsellee's frame
of reference, and (5) repertoire of leads—the resourcefulness of the counsellor to


--- PAGE 141 ---
CounselllngPfocess 121
vary his methods of approach. Thus in a counselling relationship empathy is the
counsellor's skill or capacity to view the counsellee's subjective world as if it were
his own.
Attcntiveness
Attentiveness is one of the important skills of the counsellor. To understand the
essence of the content and feeling expressed by the counsellee,. the counsellor
should be attentive while listening and observing.
In counselling, listening means more than what is meant in common parlance.
One may listen to a speech by a great orator. A student in a class may listen to a
lecturer. In both these instances the listening may be only nominal. However, in a
counselling siltiatipn mere listening is not enough and more is expected of the
counsellor. He should not limit himself to verbal communication. To secure and
establish a desirable counselling relationship he should also observe the non-verbal
behaviour of the counsellee, such as facial expressions, postures, gestures, inflections
in tone and periods of silence.
By listening and observing the counsellor sustains, extends and deepens his
knowledge of the counsellee. In other words, this helps him establish rapport and
gain insight into the psychological world of the client.
Counselling Relationship
The counselling relationship is the most important aspect of the counselling process.
However, it does not easily lend itself to a very clear definition. It conveys the
essential sense that there is an inter-personal relationship. It is a relationship of
mutual trust and confidence on the part of both the counsellee and the counsellor
and the concern for the well-being of the counsellee on the part of the counsellor.
There is an unconditional acceptance and a sense of commitment on the part of the
counsellor. Thus the counselling relationship encompasses the whole of the
counselling situation and affects its progress at every stage.
COUNSELLING PROCESS
(The term 'counselling process' implies continuous change or changes that take
^ace or rather which should take place ia the client in promoting personality
changes in a desired direction. The kind of change that the counselling process aims
at is briefly^J^ awareness on the part of the client, (2) behavioural change in adesired direction through which the client can achieve his goals, and (3) understanding
his potentialities, limitations and how to udlize them best in achieving his go^I^
^The counselling process, by and iargeriSihB"Saifl5"fEJf all problems and for all
Individuals. However, certain important differences need to be clarified. In vocational
and educational counselling the major emphasis is on collecting factual information
and helping the client understand this information in a proper perspecdv^In such
situadons the emodonal problems, though present, are not the main concern of the
counsellor. In educadonal and vocadonal counselling the decision-making and


--- PAGE 142 ---
122 CounsellliigandGuidance
planning model occupies the counsellor's attention such that he tries to help rational
problem-solving proc^ses, clarify self-concepts, values, etc. In this context
counsel!^ are olten concsned with the t^ropriate choice of educational goals or
careersQlie educational or vocational counselling usually proceeds in a stepwise
manner starting with (1) establishing a relationship, (2) stating the problem, (3)
elaborating and explaining the issues, (4) explcmng the relevant psychological aspects
of the counsellee's background, (S) structuring the nature of the process, (6) collecting

In the counselling of personal problems the psychotherapeutic model assumes a
somewhat different character. In ^is, information and planning in logical terms do
not play that central a role. The model is, by and large, unique for each counselling
situation and this uniqueness emerges partly from the uniqueness of the individual's
attitudes, interests, problems, etc., and also from the uniqueness of the counsellor's
e^riences, skills, etc. The general outline of the counselling model is (I) realizing
that-there is a complaint, problem or symptom (often people do not realize this),
(2) feeling the need for help in resolving the problem, (3) seeking help and
establishing the relationship (client-counsellor relationship), (4) expressing feelings,
clarifying and elaborating them as related to the problem(s), (5) exploring feelings
and personal resources, (6) being aware of the desirable direction of change, (7)
working through feelings and inducing the desirable change by means of
interpretation and reinforcement, (8) developing insights, (9) planning action, and
(10) implementing the action.
The above two models have much in common though they differ significantly
with regard to certain important elements. The former lays stress on the cognitive
aspects while the latter lays stress on the affective aspects.
Steps In tile Counselling Process
Stage I
The first stage is the awareness of need for help. Most individuals go about their
day-to-day lives without mucti awareness ot their situation and they appear to be
none the worse for it. Inwardly they may be experiencing suffering, yet they may
not seek help. Some individu^s experience their problems either because of their
severity or because someone close draws attention to the problems. Such individuals
are potential clients. They seek psychological asristance because of feelings of
distress. They lack the necessary competence and information to deal with them on
their own.
Stage //
The second important stage in coun^Iling consists of thedevelopment of relationship.
This can be viewed as a bridge connecting thSTJOunsellee's persoiiality witft tnat
of the counsellor's, penetrating through the outer defenses. The development of an


--- PAGE 143 ---
CounseJIIngProeess 123
emotionally waim and understanding relationship is the Hrst step in the counselling
relationship. It is characterized by mutual liking, trust and respect The counsellor
should be aware of the defense strategies likely to be exploited by the client
Usually the defense strategies fall under two basic kinds of manipulative devices:
O-Hite client may take a helpless attitude and get the counsellor to do what he
wants him K) do. and (2),.the counsellee may arouse sympathy and attentionand
avoid unpleasant tasks.'^By adopdrig either of these de^ceslfie cnihtsticcessfully
wai^ off the counselling relationship. He prevents it from breaking through his
out^ defenses. If, however, the counsellor succeeds in establishing this bridge then
he can establish optimal rapport which is sustained through the entire counselling
process.
SCa^e III
The third step in counselling is to aid the expression of feelings and clarification
of problems. In psychoanalytic terminology this is similar to 'catharsis'. In a sense,
it is a ventilation of feelings and the client experiences a feeling of relief consequent
to the release of tension. There is an awareness of relief from emotional stress
obtained through the communication of problems. A client may often obtain a
certain amount of courage in trying this technique with other feelings as well. In
this process, i^viously tied up emotions are released and can be tised constructively.
But this process has certain limitations. The client may obtain a false sense of the
resolution of conflict—ventilating his feelings may relieve him of tension and he
may very well mistake it for a state of resolution of tension. "
The expression of feelings not only helps in the release of emotional tensions
but can also help in clarifying problems. It is in this .sense that the expression of
feeling is of momentotis value in the counselling process.
Stage IV
The next stage comprises the exploration of deeper feelings. We have said in the
preceding section that the client may mistake ventilation of feelings for resolution
of feelings. It is necessary that the counsellor should not be ccmtent with a stq)erficial
view of the client's feelings. If therapeutic help is the objective, the counsellor must
try to explore the deeper feelings and conflicting situations which have not only to
be brought to the surface but also satisfactorily, resolved without damaging the
individual's personality. This step, therefore, involves analysis.
Stage V
The preceding stage logically leads to the next stage, comprising the integration
process. A proper appreciation of the feelings and underlying polarities can help
diffuse emotional tension and the counsellor can help the client see each feeling in
its prc^ perspective without either unduly exhibiting fear or withdrawal or showing
lack of concern. This stage, therefore, consists of working in close harmony with
the client with due understanding regard and sympathy for the client's innermost
feelings. In the course of such a process the counsellor is able to synthesize and
integrate counsellee potentialities, needs and aspirations and direct them towards
appropriate goals.

124 Counsellingand Guidance
Stage VI
The next stage, though not spell out very clearly, is concerned with the time
perspective. Clients usually are confused about their time pers^tive. They are not
able to see the present as logically arising from the past or the present affecting the
future. Naturally they appear baffled as they are unable to explain to themselves the
'how' and 'why' of things and usually come to grief.
Stage VII
This stage is one of developing the awareness of the counsellee. A number of coun
sellors and psychotherapists stress the importance of helping the client gain insight
into himself as well as insight into the world around him. This term, 'insight', is
usually used synonymously with awareness. Psychoanalytic therapy, for instance,
aims at providing insight into one's conflicts, repressions and inhibitions and when
once these are seen in their true perspective, they cease to be painful. London
(1964) is not quite in favour of this view, namely, that symptoms disappear with
self-knowledge, that is, when insight or awareness is obtained. He favours the
behavioural approach which stresses the importance of action. However, there is no
gainsaying the fact that the developing of awareness is of prime importance. Ellis
(1962) uses the terms intellectual and emotional insights. An intellectual insight,
that is, a rational understanding, is a prelude or necessary condition for emotional
insight For instance, a person experiences acute fear at the sight of a supposed
snake. When he realizes that the object is not a snake but only a rope (intellectual
insight) he sees the meaninglessness of his fear. In the psychotherapeutic process
the importance of awareness cannot be over-emphasized. There is another sense in
which awareness is used. It can refer to the awareness of goals—the direction in
which the self is to reach out or move forward.
Stage VIII
The last stage in counselling is generally the most crucial one in which the client
is encouraged to make use of the psychotherapeutic or counselling benefits he may
have gained to adjust himself to the world of realities. Therefore this stage is the
actual test to determine the success of counselling. If the client is not able to adapt
himself to his surroundings then we can infer that he has not gained much from
counselling. On the other hand, if the client is able to do so then we know that the
counselling has been successful. This stage marks the termination of counselling.
COUNSELLING INTERACTIONS
It would be helpful to discuss the types of inter-personal relationships that develop
in coimselling interviews so that we are aware of the complexities that may lie
beneath the surface of apparently simple behaviour.
In an interview with Mr. Datar, the counsellor, by systematic questioning, learned
that his choice of teaching was a rational one. But at the outset the counsellor had
assumed that he was going to help the client by assembling comprehensive test


--- PAGE 145 ---
CounsellingProcess 125
information which would enable him (client) make tiic appropriate vocational choice.
Test administration was found unnecessary, in this case, as the client had already
made a rational choice.
The interview between Mr. Singh and his counsellor shows another aspect of the
counsellor's style of functioning in relating himself to his clients. In this interview
the counsellor, unlike in the previous case, attempted to force interpretations and
concepts on the client. Mr. Singh's counsellor gave importance only to the
interpretation of feelings, that is, he was attempting to intellectualize the affective
experiences of the clienL Mr. Singh withdrew from counselling after a few sessions
"b^ause of the approaching public examinations". He appeared at this stage less
anxious but more realistic. The counsellor, however, believed that the client withdrew
prematurely owing perhaps to his dissatisfaction with the outcome of counselling
assistance.
After a few sessions with Mr. Naik a significant piece of vital information was
revealed that the client was dominated by his mother. In the current interview
sessions it was revealed that the client had been, in most of the early sessions, quite
passive and had not been playing his part. This was perhaps done because the
expression of direct affective experiences was not feasible. On gaining the necessaiy
insight the counsellor was able to draw the client's attention to the possible meaning
of his expressions and behaviour.
The counsellor assisting Miss Nair offered her a lead and helped her to express
and freely communicate her problem of not achieving a level appropriate to her
ability in college. The counsellor naturally hypothesized that there must be some
disturbing factor. In this interview the counsellor let tiie client recognize her problem.
The counsellor analyzed and helped her to recognize the reactions she had at
present and to pull together various aspects of her positive feelings. In the process,
she became aware of her negative feelings toward her situation. She realized and
understood tlie complexities of her feelings and her inability to work in accordance
with the demands of her situation.
Tlie hallmark of the therapeutic process is the capaciQ' on the part of the counsellor
to be sensitive to the reactions of his clients as well as to his own reactions to them.
The inter-personal process focuses on the sensitivity the counsellor must strive to
achieve for an intellectual understanding of his functions.
Limiting Counselling Relations
It is feasible for the psychological counsellor to make the counselling relationship
brief and yet induce emotional maturity in the case of people who are not extremely
maladjusted. The psychological counsellor generally tries to maintain brief
relationships with a large number of people rather than intensive relationships with
a few individuals.
Pressures Towards Extended Relationships
However, there are certain pressures on the counsellor to intensify relationships.
Demands for intense counselling relationships may emerge when the counsellor
desires to assist clients achieve their person^ity goals. The deep interest that the


--- PAGE 146 ---
126 Counsdilnsand Guidance
counsellor develops in inter-personal relationships to strengthen clients' feelings of
confidence may lead to intense and extended relationships whether they are
appropriate or not to the particular counselling goals.
Factors Contributing to Control of Relationship
The counsellor must be thorough with the methods of controlling the duration and
intensity of counselling relationships. This is achieved by;
1. Keeping the real problem injbcus—The counsellor tries to make the client
feel at ease in coming to terms with his many fears and anxieties which
have a bearing on the specific problem situation as he experiences it at the
present The counsellor discourages the client from deviations which could
lead him astray. He deals with the personality of the client as it affects his
decision process.
2. Selecting a criticalfacet of the conflict—It is often not easy for the counsellor
to initiate the th^peudc process quickly because sometimes clients approach
the counsellor without being aware of concrete problems. The counsellor in
such circumstances limits the duration of his relationship by focusing attention
on a particular aspect of the client's inner life. The process of centering on
one aspect of the client's motivations is guided by a general orientation
rather than a rigidly applied mode of action.
3. Giving more cognitive emphasis to interactions—^To keep the relationship
limited, it is necessary for the counsellor to avoid developing a vague
conception of the relationship. One way to foster activity is through
summarizing responses at the end of each counselling session, liie counsellor
could also indicate the possible new directions that could be explored in
future sessions.
4. Opening or commencing—The inexperienced counsellor experiences a
problem in starting the counselling and this initial stage largely determines
the nature of the relationship that develops in the future.
The counsellor has to be alert about the therapeutic orientation of his relationship
with the client while handling the beginning of a counselling session. The counsellor
at the beginning attempts to understand the communications of his client. Frequently,
with a large number of individuals who are unable to arrive at a definite therapeutic
orientation, the counsellor may have to extend the 'greeting' phase. If the counsellor
remains silent the client may respond by making some perfunctory statements.
However, if the client responds by remaining silent, the counsellor tries to understand
the meaning of his (client's) silence and communicates the idea that part of the
counselling task involves the client's acceptance of the initiative in the
communication process, especially at the beginning of the interviews.
The counsellor sometimes believes that feelings dealt with towards the end of
the sessions are important when the client is relatively free of the tensions that may
have been present at the commencement

Endings, Intemiptlons and FolIow«up
There are certain characteristics which distinguish counselling from other forms of
psychotherapy. They are concerned with issues, such as problems of ending,
iniemiption and follow-up. The client may either interrupt or end the counselling
relationship ai soon as he or she feels well enough. The 'client's choice of timing'
to interrupt or end counselling depends on the interaction of factors, such as the
magnitude of his conflict, the potentialities for both immediate and long-time relief
offered by the resolution of a problem situation, the depth and accuracy of the
counsellor's understanding of the conflicts and the rapport which the counsellor
establishes with the client The lack of disclosure on the part of the client is an
inevitable characteristic of counselling relationships.
Interruptions in the counselling process are frequent. Some clients leave, saying
they will come back within a specified period of dme and some decide to discontinue
the relationship before reaching their goal. In many cases, the counsellor assumes
that the correct follow-up response is to be patient and to waiL
Preparing for Endilng
Counsellors, clients and psychotherapists alike, feel that the termination of counselling
is a difficult problem. In psychological counselling forced endings are frequent. A
relatively mature client understands that within a limited lime counselling has to
progress rapidly. Some clients are fearful about the termination of the counselling
sessions. In such circumstances the counsellor must be sensitive to the client's
reactions to separation. In any ending, whether forced or otherwise, the counsellor
must have a full understanding of the client's problems and needs so as to be able
to meet them effectively.
VARIABLES AFFECTING THE COUNSELLING PROCESS
Counsellor Variables
/. General Characteristics of Counsellors
The importance of the counsellor's attitudes to counselling outcomes cannot be
overemphasized. In order to identify the counsellor characteristics which are of
concern, investigators employed four approaches:
Speculation—^The question as to what the characteristics of an effective counsellor
are led to much speculadon. The Nadonal Vocadonal Guidance Associadon (1949)
listed such characterisdcs as interest in people, padence, sensitiveness, emotional
stabili^ and objectivity as being important for good counselling. Hamrin and Paulsen
(1950) listed the following characteristics: understanding, sympathetic attitude,
friendliness, sense of humour, stability, patience, objectivity, sincerity, tact, fairness,
tolerance, nearness, calmness, broadmindedness, kindliness, pleasantness, social
intelligence and poise. Mowrer (1951) believes that personal maturity is the most
important desirable characteristic for counsellors to progress. According to the
Associadon for Counsellor Education and Supervision, the counsellor should possess
six basic qualities: belief in each individual, commitment to individual human


--- PAGE 148 ---
1/g Counsellingand Cutdan^
values, alertness to the world, open-mindedness, understanding of self and
professional commitment. Parker (1966) holds that a counsellor should possess
such characterisdcs as sensitivity to others, ability to analyze objectively an
individual's strengths and weaknesses, awareness of the nature and extent of
individual differences and ability to identify learning difficulties.
Identifying effective and ineffective groups—Stefflre, King and Leafgren (1962)
fijund significant differences between the effective and ineffective counsellor samples
on the four dimensions studied, namely, academic promise, interests and values,
personality charactefist'cs and self-concepL The effective group obtained high scores
on academic aptitude and performance and scored higher on Social Welfare Scales
of Strong Vocational Interest Blank and Deference and Order Scores on Edwards
Personal Preference Schedule, than did the ineffective group.
Hypothesized characteristics—This approach is used to find out whether certain
characteristics that have been hypothesized as necessary for counselling are present
and functioning. Bandura 0956) tested the hypotheses that competent
psychother^ists are (I) less anxious than those judged to be less competent and (2)
possess greater insight into the nature of their own anxieties than do less competent
therapists. He concluded that "the presence of anxie^ in the therapist, whether
recognized or not, affects his ability to do successful psychotherapy and insight into
his anxieties alone is not sufficienL"'®
Correlational analysis—^The fourth r^roach consists in exploring the relationship
between counsellor variables and some criterion to measure the effectiveness derived
&om conelational analysis. Studies conducted by Johnson and her associates (1967)
indicated the following conclusions:
1. EffecUve male counsellor trainees were confident, friendly, affable, likable
and generally were satisfied with themselves and their surroundings.
2. Effective female counsellor candidates were outgoing, efficient and confident
They appeared to be assertive and were more person-oriented than object-
oriented
3. Effective male and female counsellor trainees showed similarities between
themselves and were more like each other than like their counterparts from
the less effective group.
The characteristics of counsellors are assessed, employing the self-report and
rating techniques. Four types of criteria are frequently employed, namely, supervisor
ratings, counsellor's peer ratings, client ratings and Q-techniques, to measure the
effectiveness of the counsellors.
In short, the effective counsellor was found to exhibit qualities such as tolerance,
maturity, understanding and an ability to maintain an appropriate emotional distance
from the counsellee. Variables, such as age, experience and sex also, to a certain
extent, affect the counselling process.
Age—Clients perceive their counsellors in different ways depending on the
coimsellor's age. If the counsellor is younger than the client, the latter will have

Experience—High correlations were obtained between experience and age. It
was found that counsellors improve with experience. The counsellors who work in

the counsellor may be important depending on the ease or difficult' with which
they can discuss their problems with male and female counsellors.
//. Personality Characteristics of die Counsellors
Several studies have attempted to determine the personality characteristics of
counsellors which are basic to effective counselling. Studies conducted by Tuma
and Gustad (1957) reveal that close similarities in the personalities of clients and
counsellors result in greater client learning. Mendelsohn and Geller (1965) obtained
a curvilinear relationship between client attitudes towards counselling and client-
counsellor personality similarity. This difference between the findings may be
attributed to the differences between the criteria employed by the two studies.
Weitz (1957), Snyder and Snyder (1961) and Tyler (1961) have suggested the
following traits of successful counsellors;
Interested in helping people—Some investigators have reported that a 'social
service need' is necessary for success and satisfection with a counselling job. Other
investigators like Steffire, King and Leafgren (1962), Mills, Chestnut and Hartzell
(1966) and Demos and Zuwaylif'(1966) found that counsellors liked people and are
interested in helping. This attitude makes the client feel comfortable in their presence.
Perceptual sensitivity—-Tixe counsellor should perceive and understand the
thoughts and feelings of the client and should be sensitive to the clues given by
him/her.
Personal adjustment—It is natural for counsellors, as any other individuals, to
have problems of adjustment Snyder (1961) stated that they should be 'normally
adjusted' but not necessarily 'perfectly adjusted'. The counsellor should be able to
cope with his problems in a constructive manner and should not attempt to try and
solve the problems of clients when he himself is facing difficulties.
Personal security—"Wdtz (1957) suggested that feelings of personal security is
another important factor. The counsellor may feel secure in his counselling role and
fed insecure in certain areas outside counselling. This indicates that the way he
conducts himself in a counselling situation is important and not the way he behaves
in ail life situations.
Genuineness—^The counsellor should establish a genuine relationship with his
clients by which they can achieve their counselling goals. Rogers (1958a) suggests
that the counsellor should be "a real person" to his clients.

COUNSELLOR'S SKILLS
Rapport, empathy and attentiveness are the three skUIs which can either facilitate
or inhibit the counselling process. These skills are closely related to acceptance and
understanding.
Rapport—Shertzer and Stone (1968) define report as an essential condition for
a comfortable and unconditional relationship between the counsellor and counsetlee.
Rapport means interest, responsiveness and sensitive emotional involvement.
Counsellors use rapport as a technique in the initial stage of the interview to put
the counsellee at ease. Through rapport the counsellor understands and communicates
with the client from the commencement to the end of the interview.
Taking the counsellee's needs, moods and conflicts into consideration the
counsellor establishes rapport. To help him discuss his feelings f^ly the counsellor
tries to be friendly and attentive. For the establishment of good rapport there is
need for coimsellor skills and abilities, such as versatility, flexibility and reliability.
Empathy—Empathy means 'feeling into* and has a significant role in the
counselling situation. Empathy is referred to as the apprehension rather than the
mere comprehension of the emotions of another person without feeling completely
what he feels. It is "the ability to feel and describe the thoughts and feelings of
others" (Dymond, 1949). She further describes empathy as "the imaginative
transposing of oneself into the thinking, feeling and acting of another and so
structuring the world as he does".
Rogers (1962) lays emphasis on transposition rather than empathy.
PORTRAIT OF AN EHECTIVE COUNSULOR
The three aspects by which an effective counsellor can be distinguished hum an
ineffective one are experience, type of relationship established and non-intellective
factors.
Experience—^Fiedler's (1950,1951) studies reveal that counsellors who are well
trained agree with each other about their concept of an ideal therapeutic relationship.
According to Rogers (1962) also, more experienced counsellors o^er more
congruence and empathy and they are more successful in communicating with their
clients.
Type of counselling relationship—The ability to communicate and understand
their clients, maintain an appropriate emotional distance and divest themselves of
status concerns in regard to their clients characteri^ efficient counsellors (Redler,
1950,1951).
Non-intellective fiictors—Tht effective counsellor exhibits tolerance for ambigui^,
understanding (of the client), maturity, and ability to establish good social
relationships with clients and non-clients. Wicas and h^an (1966) found that
'high rated' counsellors were anxious, sensitive to the expectations of others and
society, patient and non-aggressive in inter-personal relationships and showed
appropriate self-control.

COUNSELUE FACTORS
The counselling outcomes can also be affected by counsellee characteristics, such
as counsellee expectations and readiness to communicate and to respond. The
involvement of the counsellee and his readiness to change are related to his
improvement (Cartwright and Leraer, 1963). Counsellee likability was found to be
related to success in therapy (Stoler, 1963). Introverted counsellees with greater
tolerance for ambiguiQr have greater promise of better results (Conrad, 1954). The
degree of dependency expressed by clients was found to be related to the degree
of support provided by counsellors (Schuldt, 1966).
The congruence between the counsellor and counsellee was found to have a
curvilinear relationship to "favourable outcomes of therapy" (Gerler, 1958).
Counsellee-counsellor compatibility was reported to have a positive correlation of
0.45 with counselling outcomes. Sapoldcy (1965) concludes that the "effect on
outcome of treatmwil appeared to have occurred through the differential effect the
compatibility variable had on the way the therapist was perceived by the patient".
Heller, Myers and Kline (1963) tested five hypotheses, namely, that (1) dominant
client behaviour will evoke dqwndent interviewer behaviour, (2) dependent client
behaviour will evoke dominant interviewer behaviour; (3) hostile client behaviourwill evoke hostile interviewer behaviour, (4) friendly client behaviour will evoke
frie^ly interviewer behaviour and (5) hostile client behaviour will evoke interviewer
anxie^r. The first four hypotheses were supported by the data obtained.
