INTRODUCnON
In counseUing, infonnation regarding the personality assets and liabilities of the
counsellees is a helpful point of departure. In the preliminary interview the counsellor
can secure some information that would help in understanding the counsellee's
problems. In the course of the counseUing sessions the counsellor may feel the need
for objective information. At this stage the need for using psychological tests may
be indicated. Often, along with the test data, information from non-test data, such
as case-study, cumulative records and such other information may be used for
diagnostic purposes. Tests can also be used to assess the counsellee's initial
psychological status such that the progress made during the counseUing sessionscan be evaluated.
The relation between the use of tests and psychological counselling has been far
from new, controversial or cordial. Everyone is chary of tests which are regarded
^ 'an invasion of privacy' of the individual. Testing, some counsellors hold, is
inconsistent wth the non-judgemental and non-threatening atmosphere consideredbaste to positive counselUng. Tests, according to some, create an elitist attitude and
do not r^y add to what is already known about the counsellee.
Notwithstanding the very critical attitude of some counsellors, major approachesto counselUng consider tests to serve a very useful purpose. The trait-and-factor
approach places a lot of faith in psychological tests. We shaU consider the use of
psycholo^cal tests in counseUing as diagnostic aids. We shall also discuss the non-t^t techniques as providing information useful in the understanding and diagnosis
of counsellees* problems.
The m^ical model of counselling assumes that adjustment problems are
'^presentations of underlying factors deep in the psychodynamic system.^ e belief is that such a model would not only be representative but also usefulm providing orientation. The postulates of the medical model are hotly contested
by other counsellors who prefer to use the behavioural model which does not
burden itself wiUi a consideration of the underlying depth factors. Irrespective of
the type of model one may have in mind, reliable devices are much in demand for
psychodiagnosis. The counseUor often looks upon the psychological tests as hisbasic tools in the therapeutic process. The major use psychological tests are put to


--- PAGE 155 ---
P^chological Testing andDiagnosis 135
is in diagnosis. While the importance of tests in diagnosis cannot be underestimated,
it is an equally important fact that psychological tests are useful in the evaluation
of counselling outcomes. Apart from diagnostic and evaluative uses, psychological
tests are also used in other situations involving prediction and the acquisition of
information.
A psychological test is a tool'developed for a specific purpose to be used with
a defined population. Great care is taken in establishing its psychometric properties.
Thus, a psychological test is for all practical purposes considered as an objective
test providing dependable information. This claim is hotly contested and we shall
return to it at a later stage. Psychological tests are based on the theory that they are
comparable to objective observations and that they sample the defined psychological
'trait-universe' from a wide range of respondent behaviour. Psychological tests can
also be used in providing self-knowledge. Most self-administering tests fall under
this category. Such tests purport to provide an unbiased objective understanding of
oneself.
The second use of psychological tests is for screening. This is a very useful
device and helps in conserving lime and energy. The obvious purpose of such tests
is to help determine whether individuals have any problem and, therefore, require
assistance. Naturally such an aid lightens the burden of the counsellors to a great
deal in so far as they identify those clients who require assistance. Screening tests
are usually not very elaborate. They are usually meant to provide tentative information
and it is undesirable for the counsellor to have complete faith on such interim
findings. Often individuals are not aware of their own situation (problems). A
screening device, therefore, is of very great value. Psychological tests are also used
as aids in the prediction of the future success of the testee. In such situations
usually more than one test is combined on the basis of certain objective criteria.
Most aptitude tests are used as predictor tests.
The most important clinical use of psychological tests is in the field of
psychodiagnosis. Several diagnostic personality tests like the Minnesota Multiphasic
Personality Inventory (MMPI) and ability tests like the Weschler Adult Intelligence
Scale (WAIS) are extensively used. In addition, projective tests are used with the
speciHc intSntion of diagnosis.
An important use of the psychological tests is to assist the counsellor in the
process of therapy. This corresponds to the practice of obtaining information from
clinical tests in the medical situation to assess the progress of therapy. Psychological
tests are also used in evaluating counselling outcomes. While other evaluative
criteria can also be used, the psychological evaluation perhaps can best.be done by
employing standard psychological tests.
UMITATIONS OF THE USE OF PSYCHOLOGICAL TESTS
1. Most psychological tests are developed for use with specific populations
and for definite purposes. The use of such tests with other subjects and for
other purposes appears to be a highly questionable practice.
2. Psychological tests usually yield scores that have to be interpreted in terms


--- PAGE 156 ---
jjg Comselllnssnd Guldants
of certain norms. Applying the norms derived from one population to subjectsdrawn from another population is not a tenable pracUce.
3. It is weU known that no single measure can ever be fool-proof. It is. theretore,suggested that instead of using a single test, it is desirable to combme anumber of such tests to yield a composite score which would be more
dependable than the information obtained through a single test While this
is apparently an attractive proposition it should not be forgotten that thereare serious problems in combining test scores that require very sophisucatedstatistical as well as psychometric training.
TYPES OF FSYCHOLOaCAL TESTS
Psychological tests broadly fall under three categories, namely, personality; ability
and aptitude; and attitudes and interests. There is another category of tests that is
widely used and popular in the field of education. These tests are scholastic
achievement tests. Basically, achievement tests are not psychological tests but
psychological principles are used in their construction, validation and standardization.
In the field of counselling there may be a situation indicating the need for using one
or another type of psycholopcal test. Also, the use of psychological tests is contra-
indicated in specific situations. The counsellor has, th^fore, the professional and
ethical responsibility to choose the appropriate psychological tesL
There are individuals who have us^ some tests and not found them reliable and
they generalize from this experience and make universal statements concerning the
general unreliability of ptychological tests. There are others who have found a test
useful in some situations and they believe that the test can be useful in other
situations as well. It is one of the basic assumptions of psychologists that
psychological tests are specific to the situation for which they are designed and
us^ul with the specified population with whom they are yalidat^ and standardized.
Individuals who fail to appreciate this genially make either sweeping positive or
negative statements concerning the tests.
The second misconception is regarding the infallibility of tests. Tliis again is
unfortunate because in the order, of things there can be nothing which can be
considered perfect or infallible. Test users have to guard themselves against possible
over-reaction or enthusiasm which could blind them to certain realities. Tests do
fail and they fail for a variety of reasons. They M firstly because of the limitations
of the test itself, secondly owing to the testee and his altitudes, thirdly owing to the
tester or the test administrator and lastly owing to the test situation.
Psychologic^ tests are objective devices designed and developed with great care
on the basis of sound psychometric principles. While this is gennally true, not all
tests made available commercially, follow this rigorous procedure and, therefore,
cannot be taken at face value. The test user has a great responsibility in the choice
of the test appropriate to the given situation. The test user depends largely on the
norms report^ by the test constructor. He has to examine the available norms
before he decides whether or not to use the test A few psychological tests have
been developed for use in clinical situations.


--- PAGE 157 ---
P^fcholosieal TestingandDU^gnosIs 137
There is some controversy over the statistical or clinical interpretation of tests.
The projective tests, for example, do not lend themselves to actuarial use. They are
meant to be used idcographically. In the case of personality tests there are three
basic categories of tests, namely, check lists, omnibus personality inventories
(multidimensional tests) and factored tests. Check lists cannot be compared with
the factored tests with regard to the sophistication of techniques of test development
The Mooney F^blem Check List or the problem check lists developed by several
psychologists or researchers are meant to provide a preliminary evaluation. They
are meant as screening devices and nothing more. Since they are check lists which
require the testee to indicate a particular problem the latter may not be forthcoming.
Thus the testee can withhold information because of the transparency of the test.
Personality tests of the questionnaire kind can be faked by the testee. But it is
always assumed that the testee is giving a candid response. Yet the question whether
the various tests actually measure what they purport to do remains a crucial issue.
The scoring system also allows for variations and errors. The factored tests, on the
other hand, claim to have overcome these two possible limitations of the tests.
Questionnaires, inventories and the like cannot exhaust the repertoire of the individual
response system. One often feels the limitation of answering within a 'straight-
jacket' response category. For example, to the question, "Do you feel shy?" the
three response categories "Yes", "No" or"?" do not exhaust other possibilities. The
projective tests claim two specific advantages over the personality questionnaires
or inventories. They provide unlimited scope for response and they are not
transparent. But the advantages thus secured by the projecdve tests are not without
drawbacks. They make the problems of scoring and interpretation insuperable, in
addition to introducing an element of subjectivism which is anathema to the normative
scientist.
FACTORS AFFECTING PSYCHOLOGICAL TEST RESULTS
The testce-tester attitude fundamentally affects test results. There could be two
categories of tcstees: the naive and the experienced. Some individuals have taken
so many tests during their life time that they understand the 'testee responsibility*.
They need little assistance from the tester for they (testees) understand the objectives.
Most testees are naive and strangers to the test situation. They require much help
from the counsellor. They may have a number of apprehensions that would have
to be dispelled. A testee may have certain attitudes or objectives, expressed or
otherwise, regarding test taking. If the testee's goal is self-understanding or self-
knowledge he will be candid and hot be^disposed to distort his responses. If his
objective is to make a favourable impression, or at least not an unfavourable one,
he may respond keeping the social desirability value in mind. He may fake or
distort his responses.
Verbal psj^hological tests ci^te another problem of comprehension for the
testee. Most psychological t^ts are 'culture loaded' and the expressions and idiom
may be quite unfamiliar. Fdr 'example, the apparently simple question, "Are you
often in the blues?" poses some difficulty to a testee with limited linguistic skills


--- PAGE 158 ---
138 Counselllngand Guidance
of comprehension. An item like, "Do you 'gauffaw' a lot?" is often incomprehensible
to a testee. Here it is not a question of limited vocabulary of the testee. Standard
English dictionaries do not list this word for it is not an English word. Naturally
some testees would be at a loss. Furthermore, some tests require efficiency of
performance while others are concerned with ability. Usually speed tests place
certain categories of subjects at a disadvantage.
For test administration and-usage.of tests the role of the tester is fundamental.
Several conditions are prescribed by psychologists for the proper use of tests. The
first responsibili^ of the tester is thk he should know the tests thoroughly. The
tester must be very clear in his mind with regard to the objective of testing—why
he-wants to use the test. Once this is determined he can choose appropriately from
an array of available tests. In this context he is like a medical practitioner who
chooses one particular drug rather than another because he knows what the two
drugs contain, how they act and what particular action he desires. The counsellor
chooses one test in preference to another on the basis of his knowledge of the tests
concemed and his objectives, that is, what he expects liom the tesL The choice of
a test is important, but the more important issue is of interpretation. A counsellor
is dealing with sensitive human beings. Their self-images should not be impaired.
At the same time he cannot give a wrong impression in order to preserve the self-
image of the individual. For instance, a testee believes that he has an aptitude for
a particular learning. The counsellor obtains results that belie this fond assumption.
What the counsellor should do in this situation concerns the basic professional and
ethical issues. Should he tell the truth and hurt the client? Or should he let the client
nurture his false belief complacently?
No test is infallible. The counsellor knows this important truth more than any
one else. Th^fore, he must use the test to supplement and complement other
available informadon. Perhaps he can use several tests. This brings up the issue of
combining test data. For instance, a pupil secures the grades B* in science, C in
humanities, B in languages, and so on. How should this be interpreted? Could it be
assumed that the pupil is above average, or average, or below average? There is the
question of a ftame of referwice which refers to the 'norms' appropriate to the
testee. A lest yields a numerical score, usually called the raw score, which is not
meaningful in itself. How should the counsellor interpret this raw score? Obviously
he has to interpret it in terms of a frame of reference or 'norms' applicable to the
testee. However exhaustive the i.orms may be, it cannot be assumed that an
appropriate frame of reference is available.
A counsellor should always voify the test results. This, we know, is a common
and simple scientific rigour. But verify how and with what? Physical measures can
be verified ad infmitum granting the padence of the verifier. The human individual
is not just a physical endty. Readministradon of the tests does not give the same
results because of a modification of the individual's experience during the intervening
time as a result of his taking the tests or owing to some other factors that may have
affected him. In vocational selection, and to some extent in xademic situations,
tests are used for predicting future performance. Most aptitude tests fall under this
category. If a test result can be verified in terms of its predicted value, we have a
measure of verifiability. But this is not immediately available.


--- PAGE 159 ---
P^chologlcal TestingandDiagnosis 139
Another important counsellor function in test administration is counsellor
neutrality which is once again a very iiksome matter. For instance, a subject performs
well in a given test and the counsellor may say, "you have done well", or when a
client fares poorly the counsellor may say to the client, "you have done poorly".
Either of these statements does not indicate counsellor neutrality. An experienced
counsellor could perhaps say that the client's performance is in the range of the top
quartile or is in the range of the lower quartile and so on. Among the other things
that the counsellor has to take care of is the meaningfulness of test interpretation.
What we have said" in the preceding lines is an example in point. The testee may
not imderstand expressions such as top quartile and lower quartile. An inteip'etation
should be clear and understandable to the testee.
Test performance can be considerably affected by the test situation. Certain
aspects of this can be controlled while certain others are beyond control. The basic
requirements of objective testing are (1) the testee must be physically comfortable,
(2) he should be appropriately motivated and (3) he should be willing to cooperate.
The tester on his part is expected to be patient, friendly, warm and understanding.
TEST USE IN COUNSaUNG SITUATIONS
Tests are used in counselling for several purposes, the foremost being diagnosis.
There are a munber of psychological tests avowedly designed for diagnostic use.
Some tests are used as self-evaluative devices. Many self-administering tests like
the Allport Vemon-Lindzey Study of Values fall under this category. Tests are also
designed for self-discovery and understanding, for example, the Strong Vocational
Interest Blank (1943).
A number of clinicians have warned against many pitfalls in test usage. Brammer
and Shostrom (1968) list the following cautions in the use of tests in diagnosis:
1. Not U) overstretch when the test data are incomplete and inaccurate.
2. Not to overemphasize the test results to the neglect of present attitudes and
current behaviour of the client
3. Not to administer psychological tests too quickly to facilitate diagnosis
without paying attention to other available information.
4. Not to lose sight of the counsellee's total personality and become preoccupied
with morbidity rath^ than healthy behaviour.
5. Not to assume a judgemental attitude toward the client.^
Counselling approaches differ significantly with regard to their attitudes to test
usage. Rogers (1951) stands at one extreme with his rejection of using tests in
counselling. He believes that tests can act like blinkers. The counsellor may become
a prisoner of his own test data and refuse to see beyond it. Rogers, therefore, is
averse to the use of tests. Williamson's (1950) position is perhaps at the other
extre^ne. In keeping with the Minnesota tradition, Williamson stresses that tests are
2®Lawrence M., Brammer and Everett L. Shostrom. Therapeutic Psychology, Englewood
Cliffs, NJ., ftentice-Hall, 1960, pp. 135—137.


--- PAGE 160 ---
140 Counselllnssnd Guidance
necessary aids in counselling. He believes that the clients have to be given objective
information concerning their personality, abili^, aptitudes, attitudes and interests.
The counsellor has to administer the appropriate tests and diagnose the problem on
the basis of test data. Thome (1950), the leading figure of the eclectic school, takes
a middle-of-the-road point of view. The authoritarian counsellors, namely,
psychoanalysts, do not believe in the utility of tests but do not object to using
projective tests. Wolpe and his associates (1958) as well as the behaviour therapists
are for the limited use of tests. The existential counsellors also follow a similar
approach.
Certain harmful consequences of tests have been cited. Ebel (1963) suggests that
test data may lead to erroneous opinions, such as that of a child being superior,
mediocre or inferior which can have an indelible effect on the child and do irreparable
harm to his self-esteem and motivation. Test scores, if not carefully used, can lead
to a narrow conception of abili^ and stultify the potential growth of the individual.
The tests can place the testers in a position of determining the destinies of human
beings. They (tests) may lead to an impersonal, inflexible, mechanistic attitude
towards human beings and their performance.
In recent times, test use has become so commonplace that clients are not satisfied
if they are not administered at least a few tests. Sometimes they even ask for
specific tests to be administered to them. This opens a new problem, namely, client
p^cipation in test selection. Should the counsellor choose the tests in consultationwith the counsellee or should he act independently? Those antagonistic to this view
argue that just as a physician does not consult his client as to what drug he should
prescribe, the counsellor should choose the test on the basis of his clinical judgement
of its utility. They also point to the important fact that the client is not as informed
as the counsellor to wisely and meaningfully choose the appropripie test. On the
other hand, the idea that the client should be consulted implies , that he knows
something, if not as much, of the test usage as the counsellor. The protagonists of
this view argue that counselling, being dirwted towards the self-understanding of
the client, should ensure maximum involvement of the client in the counselling
process. Consultation in test selection would thus be a fruitful avenue for client
involvement. Even if the clients do not have much significant knowledge about thetests nothing is lost in consulting them. This approach promotes the major goal of
counselling, namely, self-direction and self-dependence.
There are other practical problems which may perhaps be of interest here. It ts
argued that some clients could be sensitive to the extent that when a test is Introduced,
they may not return for further interviews. Indecisiveness on the part of the client,
resistance to the use of tests and the like could be valuable aids in counselling
which no counsellor would fail to make use of. By letting the clients know the
purpose of testing and explaining to them the goils of test administration they
could be emotionally prepared to take the tests. The client's reactions and suggesti^s
may not only help choose a more suitable test but also provide other information
that could be used to advantage in counselling.
Goldman (1961) cites some practical arguments against the client's participationin the selection of test. According to him:


--- PAGE 161 ---

1. Client participation in test selection is really "much ado about nothing". It
makes little difference what process is used (client participation or no
participation) so long as the most appropriate tests are administered.
2. The client is usually too emotionally involved with his problem to make
objective decisions regarding the choice of appropffiate tests. Seeman (1948)
found that college students who selected tests themselves did not significantly
differ from those who did not choose tests themselves. The findings of
Gustad and Tuma (1957) also support Secman's findings.
TEST INTERFRETATION IN COUNSELLING
After a test is chosen and administered, the next vital step is the interpretation of
test results. No client is content or satisfied unless he is given a sort of 'low down*
regarding his performance. Several research studies indicate that the contextual
factors in the interpretation of test data are of great significance. The counsellor
may discuss the test results individually or in groups. Several findings suggest that
the interpretation of test results in groups is sometimes more effective. Similarly,
the discussion of test results individually is effective in certain other situations.
Testees who received no test interpretation (control subjects or group) did not show
any improvement in their understanding or behaviour. In the case of educational
tests, such as scholastic or academic achievement, and vocational tests, such as
vocational inventories, interest tests and aptitude batteries, interpretadon in groups
was found to be more effective. In the case of personality tests; such as self^concept
and ideal self-perception, interpretation in a group situation was not found to be as
efiective ^ individual interpretation.
Goldman (1961) idendfies four dimensions of test interpretadon:
1. Descripdve—^It essendally provides, as the term indicates, descripdve
informadon. How the subject Compares with oth^, his likes and dislikes,
whether he is sociable or likes to be left alone, and so on, are descripdve
of human nauire and largely depend on the construct, content and concurrent
validities of the tests administered.
2. Genetic—^The test data are interpreted in order to show the 'how' and 'why'
of the subject's behaviour or experience. In short, they show how he came
to be what he is. In this type of interpretadon, the counsellor generally uses
the ex postfacto approach. He employs, in other words, predictive validities
for indicating what happened in the past, that is, indications as to what
happened previously are inferred from the present scores. To illustrate this
from the medical field we may cite the example of a physician looking at
an ECG and inferring from it that the subject has sufiered a heart attack in
the past
3. Predictive—In this kind of interpretation the counsellor Cries to explain what
is likely to happen in the future on the basis of the present test scores. For
example, a low scholastic aptitude test score may indicate that the student
may not bu able to fare creditably at college. In this form of interpretation
too predictive validity is used.


--- PAGE 162 ---
142 Counsellingand Guidance
4. Evaluative—In the previous three QTpes of interpretations the counsellor
does not try to go beyond the test data. He merely interprets them as they
are: descriptively, genetically or postdictively, that is, to infer about the
past In evaluative interpretation the counsellor has to go beyond the test
data. He may have to make a specific suggestion, recommendation or give
professional advice. Th^fore, this type of interpretation differs from the
rest It is not based on any particular ^pe of validity but it concerns the
terms on the basis of which the counsellor makes his recommendation. As
far as educational and vocational areas are concerned one of the best
approaches is to use expectancy tables. These may be available ready-made
or the counsellor may construct them. An expectancy table is a table of
norms. It is based on empirical information. For example, suppose the subjects
have taken test X. The distnbution of the subjects' achievements in terms
of percentages or grades may be shown corresponding to the obtained test
scores. From such a table, it would be easy to read off the performance of
a subject whose test score was in the range of 31 to 40 or 51 to 60, and so
on. In test development this particular technique was used by Strong Jr. in
developing his Strong Vocational Interest Blank (SVIB). He obtained the
interest patterns of specific occupational groups—doctors, engineers,
accountants, lawyers, teachers and so on. Next he compiled the interests of
the 'men in general' group. He then compared the specific interest patterns
of the two groups. It is easy to see whether a given subject falls within the
specific occupational group or within the men in general group or somewhere
in between. If the subject's scores compare favourably with those of the
specific occupational group it can be inferred that the subject has an interest
pattern that is most akin to the particular occupational group. It is, therefore,
reasonable to conclude that the subject will be successful in the occupation
concerned. Thus expectancy tables can be very valuable in providing
evaluative interpretation.
Bym (1968) has recommended a number of desirable approaches in test
interpretation in his paper The Test Interpretation—Planning Interview. He suggests
that the counsellor would do well to:
1. Have confidence in the client's planning ability, even if he has shown little
of it. The counsellor could say, "What other infoimation do you need about
yourself before you decide?" instead of saying. "May be we could see what
the results of this test, X, would be".
2 Relate the client's immediate or proximate ideas and actions to his remote,
distant or future plans. The counsellor would do well not to separate the
present from the future and treat them independenUy. For in the client's life,
the present and future would form a single continuum, dynamically and
causdly related to each other. The counsellor could say. "What can you do
this year in school to prepare for entering college in the coming year?"instead of, "Your marks are not so good now but you have good aptitude
for college work".
3 Make alternative plans look plausible and as far as possible comparable.


--- PAGE 163 ---
Psycholo^ealTestingandDlagnosIs 143
The counsellor could say, "If your plan does not happen to woik out what
else could you do?" and not, "If you fail in engineering yoii could perhaps
take to drafting".
4. Encourage the client to make his own plans rather than agree to the
counsellor's. The counsellor could say, "How do you plan to go about doing
this?" and not, "It appears to me that you have got to do this".
5. Try to introduce new educational and vocational avenues and not close
them to the student Ibe counsellor could say, "There are ten thousand jobs
besides medicine or engineering, perhaps you could qualify for many of
them" instead of, "You won't be able to enter medicine or engineering with
your low marks".
6. Relate the test data to the other experiences of the clioit The counsellor
should, never discuss test data in abstraction. He could say, "How does this
fit in with your experiences?"instead of, "Your interests look very much
like this".
7. Reflect on a client's rejection of low test scores and not just write them off
as low p^ormance. The counsellor could say, "You don't think this is your
real ability? What other clues do you have?" instead of 'Tests are not fool
proof. There could be an error".
8. Involve clients in test interpretation. Do not just read out the results. The
counsellor could say, "What did you think of the tests? How do you suppose
you did?" instead of, "On this lest your score is—".
9. Explain the purpose of the test in the manner he can understand, not in
counsellor's or psychologist's jargon. The counsellor could say, "This test
helps you to compare yourself with high school students of atove average
ability" and not, "This is test "X'. This measures numerical ability".
10. Use test results in relation to all other available information. The test data
are not goals in themselves. The counsellor could say, "Now that you have
this test information, add everything else you know about yourself instead
of, "According to this test score you could do well in mechanical work".
11. Use test results for planning for the client and not just for counsellor's
diagnosis (client-centered not counsellor-centered approach). The counsellor
could say, "This test helps you compare yourself with other students in the
ability to leam" instead of, "This test score confirms my hypothesis/hunch
that you can succeed in college".
12. Relate test data to school record (cumulative record) and do not look only
at the test results. The counsellor could say, "With your ability you should
be able to secure a first class or a high second class with average, effort",
instead of, "Your marks have not been good but you have high aptitude for
collegiate work".
13. Refresh the counsellee's memory. Do not discuss the test results by
themselves in a cold manner. The counsellor could say, 'Remember the test
you vooki about the things you liked best and liked least?" instead of, "On
Kuder you were high on persuasive and mechanical and low on anistic'\
14. Explain the test results in a matter-of-fact fashion. Do not introduce statistical
description. The counsellor could say, "This score is high, this one is low

and this one is average for engineering students. Your performance Is about
this" instead of. "You fall within the third quartile, the probability of highperformance falls within the fiducial limits".
15. Explain poor test performance or unpleasant information honestly and
meaningfully- The counsellor could say, "Your test scor^
are within the range of-successful collegiate students, but wlow average"
instead of. "Only 20% of coUegiate students have less ability than you".
16. Let the clients see their test profiles for themselves. Do not try to read them

You study them. I have another copy here. I shall foUow as you read",

17. Make, the client summarize what h^she has learned liom the profiles. Do
not do all the organizing for him. The counsellor could say, for example,
"How would you summarize your interests as you see them from your test
scores" instead of, "Your interests are high in this, low in this, lowest in
this", and so on.
18. Let test interpretation be the beginning of planning and not the end. The
counsellor could say, "With this test information you should now study the
occupations" instead of saying, "Well, that is what the tests show...occupation
appears to suit you."^'
NON-TEST CLIENT APPRAISAL TECHNIQUES
lit the preceding section dealing with the use of psychological tests we observed
more than once that tests are not infallible. They are not goals in themselves and
they should be used to supplement other information that is available concerning
the client
Some of the more important devices used in counselling under the non-test
category are: (1) autobiography, (2) anecdotal records, (3) rating scales, (4) diaries,
(5) case study, (6) cumulative records, and so on.
Autobiography
An autobiography is an introspective report of one's own experiences. The
psychological tests, it is often pointed out, cannot provide adequate information for
observations could be introduced artificially within the test situation. Protagonistsof autobiographies claim that they are able to overcome the above limitation of
psychological teste Md provide an authendc insight into their own personalities.
One of the other important merits of the autobiography is its vast scope
Autobiographies are generally considered to fall iiito two categories namelyunstructured and structured. Most literary autobiographies fall into the unstructur^trategoty. Behavioural scientists, sensing the usefulness of autobiography in recent
times, have devised what is known as a 'structured autobiography*. In contrast to
^'Delmont K. Bym, "The Test Interpretetion—PlaiminB Interview" UnnnWici....^prepared for use in training at the University of Michigan. ' ""Published paper


--- PAGE 165 ---
P^chologlcal Testing and Diagnosis 145
the unstructured one this is more purposeful, pointed and specific. Naturally it is
easier to analyze and study. The unstructured autobiography, as the name indicates,
could be systematic or unsystematic, it could concern only the individual's major
events in life, it could be a trenchant defense of certain acdons (for instance, Adolf
Hider's Mein Kempf), it could be in the nature of a confession (for instance.
Confessions of St Augustine, The Cortfessions of a Thug, etc.) or it could be a self-
analydcal account (Gandhi's My Experiments with Truth). The major difficulty with
unstructured autobiographies is the relative emphasis they place on different themes.
They may contain irrelevant material which may fail to provide information to
specific questions. The structured autobiographies are asked to be written along a
suggested outline consisting of topics such as (1) my family, (2) my childhood,
(3) my years before school, (4) my years in the elementary school. (5) places I have
lived, (6) trips I have taken. (7) how I spend my time every day. (8) my experiences
in the high school, (9) my teachers and my class fellows, (10) the newspapers I
read, (11) the books I like. (12) my interests, (13) my ambitions and aspirations,
and so on.
The advantage of this structured autobiography is obvious. It is designed to
provide answers to specific questions posed by the counsellor.
Autobiographies are also categorized according to the comprehensiveness or the
topicalness or limitedness of their contents (Annis, 1967). Combining the two
dimensions we could have four types of autobiographies, namely (1) structured
cmnprehensive, (2) structured topical, (3) unstructured topical and (4) unstructured
comprehensive. In interpreting autobiographies the counsellor looks for (1) the
client's 'willingness to reveal himself, (2) his self-insight and self-understanding, (3)
his ability to understand the content of the topic and (4) his ability to communicate.
There is a very important inherent weakness in this technique, namely, it is very
subjective and the real magnitude of each problem is . not known—whether the
writCT has exaggerated anything or whether he has tried to under-estimatc its
importance.
Baldwin (1942) has suggested a personal-structure analysis technique to obtain
a quantitative analysis of autobiographies. For example, he looks for the frequency
with which a particular item appears. This is indicative of its importance. The
second is contiguity of two items and their fiequency of appearance. Dollard and
Mowrer (1947) have developed a discomfort-relief coefficient to assess tension
changes applicable to autobiography. Notwithstanding the research efforts made so
far, it is safe to conclude that there is no fool-proof analysis and interpretation of
autobiographies.
The chief defects of autobiography are: (1) the difficult in determining the
consistency and authenticity of the data and (2) the lack of any criterion fcM* evaluating
the subject's internal attitudes and feelings concerning the important events in his
life.
The defects, therefore, limit the use of autobiographies in counselling practice.
Anecdotal Records
The recorded observations usually made by teachers are called anecdotal records.
This technique assists in the understanding of each student better.

Froehlich and Hoyt (1959) define anecdotal records as follows: "An anecdotal
record consists of an objective description of pupil behaviour in a particular
environmental setting, an interpretation of the behaviour by the observer writing the
description, and a recommendation for future action based on the incident and its
interpretation".
According to Prescott (1957), the characteristics of a good anecdote are:
1. It gives the date, place, and situation in which the action occurred. This is
called the setting.
2. It describes the actions of the individual ^upil/child), the reactions of the
other people involved and the responses of the former to these reactions.
3. It quotes what is said to the individual and by the individual during the
action.
4. It states 'mood cues*—postures, gestures, voice qualities, and facial
expressions—which serve as cues to help understand how the individual
felL It does not provide interpretations of his feelings but only the cues by
which a reader may judge what they were.
5. The description is inclusive of and extensive enough to cover the episode.
The action or conversation is not left incomplete and unfinished but is
followed through to the point where an aspect of a behavioural moment in
the life of the individual is supplied.
The anecdotal record gives information about the name of the student, grade,
date, description of the setting, description of the incident and the observer's name.
On reviewing the utility and value of anecdotal records, Shertzer and Stone
(1968) indicated that a systematic programme of observation benefits administrators,
teachers, students and counsellors to (1) gain more information about an individual's
cumulative pattern of development, (2) become better observers and interpreters of
student behaviour, (3) obtain better understanding of the pupils by the administrators
and (4) help the students realize that the staff of the school is interested in them.
Such realization benefits the pupils.
lUting Scales
The rating scales are a means of quantifying observations and are easy to use.
Several observers can rate the same individual using rating scales for obtaining
more information. The pupils' characteristics, such as dependability, honesty,
cooperativeness, self-reliance, leadership and industriousness are rated by teachers,
counsellors, etc. There are four types of rating scales: numerical scales, descriptive
scales, paired comparisons and graphic rating scales. The rating scales are subject
to personal bias, halo effect, regression to central tendency ^d logical errors. Halo
effect is "The tendency to rate individuals either too high or too low on the basis
of one outstanding trait". The tendency to rate about or close to the middle position
and to avoid giving high or low rating is called regression to central tendency.
Cumulative Records
Cumulative records provide an organized, progressive record of information regarding
the student which dstinguishes him fiom all other individuals.

The cumulative folder includes information, such as personal data and family
background; medical and health condition; date of school entry; school grades;
transcripts from previous schools attended; school test results; personality and
behaviour trait radngs, school activities; anecdotal records and autobiographies
written in class-room setdngs.
Three of the most common types of cumuladve records are the packet type, the
single card or folder type, and a combinadon of the above.
Mortcnsen and Schmuller (1966) state that cumulative records provide infbnnadon
concerning the following:
1. The previous (individualisdc) experiences of the pupil.
2. The group acdvides of the pupil.
3. The organization of needed curriculum or guidance experiences..
4. The evaluadon of the pupil.

6. The working out of district or inter-district, or state or country administrative

11. The promoUon of students to pardcular classes and in providing placement

Identify deviant behaviour and thereby assist the individual student
Pupil Data Questionnaires
The pupil data quesdonnaires consist of items regarding the student's home, family,

The pupil data quesdonnaires (1) are used to obtain comprehensive informadon
dealing with the student as he is now, employing both idiographic and normadve
data, (2) serve as a supplement to incomplete information available about students
and (3) improve the collecdon of data in an efficient manner.
SoclQmetilc Techniques
Sociometric techniques measure the inter-perscmal preferences among the members
of a group in reference to a criterion. The purpose of this technique is to measure
each individual's social worth or personal value as viewed by his peers. According
to Barclay (1966), sociometry is a method of discovering and analyzing patterns of
friendship within a group setdng.


--- PAGE 168 ---
148 hansellingand Guidance
Sociometric technique or testing falls into two categories, namely (1) the use of
choices or specific criteria to serve a particular purpose at a particular time and (2)
questionnaires or rating instruments which measure inter-personal attitudes and
feelings but not in respect to a specific criterion.
The advantage of the sociometric technique is that it provides objective
information about the functioning of individuals within their groups. When this is
viewed along with infonnation obtained by the use of other tools by the counsellor,
it gives a complete picture of the individual.
However, it should be borne in mind that sociometric tests do not give exact
answers. Their theories have not been well developed and the postulates have also
not been tested. But these limitations can also be extended to the interpretation and
application of other test results. Thus the limitations are not very specific to
sociometric tests.
Case &udy
A case study is an analysis and documentation of data collected in a case history.
It comprises the information gathered about a client, including the family history,
physical development, etc. Educational, social and vocational history is also covered
in the case study.
The case study presents a cumulative picture of the personality of an individual.
The infonnation is gathered from sources, such as cumulative records, observations,
interviews, autobiographies, self-reports, tests, teacher reactions and other school
records. The school counsellor writes the case study which provides an increased
understanding of the pupil.
While most of the guidance personnel accept the value of case studies, a few
counsellors feel that nothing new is obtained from a formal case history. It cannot
be of great assistance to the clients. The counsellors believe that any solution not
coming directly from the counsellee is valueless and, therefore, they conclude that
diagnosis based on case study is fruitless. While this is a plausible point, it cannot
be over-emphasized that a case study does help to provide and clarify the vast
amount of information needed for the understanding of a particular pattern of
behaviour of the client.
Case histories generally tend to be full of gaps and sometimes relevant information
may not be forthcoming. It is not necessary here to list the limitations and to
suggest the various safeguards that a counsellor should employ.
Case histories conventionally cover areas, such as:
1. Identifying informatioi^name, age, sex, etc.
2. Educational information—levelof education, scholastic record, subject least
liked and most liked, present educational status and future plans.
3. Personal data—general health history, family background, socio-economic
data, personal psychological relations, social psychological relations,
aspirations and the like.
4. Vocational informatioit—-jobs held, if any, choice of vocation, parental
occupation and the like.
5. Specific information indicating special problems, if any, referral agency and
the like.


--- PAGE 169 ---
P^chologlcal TestingandDiagnosis 149
In the preparation of case reports, cumulative records, if available, are of much
value. In the same way autobiographical information, if obtained, could be quite
valuable. Sometimes clients are encouraged to write projective essays on topics,
such as 'what I would like to be', 'my family' and 'my vocation'.
The case study provides an opportunity for the person to be understood and
treated as an individual. It is capable of reducing errors in diagnosis. It also helps
in the prediction of behaviour. One of the disadvantages of the case history is that
it causes delay in assistance to an individual. Another limitation is that the case
study may not be sufficient as a basis for drawing conclusions and for formulating
diagnosis for a client
It is. therefore, regarded as hazardous to place too much reliance on any single
method of client appraisal.
PSYCH0DIAGN09S
Diagnosis has always been an important and crucial step in the medical or clinical
context. In this sense it is a complex process of observation and inference involving
examining symptoms, inferring causes integrating observations and ritting them
into general categories. Diagnosis is an essential aspect of the therapeutic process.
In most medical situations diagnosis almost always precedes therapy; However, in
the psychological situation diagnosis has more than one meaning and is seldom
used as specifically as in the field of medicine. It is generally agreed that it is a
common counsellor technique involving a systematic study of the client through
appropriate means to provide a meaningful direction to the counselling relationship.
Diagnosis, in general, refers to the identification of abnormally on the basis of
the symptoms and classification of the observed characteristics of the counsellee.
According to Williamson (1950), it is a "terse summary of problems, their causes
and other significant and relevant characteristics of the client together with the
implications for potential for adjustment and mal-adjustment". In Thome's (1950)
view, "diagnosis refers to the description of the organism and his behaviour by a
variety oifmethods whose basic purpose is to discover the personality dynamics in
each individual case".
Diagnosis, according to Tyler (1953), is a means of obtaining a comprehensive
picture of the client. Patterson (1959) holds that diagnosis is understanding the
client from an external view and represents knowledge about the client rather than
knowing him. CaUis.%965) slates. "The fundamental purpose of diagnosis in
counselling is to enable the counsellor to make predictions about client behaviour
from which he in tum constructs his plans for handling the case."
Diagnosis, in a counselling situation, refers to a concise statement of the problems
of the client in his present position. It tries to identify possible causes of difficulty
in order to predict future client behaviour. Diagnosis thus, may be considered as a
hypothesis of the counsellor regarding a counsellee's present attitudes, thoughts,
etc., and possible future behaviour. Branimer and Shostrom (1968) hold that diagnosis
is a descriptive statement generally identifying the client's style of functioning. It
could be a technique to motivate desirable changes in client behaviour through a


--- PAGE 170 ---
150 CounseJllns and Guidance
description of his behavioural style. For instance, the client's understanding of
himself as a self-effacing or a self-assertive person helps motivate him to change
his behavioural style.
Shostrom (1967) holds that diagnosis provides awareness to the client which is
the first step in the actualizing process. Thus it will be seen that diagnosis is
identifying the behaviour to be modified or changed. Therefore, unless the counsellor
knows what is to be changed, he cannot possibly employ a suitable procedure to
obtain the desired results.
Rogers (19SI) is the most outspoken critic of diagnosis as a necessary step in
the counselling process. He raises the following objections concerning the
appropriateness of diagnosis: (1) It makes the counsellor responsible for improving
and understanding the client's situation and makes him Xclient) dependent on the
counsellor. (2) It makes the counsellor committed to it, even if it is found to be
unhelpful. (3) It interferes with the counselling process as such, that is, with the
release of growth forces within the client (4) Diagnosis may act as blinkers on the
counsellors. Having made the diagnosis he may rigidly stick to it by shutting his
eyes to other factors which may be of considerable importance.
Perhaps appreciating the position of Rogers, Bordin (1946) and Tyler (1963)
assign a limited role to diagnosis. Meehl (1954) and Kelly (1955) recognize the
importance of diagnostic procedures butare generally unconvinced about the validity
and dependability of diagnosis which is not strictly psychometric. Williamson (1937),
Froehlich (1956) and Hoyt (1966) hold diagnosis to be very helpful and necessary.
Psychological diagnosis generally refers to:
1. A statement of the problem or a description of the present status of the
client and probable causes of his difficulties.
2. Probable counselling techniques which would be of value.
3. Prediction of counselling outcomes.
Williamson (1939) states, "A diagnosis is,a structured summary of significant
case data." He distinguishes three distinct aspects of diagnosis: First, diagnosis of
the problem, that is, the problem of the client must be identified by the counsellor
so that he can know what has to be done about it and what approach might best
be pursued. Diagnosis thus provides orientation. It allows the counsellor to plan
doing something for the client. Second, diagnosis of the person, that is, understanding
the client through as full and as complete an appraisal of him as possible. The
counsellor should grasp the nature of the client, his needs, capacities and resources.
In this sense, diagnosis relates counsellor activities to the specific needs of the
client Bordin (1955) recognizes this step as vital to counselling. Third, diagnosis
may mean prognosis, that is, appraisal of the client's prospects of recovery. Thus
diagnosis is a complex funcdon which is often confus^ t^ause its three aspects
(problem appraisal, personal diagnosis and prognosis) are seldom distinguished
from one another.
The main purpose of diagnosis in counselling is to plan for different types
of treatments suitable for different clients. Diagnosis, in this sense, would refer
to different counsellor approaches, such as, giving information and interpreting
or helping the client's self-discovery. Weiner (1959) is also convinced of the


--- PAGE 171 ---
P^chohgtcalTestlns^dDlagnosIs 151
significance of ihe Bordin-Pepinsky diagnostic categories. The value of diagnostic
categorization is mainly for reporting or communicating. While much enthusiasm
is evident for diagnosis, it should not lead one to become blind to its shortcomings
or possible abuses. For example, a diagnostic .category such as -neurotic' is of little
help to the counsellor beyond placing the client into a stereotype category which
may not fit the client in question. Williamson's (1939) argument that diagnosis in
counselling is essentially interpreting case data is a very useful idea. According to
this view, diagnosis is a step that follows the analysis of data which forms the basis
for prognosis. Hiis view of diagnosis, often called the rationalistic view, has currency
in student personnel work and counselling. It is based on the assumption that there
is a certain lawfulness and consistency in human behaviour. This view is applicable
in educational-vocational settings. Thome (1950) takes a more clinical view of
diagnosis and asserts that an acciuate diagnosis must be made before rational
treatment can be planned and implemented. Thome's diagnostic process consists of
understanding the various levels of organization existing at a given moment
UMTTATIONS OF DIAGNOSIS
The non-directivists reject diagnosis as a legitimate counsellor activity or function.
They apprehend the dangers that are implied in the interpretative point of view of
d agnosis. It is necessary to recognize that no diagnosis can be complete, fool-proof
ai id infallible. Errors in diagnosis may arise from incompleteness or inaccuracy of
d^ta; biases and predilections of the counsellors; and &om several such acts of
cpmmission and omission. The second possible danger of rigid diagnosis is that it
could lead the counsellor to become overly preoccupied with the past history of the
client to the neglect of the present. Some counsellors hold that the diagnostic
process must be rooted in the individual's current psychological situation or milieu.
Historically diagnosis has been intimately associated with pathology. A clinician
may become preoccupied with morbidity rather than hygiology of behaviour.
There is yet another danger in leaning heavily on diagnosis. It may shift the
responsibility to the counsellor or psychotherapist who may be looked upon as an
awe-inspiring superior. This mns counter to the view that the client should take full
responsibility for his choices and actions. Rogers (1951), as we have mentioned
earlier, is extremely cridcal about the utility of diagnosis. He maintains that the
moment the counsellor attempts diagnosis he automatically takes a judgemental
atdtude. But this need not necessarily be so. While it is necessary that one should
not easily fall a victim to the temptadon of being mechanically led by diagnosis,
an effecUve counsellor would use it as a tool like any ardsan uses his tool. It is
entirely up to him as to how well or ill he uses the tool. Our examination of this
controversial quesdon of diagnosis should help us take a sciendfic aUitude. Diagnosis
is at best a kind of hypothesis and all sciendfic thinking proceeds by hypothesis
tesdng. If counselling is to be scientific it must follow the same procedure. In this
sense, diagnosis is looked upon as a guess or a provisional explanadon which could
be rejected if it cannot stand the test of fact. Thus, diagnosis would become the
scientific process of hypothesis formulation and testing and a process of


--- PAGE 172 ---
15Z Counseling and Guidance
approximation and correction. Another way of resolving the problem or the issue
could be by trying to redefine the counsellor's role as not helping in prognosis but
letting the client take specific decisions which would mean that the client should
know the direction in which he has to progress or move.
As Rogers (1951) points out, therapy is not diagnosis 'in reverse'. But it would
be theoretically impossible and undesirable hx)m the practical standpoint to do
away with diagnosis. The question is not whether or not to diagnose, but rather
wh^ the fimction of diagnosis in the helping process ought to be. The ultimate
objective of the diagnostician is very much like that of a taxonomisL The aim is
to learn as much as possible about the single individual in order to be able to
classify him in some particular group. According to Hollis (1951), there are two
aspects of diagnosis; one is our knowledge of the individual and the other is our
background knowledge about patterns of human behaviour. The underlying
assumption of diagnosis is that what we learn about one individual will shed light
on how to help another. Some case workMS feel that diagnosis is in order when it
is desirable to ascertain the presence or extent of pathology. In several counselling
situations it is helpful to Imow about other individuals particularly close to the
clients. Gombwg and Levinson (1951) speak of family diagnosis. According to
them, the nature and quality of intKaction between significant members of the
family are vital factors in the prognosis of any one of the members seeking
counselling assistance.
It is impractical, if not impossible, to do away with the need for some kind of
diagnosis in therapy. A counsellor must make decisions and plan as to how he
should proceed. In the absence of diagnosis there will be no sense of direction or
orientation. Of course, there is need to guard against committing the folly of wrong
diagnosis leading to perverted orientation. The counsellor should be alert and open
to make modifications in his diagnostic planning. The counsellor thus has to play
a delicate role of optimally balancing the Rogerian position of "withholding
judgement and attempting to stay within the client's frame of reference and trying
to understand the client diagnostically" (Brammer and Shostrom, 1968). Diagnosis
is not static. Even in medical or psychiatric situations diagnosis is often considered
as tentative. It is often subject to change depending on what new facts become
known to the therapisL In counselling situations, an undue emphasis on the diagnostic
aspects is likely to block self-expression and self-direction on the part of the client.
Pray (1947) holds that diagnosis tends to place responsibility upon the counsellor
not only for the relationship but also for the helping process. Counselling is essentially
helping the client mobilize his strengths. Diagnosis should not, therefore, by
implication, become the right to treat, correct or advise the client The counsellor
is interested in helping' the client, not in diagnosis per se. Super (1949) lists some
possible pitfalls: (1) Neglect of other possible methods of help. (2) Overemphasis
on diagnosis could result in the neglect of counselling. ^Psychodiagnosis' is also
used to mean classification, or taxonomy of. psychological problems causing
adjustmental difficulties. This process is sometimes called differential diagnosis in
which the counsellor tries to differentiate one maladjusted syndrome from another.
Several diagnostic categories are suggested by Williamson (1937), Bordin (1946),
Pepinsky (1948) and others.

COMMON DIAGNOSHC CLASSmCATION SYSTEMS IN COUNSELLING
Williamson and Darley (1937) proposed the following diagnostic classification:
1. Personality problems—Difficulties pertaining to adjustmental problems,
family conflicts, personal problems, etc.
2. Educational problons—Such as unwise choice of courses of study, differential
scholastic achievement, inadequate general scholastic aptitude, ine^ective
study habits, reading difficulties, lack of motivation, under-achievement and
the like.
3. Vocational problems—Comprising unwise vocational choice, differences
between interests and aptitudes, etc.
4. Financial problems—^Need for self-support at school and college.
5. Health problems—^Inabili^ to go about one's routine activities owing to
problems of health.
The above classification, it is held, is simply an attempt to describe the individual
in terms of his adjustment to the several demands of his environment and focuses
on the kind of difficult encountered.
Bordin (1946) suggests an alternate classification, using five categories: no
problem, lack of information, dependence, self-conflict and choice anxie^. He
believes that this scheme is close to the basic psychological issues affecting one's
life and stresses the source of difficult. These categories are briefly explained
here.
Dependence—Conflict in this area immobilizes the client and blocks active
efforts to resolve the problem of reaching a decision. Clients in this category play
a passive role and obviously have not learnt to resolve problems on their own.
Parents at home, teachers at school, ^ends in other situations have been providing
them with ready-made solutions.
Lack of irformation—Limited or restricted range of appropriate experiences or
special opportunities to acquire necessary skills, leave the client ill equipped to
solve his problems.
5c(f-cofl/ficr—Conflicts between self-conceptions or between a self-concept and
some, other stimulus function divide the individual's judgement of a situation.
Choice anxiety—^The need to decide among alternate plans could be an upsetting
experience for the client
Lack ofassurance—^The decision is often made but the client wishes to play safe
by checking with others.
Bordin (19SS) points out that this system of categories is helpful as a general
framework for examining the problems of students but it is desirable to go into
further details to understand the client
The crucial purpose of diagnostic descriptions of behaviour is to motivate the
client to change Ids behaviour. Perls (1951) believes that the client's knowledge
of himself as a self-manipulative person helps motivate him to change his behaviour.
According to Shostrom (1967), the awareness of a system of client's manipulative
style of others helps in the actualizing process of the client.
The Missouri diagnostic classification plan is the most manageable scheme

developed for research reporting purposes. In this classification a two dimensional
scheme of problem goal and cause is used. The problem goal dimension is (1)
vocational, (2) emodonal and (3) educadonal. Callis (1965) defines these three
categories as follows:
1. Vocational (VOC)—^This deals with career choice and planning, choice of
college major, and similar educadonal planning which would uldmately
implement or lead to a career plan.
2. Emotional (EM)—^This refers to personal and social adjustment problems

3. Educational (ED)—^Lack of effective study skills and habits, poor reading

come under.this category. The client is primarily concerned with adjustment

Pepinsky's (1948) classification is a modification of Bordin's categories. He
substituted 'lack of assurance' for 'no problem'. He added another category, namely,
'lack of skill' and subdivided self-conflict into cultural, interpersonal and intra-
personal conflicts. Byrne (1958) revised the Bordin-Pepinsky categories and
suggested the following categories for further research: lack of information, lack of
insight, lack of assurance, lack of problem-solving skill, immaturity in situations
and dominance by authority, person or situation. Robinson's (1963) two dimensional
diagnostic model emphasizes the client's present and past motivation and response
patterns.
SUMMARY
Psychological tests are considered useful devices for providing objective
psychological Information about the clients. The tralt-and-factor approach attaches
much Importance to the p^chologlcal test data. However, the client-centered
approach Is very critical about the use of this data. It considers test data to be
often misleading and to block the client's Insight. Between the above two

extreme positions may be placed the attitudes of other approaches. Behavioural
approaches as well as existentialist approaches give a very limited role to the
use of tests. Test use In diagnosis has been popular with several counsellors,
while a few believe that tests are Inimical to the counselling process. Testing has
not found much favour with some counsellors. While one school believes that
testlrtg Is Inimical for the promotion of a non-threatening atmosphere of
acceptance, another school holds that the Inforrtration provided by tests Is
redundant and often Irrelevant.
The more Important non-test devices are autobiographies, anecdotal records,
rating scales, diaries, cumulative records, case studies and the like.
Non-test devices have been found to give useful information but they also
suffer from subjective errors.
In p^chodlagnosls, test and non-test data are used. The type of material to
be used depends on several factors, such as the cour)sellee*s personality, the
nature of his problem and the counsellor's orientation and predlle^ons.
Diagnosis Is a process of understanding and describing the counsellee's
problem In order that the counsellor attunes himself to the situation arid helps
the counsellee gain Insight Into himself and become capable of finding solutions
to his problems.
Different diagnostic categories are currently In use, some of which are suitable
In educational situations, while others are more appropriate to clinical situations.

INTRODUCnON
An interview is a face-to-iace technique of obtaining information for a variety of
purposes. It is well known as a hiring (selection) technique. It is also employed as
a technique of research (market research, consumer research, etc.). The counselling
interview differs from the above in that its goals are significantly different and
information getting is not its major interesL What is of crucial importance is that
it is therapeutic in its goal.
Every interview, whether employed for research or for counselling, must satisfy
certain basic requisites, one of which is that there should be no element of conflict
with the interviewee. The interviewer must establish rapport by securing the trust
and confidence of the interviewee. It is from this stage that the counselling interview
parts company with the other types of interviews. The counselling interview is
unique in that it is a therapeutic device along with being an information obtaining
device.
In a counselling interview, the counsellee, after having been put at ease, is
encouraged to talk freely. The counsellor assumes the attitude of an interested,
sympathetic and fnendly listener. He neither evaluates nor judges the counsellee's
statements. Thus the essential characteristic of a counselling interview consists in
its being non-judgemental and non-evaluative. The counsellor empathizes with the
counsellee's emotional needs. He makes the counsellee aware of being
unconditionally accepted. This particular aspect does not concern the other types of
interviews. The counsellor is concerned equally with what the counsellee tries to
express but fails to communicate. The counsellor is basically concemed with the
clarification, interpretation and understanding of the counsellee's feelings, ideas
and longings. In this process, there is no place for any anxiety or stress being put
on the counsellee.
Inteivlewirlng~^Its Essential Aspects
According to Garrett (1942), the interviewer should ask himself or seek answers to
the following six questions:
1. How do I view the association of ideas contained within the interview?
2. What shifts in conversation occur which might be meaningful?
3. What content and affect are present'in the client's opening and closing
statements?


--- PAGE 177 ---
Counselllnglnten/iew 157
4. What recurrent references are present?
5. Do inconsistencies and gaps occur which might be of particular significance?
6. Does a reconsideration of the session indicate an unconscious effort to
conceal or hide that which is of concern to the counsellee?^'
Association of Ideas Contained within the Interview
It is a common practice with counsellors to review the counselling session and such
a review reveals several interesting features of the counselling interview. For instance,
the interview may appear disjointed and repetitive but careful observation reveals
a pattern of consistency. The various ideas expressed by the client suggest an
underlying theme or consciousness, though superficially, for all practical purposes',
they could appear to be no more than a conglomerate of ideas got together by fiee-
association. From the apparent confusion, the counsellor can discern the conflicts
or problems or complexes that are encountered by the client. This is a very important
psychoanalytic technique of therapy. The association of iddas, therefore, may bring to
the fore the counsellee's feelings which he may not be disposed to express otherwise.
Shifts in Conversation
The counsellee may appear to be rambling in his conversation which may seem
senseless. A review of ^is could reveal significant material. What kinds of shifts
were made by the client? When did such shifts usually take place? Was the client
trying to cover up something by changing the topic or was he trying to introduce
new material to help clarify what was said earlier? Shifts also could suggest the
sensitive areas of the client's experience.
Opening and aosing Remarics
These remarits of the client may apparently mean nothing. However, the counsellor
may obtain a significant insight when reviewing these opening or closing remarks.
For instance, they may suggest reluctance on the part of the client or they may
indicate his sincerity.
Recurrent Reference
When a client refers to a particular idea or experience in the course of the counselling
interview several times, it may be of special significance.
Inconidstencles and Gaps
Some of them may appear self-contradictory but inconsistencies and gaps could
suggest resistance or traumatic experience which the client unwittingly discloses in
the conversation. During the interview the counsellor may not realize the significance
of such material.
^'Annette Garrett. Interviewing: Its Principles and Methods, New York, Family Service
Association of America, 1942.
