In review, however, the counsellor is more likely to appreciate the concealed meaning
of the client's statements or inconsistencies or gaps in his conversation.
In verbal communication the counsellor should also notice the rapid or the
halting way in which the client speaks, the gaps in the speech and differences in
tone and voice, which could provide a wealth of information.
NON-VERBAL COMMUNICATION IN INTERVIEW
From the verbal material obtained in the interview the counsellor could gain
significant insight into problem areas or disturbances in the client. While verbal
expression is eloquent and direct, non-verbal expression could sometimes be more
revealing. There have been instances when speech has been misunderstood. And
even if speech is not misunderstood, it cannot be assumed that all feelings can be
adequately verbalized. Hence a counsellor should be watchful and alert to take note
of the non-verbal communications made by the client howsoever random and
irrelevant they may appear. Non-verbal behaviour grows out of the counselling
relationship. Understanding of non-verbal communication is basically related to
factors, such as the sensitivity, training and skill of the counsellor. Non-verbal
communication provides for an intuitive understanding of the counsellec, and its
importance, therefore, is enormous.
Non-verbal communication includes gestures like body movements, smiling,
blushing, weeping and other postural movements. Scratching the head, resting the
face on tlie hand, crossing the arms across the chest, cracking the knuckles, riddling
with the ringers, rubbing the thumb with the ringer, closing the nostrils or placing
the index finger on the nostril, biting the index finger, biting the lip, holding the
chin, playing with such things as a key chain, ring, pencil and the like'are also some
of the common devices generally employed by individuals in their non-verbal
communications. Attempts have been made to categorize body movements so that
they can be more objectively interpreted. We can wimess this objectivity to a
degree in any tradition or system of dance or pantomime where various postures
or gestures are employed to communicate certain feelings, moods and ideas. Facial
expressions are yet another source of information and understanding. It is said that
*the;face is the index of mind*.
It is naturally felt that the counsellor would profit if there was a category system
which could be employed to interpret non-verbal communication. Several attempts
have been made. For instance, Bronfenbienner and Newcomb (1948) have devised
a framework to categorize the emotional and dispositional expressions. They
identified the following five dimensions: (1) quality of motion, (2) locus of activity,
(3) direction or plane of movement, (4) front of body contour and (5) body area of
activity. Ruesch and Kees (1956) have developed a theory of non-verbal
communication. They use the term 'action language* as opposed to 'sign language*.
Ruesch (1955) has stressed the importance of non-verbal communication in
psychotherapy. Ekman (1964) believes that two Qpes of infonnation can be obtained
from non-verbal behaviour (1) specific and direct meaning and (2) infonnation


--- PAGE 179 ---
CounsellingInterview 159
about other behavioural variables. Kagan and his associates (1965) have developed
a typology of non-verbal behaviour. They obtained video-tape pictilres of their
clients and examined them closely. The non-verbal behaviour could be of three
categories: (1) the client may be fully aware of the behaviour, (2) the client may
be marginally aware and (3) the client may be entirely unaware. The behaviour
could be analyzed with respect to affect and/or content. The client's non-verbal
behaviour may also be viewed in terms of duration. It may be momentary, it may
last for a considerable time, or it may be persistent. Now in terms of the two
dimensions of awareness and duration, there can be (3 x 3) nine categories. Kagan
and his associates (1965), from the study of video-pictures of their clients, have
found gestures to be primarily concerned with emphasis. (1) The subject says
something and he gestures largely to emphasize his verbal expression. (2) Gestures
help facilitate communication. (3) Gestures may also be used to portray or
communicate a specific idea. (4) Gestures may be revealing. Usually this category
falls under the unaware dimension. These types of gestures convey to the counsellor
information which is not available to him through verbal communication. Gestures
which reveal the nature of the client usually come under the category of habitual
behaviour which the client is not aware of. But the awareness may not be the real
meaning of the gesture. For example, the client may meddle with a bunch of keys
which he (client) may be unaware of. This behaviour may often indicate existing
tension, anxiety or nervousness which the client is unconsciously expressing. (5)
The last category of non-verbal communication has also an affect content or an
emotional charge. The client may cry or weep. In this obviously the client is aware
of his own behaviour which communicates his feelings. It is an unmistakable
demonstration of feeling. Similarly, the client may also demonstrate through other
gestures a desire for counsellor approval.
The intuitive character of non-verbal communication remains an unexplored
domain. Though this area is of great importance, it has not generated sufficient
research. One of the earliest efforts were made by Maccoby and his associates
(1965) in teacher-training situations. They showed to a group of judges comprising
teachers—experienced and inexperienced—and others, films of student-teacher
interaction. When the non-verbal cues alone were considered there was no significant
improvement in jhe accuracy of judgement. Training the subjects for some time
with a few selected non-verbal cues resulted in an increase in the accuracy of
judgements.
Any reference to the study of non-verbal behavioural typology would be
incomplete if the important study of Kagan and his associates (1965), namely, the
Inter-personal Processes Recall (IPR) was not considered. They restricted their
study to gestures including arm, hand and postural movements. Obtaining a vast
repertoire of non-verbal behaviour of clients they tried to validate their typology.
The non-verbal behaviour considered was along three dimensions, namely, source,
awareness and duration of behaviour. The source was related-to the client's affective
exp^ence during the interview. Awareness concerned the counsellee's awareness
or otherwise of his acdons. Duration concerned the length of time for which a
particular behaviour persisted, the number of times the behaviour occurred, and so
on. Duration was categorized by Kagan and his associates into six categories.


--- PAGE 180 ---
160 Counselling and Guidance
namely, emphasis, facilitation, portrayal, conscious revelation, unconscious revelation
and expression of aSecL
Emphasis is usually conveyed through movements of the hands and head. The
client is usually unaware of his non-verbal expressions made for a brief duration.
Facilitation gestures are usually accompanied by verbal content and the counsellee
is marginally aware of them. Portrayal gestures are usually of longer duration and
are- made consciously. The source of the gestures for emphasis, facilitation and
portrayal are directly related to content, that is, they supplement verbal content or
communication; gestures for revelation, either conscious or unconscious, made to
express feeling, have their source in the affective domain. They indicate the feelings
of the subject whether or not he is aware of them.
COUNSUIEE—COUNSEUOR RELATIONSHIP
The success of the counselling interview largely depends on the nature of the
relationship between the counsellor and the counsellee, the latter's readiness to
communicate and his real desire to improve. The essence of the counselling interview
lies in securing aI^effective relationship which reflects permissiveness (tolerance
and indulgence), kindliness and warmth. This relationship, if established, aids in
reaching a therapeutic relationship, leading to a resolution of the counsellee's
problems so that he/she is able to bring about greater personal balance, more
frustration-tolerance, and better integration of his personality. This means the
counsellee has less anxiety, less unrealistic behaviour and can resolve a number of
his or her conflicts.
The counselling relationship differs from other kinds of relationships like those
existing between p^nts and children, between friends, between teachers and
students, and so on. ^me of the relationships may exhibit indifference and apathy.But most of the relationships above exhibit aHection and social bonds. Counselling
relationship, while being open and accepting, is essentially an objective relationship
such that "under ideal conditions the counsellorxaccepts everything the counsellee
says as an experience that can.TCCur in human beings without taking responsibility
for it or without evaluating it'^(McKinney, 1958).The crux of the problem lies in establishing an effective counselling relationship.
Counsellors as individuals bring into the situation their own needs, values, anxieties
and conflicts. Some of them have other roles to play such as those of a teacher,
parent, or supervisor outside the counselling situation. Naturally, they will introject
the attitudes of the concerned roles. They may interpret counsellee symptoms as
impulsive, obstinate and irralional.^ey may have rigid expectations concerninghow people should conduct themrelves and these could come in the way of
establishing a good relationship which is characterized as an unconditional
acceptance Individuals as teachers and supervisors accept or praise pupils or others
so long as they conform to/the norms expected of them. Such acceptance is called
conditional acceptance. This is not expected of a counsellor in a counselling situation.
What is expected of him is his unconditional acceptance of the client, that is, the
counsellor does not prescribe or demand compliance to his expectations. For example.


--- PAGE 181 ---
Counselling Interview 161
the parent accepts his child and showers concern and affection, notwithstanding the
fact that the child has committed an error or misbehaved. For the parent, he/she is
his/her child, and this relationship does not end because of the misdeeds or mistakes
committed by the child. The parent's affection is uncondidonal. This does not
preclude the fact that a parent may experience unhappiness and misery owing to
his/her child's behavioui^
INTERVIEWING TECHN1Q.IIES IN COUNSELLING
Coimselling techniques concern the specific procedures and skills employed by the
counsellor in securing his counselling goals or objectives. There could be variations
in the techniques employed by diHerent counsellors, which could be either owing
to subjective factors, such as responsibility, leading and planning statements of the
counsellor or to the specific nature of the counsellee's problem, or to both. However,
there is always a danger of becoming too technique-conscious in one's approach.
This kind of rigid technique-oriented approach sometimes makes the counsellor's
position look ridiculous in his blind adherence to thumb-rules or fixed formulae.
Similar techniques cannot be applied to all clients. There is a subjective element
involved in the choice of a specific technique by the counsellor. Usually counsellors
develop varying styles based on their appreciation of the counsellee's needs. The
different techniques, at any time, are in the constant process of empirical validation.
We will discuss some of the well known techniques which have been experimentally
validated.
The foremost issue concerns the basic nature of the approach, namely, the client-
centered approach or the non-directive approach, the directive approach, the
authoritarian approach and the eclectic approach. The nature of direction in a specific
approach is concerned with the amount of lead taken by the counsellor, the
involvement of the client and other such basic matteis. For instance, the authoritarian
approach assumes that the client is ignorant and helpless in the matter confronting
him as it is determined by uncoiiscious forces and that it is for the counsellor to
take the responsibility of helping to solve the client's problem. The'non-directive
approach, on the other hand, assumes a more or less diametrically opposite position.
It holds that the counsellor is igntiiant about the counsellee's personality and
therefore, does not know anything about the client's problem. It is for the client,
therefore, to solve or resolve his problems by his active participation. The counsellor
helps the client by providing a conducive atmosphere exuding warmth and
friendliness devoid of tension and stress. The directive approach assumes that
individuals have different degrees of knowledge about themselves as well as their
environment. They fail to solve their problems or make necessary choices leading
to the resolution of their problems as a result of lack of sufficient information or
ignorance about certain critical issues. The counsellor, therefore, has to give, objective
and dependable information to the client regarding his assets and liabilities as well
as information about the situation in all its aspects. The eclectic approach would not
like to identify itself with any particular theoretical point of view. The eclectic
counsellor believes that he should have freedom to choose the approach that suits


--- PAGE 182 ---
162 ComseJIIns and Guidance
his client. Thus, the importance the different approaches assume depends on the
manner in which a counsellor has to deal with his client.
While it could be said that a technique without a proper theory and philosophy
would be blind, we could with equal force and conviction say that mere theory and
philosophy without application would be sterile; therefore, we cannot divorce a
technique from its thwretical moorings. Counselling techniques may be seen as the
individual innovations of the counsellors to suit each counselling situation. Some
of the innovations have stood the test of time and have come to be accepted as
dependable techniques.
Speaking of techniques, we could identify the individual character of each of
them from the time the counsellee makes his first contact. This is a crucial stage
and the importance of the 'opening technique' cannot be overemphasized. How
does the counsellor make his first move? In other words, how does he establish a
feeling of trust? There could be different techniques of securing the trust of the
client but it would be fruitless to try to explain or describe them as they grow out
of the counsellor's experiences and become important skills. For example, some
counsellors go out to receive their clients when they arrive. Others warmly greet
them and yet others just smile at them. All the three approaches may be good and
successful in securing rapport and a feeling of trust. Some clients may react warmly
to the counsellor's reception, others may not be very much concerned with iL The
next question is that of breaking the ice. What kind of topics should be talked
about? Would it be belter to plunge into the counselling session straightaway or
would it help to have a brief conversation on non-affective items such that the.
chent feels comfortable and gets a sort of breathing time to put himself at ease?
STRUCTURING THE COUNSELIING RELATIONSHIP
The counsellee arrives with several feelings, attiuides and expectations. He is often
nervous and wonders what is going to happen. It is essential that the counsellorin es It clear to the counsellee regarding what may take place in the counselling
situauon. This is called 'structuring'. Much has been written about this. Sometimes
counsellors are ^d to use an unstructured situation. But the problem is quite^klish or sensitive in that there can be nothing like an unstrucuired relationship.
minimal structuring as contrasted with structuring the situation.What do we mean by structuring? For most counsellors, structuring concerns the
nature of the counselling relationship and indicates the limits, roles, goals and the
e. In short, structuring concerns the practical mechanics of the counselling
relationship. It dispels many initial misconceptions about counselling. This kind ofinitial uriderstanding, accor^ng to some counsellors, could be of great value to the
chents. It is good if the client has some understanding and grasp of the matter.
What does he expect from the counselling relationship? What would be his
responsibilities and commitments? What is the amount of time that would be available
to him? What fees, if any, does he have to pay? and the like. When a client does
not know anything about such matters, he is obviously going to feel uncomfortable
and anxious.


--- PAGE 183 ---
Counselllnglntervlew 163
Structuring has other important goals. Most clients have faulty notions about
counselling. Some clients ask the counsellor to psychoanalyse them. Others may
want the counsellor to give a few tests and interpret the results. While the counsellor
may do what the clients expect him to do, if found necessary, it does not mean that
the counsellor will always have to do what the client asks for. Thus structuring the
interview dispels some of the misconceptions. It also provides the counsellee with
the necessary orientation to the counselling situation. Usually in referral cases
clients tend to become truculent or assume a tacitiuo attitude because they labour
under a misconception that the counsellor is part of the establishment and that the
counsellor is only an agency to justify the action of the management. This is
frequently the situation with clients referred to by industrial managements or by
school or college authorities. Structuring helps to reduce anxiety in the clients.
There is yet another category of clients who are convinced about the wastefulness
of this process and believe that it is not going to be of much consequence to them.
Such clients tend to respond at the superficial level and may not actively participate
in the counselling relationship. Structuring in this situation may help save much of
the time of the counsellor as well as that of the client.
Most importantly, structuring thus helps' clients obtain a certain amount of
orientation to the counselling situation.
DEGREE OF LEAD
The second technique or style of functioning concerns the degree of lead to be
taken by the counsellor. Since a lot of material is written on this issue, we shall
attempt to give a very brief description of the different leads. Robinson (1950) has
used the term 'lead' to connote, "a team like working together in which the
counsellor's remarks seem to the client to state the next point he is ready to accept".
Lead refers to the kind of communication, verbal or otherwise, made by the counsellor
which helps, invites, directs or prods the client towards making a response. For
example, the counsellor may use silence as a lead. The counsellor's role in this
context would be one of receiving. The counsellor may merely restate what the
client has said. In this the counsellor's role is one of acceptance. The counsellor
may employ another lead—the reflection of feelings. He may say, "you feel like...."
Here the counsellor's role is one of making the counsellee understand. The counsellor
may explore. This is suggested by "yes, go on" or "tell me more about it", etc. The
counsellor's role here is one of searching. Counsellors, therefore, employ different
leads and play different roles designed to elicit feeling or facilitate understanding
or action. In the latter two contexts, namely, understanding and action, the counsellor
may summarize the client's expressions, attempt a tentative analysis and interpret
the client's expressions and feelings. He may resort to direct questioning to investigate
a wider area or delve into the client's feelings. Usually the counsellor provides
reassurance, support and encouragement to help build the confidence of the client.
To ensiue action the counsellor may, in addition to assurance, employ techniques
such as suggestion, persuasion, urging and even cajoling. What kind of technique
the counsellor should use, and with what type of client, cannot be explained as a
matter of formulae or thumb rules. Much depends on the counsellor's intuitive


--- PAGE 184 ---
164 Counsellingand Guidance
judgement boni out of his experience and the situation on hand. In some speciflc
situations, the counsellor may give advice in addition to information to facilitate
acceptance. This should not, however, be mistaken for the type or kind of advice
given by parents., teachers, friends, neighbours and well-wishers. In essence, the
advice given by a counsellor on closer examination would be found to be no advice
at all. Usually, it takes (he form of the question, "What do you think you would
do?" as an answer to the client's question, "What do you think I should do?"
SILENCE
Silence perhaps is the most difficult technique to master for most counsellors who
are teachers. More often than not, they are prone to think client-silence as
synonymous with counsellor failure. Naturally they feel embanassed and get annoyed
with the situation. However, silence is a time honoured technique employed by
pastoral (clergy) counsellors. There are certain qualitative differences in this mode
of response. For instance, there could be a pause in the conversation. This pause
could extend into an uncomfortable silence. The counsellor may view this as a
refusal on the part of the client to communicate.
As has been mentioned, the counsellor may also employ silence as a technique.
He may use it deliberately for organizational purposes or to terminate the counselling
session.
relationship techniques
The goal of the counsellor is to bring about the desirable change in the client's
behaviour. The behaviour exhibited by the client as a result of counselling is the
proof of his acceptance and action as influenced by the techniques designed by the
counsellor.
Rogers (1942) stresses the importance of relationship techniques, the first among
which is the reflection of feeling. The client usually talks about his feelings in an
unconcerned way as if his feelings are something apart from himself. This method
serves as a defense mechanism. The counsellor, by trying to make the client reflect
on his own feelings, directs the attention of the client to himself. He makes the
client see that the feelings are part of the subjective self, and when once understood
and appreciated, they cease to be bothersome. But this is very difficult to accomplish.
It is not only intangible but also very subtle. The counsellor, according to Rogers
(1951), attempts to mirror the client's attitudes and feelings for his improved self-
understanding. The word 'mirror' is very important in this context. Notwithstanding
the fact that several mirrors distent, sometimes grotesquely, the counsellor is supposed
to be like a neutral surface reflecting the client's feelings back to him such that he
is able to gain a better understanding of himself. There is a real danger of
misunderstanding this issue. When we say understanding feelings, usually it is
understood as intellectuailizing feelings, 'or in other words, the deaffecting of
affections. By reflection of feeling and self-understanding is meant a better
appreciation, identification and expression of feeling and not the negation of it The


--- PAGE 185 ---
Counselling Interview 165
expression of feelings is actually encouraged by the reflection technique. As feelings
are the source of most problems, clients have a marked tendency to disown and
distrust their own feelings. The technique of reflecting feelings is aimed at reversing
this process. The client is assisted to trust his feelings and thereby derive his
strength, not by denying.a part of himself, but by mastering himself.
The second relationship between the counsellor and the client is the conveying
of experience through both verbal and non-verbal means. Clients' verbal or non
verbal behaviour conveys feelings. The counsellor, on his part, may also communicate
by reflecting his experience, employing the same means. There could be concordance
or harmony between what is said verbally and what is communicated non-verbally.
Often what is said verbally may not be reflected in the non-verbal gestures. This
common experience with human beings has often led to the peiplexing picture of
discordant reflections of experience. What is said verbally may not be really
communicated through the non-verbal channels of communication of gestures, tone,
voice, posture and the like. It, therefore, becomes necessary for the counsellor to
acquire the skills and perfect them such that he is sensitive to the non-veibal
communication employed by the client to reflect experience.
SHARING OF EXPERENCE
The relationship between the counsellor ^d the client is cential to the therapeutic
process. This relationship may be conceived ^ a continuum with personal
responsiveness and reflection of feeling at one end and sharing of experience at the
other end. At a somewhat central position lies reflection of experience. Sharing of
experience consists in expressing his own feelings, ideas and experiences by the
counsellor with a view to helping the client experience his own feelings in a more
expressive fashion. Sharing of experience corresponds to modelling in the behaviour
therapy. In this the counsellor, by expressing his feelings, lets the client emulate
him. Thus sharing of experience involves the counsellor's willingness to share with
the client his own personal feelings. Reflection of feeling, reflection of experience
and sharing of experience together contribute to the actualization therapy and are
very much identified with the Rogerian therapy. Reflection of feeling involves the
identification of the feelings expressed by clients: It is very often difficult to identify
the feelings expressed by clients. Reid and Snyder (1947) have found appreciable
variation among counsellors in their identification of clients' feelings. Feelings fall
under three broad categories, namely, positive, ambivalent and negative. Positive
feelings are ego-constructive and help in the process of self-actualization. Negative
feelings, in contrast, are ego-destructive. Ambivalent feelings usually are conflicting
feelings expressed at the same time towards the same subject. They correspond to
the love-hate relationship. Ambivalent feelings are of particular importance from
the point of view of counselling because they help the counsellor identify the
apparent contradicdons and reflect them to the client. Ambivalent feelings could
b^ome a source of great inter-personal tension. One of the goals of counselling is
to make the client realize the apparent contradictions in his feelings.
Reflecdon of feeling, reflecdon of experience and sharing of experience have


--- PAGE 186 ---
166 Counsellingand Guidance
been described above as significant devices in counselling. However, reflection of
feelings or sharing of experience are perhaps the toughest and most challenging of
the counsellor skills. Some of the difliculdes of reflecting are explained below.
Stereotype
This is a ^pe of mannoism that individuals employ and a counsellor could innocently
acquire a mannerism of his own in using the same phrase, such as "you feel" or
"I see". These kinds of stereotyped expressions may not help to arouse the feelings
of the clients. They may, on the contrary, make the client more rigid.
Timing
Timing has a unique place in the order of things. When something is done at the
appropriate time it yields optimal results. However, it is not always easy to judge
the proper timing. In counselling this is of paramount importance. When the
counsellor should or should not act, that is, when a certaia action is appropriate or
not, is of great importance in determining the course and success of the counselling
process.
Selection of Feelings
The client may express several feelings of varying importance. The counsellor
exercises his subjective judgement in choosing to reflect one feeling rather than
another. In this way, the counsellor actually is directing the client along certain
channels which he deems iinportant. In this sense the non-directive approach, on
closer examination, is achially a directive approach. Often this subtle but important
point is missed and the Rogerian approach is emphatically declared as a non-
tiirective approach par excellence. •
Content
The material expressed by the client could be of different degrees of significance
from the point of view of the counsellor. A wrong approach would be to reflect
content, that is, to repeat the words or the substance of what the client has expressed.
The counsellor blindly or mechanically states what has been said by the client
Reflecting content is of little value in counselling. Often it may be detrimental to
the counselling process. The counsellor should primarily be concerned with feeling
but not with content. If the counsellor were to be so concerned, he would be
missing the essence of the communication.
Depth
This connotes the obvious experience of our day-to-day life. We experience some
feelings deeply while many feelings may be experienced superficially. In other
words', some of our feelings could be shallow and others deep. A counsellor could
by attending to the shallow feelings, be wasting his time and energy. At the same
time it cannot be gainsaid that the counsellor should not reflect too deeply. Either
extreme may prove counter-productive.


--- PAGE 187 ---
Counselllnslntervlew 167
Meaning
Perhaps this is one of the common ways of secondary elaboration indulged in by
all of us frequently. When something is said we either read too much meaning into
it or do the reverse. This is the common concern of all our communication techniques.
For example, if someone says that he saw a tiger, the listener may report that the
speaker smd that he saw a big tiger. Much of this addition or omission is unintentional
and may also be quite harmless. But there are occasions when a slight addition or
omission could change the whole complexion of a communication. A counsellor
should guard against committing this common error. A counsellor is not supposed
to add or detract any meaning, however trivial, in any circumstance.
language
The importance of language is easily appreciated. It is through language that the
nuances of feelings are expressed. A counsellor is expected to be careful in the
choice of his words. He cannot afford to be careless with the most important tool
of communication, namely, language. In the same way. he is expected to follow the
client's language as carefully as possible.
Thinking
The reflection of feeling or experience could vary in timing. The counsellor may
employ Immediate reflection or may use the technique of summary reflection. The
difference is that in immediate reflection the counsellor deals with one feeling at
a time. It also means that he idendfies the feeling as it is expressed and immediately
reflects it, in which process he may interrupt the client's flow of expression. In
summary reflecdon the counsellor may reflect a number of feelings at one time and
he may not interrupt the client until he finds a logical or appropriate pause. But he
may miss out a few feelings in the process owing to memory lapses. The last kind
of reflection is called terminal reflection and it comprises a summarizing process
usually conducted at the time of the termination of the counselling relationship.
The foregoing account will have indicated the importance of reflection as a
counselling technique. However, nothing has been said regarding the effectiveness
or the conditions which affect the effectiveness of reflection. First of all, it needs
to be understood that reflection helps the individual (client) to feel understood.
People often experience this feeling of being misunderstood and yearn for proper
understanding. Through reflection, the feeling of being misunderstood is dispelled.
The effectiveness of reflection consists in not being misunderstood. Reflection
helps to break the neurotic cycle which is commonly experienced by clients. This
is expressed in statements, such as "he will not understand me and, therefore, there
is no purpose in trying to understand him". This vicious cycle of reasoning is
broken by the reflection technique. It was explained that the reflection of feeling
helps in self-understanding. The effectiveness of reflection consists in helping the
client understand that feelings determine his behaviour. Reflection, therefore, has
a clarifying or simplifying function. It helps the client to evaluate his feelings when
once he is able to appreciate their significance in contributing to self-understanding.
This logically leads to the power of choice that reflection gives the client. Reflection


--- PAGE 188 ---
168 Coun$eIHngandCuldence
on several of his feelings will help him in knowing the significance of each one of
them. Thus the client is able to choose what would best serve his purpose. Finally,
reflection helps clarify a client's motives. Often clients are tempted to say, "I feel"
or "I feel like". Seldom does he say, "I feel like this because". This power of
reasoning leads to the core (underlying) motive or experience.
Acceptance
I  The second relationship technique is acceptance. Rogers (1951) places great
importance on the unconditional acceptance of the client by the counsellor. The
other approaches of counselling have not made this one of the basic issues.
Acceptance is based on the belief that the client has dignity and worth. It is also
based on such important assumptions as the right to make decisions and to be
responsible for one's own actions and hence for one's life.
Acceptance provides the necessary psychological climate for the counselling
interview. It helps the clients get involved in the counselling process and thus
minimizes the possibility of the adoption of defensive attitudes through
rationalizations, denials, explanations, etc.
Acceptance implies neither approval nor a patronizing attitude. The client should
not be under the misconception that his expressions will be approved or disapproved
by the counsellor dependLig on whether he is accepted or not. Again, acceptance
is not a neutral attitude. It is positive in its response. Acceptance is not to sympathize
with the client or tolerate him. The counsellor has to communicate to the client the
sense or feeling of acceptance, such that he experiences the warmth and friendliness
of the situation. Brammer and Shostrom (1968) state that there are three major
observable elements through which acceptance can be expressed by the counsellor:
(1) facial expression conveying the genuine interest of the counsellor, (2) tone of
voice and its inflections, and (3) distance and posture of the counsellor. Actions,
such as yawning, fiequent movement of the hands and legs, changes in the posture
and other similar cues have negative significance and communicate lack of
acceptance.
Special Relationship Problems
While the counsellor may use and apply his chosen technique with all the wisdom
and skill at his command, it is often found that certain psychological phenomena
aid or limit his efforts. More often than not, counsellors are baffled when they
encounter such situations which usually hinder the process of counselling. The
phenomena, namely, transference, counter-transference and resistance have been
as special relationship problems. The phenomena have been recognized
to be of central importance in the psycho-analytic technique. It is recognized that
counselling cannot ignore the special relationship problems and they are considered
to be as valid to counselling as they are to psychoanalysis.In psychoanalytical thinking, transference is a process by which the client's
attimdes, formerly expre^ed towards one person (usually the parent of the oppositesex), SK transferred or prejected to the counsellor/ Transference, for the existential
thCTapists, does not meaii the same as it does for a psychoanalyst. The existentialist


--- PAGE 189 ---
Counselllnglntervfew 169
does not believe that transference implies the transfer of a client's feelings for his
family members to the therapist. The neurotic is one who has not grown beyond
the restricted forms of experience characteristic of a child in most affective areas
of development. Hence, in later years he perceives others or tlie therapist in the
same manner as he perceived his father or mother as a child. The problem of
transference for the neurotic client is primarily one of relationship to events in the
present and his perception of the present situation in terms of his past experience.
Transference
Transference could be positive or negative in nature. Positive transference involves
the expression of feelings of affection or dependency, and negative tipisference the
expression of feelings of hostility and aggression towards the counsellor. A counsellee
may react to the counsellor as he would react to his parent Sometimes the affective
reaction could be a negative one in which the counsellee may feel (erroneously of
course) that the counsellor has contempt or anger for him. The counsellee sometimes
shows positive affective reactions, such as adoration, and the counsellee is often
unconscious of his reactions towards the counsellor.
Wood (1951), discussing transference in client-centered therapy and
psychoanalysis, gives the following illustration: During the second interview his
client observed "...it seemed to me that as we were talking along, that you, not only
as a counsellor but you as an individual were getting sort of excited about this thing
too, just as I was. And that, well, at times, you were no longer a counsellor to me,
but you were just another person that I was talking over this problem with". During
the fourth interview the client observed, "as a matter of fact, a peculiar thing, I hate
to admit it (laughs) is that, except in the last two interviews, I don't believe I've
been much concerned with your reflections. You probably realize I have been
moving pretty fast and somewhat running up middle of your spine at times without,
uh, knowing it, desiring to go ahead. A sort'of manic euphoria (laughs). But I guess
I have done enough to you today".
In therapeutic use, the counsellor does not view transference as a problem, but
as a situation in which the client gives the therapist valuable information on how
he perceives his world. Thus, the transference relationship is a rich source of inter
personal data. Rogers (1942) believes that the feelings of transference develop
when the client perceives that the 'other' person (counsellor) understands him
better than he understands himself. Initially, that is, before transference there is no
relationship between the client and the counsellor which involves transference.
After the initial contact and development of relationship which widens eventually
to provide a situation for the appearance of transference, the client's identification
with the counsellor becomes stronger, leading to transference. When transference
is resolved the client withdraws his projections, culminating the therapy.
Therapeutic Functions of Transference
Strong transferences towards the counsellor are often complicated. But transference
of a less intense nature serves to build the relationship by allowing the clieril to
express distorted feelings without the usual counter-defensive reqx}nses. Transference


--- PAGE 190 ---
t70 Counselllngand Cutdancs
promotes the client's confidence in the counsellor through his handling of the
transference feelings. Such feelings help to amplify the client's emotional
involvement with the problem and enable him to continue the counselling
relationship. Transference further helps the client become aware of the origin of his
feelings in his present life situation through interpretation. The transfened feelings
along with maladaptive behaviour tend to disappear when insight is gained and
more satisfying and mature relationships with people are established. The counsellor
should not fit himself into the client's projections so as to satisfy the client's
neurotic needs. If the counsellor does this, there is a possibility that the projections
will be perpetuated by being reinforced.
How does the counsellor work with the transference relationship? The primary
technique for resolving the transference feeling is by simple acceptance. This will
enable the client to live or act out his feelings. 'The client recognizes that the
transference feelings belong to himself and not to the counsellor. More frequently
the counsellor can ask clarifying questions concerning what the client manifests in
the form of anxiety. "You seem to be unloading on me today. Why do you suppose
this is happening?" This statement explores the client attitudes first and gives him
an opportunity to interpret his own feelings. The counsellor reflects the transference
feeling and by this process the client gains more insight into his feelings. The
counseUor may interpret the transference feeling directly. The object of this is to
clarify the relationship between the client's earlier inter-personal relationships and
his present behaviour. The counsellor may just focus on the client's present behaviour
rather than question its origin. The principle involved is that all feelings need not
automatically be construed as transferred from the past. Some feelings may be the
Insult of gentune interaction between the therapist and client
Couiiter<transference
Counter-transference is the projection of the counsellor's feelings towards the client.
In this the counsellor is reacting in a similar fashion as the client transferring his
feelings. Counter-transference, therefore, refers to the emotional reactions and
projections of the counsellor to the client. This could be a serious handicap to the
client's transference in the counselling process. The counsellee by his behaviour
may remind the counsellor of some past experience and he (counsellor) may react
to the counsellee affectively which may be either positive or negative. The counsellor
may view the counsellee as an impulsive, head-strong and selfish individual. This
is an instance of counter-transference. Compulsive advice-giving is a surreptitious
and subtle form of counter-transference. Counsellors tend to easily take an "if I
were you" approach even in the counselling relationships. A common counter-
Iransference fteling is the idea that the counsellee must somehow like the counsellor
and be pleased with him.
What are the sources of counter-transference?
1. The counsellor's-uiuesolved personal problems may be one source and they
indicate the need for counselling the counsellor.
2. Situational pressures coinciding with the counsellor's problems may aggravate
his latent feelings.


--- PAGE 191 ---
CounsellingInterview 171
3. Counter-transference may emanate while the client is communicating his
feelings to thg counsellor.
If the counsellor tends to be overly sympathetic it could be because of the underlying
need for sympathy and attention on his part. The counsellor's value-structure could
be a veritable source of counter-transference. The very nature of the counselling
relationship puts the counsellor in a position to influence the clienL This happens
notwithstanding the counsellor's objective, non-judgemental and permissive
(indulgent) attitude. It is often difficult for the counsellor to avoid conveying the
feeling that he regards emotional maturity, for example, as an important goal of
counselling. Usually the counsellor conveys his values to the client. Professionally
speaking, there is no question of conveying personal values in the counselling
process, even if they are to facilitate counselling.
Resolving Counter'^ansference Feelings
After an awareness of the feelings of counter-transference the first step consists of
the counsellor asking himself, "Why is it so?" The counsellor must accept the fact
that he has varied feelings about the client and that he will change somewhat by
the counselling experience. The counsellor must be aware that his anxieties could
arise from insecurity in the counselling role.
Every counsellor who feels uneasy about his responses to a client should admit
the possibility that his comments are a form of his own projections. All that may
be necessary is to admit this possibility fiankly and attempt to change. Though
there is no objective evidence to indicate that it is useful to discuss counter-
transference feelings with the client it is found to be a mild, reassuring and
interpretative reference, helpful in allaying anxiety. The counsellor can use his own
awareness of himself as reflected through the therapeutic process to enhance his
own growth and resolve his difficulties. Counter-transference can sometimes be
handled easily by asking the client to discuss the problems in ^up therapy situations.
Resistance
The term 'resistance* was used by Freud (1903) to indicate the unconscious
opposition in bringing material fiom the domain of the id into the ego. Resistance
is explained as one of the protective functions of the ego. According to Bordin
(1968), "Resistance is the reflection of the patient's inability to deal directly,
realistically and constructively with his impulses as they appear during the process
of therapy."
In the counselling situation one of the principal realities of building and
maintaining effective counselling relationship must concern itself with the
phenomenon of resistance. Resistance could be understood as a special defensive
form of transference. It could be a product of the outer defence system protecting
the client from situational threats or of the inner defense system guarding the client
from his unconscious impulses. The existentialists view resistance as a tendency of
the client to renounce his unique and original potentiality which is inalienable.
According to existentialists, resistance is exhibited as social conformity. May, Angel
and Ellenberger (1958) explain that "Social Conformity is a general form of resistance


--- PAGE 192 ---
172 Counselllngand Guidance
to life",...■and even the patient's acceptance of the doctrines and interpretations of
the therapist may itself be an expression of resistance". The client often appears not
to make any effort to overcome his difficulty. On university campuses we come
across several students who represent Q^ical instances of resistance. Usually a
student may meet the counsellor and speak beseechingly about his situation and the
importance of the need for help from the counsellor. More often than not, the
student does not keep the appointment if made, and may not turn up on lime even
if he were to keep the appointment. Resistance, like transference, is explained to
have different implications for psychothraapy and counselling. From the point of
view of counselling, resistance can be understood as something which opposes
progress in problem solving. Therefore, the counsellor is very much concerned with
the need to reduce resistance as far as possible. Resistance exists in varying degrees
in all counselling interviews and may vary from a rejection of counselling or overt
antagonism on the one hand, to subtle forms, such as hesitation, inattention and the
like on the other. During the counselling session, the counsellee just sits rigidly and
does not make any effort to present his problem. If persuaded patiently, he may
come out with a statement which usually runs somewhat like this, "I just don't
know what to talk about. I never expected to do the talking". If asked to try to face
his problem and speak freely about it, he becomes uneasy and tries to be evasive,
making some general statements like, "Everybody wants to score well and succeed,
I want to succeed too". He never comes to grips with his real problem and there
is a lot of evasion concerning it At the end of the session he may just leave the
counsellor wondering whether he will return. A simple example of resistance is
embarrassment which is the tendency to make contact and retreat at the same time.
Blocking is another example of resistance. Although resistance is present in all
interviews to some degree the client is seldom aware of it Since resistance is
largely an unconscious phenomenon it is manifested as an ambivalent attitude
towards counselling.
Source of Resistance
When the client perceives the counsellor or the situation or the specific topic as
threatening, resistance is exhibited. It could be either internal or external in origin.
Iiitemal resistance is the inclination of anxious clients to withdraw from usually
distasteful attempts to seek and to modify paoems of behaviour or personality
structure. It, therefore, represents a fear of growing or of not wishing to be self-
supportive. The common forms of pretwice are also instances of internal resistance.
For example, a student's poor performance is explained as being due to some
outside fector, such as tough question papers or strict evaluation. Another example
of resistance is reification or conversion anxiety which is the client's fear of
expressing his feelings in words. E^^ples of such resistance are unwillingness to
express anxieties about contacting diseases of death, etc. External resistance usually
grows out of poor techniques of coping on the part of the client An illustration of
external resistance could be one in which the counsellor suggests methods of
improving social skills. The client may become anxious and fail to employ them
as he may have anxiety about other external factors interfering with the application
of the new social skills. Resistance may also result from lack of readiness on the


--- PAGE 193 ---
Counselllnglntervfew 173
part of the client A client may not realize his responsibilities in the counselling,
situation and may resent spending time with the counsellor expressing or
communicating his ideas. The counselling relationship is often viewed as a
paradoxical situation by the client. The 'accepting' atmosphere encourages the free
expression of feelings and yet the client is not ready to express or to accept his own
feelings. This relationship may force a premature examination of the client's feelings,
leading to considerable resistance. There are also mixed sources of resistance which
may imply internal resistance, in addition to external resistance. Knowing the sources
of resistance would be of considerable value to the counsellor in understanding the
real nature of the problem he has to deal with.
Functions of Resistance
Resistance, we have explained, has a defensive function for the client Apart firom
this it also has value for the counsellor. It gives an indication of the progress of the
counselling interview and may serve as a basis for the diagnosis as well as the
prognosis of the case on hand. Resistance provides a glimpse into the client's
defensive structiue and could inform the counsellor when he is heading on taboo
territory. Resistance, if known to the counsellor, offers valuable interpretative
information. From the point of view of the client, resistance acts as a protective
mechanism to keep acute anxiety under control. Resistance may manifest itself in
a number of ways which are usually negative. The most significant manifestation
of resistance is silence or refusal to speak or communicate. Resistance may take
other forms as well, like refusing to get emotionally involved, not being cooperative,
maintaining a persistent aloof attitude, etc. Bugental (1952) postulates five levels
of resistance varying from lagging, through inertia, tentative resistance, true
resistance, to rejection. At the lagging level the client is found to transfer
responsibility to the counsellor. The response pauem is one of distractions and
slowness in responding. The inertia level exhibits a strong sense of disinterest
demonstrated by such behavioural signs as monosyllabic answers, disregard of
counsellor leads and the like. Tentative resistance is indicated by behaviour, such
as argumentation, exhibition of physical tension, expression of hostility in an inhibited
form and the like. True resistance is exhibited by withdrawn behaviour or by
making vague or diffused answers to counsellor questions. Rejection is the extreme
form of resistance which is exhibited by refusal to communicate sufficiently in
spite of persistent and persuasive attempts on the part of the counsellor.
Thus resistance is a special relationship problem between the counsellor and the
client. Methods of handling such situations have to be explored.
Nfr-. Gupta was admitted as an in-patient for a variety of symptoms. He had
stiffness in his legs and back and was suffering considerably. Physical examination
revealed nothing positive. No organic basis for his symptoms could be identified.
He did not Improve even after a week in the hospital after which rime he left. He
was referred to the counsellor who found him extremely restive and irritable. He
was even hostile. But patient handling of Gupta revealed that he was unwiUing to
see the counsellor. The counsellor remarked, "I understand you don't want to see
me. You think that you feel worse after a meeting with me. If you talk out yourdifficulties perhaps it will be of help. Nothing is lost, you know, if you spend some

time with me airing your difTicullies and letting off steam." Gupta was reluctant buton persuasion promised to see the counsellor. In the course of the next two months.Gupta met the counsellor more than half a dozen times. He still held that he wasill but agreed that he felt better. This is a case of resistance. In most neurotic cases,
the symptoms serve a protective purpose. The person clings to the symptoms toescape feelings of disgrace, failure or inadequacy. Guilt-feelings, fears, distor^ideas, and the like are apparently abhorred by the counsellee but he resists givingthem'up. A reduction in client resistance, therefore, is the essential first step Wcounselling.
Resistance may take an inexhaustive variety of forms. Sometimes the counseliu®
expresses resistance verbally by saying that there is nothing wrong with him. There
is, therefore, no need to see the counsellor and talk with him. "I have no r^
problems and I don't know what to talk about." This is an instance of initial
resistance. After the effective relationship with the counsellor is established,
resistance is overcome and the counsellee may find that it has been a worthwhile
experience going through the counselling process.
The client makes an appointment with the counsellor and seeks help in resolving
a personal problem. He arrives at the counselling centre at the appointed time. The
counsellor receives him warmly and makes an appreciative comment regarding the
counsellee. The counsellee smiles and then blushes and after a brief silence begin®
pouring out his problems. The counsellor listens uninterruptedly and makes an
occasional monosyllablic remaric and conveys through it his empathic feeling. The
counsellee verbalizes his feelings for 20 minutes and stops. The counsellor says,
understand you. You have my sympathies. I wish I could do something for you.
The counsellee, with a grateful look, tells the counsellor, "You have already done
a lot for me. I feel a great sense of relief. I have, in pouring out my problems,
gained an insight into them."
A final year engineering student calls at the Counselling Centre and enquires
whether he could take some psychological tests. The counsellor does not enquir®
as to why the student desires to take the tests but smiles at him .and gives him
appointment. The student arrives at the Centre for the appointment. The counsellor
greets him with a smile and says, "Mr; Rao, you are going to do the talking, I shall
just listen to you. This will give you an opportunity to discuss your problems in the
light of the tests you are going to take." The counsellee sits silently. He is hesitant
Counsellor "You find it difficult to begin talking." Counsellee: "I don't know what
to talk about. I did not expect to talk here. I told you I wanted to take tests."
Counsellor, "You are right, you wanted to lake some tests. You had something 1"
your mind. Feel free and sp^ openly about it I can perhaps understand exactly
what you want" Counsellee: "I want to improve myself and be a success."
The real problem is his talking in general terms. The counsellor, by suitably
structuring the situation, reflects and clarifies the counsellee's feelings. This helps
the counsellee overcome the resistance.
Handling Resistance
Several techniques are suggested for handling resistance. (1) The noting but
disregarding technique is another name for ignoring the symptom by the counsellor.


--- PAGE 195 ---
Counselllnslnterview 175
The counsellor, by resorting to this approach, has much to lose because he will not
be able to break through the resistance by merely ignoring it (2) hi the minor
adaptations technique, the counsellor actively tries to reduce the client's resistance
by whatever methods he can employ. One such technique consists of reducing the
emotional impact of the discussion by moving more towards the cognitive realm
from the affective area. This is a useful technique on its own merits but falls short
of delivering the goods, namely, breaking the resistance. Another minor modification
is to change the pace of transaction. Sometimes clients may experience difficulty
in keeping pace with the counsellor. In such a situation a change in pace would
naturally be helpful. Also the use of humour could, if used judiciously, help reduce
resistance. There can be a danger in this if the humour backtires, that is, has an
awkward effect (3) Another method of reducing resistance is by the temporary
diversion technique. The important element in diversion technique is that of changing
the subject The counsellor could also limit his involvement in the process by
assuming a more detached and disinterested attitude. A common techpique of
diversion is to suggest bibliotherapeutic reading matter. (4) The direct manipulation
technique consists of the counsellor's use of active methods to break the resistance.
This is done by interpreting resistance and thus helping the client to gain insight
into himself. (5) Other manipulations consist of such techniques as reflecting feelings
or resorting to threats. The latter is an extreme form in which the counsellor
announces, "If you do not want to achieve this we will stop doing anything about
it". (6) The last of the techniques suggested is direct confrontation which employs
in-depth questioning concerning the theme of resistance.
SUMMARY
The counselling interview serves to obtain Information from the client and also
acts £is a therapeutic process. It is a matter of common experience that In the
counselling Interview, the counsellor Is often confronted with non-verbal
behaviour. A few counsellees who are vocal may talk freely after the Initial
resistance Is overcome. But most counsellees find it much simpler to grin or to
use gestures, body movements, silence and such other devices to supplement
what they are communicating verbally. A number of counsellees just keep
silent. Frequently these devices may be Ingenious decoys or techniques to
camouflage and/or conceal the real meaning of their expressions. A relatively
inexperienced counsellor may find the situation quite annoying. With a little
experience and patience, the counsellor would certainly find the non-verbal
adjuncts to the verbal expres^ons of counsellees significant and not meaningless.
With the necessary sensittvl^ and keeness of observation the counsellor would
find the non-verbal cues to yield a wealth of Irrformatlon perhaps more significant
than that made available through the spoken words. Non-verbal behaviour Is
seldom unrelated to the expression of feeling on the part of the counsellee. And
certainly It is never random. It Is vdtally related to the verbal expressions of the
counsellee. Words have acquired specific meanings through conventional usage
but non-verbal expresslorrs are not understood for lack of a universal code. This
is understandable. IMfierent individuals may rise dissimilar behavioural expressions
to communicate tiielr feelings and meanings. There could be Individual variations

INTRODUCTION
Since counselling is generally considered as a direct one-to-one relation between
the client and the counsellor, it is viewed, as individualistic in its approach. In
recent times, with several cataclysmic changes taking place in society, many
traditional concepts and meanings no longer hold. There have been oemendous
societal pressures and demands such that the one-to-one relation has become
uneconomical and wasteful and may appear to lack social sensitivity and
commitment. In developing countries, for inst^ce, medical services are not available
to a great many people. Opening more training institutions (medical colleges) could
only solve the problem marginally. In the field of counselling also, the available
trained personnel and the demand for competent assistance are alarmingly unrelated.
In this context, group counselling has been thought of as a practical solution.
CASE FOR GROUP COUNSELLING
Renowned therapists like Mesmer, effected their cures in a group setting. It is
argued that in a group setting one could exploit with advantage the group processes
of social facilitation, conformity and suggestion to help promote the therapeutic
process. In a group setting, the individual tends to lose his identity and, therefore,
is less self-conscious and responds more naturally. These and other arguments have
fostered the group approach in counselling in recent times. It also has a gieat
economic appeal. Administrators often turn down proposals on the basis of economic
impracticability. The suggestion of the appointment of a hundred school counsellors
in a district would be viewed with consternation by the management (government)
even though this number may not be adequate to deal with the numbers entering
schools and colleges. One counsellor in a school with two thousand pupils would
be like a drop in the ocean. Granting that as many counsellors as are needed are
appointed the problem of fmding the qualified personnel persists. However, economic
considerations far outweigh professional considerations. There is a psychological
ajqjeal which most protagonists of groiqi guidaince take recourse to. The psychological
appeal derives its substance from the experience of group interaction or interaction
with others which helps develop individual personality. Group interaction helps to
change some attitudes, beliefs, feelings, needs and the lives of individuals in a


--- PAGE 198 ---
178 Counsellingand Guidance
social setting. We know of the bandwagon effect in politics. We also know the
effect of public appeal or consumer appeal on the individual. The experiments of
Asch, Witkin and others have shown that individual perceptions change signiflcantly
in response to group pressures.
There is yet another argument in favour of group counselling. This we may call
the human concern of man towards the members of his society. Great religious
seers and prophets have striven indefatigably to help suffering humanity. Scientists,
explorers and discoverers in their quest to conquer nature have exposed themselves
to imimaginable hazards and subjected themselves to severe privations in the service
of socieQ'. Hippocrates, Socrates and Florence Nightingale have also rendered succour
to humanity. To achieve the goal of relieving suffering, the counsellor should also
strive to give his best to the largest number who need his assistance. This can be
achieved only through the group approach.
emerging field of group counselung
Facerto-face interaction between the counsellee and counsellor has been considered
as counselling in which the counsellor helps in resolving the counsellee's problem(s).
There are practical situations, however, in which a counsellee directly involves
othCT.members who may be his family or members of his group. In such a situationindividual counselling may not be quite effective. Group counselling thus becomes
a practical means of helping to resolve problems by harnessing the social processof group dynamics, social facilitation, and so on. The method offers promising
possibilities of resolving inter-personal conflicts. Group counselling could be lookedu^n as an extension of individual counselling in which free communicationbetween members is encouraged and maintained, leading to an understanding and
evaluation of each others' points of view. Before presenting one's own point of^ew It is necessary to grasp the other person's frame of reference to understand his
feelinp..By this process heated emotions are allowed to cool off,g to a discussion by which differences can be resolved, if not eliminated. In
e ^oup approach the potential negative feelings and emotions concerning other
membere are eliminated from the debate. The practical significance of this approaches m the fact that there is no question of.one member losing and the other member
gaiiung, but is the outcome of consensus or the best solution.
^i^llors are often confronted with individuals with similar problems. They^y d It profitable to arrange for a meeting as a group of all the subjects withim^ ar problems. This method is called group therapy, and it helps if persons
oth^ have difficulties similar to their own. The aims of group counselling
of individual counselling except that there are certain additional11 g features in the former. A conducive environment is created, resistances
are towered and the release of tadividaal tensions is faeiiitated.
roups may differ from one another in many respects. We know of primary and
secondary groups. The distinguishing feature of a primary group is that it usuallytends to be small such that there could be a face-to-face and direct interaction.
Often pnmary groups are defined as comprising members of a family. But it need


--- PAGE 199 ---
Croup Counselling 179
not necessarily be so. The secondary group is a larger group and may seldom have
face-to-face interactions. Further, groups are also defined as in-groups and out-
groups. The in-groups are not always well knit homogeneous groups with a defined
purpose as contrast^ with the out-group. Members who do not belong to the in-
group are perceived as members belonging to the out-group. Groups may have
several heterogenities, for example, the members comprising a family may not all
be of the same age, members comprising a school class may hail from different
socio-economic backgrounds, and so on.
STRUCTURING GROUPS
In counselling, the term 'group' is used with a certain connotation. The groups, in
group counselling are generally small, normally limited to a manageable size of
about six or ten membersTThe second consideration is that all the members in the
group should have similar problems or difficulties requiring assistance. Thus the
counselling group is a homogeneous group with respect to the purpose for which
the members of the group have been assembled. Prior to their meeting one anotho'
at the initial session, the members could be strangers to one another. It is the
Qpunsellor's prerogative to choose the members or the group. The members of a
group have a common goal, namely, to overcome their problem or to find a
solutidn to their problem. The counsellor's approach can be a non-directive one or
a directive one, depending on tne level (age or educational) of the group. If the
group comprises matore clients, the counsellor may take the non-directive approach.
On the other hand, if the members are boys or girls who are relatively immature
the counsellor has to use the directive ^proacH.
It should, however, be recognized that group counselling cannot be resorted to
for any and every kind of problem. Only certain kinds of problems lend themselves
easily to group counselling procedures. For instance, the question of vocational
choice could be treated with advantage employing the group ^proach. A behavioural
modification problem, for example, smoking, could also be treated in a group
setting. But problems conconing deep psychological conflicts may not be amenable
to group techniques.
There is a very significant professional and ethical consideratitm that underlies
this counselling service confidentiality. Clients entrust their confidences and it is
unethical and unprofessional to divulge them. In a group-counselling situation
problems which do not involve questions of confidentiality alone can be treated.
Vocational choice which we alluded to is a very tqipropriate theme. Indeed, it
would be better to treat it in a group setting rather than discuss the vocational
problems and choices of each client individually.
Effective group counselling does not m^ that individual members are allowed
complete freedom. While freedom is necessary to some extent, too much of it may
make some members feel frustrated and disturbed leading to the danger of the
group eventually breaking-up.

UMITATIONS AND ASSUMPTIONS OF GROUP COUNSELLING
Group counselling is not suitable for all subjects and for all situations. It is advisable
not to use it with p^ons who have deep unconscious conflicts. It is not suitable
for psychopaths and subjects with high levels of anxie^. It is not expected to bring
about profound changes in personality structure. It can best be viewed as a kind of
supportive technique for the normal counsellees. An integration of group sessions
with individual sessions has been found effective in many instances.
Group counselling is based on certain assumptions:
The assumption is that individuals should possess the necessary latent capacity
to trust and to be trusted by other group members. They should exhibit a basic
concern for other group members. This permits group cohesion and provides an
atmosphere of support and securi^ for each member of the group to experience and
share individual problems. Lack of trust and feelings of social guilt found among
disruptive adolescents cannot lead to any deep relationships within the group and
such individuals 'cannot become concerned about others. The group counselling
technique is not successful in such cases.
The second assumption about group participation is that "each individual has the
potential to take responsibility for self-change" (Schwartz, 1976). Persons may
exhibit the desire to modify their life styles. Disruptive adolescents perceive their
life styles as fixed and feel powerless to deal with the social environment. They feel
that theirestiaints and control exerted by others leave them with no alternative but
to take ^pcourse to fighting, stealing, deception, etc. They do not accept that something is Y^rong or deficient in themselves and that they must try to rectify it. Rather,
they feel forced into situations in which they are compelled to take certain actions.
The third assumption is that group members can leam and understand from the
objectives and methodology of group processes. Instead of being goal-oriented the
individuals may be impulsive, instead of being interdependent they may act only
out of immediate self-interest, instead of being empathetic they may feel insulated,
instead of accepting their feelings they may disclaim them. In the group approach,
expectations must be dealt with first. The distortations, confusions and ignorance
of the members have to be dispelled. The counsellors' objective should be to
reform them and not to make them conform. The misconceptions must be dealt
with one at a time and cleared to make individual participation free and open.
Didactic instrucdon facilitates affected learning. Dealing with mistrust is important
because mistrust inhibits group cohesiveness. Self-responsibility is focussed as a
primary goal. A decision involves a choice and a denial which sometimes leads to
disappointment The members must be made to accept disappointment as part of
everyday living without being plagued with feelings of guilt. The objective is to
leam that there is always a choice to be made which may mean denying oneself
something else.
The last assumption is learning problem-solving skills. As the members of a
group talk, the leader explains, compares, distinguishes and summarizes. The
group discusses possible solutions and the rationale for each proposed alternative.
The proposed solutions are then discussed in the light of the techniques to be
employed.


--- PAGE 201 ---
Croup Counselling 181
MECHANICS OF GROUP COUNSEUING
In the group setting the subjects meet at em appointed hour. The counsellor would
introduce the members of the group to one another and commences the session with
an opening statement that is aimed at starting the discussion. He could speak of the
importance of vocations and suggest that young people should think deeply and
make an appropriate vocational choice. A member in the group could start with a
statement of his vocational plan. Others would respond by reacting to his plans. He
could ask for suggestions, define his own position and defend his choice, rejecting
suggestions that do not conform to his thinking. In this process, each member of
the group cannot only think aloud but help clarify his own and others' portions as
well. In dealing with academic problems sometimes it may be useful to employ
group techniques. For instance, if the group is considering the problem of study
skills and practices, each person present can benefit from the experience of other
members in the group. This helps identify one's own weaknesses and strengths. It
promotes self-discovery and self-understanding. A counsellor in an individual setting
may spend several hours, during which a client may be put on the defensive such
that he does not see his own weakness but tries to evade it or to explain it away.
Group techniques are best suited to vocational or educational counselling.
In group counselling the size of the groups is usually kept small such that
individual contact and close proximity enable free and effective interaction between
the members of the group. The group counsellor has the primary responsibility of
selecting the members for a group. The criteria normally employed in the selection
of members are: (I) the subjects have a common goal, (2) they belong to the same
age group, (3) they have similar, if not identical, problems and (4) they have a
capacity for self-direction. The other Qpes of groups include guidance groups,
family groups, T-groups, special therapy groups, marathon groups and other special
groups.
TYPES OF GROUPS
The guidance group is usually a group which seeks information. Here the emphasis
is on imparting information. However, there are other views which discount this
suggestion. For example, Bennett (1963) holds that group guidance is not confmed
to the giving of information. It is meant to provide opportunities for learning with
emphasis on self-direction through the provision of assistance and orientation in'
new educational settings for the efficient use of available facilities and opportunities.
Group study of problems of inter-personal relations in school and college life can
modify both individual and group behaviour in socially acceptable ways. Problems
of growing up, making adult adjustments, using the principles of mental hygiene
in living, and appraising personal attitudes, interests, abilities and personality for
better personal and social adjustments, could be dealt with by the group approach.
Group study and the application of efficient methods of learning and group stody
about occupational life and problems of occupational adjustment and progress,
could also be effectively considered by group guidance. In addition, guidance groups


--- PAGE 202 ---
182 CounsefUngandGuidance
are also intended to provide for the therapeutic effects of group procedures (1)
through an understanding of common human problems, (2) the release of emotional
tensions through increased insight into personality dynamics, (3) the objectives of
guidance and how to secure them more economically and effectively than would
be possible in an individual approach, (4) the implementation of individual
counselling and how to make it more effective through background study of common
aspects of problems and the reduction or elimination of many emotional barriers
through the discussion of unique aspects of common human problems.
The above description of group guidance brings it very close to group instruction.
When the teacher is the centre of activities, the term 'group instruction' is more
appropriate. On the other hand, if the emphasis is on the members of the group the
term 'group guidance' is suitable.
GROUP COUNSELLING—ns VALUE
According to Mahler (1969), group counselling is important to:
1. Learn to understand other people and their viewpoints.
2. Develop a deeper respect for other pecqjle, particutoly those who are different
in many ways from oneself.
3. Gam greater social skills in dealing with peers.
4. Learn to share with other people a sense of belonging by participating in
group activities.
5. Clarify one's own concerns, problems, values and ideas through discussion
with others having similar problems in like areas.
In the educational setting group counselling is of great value in:
1. Exploring what it means to be a person—^"Who am I really?" "What do I
want out of life?"
2. Developing greater confidence in one's own perceptions—"I know this is
what I must do, even if my parents do not agree".
3. Learning to understand other pec^jle belter and leaming to really listen to
others—"I can attune myself to what people are saying, what they are really
trying to express. It amazes me that people can feel so differently about the
same experience".
4. Integrating one's feelings and thinking—"I never thought about why...was
behaving the way he did.... Now I can understand him".
5. Be»ming more effective in social situations—'1 am not so afraid of meeting
pet^le and talking with them.
Group counselling helps in re-examining one's present values and trying outnew v^ues—"I always did what I felt like without thinking about others. Now I
appreciate that it is nice to think about others before deciding to do what I want".
It provides a climate for a healthy exploration of feelings and control of them—'1
had so many reservations, never could I be so fiank and express myself, and
promotes leaming how to be more responsible for one's own behaviour—'1 used

to spend so much time fighting every one and had not enough time knowing what
I really wanted to do". It explores one's relationships with other people such as
authority figures, parents, teachws, siblings, peer^r-'l always wondered why people
did not seem to want me for a close fnend, but now I am beginning to undp^rstand
why". For the counsellor, these basic purposes can provide a frame of reference and
