Some of the aims df^ucational guidance are to help the pupil:
1. Choose the curriculum which suits his/her abilities, interests and aspirations
or goals optimally.
2. Acquire efficient study habits and practices which would enable him/her to
achieve desirable levels of academic success.
3. Develop special interests and talents outside the academic field since the
demands of life could be myriad and confusing.
4. Understand the purpose of education and the functions of school in relation
to his/her needs.
5. Develop his/her potentialities in areas in which he/she is interested.
6. Develop vocational interests and an urge to work in the chosen vocation.
7. Enjoy his/her life at school through happy and rewarding inter-personal
relationships with teachers and other pupils.
Educational counselling is a continuous process. Each pupil must be helped to
adjust himself to the world of his academic work and its demands by developing
desirable curricular interests and worthy life goals, cultivating efficient work habits,
sound study skills and jracti^, fostering desirable inter-personal relations, securing
satisfactory mental health and acquiring a high sense of morale.
Pupil f^lure is a serious concern of counselling. Teachers ofteii refer pupils with
unsatisfactory academic grades to counsellors. But other pupils can also be
significantly helped. Counselling is the most important agency which can help
young people develop into normal and healthy individuals who are emotionally
mature and who can make significant contributions to their communities.
.At this level pupils have to be given vocational guidance to enable them to
prepare themselves to choose an appropriate occupation and to progress in it. All
educational guidance implies vocation^ guidance also.
COUNSELLING AT COLUGE
A total counselling programme at the collegiate level would comprise an extension
of the various services provided to the pupils at the earlier stages of their lives. The
collegiate student is for all practical purposes an adult with no adult responsibilities.
The objectives of higher education include the development of (1) a sound philosophy
of life, (2) an ability to enjoy life in many areas, (3) sensitivity to the different
aspects of the environment and (4) the capacity to be free-willed individuals, that
is, individuals who appreciate freedom.as being inescapable from responsibility.
Higher education aims to make them creative and constructive individuals.
Counselling service at the collegiate level is fairly comprehensive.
1. It is the culmination of the guidance the pupil receives at all the lower
school levels.
2. It emphasizes constructive self-guidance among students in meeting adult
responsibilities.


--- PAGE 227 ---
Guidance and Counselling In the EducaOomil Setting 207
3. It provides necessary assistance to overcome academic and social deficiencies
and thus helps to enrich their lives.
4. Another equally important activity is to develop healthy vocational and
professional interests among the students. Usually the students are encouraged
to visit the student counselling bureaux, as often as necessary, and feel free
to seek assistance. The kind of assistance provided is multi-dimensional—
health, residential, fmancial, social, recreational, vocational, academic and
placement assistance.
Counselling service for adults comprises a follow-up service which may help
counsellees secure contintiing education and assistance for personal and occupational
adjustments.
Counselling is thus a continuous and pervasive process of assisting people to
become more efficient, adjusted and happy. Counselling service comprises giving
information and help towards understanding oneself as well as others, such that
individuals are able to act freely, independently and be responsible for their own
choices and actions. Special counselling assistance could be provided in a variety
of fields like employment, education, social life, finance and personal adjustment.
Under each of the major areas listed above, counselling services may help provide
relevant assistance in (1) choosing a curriculum, learning and developing efficient
methods of study and seeking necessary remedial assistance in the field of educational
counselling and (2) pre-employment activities and job placement services in the
field of vocation^ counselling.
Motivation is the key to learning and it is in the matter of motivation perhaps
that counselling is in a better position than the other aspects of the school/college
programme to make an effective contribution. Motivation is a link between feeling
and thinking. Counselling aims at forging this link by helping to crystallize feelings
by giving them expression, direction and intellectual substance. If academic failure
is to be forestalled or academic standards improved, it is' imperative that counselling
assistance be provided and relevant values inculcated to stimulate the academic
and cultural aspirations of students (Rao, 1967).
The entire course and process of education is punctuated with significant
psychological issues. These have to be attended to if educational objectives are to
be realized . One of the first steps consists in the selection and admission of
students to educational institutions. What criteria have to be used in selecting them
for admission? It is a imiversally accepted fact that pupils differ from one another
with regard to abilities, interests, attitudes, aspirations and home and social
backgrounds. Questions such as, "Should the pupils know as much significant
material as is available regarding their curricula?" "What kind of activities are
required?" "Do the pupils have the necessary background training?" "Are
they really interested in the subject matter?" "What is its value to them?" are
relevant .
The choice of subjects is more fiequently made by the parents than by,the
children. Counsellors could discuss with parents questions such as those concerning
the choice of subjects for their children. '•
Another important area crucial to scholastic success is the stiidy skills and practice
of the pupils. Most student failures can be traced to faulty or inappropriate study


--- PAGE 228 ---
208 Counselling and Guidance
^Us. Improvement of these can help to a large extent in pupil progress. A related
area of vital importance is the area of interpersonal relations. A pupil who believes
that his teachers bear a grudge against him or that they are prejudiced against him
will And himself in an alienated and un-congenial atmosphere. A student will also
be greatly handicapped if he considers his fellow students unsympathetic and hostile.
Poor inter-personal relations may lead to his becoming withdrawn and pessimistic
and may sometimes lead to feelings pf inferiority. Another significant area concerns
the mental health of the learner. If a pupil is listless, worried, anxious, obsessed and
harassed by a host of problems—real or imaginary, his efforts to read are seriously
undermined. Educational guidance addresses itself to most of the above problems.
The area of educational .counselling is broadly divided into three sub-areas. The
Arst deals with the appraisal of the strengths and weaknesses of the learner through
administering objective tests and discussing these in the light of his choices, ambitions
and aspirations. This is aimed at providing a proper choice of curriculum and
leading to curricular adjustment The second concerns identifying the strengths and
weaknesses of the study skills and providing the necessary remedial services. The
third concerns resolving personal problems and improving inter-personal relations,
leading to better mental health.
The impact of education on each individual pupil at school and later in his life
depends upon several factors. The most important of these are usually identified as
the meaningfulness of educational programmes, the effectiveness of the instruction
and the motivation of the learners. Educational counselling as a service is expected
to support educational efforts to yield rich dividends in pupil adjustment and progress.
It is a process of helping leamers to understand themselves and the world around
them, to adjust themselves more efficiently and appropriately to other fellow beings.
Counselling, therefore, should be viewed as an integral part of the total school/
college programme. Some of the several functions of counselling are:
1. The appraisal service to assess objectively the potential of pupil—academic,
vocational, personality—by utilizing a variety of personal, psychological
and social data.
2. The information service to provide acctiraie, up-to-date, exhaustive and
reliable knowledge in educational, vocational and social fields so that students
are able to mate better choices and take wiser decisions.
3. The counselling service to help provide assistance towards self-understanding
and development through face-to-face and small group relationships.
4. The planning, placement and follow-up service designed to increase
vocatic^ development by facilitating students to choose and utilize
at^ropriate employment opportunities.
5. The evaluation service to provide feedback information for the benefit of
the school/college administration and the community at large.
The essential theme of counselling is the understanding of the personal experiences
of pupils in all their variety, depth and intensity in terms of the opportunities
available and the choices open to them. For this, it is necessary that die pupils
recognize their strengths and weaknesses and interpret them realistically. Counselling
is a disdnct product of the American educadonal system and it is universally


--- PAGE 229 ---
Guidance and Counselling In die Educadonal Setdng 209
accepted that in no other country has this movement developed to the extent it has
in the USA. The necessary conditions and proper atmosphere were present for the
rapid growth of the counselling movement The most important factors that influenced
its course were: (1) the U.S. Federal government support to the guidance movement
in a big way by providing precious funds and also by enacting the necessary
legislative measures to provide for guidance in the educational institutions, (2) the
psychometric movement which helped guidance personnel to be able to objectively
assess pupils' strengths and limitations and (3) the growing awareness among
educators and public-spirited men of the need to assist school pupils to make proper
educational and vocational choices. The principles basic to guidance are provided
by the work of Miller, Gribbons, Beck, Wrenn and Kehas. The general principles
of value for the practice of counselling in school are;
1. Counselling is concerned primarily and systemadcally with the person^
development of the pupils.
2. The approach and the technique to be adopted depend on the individual's
behaviour.
3. Counselling is oriented towards cooperation between the pupil and the
counsellor and is not a compulsive predetermined process.
4. The counsellor firmly recognizes individual worth and dignity and one's
right to choose and to make decisions.
5. Counselling, in its essence, is an educational process. It is, to be more
appropriate, an essential dimension of education.
6. Counselling in school should never be treated as an emergency reaction
pattern but as continuous, sequential and programmatic.
ihe^(5leOF TEACHERS IN COUNSELLING
In the school settings in India teachers are the primary guidance personnel. They
render non-professional assistance to pupils which may be of some help. In the
advaiKed countries, most school systems have accredited couitselling programmes
provided by the personnel on the staff of the schools. Most schools have school
psychologists to assist teachers in their work with pupils. The purpose of providing
counselling swvices, in the words of Rogers (1962), "is to enhance the pasonal
development and psychological growth toward a socialized maturity of its clients".
Arbuckle (1963) states the following functions of school counsellors in elementary
and secondary schools:
1. The counsellor helps emotionally disturbed children to arrive at h^pier and
satisfying solutions to their problems.
2. The counsellor helps children with their academic difficulties.
3. The counsellor is concerned with preventive and remedial measures. At the
elementary school level there is particular stress on the preventive and
developmental aspects so that there may be less need for remedial work
later on.
4. The counsellor cooperatively works with teachers to help them gain a greater
understanding of the pupils in their classes.


--- PAGE 230 ---
210 Giunselllng and Guidance
5. The counsellor helps parents obtain a better understanding and appreciation
of their children.
6. The counsellor uses appropriate test devices for diagnosis and counselling
purposes.
7. The counsellor maintains extensive and up-to-date records concerning pupils
for whom he is responsible.
8. The secondary school counsellor spends much of his time helping suidents
to make wise decisions regarding college courses or jobs.
9. The secondary school counsellor aids needy sUidcnts to obtain assistance.
10. All school counsellors work closely with other specialized personnel.
The nature of the responsibilities of the school counsellor suggests two major
roles—counselling and consulting.
The counselling ro/e—Th'e counsellor directly deals with students on matters
concerning emotional problems, self-understanding, decision-making, educational
and vocational planning, etc.
The consulting ro/e—The counsellor works with teachers, parents, educational
specialists and administrators on matters involving student understanding and student
management
The teachers' ro/e—Several writers, such as Roeber, Smith, Erickson, Humphreys,
Traxler and North believe that teachers should be expected to perform counselling
duties.Mathewson (1962) slates, 'Teachers engage in appraisal of pupil characteristics,
adjustment of behaviour, evaluation of individual performance, etc., and may even
undertake some individual counselling. To the extent that these functions are
performed professionally, teachers are participating in guidance practice".
But these can only comprise a set of restricted functions of teachers. Most
teachers put in considerable effort to cater to individual differences and to assist
pupils to participate in cooperative teacher-pupil planning.
In addition to the above, teachers are expect^ to help in the counselling services
through:
1. Studying and diagnosing children.
2. Identifying and referring pupils neediiig special assistance.
3. Preparing and maintaining guidance records.
4. Helping pupils develop effective study habits.
5. Contributing to pupils' educational and vocational planning and placement.
Wrenn (1962) has summarized the following principles from the personnel point
of view in education:
1. Guidance in education is given upon seeing the learner totally.
2. The philosophy of guidance axiomatically believes in the dignity and Integrity
of the student and his right to self-fulfilment.
3. Guidance should assist the student's plans for the future as well as enhance
the possibility of his living optimally in (he present.
4. Guidance is the prime advocate of individual differences in school. These
differences are to be recogiiized, taken advantage of and provided with
suitable conditions for their full expression.


--- PAGE 231 ---
Guidance and Counselling In the Educational SetOng 211
5. Guidance should take advantage of the variety of methods available and
choose the appropriate one for the pupil to deal with the task on hand.
6. The quality of the relationship established between the guidance worker and
the pupil and between the guidance worker and the teacher is of importance.
7. Guidance services must form part of the central stream of the educational
effort.
EDUCATIONAL COUNSELLING AND CURRICULUM
The school curriculum is a systematic organization of courses of study and activities
designed to further students* knowledge and competencies. Several types of cunicula
such as general, business and vocational, and industrial arts are offered at the
school level in the West In India curricular openings are relatively few with little
choice afforded to pupils. The curriculum is designed to help the individual pupil
achieve his potentialities and become capable of self-direction. Educational
counselling is aimed at enhancing the effectiveness with which the pupil profits
from the curriculum. Guidance is also used in the context of helping the pupil
acquire efficient learning skills and practices.
The systematic planning of curricular opportunities helps the pupil by providing
experiences which strengthen the feelings of adequacy and belongingness. The
curricular activities also provide exploratoiy avenues though which pupils develop
their interests and abilities. The curricular experiences contribute to the knowledge
necessary for educational and vocational planning. Educational counselling
contributes to curriculum development in a number of ways, one of which is to
make the goals of curricular activities congment with the needs of pupils. Another
way in which it helps is to enable testing, planning follow-up and other counselling
activities to contribute to curricular development, and yet another is to enable the
counsellors assist the individual pupil to understand and to choose difierent courses
to suit his requirements and develop social and vocational competencies needed for
successful living in a complex society. Educational counselling also assists
administration in a significant way. The educational .administrator is interest in
the effective functioning of the school/college and counselling helps in realizing
this goal in a mote effective manner. However, it should be borne in mind that
counselling is primarily concerned with the achievement of individual goals.
Several factors interfere with the effective programmes in schools and colleges.
The major areas of friction lie in the differences between the stated promises and
the i^actices adopted. The public in general, and administrators in particular, do not
understand the functions of counselling. The administrators naturally demand that
the guidance workers help them even when this may clash with the interests of the
individual students.
The counselling personnel expect the administrators to provide the necessary
facilities for the effective organization of counselling services and look forward to
sympathetic assistance from the administrators. They expect them to take a positive
interest in counselling programmes.
The administrators, on the other hand, expect the counselling personnel to serve


--- PAGE 232 ---
212 Cotmselllng and Cujdanee
the interests of administration. Often this causes much tension and friction between
the counsellors and administrators. The administrators expect counsellors to handle
the discipline of the institution and to minimize disciplinary problems. The
counsellors believe that such problems could be minimi^ through organizing
extra-curricular activities and encouraging student interests which would provide
suitable, avenues for their expression as well as their cultivation. The counsellors
believe, and rightly so, that a knowledge of students, an understanding of their
problems and the optimum use of educational and preventive measures could
significantly assist in countering indiscipline and thus help the insdtutional climate.
COUNSELLING AND HOME
The impact of the home environment on the individual pupil is of great significance
for school/college learning. The findings reported of Elmtown's youth are of great
interest for educationists as well as counsellors. The pupil/student benefits from
school/college if the school and home complement each other in educating and
socializing the pupil. Most learning problems arise from poor home conditions and
lack of understanding on the part of par^ts as well as teachers. Counsellors could
render yeoman service by helping parents and teachers understand their children
and pupils better. Counsellors could also help the pupils gain better understanding
of their own needs, aspirations and cravings and help them plan their educational
and vocational goals.
Educational counselling could also help harness community resources for the
development of youth through optimal referral services.
EVALUATION OF PROGRAMMES OF EDUCATIONAL COUNSUUNG
1. One of the important criteria of a good system is a desirable counsellor
student ratio. As counselling involves both Individual contact with most
pupils and long term contxt with some pupils in need of counselling
assistance, the counsellor-student ratio must be reasonable.
2. The counsellors should'be qualified for their positions. They should be
personally inclined and professionally prepared to be counsellors. A master's
degree in counselling is an essential qu^ification.
3. Necessary physical facilities should be available.
4. Adequate financial support should be provided.
5. The personnel should be self-evaluative and research oriented.
6. Counselling services should be available throughout the academic year and
throughout the pupils' academic lives.
7. Counselling services should provide for the appraisal of students and help
them to adjust, plan and develop.
8. Updated informational materials should be available and accessible.
9. Necessary records should be maintained which could be used to help pupils'
self-understanding and development.


--- PAGE 233 ---
Guidance and Counselling In the Educational Setting 213
Counselling services are based on client needs, for example, in an educational
setting the student needs to understand himself, know his personal characteristics,
understand environmental conditions, orient himself to present and future situations,
develop personal potentialities, etc. School/college counselling centres should provide
appraisal, planning, information and counselling services. The efficiency of the
services depends on the balance among corrective, preventive and developmental
functions.
Limitations Inherent In Evaluation
1. School counselling personnel do not have time for evaluation.
2. They are not trained to conduct evaluative studies.
3. Owing to the lack of belter techniques and tools, most of them depend upon
subjective approaches to determine the adequacy of their services.
4. The necessary data for evaluation is often not available.
5. The required funds for evaluation are not available.
6. The administration is not very keen about evaluation.
7. Hie necessary cooperation from the teaching personnel, administration and
parents is often difficult to enlist.
SUMMARY
Counselling In the educational context comprises a very Important and vital part
of educational activities. Many students at dlRerent levels of education have
been found to function at levels far below their capacities. Counselling assistance
would certainly help to brighten the lives of many young people.
Counselling Is Indeed an Important dlinenslon of education. It promotes
emotional maturity, personality development, self-responslblllty, creativity and
eiblllty to solve problems. In the complex contemporary world, counselling Is
rapldb' becoming an Important part of the educational structure. The administration
has to take a positive attitude towards counselling and pixwlde the required
facilities to the counsellors to function optimally.
Home and community resources should be nreanlngfully harnessed for the
counselUng needs of pupils/students. The main brunt of covinselllng responsibilities
win fall on the teachers, at least In the schools. They need the necessary training
for acquiring the necessary skills. They have to cultivate a healdiy attitude
towards counselUng. Counselling programmes need to be evaluated horn time
to time. The specialist skills for rriaklng objective evaluations are generally not
available with the teachers or even with some trained counsellors. However, tire
Importance and need for evaluation cannot be underestimated.

C. VOCATIONAL GUIDANCE
INTRODUCTION
Qrtie recognition of the fact that education should equip the individual to enter anoccupation and be able to make a living, makes vocational counselling an integral
part of the educational process. Thus counselling in the educational setting cannot
be comprehensively and purposefully rendered without including counselling towards
vocational development Therefore, educational and vocational counselling are
topther provided to both school and college-going students.^(We may recall that the counselling movement had its origin in the vocational
guidance movement Thus it was the forerunner of counselling psychology. A few
years before the end of the last century, Jessie B. Davis (1898) started this movementj)
He set up an Educational Career Counselling Centre in Detroit in 1898. Within a
decade after'this pionieering venture, Eli Weaver (1907) published his book Choosing
a Career in 1908 and Frank Parsons started the Vocatioij^^ureau of-Boston.
Later, his book Choosing a Vocation was published. The^eftect the early interestof educators and social workers in the vocational development of youth.^C^The choice of a career is undeniably one of the most crucial decisions one makes
in iife.jThe irony is that such an important decision is often made quite early in the
life of an individual and is sometimes made without giving as much thought to it
as is often given to such things as buying a necktie or a pair of shoes, ^he choice
of work determines how an individual's time is going to be spent, what type of
people he will associate with, what kind of place he will have to work and liv6 in
and a host of such very important things. Naturally a career should be chosen with
utmost care, thought and planning. Often in the matter of vocational choice, an
individual may find himself unequal to the task, or in a dilemma to choose one or
the other, or be totally in the dark. All such individuals require assistance called
vocational counselling. If vocational counselling were made an integral part of the
total educational process, it would be most meaningful, helpful and useful to the
individual. It will be helpful if the counsellor is knowledgeable and has the necessary
information concerning how individuals develop vocationally. Such information, if
available to the counsellor in the process of counselling, mak^ the choosing of a
career easier and simpler.
THEORIES OF VOCATIONAL DEVELOPMENT
Each counsellor has a set of assumptions that guide his actions in the pursuit of his
role as a vocational counsellor. The set of assumptions which guide his actions
comprise his 'theory' of vocational development. Several theories of vocational
development exist and a systematic attempt to classify them on the basis of their
similarities or otherwise is useful.
Herr and Cramer (1972) have suggested a working classification of vocational
development theories:


--- PAGE 235 ---
Culdance and CounseiUng In the Educadonal Setting 215
The trait-and-factor or actuarial theory emphasizes the individual's innate abilities
and acquired interests and their relation to the demands of the different wori:
situations.
Starting with the tradition of Parsons, Paterson, Darley and Williamson (1920)
developed the trait-and-&ctor approach at Minnesota. The underlying thesis of this
approach is very simple. According to it, individuals have different innate capacities,
abilities and aptitudes for different kinds of work. In vocational guidance, the
purpose is to match the individual and the occupation optimally for mutual benefit
This view is based on the psychometric tradition. There are a number of issues that
this theory fails to explain. For instance, two individuals with different abili^
patterns may enter upon a single occupation but may progress differently and may
have different levels of job satisfaction. Further, this theory takes the static and
somewhat rigid point of view that individuals fit into specific jobs and would be
like fish out of water if they found themselves in different kinds of jobs. This was
based on the commonsense approach of 'putting square pegs in square holes', that
is, fitting individuals into appropriate jobs. It is increasingly being realized from the
experiences of several people that an individual, on taking up a job which is not
to his liking and yet is helpless to get out of it. would in the course of time adjust
himself and not remain frustrated for the rest of his life. This suggests that a square
peg in a round hole will not remain square all the time. Its angularities will get
rounded. Further, there are several thousands of occupations. The Ministry of Labour,
US Government, for example, has listed not less than 40,000 occupational titles in
its prestigeous publication Dictionary of Occupational Titles (DOT}. In India also,
the Ministry of Labour in the National Classification of the Occupations (NCO) lists
over 10,000 jobs. The number of occupations can never remain static. New
occupations are ever on the increase. Some occupations are becoming obsolescent
and are disappearing. Therefore, fitting individuals into jobs (yet to evolve or likely
to disappear) is becoming increasingly difficult
The decision theory holds that individuals consider various alternatives and decide
on the one which promises satisfaction. This does not, however, mean that the
altonatives are rationally or dispassionately considered.
The sociological theory emphasizes sociological factors which influence individual
development and vocational choice. For example, one's social status, social group,
conventions, etc., exert an influence on one's vocational choice. A young man
hailing from the upper class of society would not like to choose an occupation
associated with the lower class of society.
The psychological theory holds that vocational choice is affected by the
individual's personality structure, his early experiences, motivations and needs.
"Uie developmental theory emphasizes that vocational choice is not a static
decision, but that it is a process subject to continuous pressures for modification
and adaptation. Most vocational choice theories stress developmental factors in the
individual's life experience. Environmental factors affect young people by providing
or denying them opportunities for their growth. The individual has some amount of
freedom' of choice. Super, Ginzberg, 'fiedeman and others subscribe to this point
of view. Others, like Flanagan, Crites, Gribbons, Lohnes.'Samler and Beilin, also
hold developmental points of view. Anne Roe, Holland,-Hoppock and others stress


--- PAGE 236 ---
216 Counselling and Guidance
psychological needs to be of paramount importance in determining choice.
Psychoanalytically oriented thinkers like Bordin, Nachmann and Segal explain
vocational development in terms of personality dynamics. Miller and Form,
HolUngshead, Blau and others emphasize sociological factors, such as the influence
of the home, school, community, etc., in vocational choice. (Tolbert, 1974).
The decision theory has profoundly influenced vocational development theories.
Decision-making stresses that the need for information, self-knowledge, and
perception of rewards and deterrents is of prime importance in making decisions.
Gelatt, Hilton, Hershenson and Roth contribute to this view.
There is yet another point of view which may be identified as the existential
view. Simon and Standley have stressed fulfilling potentialities and experiencing
responsibility as major factors in relating vocational choice to 'becoming'.
It is neither practicable to consider the several theories in any detail nor is it our
piupose to do so. What is sought is to present an overview to help.appreciate the
need for vocational counselling at different life stages of the individual.
Super's approach is often labelled as "...differential—development^—social—
phenomenological psychology". He stresses four aspects, namely, vocational life
stages, vocational maturity, translating the self-concept into vocational self-concept
and career patterns. The vocational development of the individual is an aspect of
the total development which is affected by one's psychological and physiological
attributes as influenced by environmental conditions. Super (1953) formulates ten
propositions which comprise his theory of vocational development The propositions
in brief are:
1. Individuals differ with regard to their abilities, interests and personality
attributes.
2. They are capable of entering a number of occupations by virtue of their
abilities, interests, etc.
3. Different occupations require different pauems of abilities, interests and
traits.
4. The preferences of people for different vocations change with their self-
concepts which are modified with time and experience. This makes choice
and adjustment a continuous process.
5. This process of adjustment involves a series of life stages which are identified
as growth, exploration, establishment, maintenance and decline. In each of
these stages there can be periods corresponding to fantasy, tentative and
realistic aspects and the trial and stable phases which make up the establish
ment change.
6. The career pattem of the individual is determined by^veral factors, important
among which are parents, socio-economic conditions, intelligence, personality
and available opportunities.
7. Vocational development can be guided by assisting the maturation of abilities
and interests and providing for rwlity testing.
8. Vocational development essentially consists in implementing a self-concept
which develops as a result of the interaction between the subjective factors
and the environmental conditions.


--- PAGE 237 ---
Guidance and Counselling In die Educadonal Setting 217
9. The process of compromise involves role playing either in imaginary
situations or in real life situations.
10. Satisfaction fiom work is dependent on the extent to which the individual
is able to find expression for his abilities, interests, personality traits and
values. Work satisfaction also depends on the work situation.^
Super's theory helps in understanding the developmental concerns of young
people.
Ginzberg's theory of occupadonal choice is also a developmental theory, according
to which individuals move through a series of stages and the process of occupational
choice is influenced by the individual's attributes, educational background and
situadonal constraints. The movement of the individual through the various stages
is irreversible. An option once made caimot be undone. Ginzberg identified the
fantasy, the tentadve, the transidonal and the realisdc stages in the process. Ginzberg
later modified his theory in certain aspects (1970,1972). Irreversibility, which was
an important concept, was downgraded. This was owing to the recognidon of the
fact that the process of vocadonal choice extends over a much longer period of
time. Ginzberg subsdtutes 'opdmizadon' for compromise as a strategy in occupadonal
choice. The constraints are given a more important place and considerable weight
is attached to them in the revised theory. The opportunity, structure and value
orientadon were also given more emphasis.
Tiedeman and O'Hara's career development theory defines the process as building
a vocadonal identity through differentiation and integration. The theory identifies
foiu* steps: (1) the anticipation phase, involving the exploration of goals, past
experiences, abilities etc., (2) the crystallization phase which concerns values, goals,
etc., (3) the opting for a particular choice which follows crystallization of goals and
values, and (4) clarification which concludes the differentiation phase of decision-
making.
The individual enters the second phase of implementation and adjustment.
He puts his plans into effecL The three sub-steps included in this process are
(1) induction, that is, entry into the situation, (2) reformation as a result of the
individual's experience of the situation in which he enters (reformation consists of
responding to and adjusting to the environmental changes) and (3) integration,
which is a balance between the individual's needs and the demands of the situation.
Anne Roe's theory of career development is very closely related to Maslow's
personalia theory, llie theory is stated in a set of propositions:
1. Genetic inheritance is important It sets limits to potential development
2. The development of inherited characteristics are affected by unique
experiences, cultural background and socio-economic factors.
3. The pattern of development of interests, attitudes and personality is
detranined by the individual's experience. The direction of development is
detCTmined by early satisfactions and frustrations. The mode and degree of
the satisfaction of individual needs determine which of the needs become
D.E. Super, "A theory of Vocational Development", American Psychologist, 1953, 8,
pp. 189-190.


--- PAGE 238 ---
218 Counselling and Guidance
the strongest motivating factors and which do not. The pattern of psychic
energies is the major determinant of interests. The intensity of the needs and
their satisfaction determine the de^ee of motivation.
Holland identifies six occupational environments—realistic, intellectual, social,
conventional, enterprising and artistic. Each environment involves levels similar to
Roe's. Hoppock's theory is known as the composite theory which vocational
counsellors are greatly concerned with. Hoppock explains that a specific occupation
is,chosen on the basis of the belief that it will best meet one's needs. Needs may
be vaguely felt or clearly understood, in eithCT case, they influence choices.
Vocational development starts with the awareness that an occupation can meet
one's needs. It progresses till one's needs are fulfilled. Knowledge about oneself
affects occupational choices. Information ^ut occupations also helps in the choice
of occupations.
The psychoanalytical theory of vocational development emphasizes the following:
1. There is a continui^ of human development from infancy to the adult years.
2. Instinctual Oibidinous) sources of ^tification are the same for all—adults
or childr^.
3. An individual's pattern of needs is determined in the first six years. The
needs may be modified only to a slight extent.
4. The occupation one seeks to enter is determined by the needs developed in
the first six years.
5. The theory applies to all ages and all levels and all types of work. However,
it does not apply to those who are restricted or motivated by external factors
and to those who can find no satisfaction in work.
6. Work represents the sublimation of infantile impulses into socially accepted
channels. Lack of knowledge concerning occupations may result in the
choice of wrong occupations, that is, one which does not fulfil one's
expectations.
7. All jobs are described in terms of psychoanalytical needs.
Sociological theories stress economic and sociological factors in job choice. All
theories stress the importance of natural ^dowment, physical conditions and social
strucUire in determining personalia development through education, socialization,
etc., and also influencing social mobility, shifts in industrial requirements, etc.
These together constitute the socio-psychological and socio-economic factors.
The socio-psychological factors govern the immediate determinants ofjob choice
based on occupational information, occupational demands, etc. The socio-economic
organization determines the available opportunities in the world of work. The
subjective personality factors, socio-psychological attitudes, prejudices, status, etc.,
and one's own occupational and technical qualifications determine vocational
preference. Further, the socio-economic factors affect the standards of selection
practices. A harmonious relation between them results in occupational entry.
All decision-making theories stress the importance of decision-making in
vocational choice and development. Past experiences are also important for decision-
making.
A step-wise process of decision-making is given below.


--- PAGE 239 ---
Guidance and Counselling In the EducadonaJ Setting 219
Purpose or objective; data collection; possible alternatives; likely outcomes;
desirability of outcomes; evaluation of a decision leading to either terminal decision,
the outcome of which has to be checked against the purpose or objective or
investigatory decision which has to be checked against the data and does not lead
to any outcome. In this system, value and utility play important roles. ThK'e is
naturally an element of risk in decision making.
Hilton's theory stresses that the recognition of dissonance leads to decision-
making. The individual thinks that an occupation has more unattractive than attractive
features and since the dissonance level is high, he is convinced that the decision to
choose to enter it will not be satisfactory. He feels the need to reduce the level of
dissonance in his life. A consideration of some of the representative theories leads
to certain common, universally accepted principles which are:
1. Uniqueness of the individual and his traits, interests and abilities.
2. Interaction of the individual with the situation which determines his
developmenL
3. Career development begins early and continues throughout the life of the
individual.
4. Career development involves growth and synthesis of the self and
environment.
There are stages in career development which largely reflect psychological,
physiological, sociological and economic factors.
Career development involves the making of increasingly responsible choices.
The choice of a career is based on (1) subjective factors, namely, values, (2)
occupational opportunities, (3) the degree of expectadon the individu^ has of being
accepted and (4) the expectadon of sadsfacdon.
The dirccdon and level of career choice are guided by familial and cultural
factors.
Career maturity is revealed through an organized set of behaviour and atdtudes
that help meet the demands of the situadon successfully. It involves making one's
own choices and one's willingness to take responsibility for them.
SUMMARY
A number of theories of vocatlortal development have been proposed. Each
theory stresses one point of view and thus does not explain the complex
process In Its totally. For the vocational counsellor the various theories of
vocational development provide useful points of departure. Since his clients
come from different cultural backgrounds and hold dIRierent views no single
theory can satlsfoctorlly explain the complex process of vocational choice.
THE PROCESS OF VOCATIONAL COUNSELUNG
Vocational counselling is a process which can be found in operation in diffident
settings and under different conditions of work. The main thrust of vocational


--- PAGE 240 ---
220 Counselling and Guidance
counselling is on vocational planning. Vocational planning detennines cumcular
choices and provides the necessary motivation for scholastic achievement Therefore,
vocational counselling in its true sense operates alongside educational counselling.
They play mutually complementary roles. However, vocational counselling may be
offered in situations outside the school and college, as the process aims at providing
vocational orientation. The situation is essentially a learning situation and is best
found to function in a non-authoritarian setting. More often than not. the process
of vocational counselling is oriented to the future such that the counsellce is able
to plan and implement new techniques for meeting future problems. In vocational
counselling ^ere is need to reduce the anxiety of the counsellee regarding his
vocational problems but psychopathology is not involved. The vocational counsellor
aims at enabling the counsellee to adopt more positive attitudes and become more
realistic in the estimation of his assets and liabilities. Psychotherapy has some
relation to vocational counselling but psychotherapy is seldom achieved through
vocational counselling.
Before the vocational counsellor proceeds with the process of helping the
counsellee there is need to establish rapport through accepting and understanding
each other's role and objectives. The counsellor would require an objective appraisal
of the counsellee's abilities, aptitudes, interests, likes and aspirations. He may use
the objective data along with the information obtained in the interview sessions to
help the counsellee understand his vocational goals. It could become necessary to
make the counsellee realize the inappropriateness of his vocational goals but this
does not necessarily mean that the counsellor would discourage the counsellee from
persisting in his vocational plans. The vocational counselling process essentially
involves flexibility and change. If the counsellor is able to help the counsellee
appraise his own abilities in an objective manner, the latter himself would change
his vocational plans. This is what is meant by flexibility. On the other hand, if the
counsellee were to doggedly persist with his myopic plans it would only reflect his
irrationality. One of the important articles of faith of all counsellors is their belief
in the rationality of individuals and their capacity to make intelligent choices and
meaningful decisions.
The non-authoritarian nature of the counselling situation provides for a free
atmosphere in which counselling can function effecdvely. After all, the job of the
counsellor is not to make a choice and impose it on the counsellee. Often counsellees
make wrong choices owing to false self-perceptions and inadequate appraisal of
their own abilities. It is one of the functions of the counsellor to help the counsellee
gmn insight into himself.
The other important fimction of a vocational counsellor is to provide complete
career information. It is only after considering the occupational infoimation that the
counsellee can make vocational plans. Shartle (1951) holds, "the role of vocational
information as a part of counselling pitx^s is an important one...the counsellor's
appraisal of the individual who is making a vocation^ choice must be in terms of
the vocational alternatives".
The counsellor must facilitate optimal confrontation with minimal anxiety when
approached by a client who is at a transition point in his vocational career.


--- PAGE 241 ---
Guidance and Counselling In the EducatJonal Setting ZZl
EXPLORATION AND CONTRACT SETTING
It is necessary for the vocational counsellor to proceed with great care as he has
to tread a fine line between two major limitations. The first limitation is that the
client may have a very restricted set regarding what is relevant to his choice. The
other limitation arises from the counsellor's efforts to counteract this restricted set
by appropriately offering therapeutic help.
The personal issues involved in the choice of a vocation raise questions about
a person's capabilities. An individual's thoughts and feelings are related to his
reactions and observations of himself. He imagines himself in an occupation by
eliciting such reactions which serve to establish his needs and desires and his
anxieties about fulfilling them. The counsellor must keep in mind the developmentally
based conflicts that might be provoked by the choice of a particular vocation.
THE STATE OF CRITICAL DECISION
The examination of an individual who is desperate about choosing an occupation
will reveal an internal struggle for growth and change. The counsellor must be
cautious in making explicit statements regarding his choice.
Counselling for limited goals is conducted by keeping the realistic problems in
focus and directing attention to a strategically select conflict. The ideas that are
relevant to vocational identity have to be kept as a central theme in working
towards change. If the client opts for change, the counsellor has to decide whether
he is competent enough to perform his role in the change process.
The developmental model establishes a close link between personality develop
ment and career development which provides a basis for eliminating the dichotomy
between vocational and personal counselling without substituting one for the other.
The simplest of the theories was propounded by Ginzberg in 1951 at Columbia
University. According to him there are four major stages in the vocational
development of an individual. In the early years of childhood there is the stage of
'no choice*. A little later the child is able to say what occupation he would like to
pursue. And every time he is asked he gives a new answer. There is no definiteness
in his choice (Rao, 1968). This state is called the fantasy stage. Next, the child
enters the 'trial and error' stage and finally the stage is one of stabilization. Thus
we have in terms of the psychological processes, a definite explanation afforded for
the choice of an occupation. Persons do not enter occupations accidentally or
impulsively. Occupational choice usually has a long history in the life history of an
individual. In Ginzberg's (1951) theory, during the period of *no choice* which
ccffresponds to the 'period of latency', the child is largely preoccupied with his own
body and his immediate environment When he grows up to the pre-puberty stage,
he 1^ certain interests which widen as he enters the post-puberty stage. Depending
upon the strength of each interest that is operative at a given moment, he may
choose the vocation that is supposed to satisfy his interest This is the fantasy
stage. He soon grows up to outlive this stage. Next is the tentative stage in which
he considers his capabilities with a certain amount of realism. There are other


--- PAGE 242 ---
^99 Counselling and Guidance
sub-periods in this stage, namely, the value stage, that is. he tries to think of
entering an occupation that is valued high by his community such that he would be
recognized by his society. Next comes the transition stage which roughly corresponds
with the terminal stage of his school education. The transition from school to
college marks a big break with the past. It is a great leap into the future. Most of
his earlier ideas appear unrealistic and now the young man tries to choose the kind
of occupation that would meet most of his demands. This is the realistic stage and
proceeds from the state of exploration through crystallization to specification. The
last is the stage of stabilization. The advantages of Ginzberg's theory are its simplicity
and commonsense. However, there are a number of limitations or questions which
this theory does not answer. The foremost among them is the total neglect of the
importance of the environment A person's entry into an occupation is not entirely
a matter of individual choice (Rao, 1970). This is best epitomized by the
Shakespearian dictum, "if wishes were horses beggers would ride".
Steffle's (1966) theory of vocational development includes the following:
1. An occupation permits the expression of an individual's personality.
2. The individual's choice of a particular occupation represents the mask he
would like to wear in society.
3. An occupational role usually represents an approach-reaction and
simultaneously an avoidance-reaction, that is, it appears attractive and hence
tempting enough to be chosen. At the same time it also suggests the less
apparent and possible hazards leading to avoidance-reaction.
4. Society exerts certain limiting forces which determine the occupational
po^nality of any individual.
In sum:
1. The factors which lead an individual to choose an occupation are influenced
by his age, sex, social class, etc.
2. For some individuals occupational choice may be crucial and ego-involving
and for others it may be peripheral to their personal identity.
DISHNCTION BETWEEN VOCATIONAL COUNSELLING AND VOCAHONAL
GUIDANCE
Vocational counselling is often mistaken for vocational guidance which largely
consists of providing career or occupational information to pupils. With the ever
growing complexity of modem living, different kinds of ofxupations are emerging.
Most young men and women are handicappied by inadequate information about the
opportunities available to them, the requirements which they have to fulfil to enter
those occupations, and the places (locations) where specidized training facilities
are available. Young men and women should know all about the opportunities open
to them so that they can make the best use of them. Educational institutions as well
as governmental agencies are realizing the importance of dissemination of career
information. Most people fail to realize their potentialities largely owing to their
ignorance concerning how to put their potential to use. Vocational guidance thus


--- PAGE 243 ---
Guidance and Counselling In the Educational Setting 223
largely concerns itself with providing occupational information. To do this
successfully the bureau has to collect, classify and disseminate occupational
information by employing several media of communication, such as bulletin boards,
career pamphlets, film strips and films, individual interviews and group discussions.
In addition to giving information the guidance worker may occasionally be called
upon to perform a wider function of clarifying the seveik questions concerning
occupations.
Vocadonal counselling is closely related to the above functions. It is carried out
at the same location and often by the same person(s). Therefore, the distinction
between vocational counselling and vocational guidance is blurred. Sometimes no
distinction is made or recognized. However, this distinction is dealt with here.
Vocational counselling does not consist in giving vocational information. It is
basically more concerned with the vocational development of an individual, that is,
it is concerned with his personality growth. Vocational counselling has for its locus
the client or'the individual. It is concerned with the discovery of his potentialities,
interests and aUitudes such that he is helped to 'actualize' himself in the pursuit of
his occupation. The occupation is thus the means of self-realization or self-discovery.
Vocational counselling employs several techniques of client appraisal and assessment
and through the counselling process or the counselling interview(s) the client is
helped to discover for himself the ways to fulfil his urge for self-actualization.
SUMMARY
Earlier, counselling of vocational choice centered on extrinsic mottvatlons for
work and vocation. Later It was realized that vocational counselling called for a
more Informed approach to acquaint the adolescent with the kind of work he
could profitably choose, Several monographs and pamphlets describing various
groups of occupations are available to help the youth. However, they only
provide basic Information about the occupatlorrs.
The next stage In the theory of vocational choice centered on a mbced,
extrlnslc-lntrlnslc motivation model. It called for matching the p^chologlcal

To ensure satisfaction, characteristics or qualities Intrinsic to the occupation,
vocational Interests and personality aspects were considered necessary to be
assessed by testing. The counsellor was responsible for Interpreting his client's
test results In such a way as to make dear to the client which occupation would
fulfil the requirements to maximize his chances of success.
More emphasis was laid on personality theory and personally dyrramlcs In
the late thirties. The client was given vocational courrselllng by either the same
person or another person and either In the same agency or In a dlHerent one.
The process often reverted to the earlier model when the dient expressed his
desire to deal with the problem of choice and refused to reveal the neurotic
basis for his dlfflcuiy. This phase Is called the dual model, the extrlnslc-lntrlnslc
choice model or the Inner dynamic of symptom model.
The developmental conception of vocational choice has been emerging for
more than a couple of decades. Super (1953) points out that an Individual's
vocational career consists of a whole series of choices, first at,educaUrmal translHoft

points and later at occupational ones. Holland (1959) has prepared a set of

vocational counselling which views vocational development as a self-confrontation
which an Individual Is able to experience at various phases In his life cycle.

INTRODUCTION
Humanism is the predominant element in counselling. The movement had its origin
in the concern to ameliorate human suffering. Counselling has rightly focussed on
the individual and the problems conceming the individual. However, individuals do
not exist by themselves—they are members of a family, they are employed in an
organization and so on. Some of the problems of the individuals have reference to
the social situation in which they find themselves. With the ever increasing
complexity of life there is need to adjust and adapt oneself to the changing needs
of society. Developmental problems could also arise from natural growth processes
necessitating appropriate adaptations to changing needs and responsibilities.
Our concern thus far was essentially with the individual and counselling was
considered a face-to-face, one-to-one helping relationship. TTiis relationship could
be utilized for a variety of situations, in addition to the ones we have considered
in the educational context. In the present chapter we shall discuss some of the
special areas in which the counsellor may be called upon to function.
One such special area may concern family group consultation. This essentially
is an extension of the group counselling technique. A few families are brought
together for a possile resolution of their problems. Another interesting area concerns
counselling with families regarding their children. A related area is counselling
with parents. This has a twin goal. On the one hand, the counsellor tries to help the
parents and on the other, the children through counselling the parents. This is to
help provide the parents with a better insight into their children's activities and
problems.
With an increase in social strife, tensions and unrest, there is an increasing
incidence of juvenile delinquency. Counselling the delinquent is one of the most
promising ways to help save youth firom resorting to delinquent behaviour. More
often than not, the delinquent is a reluctant client. There are also other clients who
are reluctant for various reasons and whom counselling can help.
Marriage is an important milestone in the individual's life. To a very large
extent, it makes for the individual's happiness. Marriage counselling deserves more
attention than it is getting at present. I^-marital counselling also could be a very
useful service to young men and women. The section on pre-marital counselling
briefly outlines the various issues involved.
In recent times, with our growing concern for social justice and fair play, we are
becoming increasingly aware of the various disadvantaged groups. The foremost


--- PAGE 246 ---
Z26 Counsdllng and Guidance
among them are undoubtedly women. In a society dominated by males, women
have been subjected to some amount of discrimination. It is essential that women
are enabled to become more self-reliant and self-dependent. In this context
counselling is assuming more importance.
There are several areas calling for specialized counselling services and we do
not intend to discuss all of them. The basic concern of this chapter is to introduce
the reader only to some of the special areas.
FAMILY GROUP CONSULTATION
The home and the femily comprise the most important and informal agencies of
education. The family serves as the primary model for personality development.
The family is considered by several authorities as an extension of the individual
pCTSonality. Therefore, it is rightly held that "family systems of behaviour become
individual systems of personality".
Family groiq) consultation is a method of counselling that begins with an analysis
of the self-defining processes in each one of the four families in the group. This
method was introduced by the Counselling Centre for Adults and the Medical
School, Psychiatric Division of the Oregon State System of Higher Education in the
1960s. The method was evolved to meet the several referrals, made by school
guidance counsellors to the Centre, which showed no medical or psychiatric
pathology but were described as behaviour problems. Tlie counseUors first invite
the concemed famfiy of the client for an initial interview. In this initial session the
counsellors meet as many members of the family as are avaiUble and enter into a
sort of 'contract' which leads to the other stages. The other famiUes are also chosen
and met in this manner by the counsellors. Usually no more than four famUies are

Initially he has to work with the members he has been able to establish contact
with. Each of the families may be sensitive about certain issues. The counsellor
