It is the job of the counsellors to actively promote this intercourse. There is likely
to be initial resistance and the families should be allowed to overcome the resistance
and learn to narrate their stories naturally. Usually the ^ily group consultation
method needs as many as 8 to 12 sessions.
COUNSELLING FAMILIES
Family counselling is concerned with the family system and changes that can be
made in that system. In a sense, the client is the family. If the interaction of the
family with one of its individual members leads to stressit is a symptom of a sick
system. The symptom, if allowed to persist, may not only cause much misery to the
individual but also to the rest of the members in the family. Therefore, the practical
consequences are great. Different types of family counselling are in vogue. First
there is the conjoint family counselling in which the counsellor meets the family
and understands the patterns of interaction within the family. The focus is on the
family discord or problem. In this approach no member of the family is dealt with
individually. In the multiple impact counselling, several counsellors work with
individual members of the family intensively over a period of three to four days.In this approach also the focus is on the family system. The network counselling
approach starts in a concentric way, working with the unit (nuclear) family and
proceeding towards the neighbours, friends, relatives and others. The objective of
this approach is 'retribalization', that is, creating a social network for the individual
member or family in distress. Yet another approach is multiple family counselling
in which a number of families are brought together and are enabled to be counselled
simultaneously. This approach provides for different families, opportunities for
observation, imitation and identification with other families. This results in social
facilitation and reduction of social inhibition.
In clinical work with .individual patients it became increasingly obvious that
there was more to the problem than what the patient was apparently reporting. The
fact that the relationship between the patient and his family is of importance was
mcognized a long time ago. It was seen that communication between ^e individualmid the rest of the members in a family was in most cases muffled and barriers
seemed to be erected. In the early days of counselling the idea of family therapy
was suggested by the structuralist approach. This leads to questions like, "What is
the purpose of the family?", "How does it function?", "What roles are assigned to
its members?", "What are the goals of a family?", "Are the goals of the individual
at variance or in conflict with those of the family?". This points to the goal of
family counselling: "What should be the outcome of family counselling?", "Should
the relationshipCs) between the children be examined?" Family counselling aims at
some kind of change. What should the extent of change be? The techniques to be
used are only matters of detail. The goal of family counselling is not merely to


--- PAGE 248 ---
228 CoimsdIIng and Guidance
remove some symptoms but to create a new. way of living. This involves helping
people to express emotion. Within the family set-up individuals are either too rigid
or too fluid. Either of these is not desirable, for the former type of individuals are
blind to the new learning and the latter contribute to the destruction of family life.
The goal of healthy family relations is to strike a balance between the two extremes,
namely, continuity of the old and openness to the new experience. The family
change is facilitated by the counsellor by shifting the balance within the family and
by advising the members on how to relate to one another in new ways and if
necessary to examine its value system and provide for appropriate changes in it
The family is a complex entity comprising interlocking systems and sub-systems.
Fundamentally, the family is an affectual interaction system. The a^ectual system
within the family could be seen as interlocking triangles. So an affective method
of changing the family system involves 'detriangulation'. This is done by helping
the persons to respond to the system and not just react. The family changes when
the interlocking triangles change. The counsellor's intervention is most necessary
in this process The counsellor helps the members, for example, the marital partners,
to deHne and clariiy their roles and their relationship, to get detrianglcd from the
family emotional system, to learn other ways of functioning emotional systems by
communication of feelings. The counsellor can separate out their fantasies, feelings
and their thinking systems, thus enabling the persons to know themselves better and
also view others more objectively, leading to a better or higher level of maturity.
A person starts life as an undifferendated part of the family. In course of dme
he learns to establish his own identity and at an appropriate time separates himself
from his family. This involves forming new emotional attachments and the
detriangulation of other emotional relations.
An ecological perspecdve is emerging in family counselling. Ecology deals with
the relationship tetween organisms and their environment, the interplay between
the two and their interdependence. Here it refers to the interactions in the family
system among the members and their relationship to socie^, their neighbourhood,
school and other significant social systems. Acterman (1956, 58, 66, 70) places
enormous emphasis on this approach and holds that one cannot compartmentalize
individual, family and other social systems. Siuprisingly, nOt much work is done
with cultural factors in family counselling. In the multifamily counselling approach,
cultural differences are brought together when five to six families with different
backgrounds meet. Family counselling in the years to come must grapple with new
models.
COUNSELLING WITH FAMILIES CONCERNING CHILDREN
The family is the primary group of society. Its characteristic feature is the affective
bonds among the members in the family and a concern for each other. Counselling
cannot afford to ignore such an important aspect of human life. Family relations are
broadly of two types—the parent-child relations and the husband-wife relations.
When the members of the family are disunited, tension, distress and misery are the
natural outcomes. The family counsellor should help find ways and means of


--- PAGE 249 ---
Special Areas In Counselling 229
reducing, if not eliminating, the strife, mubial distrust and ill-will among the members
of the family. Most problems in family relations have been identified to result from
misunderstandings which is the layman's term for lack of communication. The
parent-child relationship comes under stresses and strains for very simple reasons.
Growth is a natural process and a normal phenomenon. Children grow and
consequently become progressively less dependent on their parents. Each family
has its own ethics and provides to its members a philosophy of life which is
communicated through non-verbal and informal means. Many a time parents forget
that children cannot be Judged from their own standards of morality or decency or
culture. Quite often parents try to compensate for their failures by wanting their
children to achieve what they could not. They tend to become unrealistic in their
demands and this causes fhistration on both sides.
Sometimes parents take decisions on behalf of, or for their children. These may
not be to the satisfaction of the children themselves and causes tension between the
parents and children. There could be fundamental diHerences in important issues
such as values and relatively unimportant ones such as fashions. The generation
gap leads to an identity crisis and sometimes to alienation which adversely affects
family health. There is yet another area of family relations which concerns sibling
relations. Most common conditions are sibling rivalry and jealousy and unfounded
antipathy among children in a family. Family counselling is concerned with these
and other related problems and aims at the release of tensions and the building up
of harmonious relations. The counsellor here uses the group counselling techniques
as well as individualized counselling techniques to resize his goals. He may have
a few sessions with the parents individually and then several with the children. The
major effort is towards increasing communication leading to better understanding
and appreciation of the individual members of the family. Unfortunately this area
has received minimal attention partly because it is very impracticable, especially in
a highly industrialized society, to be able to assemble all the members of a family
for coimsclling sessions.
COUNSELLING WITH PARENTS
Most problem children are products of problem homes. The disturbing features in
a home affect the harmonious development of the children. The incalculable harm
which parents do to their children is usually not grasped by most parents. Parent
counselling is aimed at helping parents become sensitive to the possible adverse
effect of their behaviour on their children. By helping the parents gain a better
understanding of themselves and their own personalities much harmony could be
effected.
Parent counselling deals with the area of parent-child relationships concerning
the dimension of dependence-independence. Most parents are deeply concerned
about the well-being of their children and are afraid that if left to themselves the
children may harm themselves. Hence they become over-protective which is resented
by the children. Another area of parent-child conflict concerns vocational choice.
Most parents begin with the presumption that they know what is best for their


--- PAGE 250 ---
230 Counselling and Guidance
children. Children have their own ideas and this usually results in a clash of ideas,
interests and personalities. Parent counselling thus is one of the important services
that can help foster a healthy home atmosphere.
It is becoming increasingly recognized that there should be a close liaison between
school and home, parents and teachers. For this purpose parent-teacher associations
(PTAs) have been formed. The schools managed by local self-government bodies
in India pay scant regard to the need for PTAs. A few missionary schools and
private schools have been successfully holding PTA meetings and reporting
encouraging results. It is firmly believed that there is a genuine need for counselling
parents.
Parent-teacher meetings are becoming more common in schools. A parent may
visit a teacher at the latter's request or a parent may want to know why his/her child
has not done well in a particular subject handled by the teacher or ask the teacher
for an explanation regarding a punishment to a pupil. There are other parents who
believe in having informal contacts and hence visit schools. Sometimes parents
may feel embarrassed or offended or belittled about being asked by the teacher to
go over to the school to discuss their child. Some parents get annoyed because they
believe that it is the business ofthe school to take complete charge of their children
and that they have no role to play.
Parents usually are a heterogeneous lot They have their own perceptions,
expectations, prejudices, likes and dislikes about the school or about individual
teachers. A teacher's ^prehensions of parents are not entirely unfounded. They
find that some of the parents are belligerent, fault-finding and unsympathetic. Some
parents are uncooperative and disinterested.
Parents understandably are indulgent and so they see their children in a different
light On the other hand, for the teacher, the child of a particular parent is one of
the several hundred pupils he may be seeing daily. The parent, as a parent, may not
be able to see the problem of his or her child as the teacher sees it (as a problem
of a member of his class). If the parent is told of a conduct problem of his child,
he may feel hurt, embarrassed and may even become disturbed. The parent may
take a defensive attitude or react in a hostile manner. Some parents may feel hurt
and become very apologetic. The counsellor has to see the pupil's actions without
bias and enlist the parent's cooperation for doing something positive for the child.
The parent, motivated by his protective instinct,may defend the child's actions. In
all such cases, the counsellor must behave with great caution and professional
experience to win over the confidence and trust of the parent and help him see the
shortcomings or the problems of his child in an objective manner. This requires a
considerable amount of sympathetic understanding of the parent. When once the
parent's confidence and trust are secured, it becomes easy to enlist his/her
cooperation. The assurance of confidentiality and privacy will reassure him/her.
Some parents have difficulty in expressing themselves. A parent may be reluctant
to talk. The counsellor has to first establish a warm relationship to open up lines
of free communication by talking about the positive aspects. The parent's initial
resistance can be overcome slowly with patient handling. This brings home the
importance of good relationships for the natural release of feelings. By adopting an
understanding attiuide, the defensive reactions of the parent can be surmounted and


--- PAGE 251 ---
Special Areas In Counselling 231
by persuading the parent to talk, his inhibitions can be overcome. It is always
necessary to remember that the manner in which the parent sees the probem of his
child may be very different from the way in which the teacher or counsellor sees
it The important objective of a parent-teacher conference is to gain insight into the
child's behaviour to get a proper perspective from the point of view of the classroom
situation and the home environment If the parent thinks that he has to take the
blame for the failing of his child he may take a hostile attitude towards the school
but if the parent is made to feel that he will be helping in the resolution of his
child's problems, he will take a different attitude. In the course of the meeting the
parent may even be prepared to recognize the problems of his child which he would
have otherwise stoutly rejected if presented in a different manner.
Sometimes parents' help is sought to gain some information about the child's
personality problems. Such information concerning the pupil may go a long way in
resolving his problem and help him in his scholastic work.
In most PTA meetings, group sessions can be organized to use the group approach
to resolve problems. In group situations people see their problems in relation to
other people's problems and find them similar and, therefore, not unique.
Understanding insights can help a great deal in reducing the tensions and anxieties
of parents.
COUNSELLING THE DELINQUENT
Delinquency is a symptom of emotional immaturity leading to socially unacceptable
or reprehensible behaviour of the youth. Delinquency is one of the most common
problems reported among the post-puberty or early adolescent children. One of the
common symptoms of delinquency is truancy. Delinquents commit petty offences
like thieving, shoplifting, and so on. Most delinquents are emotionally immature
and their behaviour is a compensatory reaction. Sometimes it becomes an act of
gangsterism. The emotional upheaval and brittleness resulting fham rapid physical
growth and accelerated endocrinal functioning result in extra energy seeking
expression in suitable outlets. There is also a greater need for recognition. Horror,
crime and other movies as well as stmy books provide the adolescent with a
convenient form for day-dreaming and self-identification. Most adolescents limit
themselves to day-dreams. But a few also resort to socially unacceptable means of
expressing their energies to seek recognition. They fail to adapt and adjust to social
norms. Counselling of such people is not easy.
The following case illustrates the need for counselling assistance. Mr. Dever is
a 19-year old flrst year degree student He is well-built and of robust health. vHe
hails from a medium-sized town and belongs to the middle class socio-economic
group. He is very much interested in athletics and is popular with his fnends. He
appears to be very well adjusted. He has a good social life and enjoys it He is the
elder of two brothers. His parents are greatly concerned about his future. Devw
feels that somehow he is not given sufficient freedom at home and believes that he
is treated as a child by his mother. His marks are below average and he does not
aiq>ear to be worried about doing any better. He believes that somehow the good


--- PAGE 252 ---
232 Counselling and Guidance
points in him are not getting due recognition. Therefore, he feels there is no need
to work any harder. Under the garb of his hard-working, cautious and ambitious
nature there is a strong undercurrent of nervousness, self-consciousness,
discouragement, unhappiness and anxiety. He takes a very aggressive posture to
impress his personality upon his peers. He is known to indulge in petty offences
and has been apprehended and left off with warning but he persists in his behaviour
and there is no sign of relenting.
COUNSELLING RELUCTANT CLIENTS
Counselling, we have observed earlier, is help voluntarily sought by the client. But
this is not always the case. Occasionally counsellors have to work with clients who
are reluctant to discuss matters with the counsellor. Such clients can be identified
in different situations like the school, home and work situations. Reluctant clients
are usually those who are the referral cases. They may show open defiance or
express their reluctance in more passive ways. They do not take any responsibility
and exhibit an unwillingness to communicate. The counsellors find that they exhibit
non-facilitative emotions.
Counsellors also sometimes become highly anxious and feel inadequate when
dealing with non-communicative clients. Some counsellors may become angry with
clients owing to a feeling of frusuation or a sense of loss of status and prestige. In
most situations the counsellor should learn to deal with himself non-defensively to
be able to successfully cope with reluctant clients. Let us take, for example, the
case of a tenth grade pupil. His academic achievement was in the range of superior
to very superior. Suddenly something went amiss and he started scoring lower
grades. He also became a regular defaulter in submitting home assi^ipients. This
exhibition of a kind of indifference to classwork persisted for some time and was
noticed by his teacher who was surprised and shocked that such a bright pupil
should progressively deteriorate in this way. The pupil was referred to the counsellor.
The counsellor assured the student that there was no question of punishing him for
anything. All that was planned was to have a firee and friendly chat with him. When
the pupil felt sufficiently at ease, the counsellor opened the records and slowly read
the pupil's grades, term after term, making sure to impress on him how fast his
grades had declined. The pupil appeared to agree with the situation but believed
that gradually the marks would improve. The counsellor asked the pupil to explain
how he was going to do this. This helped the pupil to open up to the counsellor.
There was some problem at home that bothered him very much but he was unable
to do anything about it except feel unhappy and miserable. Session after session,
the counsellor met the pupil and followed upon the situation at home and in the
process also helped to make the pupil realize that there was no reason for his
academic work to suffer due to the problems at home. Counselling helped the pupil
to make a self-examination of his situation and to realize that his indifference was
only a reaction to his dissatisfaction with his home life. With such an insight the
pupil began working again at the normal level and quickly regained his lost position
in class.

MARRIAGE COUNSELUNG
Marriage counselling is indeed\^a very wide field and has three important areas,
namely, pre-marital counselling, counselling for belter marital harmony and
counselling to eliminate or forestall a marriage ft'om breaking up.
Owing to the tradidonal nature of Indian society, marital counselling has not
gained importance. Basically marital counselling is not different firom individual
counselling. In the case of individual counselling the counsellee is the individual
client. In marriage counselling the client is not either of the married partners but
the marriage relationship itself. Counselling helps in the understanding of this
marriage relationship and in putting it in its proper perspective. Marriage counselling
is looked upon as a form of crisis -intervention. If the precipitating events are
understood, something can be done to forestall the crisis itself. The preventive
aspect should receive attention first, whjie intervention can be conveniently dealt
with later.
A crisis in marriage relationships could arise from the intrusion of a third party.
If this third party has affective relationships, it could cause an emotional turmoil
leading to a crisis. Another factor that could pose a threat to a marriage is the
change in the family structure. A third source of crisis could be illness in the femily.
Another source of tension could result from strong likes and dislikes and a difference
in beliefs and life styles of the couple which have recently emerged owing to some
extraneous factor(s). Other causes may be financial upsets and changes in the work
situations. Such precipitating factors could cause much stress and strain in the
family.
Marriage is an important event in the life of an individual. It has a number of
dimensions and functions. Most religions, with the exception of Islam, consider
marriage as a sacrament and not a social contracL Oriental societies like the Japanese,
Chinese and Indian societies have a highly conventional and traditional conception
of marriage. In these societies it is not merely a matter concerning two individuals
but is looked upon as an event involving families and communities at large.
Therefore, the question of individual choice of a mate or partner is limited. The
consent and approval of the family and acceptance of the new member into the
family becomes the desideratum. This conventional idea of marriage as a sacred
bond between two individuals or as an indissoluble union-, become|.^uite difficult
to accept with the stresses of rapid industrialization and urbanization. In western
societies, perhaps owing to historical reasons, liberal attitudes are current in so far
as marriage is concerned. The enactment of civil laws solemnizing marriages have
further made them quite unconventional. Secular ideas of marriage have propagated
the view that marriages are matters of convenience, and if one of the parties chooses
to get out of it he/she should have the freedom to do so. The force of this argument
has compelled social legislation to be enacted in almost all countries providing for
divorce under certain stipulated conditions. The twin issues of marriage and divorce
loom large in social and domestic lives.
American society evolved several new conventions and customs, one of which
concerns marital counselling. This is the institution of 'dating'. This is a unique
ejq>eriment which has come to characterize the American social system. Dating is
1 .-Ml


--- PAGE 254 ---
234 Counsetling and Guidance
a socially approved and normal practice. The young boys and girls meet ^veraltimes by themselves to understand each other better before stepping into matrimony.Usually dating is also considered an index of social success and social desirability.
Marital counselling has evolved in the US culture as an important service to help
secure happy marriages.
In recent times, studies have revealed that marital counselling has come to be
a continuous process with its beginnings in the days of coiuTship, its course
progressing through marriage to times of stress prior to the parting of ways. The
marriage counsellor must be acutely aware of the philosophy and objectives of
marriage. People enter into marriage for happiness, companionship and affection.
More aspects should also naturally enter into matrimonial alliances. In an open
socie^ where the individuals are free to choose their partners in marriage the
relationship is one of understanding and regard for each otfier. Fepj)le many out of
such considerations as wealth, position, or attraction for the personality, of the
partner. This latter aspwt is usually termed love. The counsellor has a very important
role here in helping the parties understand each other such that they are not
overwhelmed by fanciful misconceptions. Each must seek the other for what he or
she is and emotion should not be permitted to have, the better of reason.
The second aspect of matrimony concerns compatibility. Can incompatibilities
sustain a marriage for long? The parlies to the marriage should have similar attitudes,
interests, cultures, likes, value systems and, so on. A fundamental aspect of
compatibility is age. People of different ages will not have similar interests. Age
is also important from the viewpoint of sex gratification. It is a physiological fact
that the sex urge is at its peak in early adulthood. As individuals grow older the
urge is expected to progressively become less dominant The marital counsellor
cannot under-estimate or afford to ignore the role of sex in marriage. Sex is a
means for human beings to obtain stimulation and gratification through their senses.No r^igion. either primitive or modem, no society, aboriginal or civilized and nolaw, barbarian or progressive, has ever underestimated the importance of sex in
m^ge. The marriage counsellor has to keep this in focus aU the time when heIS involved in mantal counselling.

are strangers to each other. In the Indian situation the social fabric does not permit
a period of courtship. This, therefore, requires treatment on a different footing. In
most of the western societies, the premarital stage is considered a very vital stage
in determining the success or failure of marriage. The institution of dating and oth^
such socially approved ways of meeting each other are aimed at an understanding
of each other such that mutual bonds of liking and affection can grow. Several
affairs end abruptly at this stage, while a few others continue for very long but
ultimately break down. Premarital counselling seeks to preclude such a situation.
The counsellor helps the parties to gain a fuller understanding of themselves as this
is basic for a happy marriage. Affairs which have nothing besides physical anraction
or sex gratification to sustain them cannot last long. The problem of choosing a
partner and entering matrimony is assuming great significance in modem
industrialized and urbanized societies where every person works to make a living.
A career is, as important if not more, in the context of the women's liberation
movement The concept of male domination which is to be countered by the female
leads to quite a few problems.
Marriages run into problems due to lack of understanding between partners,
leading to strained relations. This situation would seldom result if couples were to
have an empathy for each other. It is perhaps the surest means of making the
marriage a success. Empathy has to be cultivated and is one of the important factors
for the sustained growth of a husband and wife relationship.
Marital problems result in stresses and strains owing to lack of communication
or faulty communication. Misinformation breeds misunderstandings and tends to
create an information vacuum.
The socio-economic factors that make or mar a happy marriage concem finances,
social life, religious and other values.
Finances—^Finance could cause enormous inter-personal strains as it is one of
the important means of satisfying many needs. Scarce finances could cause serious
problems of adjustment.
Social life—With the tirban and metropolitan conditions of life, there is much
scope for socializing. Individuals have their own clubs and associations. Sometimes
excessive socializing could lead to misunderstandings and conflicts.
Religious and other values—^Most societies attach great importance to religious
values. When one of the partners changes his/her religion the other is free to
dissolve the marriage.
Relatives and dependants—^Interference by members in the family, such as in-
laws can jeopardise a happy marriage.
Occupational demands— couples may have very little time to be together
and may feel aggrieved because of the enforced lack of communication. In seeking
out avenues of personal activity they may seriously hinder a successful marriage.
The most important problem centres around sex conflicts. Marriage counsellors
have to skillfully deal with the underlying psychological problems that serioiisly
hamper a successful marriage. Frigidity on the part of the wife and impotency on
the part of the husband are the most common factors which wreck a marriage or
make the partner a neurotic. Frigidity and impotency could result from either
physiological or psychological factors or from teth. The counsellor must have a

knowledge of the problems that could lead to the dysfunciioning of the sexual lifeof the couple.
Structuring
Marital counselling, we have seen, is a very delicate process and it has to be
handled with enormous care with different kinds of clients. There cannot \ie a fixed
or a set approach. The first prerequisite of a counsellor is to understand his role as
clearly as possible. For example, he should recognize that he is not an arbitrator- |
He is not supposed to be telling the couple who is right and who is wrong. His role ,
is essentially confined to helping the parties understand themselves and each other.
This process of understanding is assisted by helping the members learn more aboutthemselves. Most human beings suffer from myopic understanding of themselves.
Sometimes they refuse to recognize their own faults or weaknesses. The client has
to be helped to discover for himself his fdllngs by an indirect and least upsetting
process. The counsellor has to use his skills with the utmost care and perhaps theclient-centred approach or the non-directive approach is the most appropriate.
In stnicuiring the siuiation the counsellor is concerned with the mechanics of the
situation. Structuring is usually concerned with the liming of the counselling sessions,
their duration, a definition or at least an indication of the client's responsibility,
One important fact that the client must learn is that the counsellor is not there to
give solutions; he only provides them with a sense of orientation which enables
them to believe that a solution has to be found on the basis of their own involvement
Marital counselling, like any other counselling, is stricUy voluntary. Clients seek
assistance on their own and the counsellor offers assistance only when it is soughf
for by the clients.
Another issue in structuring concerns the fees. The scale of fees has to be
worked out both by the counsellor and the clients. The timing and duraUon of thecounseUing sessions also have to be worked out to the mutual convenience of the
cUents and the counsellor. The counsellor should make the clients understand theimportance of tune and should not encourage a laissez-faire atUtude on the part of
the clients.
As counseUing is a profwsional service and has an ethical code, it respects theconfidences of the clients. T^ counsellor has to secure the trust of the clients and
estabUsh a healthy ra^rt Chems do not usually volunteer information and thecounseUor has to^lfully elicit iL Another very fundamental and important aspect

COUNSEILWC WOMEN
I„ the late sixties a pepuUst and vocal woman'i liberation movement made its


--- PAGE 257 ---
appearance. Marriage is no longer the only option for every woman. Some wom«i
deliberately opt out of matrimony Or choose to bear no children and become
careerists. The modem woman is in a world of transition with no specific traditions
or convendons to guide her. So in trying to find their feet women are se^ng
counselling assistance. Counselling of women has become a special area of concern
in modem times. It was traditionally believed that men and women difiered
significantly from each other in their physical capacities. The most crucial question
today is whether, owing to such physical differences, the status and role of then and
women in society should differ. If so, should women be assi^ed to inferior positions?
While men have a very large number of occupations to choose fiom, the occupations
open to women are vay restricted. Som^ow literature and story books have
presented women as dependent on men, docile and shy, and hardly ever as great'
intellects, successful scientists, mathematicians, or researchers.
Women today have more avenues open to them than their counterparts had in
the first part of the tw^tielh century. Many significant changes have taken place
owing to the two World wars, knowledge explosion, urbanization and
industrialization. Modem expectations in advanced societies place severe strains on
those women who continue to conform to the out-moded sex-role stereotype.
The male stereotype is regarded more positively. Broverman, et aL (1972) have
reported that women have more negative self-concepts than men. An interesting
study made by GoldbCTg (1971) reveals that when professional articles w^ to be
evaluated by women, they generally under-valued them when they thought that the
authors of those papers were women. Wolfe (1969) argues that the sex role identity
is closely related to the careers chosen by women. Hom^ (1970) concludes that
"when the fear of success interferes with the desire to be successful the result is an
inhibition of achievement motivation". Many young women, according to her, have
a conflict between their need for achievement and the need to conform to their
female image. Such conflicts lead to negative emotional consequences.
Owing to extensive western influences, expanding avenues for education and
wider employmrat opportunities, most beliefs about women once held rigidly by
our socie^ are no longer accepted as tenable universal truths. Whether acc^ted by
all or not, change is obviously the order of the world. This is not just a phenomenon
limited to India. The last two centuries have brought about many significant changes
all over the world, leading to a weakening of the hold of conventional customs,
traditions and beliefs. Owing to the disintegration of old values and beliefs, one of
the foremost gains of the new generation is the freedom of choice. Freedom of
choice is typically a new freedom for women. While it is true that most women are
not yet-aware of this freedom and continue to live in blissful ignorance under the
shadow of time-worn conventions and traditions; some women have certainly
exercised their choices freely. The only option for women was marriage and continues
to be so for many even today. But with education, wider and more attractive
opportunities for employment, this belief has been sufficiently eroded. Women in
increasing numbers are pursuing several non-traditional occupations, with some
even choosing to remain single.
Women from lower economic strata have been working from the ancient times
due to economic reasons. They have been working out in the fields and in cottage


--- PAGE 258 ---
238 Comselling and Guidance
industries, sharing the economic burden with their men folk in order to support
their families. Today women are working shoulder-lo-shoulder with men in several
avenues not considered traditional occupations for them. Notwithstanding all this,
women are considered inferiw and dependent. The traditional occupations of teaching
and nursing were considered most appropriate for women as they involve caring
and nursing. Though the same avenues continue to attract women in large numbers,
more women are now entering non-traditional areas and for reasons other than
economic considerations. An outstanding contribution of education has been instilling
the spirit of freedom and self-depen^nce in the minds of men and women. Modem
women have increasingly come to realize the need for economic self-sufficiency
and independence. It is only when the two needs are squarely met that women can
think of and appreciate the vital importance of freedom of choice. The basic tenet
of counselling and guidance is that for self-actualization, the individuals need to be
free first.
Sex stereoQ^ are tradidonally promoted through socializaUon. The educational
system also reinforces the sex stereotypes as an important agency of socialization.
A belief based on these stereotypes is that the sexes are unequal and are, therefore,
suited for different vocations. Social and economic roles are also determined by the
sex stereotypes. Thus women s role was always limited to domestic work and
home-making. A woman is expected to play a subservient role and not lake any
decision. evM in matlem conceming the home. social and economic status and have been victims of traditional stereotypes. Since
they wrongly believe themselves to be unfit for certain types of work, they apparently
conform to this belief and develop negative self-concepts and accept an inferior
status as natural. The substitution of conservative sexist stereotypes by rational and
scientific ideas will lead to appropriate and positive attitudes towards women.
In counselling women it is important to jettison these false and untenable ideas.
Only then can female counsellee(s) be helped, to outgrow the discriminatory
stereotypes. The counsellor should strive to bring their biased negative feelings into
the open so that they are able to think better of themselves rationally. It is not often
easy, if not impossible, for the counseUee(s) to face the traditional stereotypes
boldly. Sympathy, understanding and persuasion are necessary' to put them onlireir
feet. Otherwise, the exercise of counselling may fall into the danger of perpetuating
the very stereotypes it struggles to discard and dismiss. There could be unconscious
biases and feelings which the counsellee should be helped to become aware of. The
counsellor may have to help the counsellee discard her personal sex-role bias through
sensitivity training.
The technique found always useful is the method of raising consciousness, which
could serve as a take-off stage. An example of raising consciousness would be a
session in which a small number of women students are made to sit in a circle and
asked to talk freely about their experiences in school/college and at the place of
work. The other students in the class may listen to the discussion and comment on
it The free exchange of ideas often reveals several instances of blatant discrimination.
However, merely becoming aware of social discrimination is not enough. It must
be followed up by appropriate action. More often than not, some of tlie women
students may be subtly discouraged even to choose non-traditional careers unwittingly
by the counsellors. Women counsellors are often in conflict over the variety of
choices open to them because they are brought up with the old conservative cultural
ideals. Most educated women today know that the contemporary world is different
ftom that of their mothers and grandmothers. Yet they are emotionally tossed
between the bid and time-worn ideas and the new ideas.
An important area of counselling deals with lack of confidence. Often people
pursue the path of least resistance. It is necessary to overcome the inertia and lack
of confidence. The counsellor must help build self-confidence not merely at the
intellectual level but also at the affective level, i.e., counsellee should be made to
feel self-confident enough to express herself freely and act accordingly.
Counselling of women presents many challenging issues and fascinating
possibilities.
.Middle-aged women who are brought up traditionally, often find themselves
left in a void, facing identity crisis. Their children are grown up and preoccupied
with their studies and other vocations. They no longer need the mother to do
anything for them. The husband is busy with his occupation and mostly lives in a
world of his own. In such a situation, the middle-aged wife feels lonely, with very
little work of her own. She begins to feel that she is not needed any longer by her
children and husband. She may become depressed and withdrawn. She develops a
feeling of emptiness and devoid of purpose in life. This feeling of void must be
overcome and can be tackled best by finding a suitable employment so that her time

may experience feelings of helplessness. Yet another kind of conflict may arise

Thus counselling concerns several vital problems. The first concerns family
health and education. With the population explosion there is an urgent need for
women to be appropriately counselled regarding family health. Next, there is a need
to help them understand their roles as normal adult members of society. There is
a need for adjustment and acceptance of behavioural norms appropriate to her sex.
The above can be illustrated with the help of a few case studies. Consider the case
of a woman who is not prepared for the kind of situation she finds herself in,
following a divorce or the demise of her husband. The woman may not have cared
to acquire any skills and/or to attend college. Finding a suitable vocation for such
an in^vidual is a problem. Counselling with women thus concerns preparing women
to face the challenges of transitions in life situations. Counsellors have to be creative,
innovative, ingeneous and prepared to improvize to guide each woman in need of
help and follow a course most appropriate for her in the light of her educational
background, talents, capacities and opportunities.
COUNSELLING WEAKER SECTIONS
One of the characteristic features of the Indian socie^ is the diversity of its people.
Though India has been the seat of one of the great ancient civilizations, it has,
paradoxically for over three centuries, if not more, been an underdeveloped country.
This backwardness has brought into relief the differences between various sections
of socie^. After independence, contemporary society has been in the throes of
socio-economic and political change. Several divisive forces, the origins of which
are vague and unclear, have sprung up. In course of time, the different communal
segments grew overly self-conscious and increasingly suspicious of each other.
Even after nearly five decades of freedom, communal cleavages not only continue
to exist, they are growing wider and deeper. Psychologically speaking, the social
ph^omenon of pluralism reflects the fact that the social groups exist sq)arately for
whatever reason, naturally or voluntarily or out of compulsion. They develop diffbrrat
languages, habits, mannas, social attitudes, prejudices, perceptions of themselves
and others, values and norms that guide their behaviour. Consequently, they beccHne
culturally different The members of the Indian society are identified as separate
ar)d unequal groups and this fact is seen throughout the social order. The groups
cultivate mutual distrust and misunderstanding of one another, resulting in ill-will
among themselves. Notwithstanding all professions of national and social integration,
the diff^ences create serious prejudices and rifts among different communities.
The socio-economically weaker sections, or Scheduled Castes comprise several
groups that have serious differences among themselves. The only common facttH"
is the socio-economic backwardness forced upon them from generations and reeling
under its oppressive tyranny, thus developing serious feelings of inferiority. The
differences are reflected in deficiencies of language, values, education, income,
housing and general cultural lifestyles. Consequently, the members of these groups


--- PAGE 262 ---
242 Cotmsdllng and Guidance
have been socially discriminated and, until the late 1930s, were treated as
untouchables.
Counselling the weaker sections needs special attention and care. Counselling is
a dynamic, purposeful, psychological interaction and its goal is to assist the
counsellee(s) adjust more effectively and qualitatively belter to environmental
demands- In tmler to be successful, the counsellor should be able to relate himself
to the client(s) optimally. He must be able to reasonably assess the client's state of
adjustment and must know what ought to be done to help the client improve his/
her current adjuslmenL It should be recoffiized that cultiual differences affect the
ability of the counsellor to relate himself to his client and to discuss the problems
he may encountw in making a diagnosis of the socially and economically weak
client The difficulties inherent in arriving at a warm and purposeful relationship
are outlined below.

to culturally impoverished backgrounds, are unable or unwilling to participate in
the counselling exploration. Therefore, techniques such as prolonged silence should
be avoided. Until positive rapport has been established, the counsellor should pay
more than usual attention to structuring the counselling situation.
Resistance
The counsellee's opposition to the goals of counselling is referred to as resistance.
It manifests itself in a variety of ways such as self-devaluation, intellectualization
and even overt hostility. The counsellor may be unfamiliar with the nuances of the
cultures of the weaker sections and assess their behaviour as an instance or just
another effect of social and economic deprivation. Sometimes resistance is exhibited
as not coming on time for the counselling session or being irregular to sessions or
even failure to keep the appointment(s). Clients of the weaker sections are often
v^ reluctant to disagree. They often silently acquiesce and appear to accept the
counsellor superficially. Sometimes they may be uncooperative with the counsellor
or with someone of higher status.
I
Transference
An individual's reaction to a person in the present in a manner similar to the way
he has reacted to another person in the past is called transference. In other words,
transference is the repetition of an old relationship in a new situation which may
appear embarrassing to the counsellor or other persons. Transference may be
conscious or unconscious, positive or negative. It is a form of resistaiice to the
goals of counselling. The socially backward clients expect the counsellor to exhibit
majority-group attitudes either because of direct experience with such persons or
because of socialization which causes them to react to members of majority-groups
with suspicion. School counsellors who are perceived as outsiders find these pupils
hesitant, shy and reluctant to talk freely.
Counter-transference
Transference is a counsellee reaction to the counsellor in a manner he reabted to
some other person in the past. It is transferring of the counsellee's feelings towards
another person to the counsellor. In counter-transference the reverse is implied. The
counsellor transfers his feelings to the counsellee. It leads to persistent, inappropriate
behaviour towards the counsellee and enormous strain in the counselling relationship
owing to preconceived ideas about the weaker sections. A common expression of -
counter-transference is the counsellor's tendency to be excessively sympathetic and
indulgent with the' clients. The counsellor often considers it appropriate to use a
different set of criteria (achievement, performance, etc.) for the socially backward.
This does no good to the client and may even lead to the pygmalion eff^t
Language
Language is part of an individual's culuire or sub-culture. InabiliQ' to comprehend';
lanpiflgft results in failure to understand the Vlient. In order to communicate

244 Counselling and Guidance
effectively, the counsellor must be able to understand the verbal and non-verbal
language of his counsellees. It is more difficult to understand non-verbal
communication. Individuals speak not just with their voices but also with their
gestures. Knowledge of a client's language and its nuances are important in
counselling, because most counselling techniques demand a good understanding of
this in order to be able to establish rapport
Psycholo^cal Barriers
Self'dlsdosure
This is the willingness to let another person know about what one thinks or feels
or wMts. It is basic to the counseUing process that the relationship should be open
as it is crucial to the establishment and maintenance of rapport Thus it is a pre
requisite for achieving the goals of counselling. Reluctance to disclose on the part
of the counsellee is a serious problem to contend with.
SelF-batred
Socially and economically weaker individuals sometimes tend not only to despise
their groups, but also hate themselves for being members of this group.
Personalism
Mother stubborn counselling barrier often experienced is personalism. It suggestsat individuals are more interested in their consideration for people than for
procedures.
Listening
Sym^thedc listening is the heart of the counselling process. It is often fallaciouslyconsi a p^ive activity. Owing to inappropriate socialization, many socially
S  7 individuals are poor in listening skills. Their homes are often fiUedn and confusion with everybody talking simultaneously. The young ones
n earn not to listen but to emotions. A blank stare or an empty facial expression
often means that the client has not followed what has been said.
Mocfes^
Mo^ty, usually considered a desirable quality, is not quite useful in counselling,
^  counsellee is too modest A false sense of modesty blocksexpression of overt negative feelings. Such blockages are not helpful in counselling.

f!! achieve the goals of counselling, the counsellor must be able to relateth». The counsellor must be able to determine

instruments, the counsellor may not always be able to diagnose correctly. There are
several problems inherent in the use of standardized instruments with clients from

Intervention
Determining preventive and corrective measures is quite difficult and applying
them to socially disadvantaged clients is not easy.
The most important of all is the counsellor's attitude. The counsellor should
exhibit an attitude of uncondU'ional self-regard towards his clients.
COUNSELLING DRUG ADDICTS
Many psychological aspects of drug addiction represent non-adjustive behaviour
that some individuals resort to. Broadly speaking, the reactions of drug addicts fall
under the category of character disorders. In the last three decades, the phenomenon
of drug abuse has assumed enormous proportions and has become a very serious
threat to order and society's survival. Hence it demands urgent consideration. In the
early decades of the twentieth century, alcoholism posed a serious social problem
and usually involved adults and older persons. Now drug addiction has taken roots
among adolescents and youth. It does not of course mean that it ceases to be an
adult problem. Those who pick up this habit become wrecked personalities.
Over the last three decades, there has been a sea change in the socio-economic
conditions of the youth. They are becoming highly politicized. Owing to defective
economic planning and educational policies, more and more youth are being turned
out of colleges and schools with degrees and diplomas that are not worth the paper
on which they are printed. More youth arc becoming unemployable and are
disillusioned because the education tiiey have received was not designed to equip
them with skills or competencies for the employment market. Naturally, there is
growing frustration. Those in colleges and schools, seeing and knowing the plight
of their" seniors, are becoming anxious, losing faith in the value of their education.
They are also exposed to other tensions and stresses present in the society, owing
to socio-economic and political factors. Youth are becoming alienated. They have
strong feelings of 'anomie'. Some experience identity crises and develop feelings
of distress. All these factors lead to unrest, stress and strain in the youth. The
restless state of mind often makes weak-willed youth gullible and fall into the
company of drug users. In course of time, they become victims of drug addiction.
The use of drugs becomes a means of escape from feelings of void and helplessness.
Those initially attracted to the thrill of drugs soon become addicts and helplessly
dependent. They develop a sense of craving, heightened states of anxiety and
physical suffering.


--- PAGE 266 ---
246 Coimseiling and Guidance
The youlh is not altogether to be blamed for this state of affairs. In our fast
society, no one has the time even to lie down for a couple of days if feeling unwell.
One has to keep going. The pharmaceutical companies dish out several kinds of
doubtful drugs and advertise their products aggressively and effectively through the
mass media. This makes several people resort to drugs. In fact, the present generation
may be called the drug-devouring generation. People want instant relief, and
therefore, swallow one pill or another. The young, observing the adults resorting to
phoney medicines for instant relief, follow suit This explains how youth arc turning
to drugs. Most adults find it difficult to get relief from their tensions and anxieties
through self-discipline. They find it easier to swallow pills, no matter even if the
relief they feel is only briefer temporary, hi this brave new world, we arc developing
an increasing inability to tolerate even small amounts of physical and emotional
discomfort Modem urbanized industrial societies look for painless life at the cost
of freedom. Incr^ing number of youth turn to drugs that provide a sense of thrill
by creaung feelings of upness'.

established conventions and traditions to serve as guidelines appear to have
abandoned the youth to arbitrary modes of behaviour, which by and large are
inconsistent and often irrational. The young today fmd themselves living in a void
without personal involvement and a sense of belonging. Drugs come to fill the
vacuum and become a means to gain a sense of belonging, to escape from the sense
of alienation. A number of young people are becoming so excited with speed that
they seek drugs which provide them 'kick*. Some drugs lead to hallucinations and
paranoid states. In some cases they even produce a disorientation of time and place
and cause amnesia as the effect of the drug wears off. Continued use of drugs may
produce permanent brain damage and serious personality changes.
The dynamics of drug addiction are complex and not fully understood. However,
a number of socio-cultural and psychological factors have been emphasized. The
personality traits of addicts suggest impulsiveness, rebelliousness, dependency, etc.
As a group they are characterized by low frustration tolerance, inability to endure
tension and exhibiting feelings of inadequacy and self-devaluation. Many addicts
are immature and dependent individuals who have unrealistic levels of aspirations
and are unable to face failures. And thus they begin using drugs for alleviation of
insecurities, anxieties and tensions.
Treatment on a psychological level involves personality assessment which focuses
on the individual's present mental state and on the role of personality and emotional
stress in the development of the disorder. The assessment procedures involve
interviews and use of psychological tests. Information regarding marital, occupational
and other data concerning the individual's life situations is obtained from family
and other sources and the total picture obtained is used as a basis for understanding
and providing appropriate treatment of the disorder. Treatment may involve medical,
psychological and sociological procedures. Medical procedures include drug therapy.
Although it is effective in alleviating some neurotic and psychotic reactions, it does
not lead to resolution of inner conflicts or personality ^ange. Therefore, there is
often a relapse when treatment is withdrawn. Psychological treatment aims at
alleviating the individual's maladjusted behaviour and strives to bring about
personality change to fost^ more effective adjustment Psychological treatment
falls under three categories:
1. Supportive psychotherapy aims at helping the individual feel more adequate
to face his problems confidently.
2. Behaviour modification aims at modifying the individual's maladaptive
behaviour through substitution of more effective coping techniques.
3. Re-educative psychotherapy helps gain an insight into oneself such that one
is able to modify and/or change faulty assumptions and attitudes, paving the
way for fundamental changes in personality organization. It would also be
necessary to deal with the individual's social environment and his/her
adjustment to it. Conditions of stress in the individual's life sihiations that
interfere with his adjusunent should also be modified. In most cases, changes
in family situation help make rnbre effective adjustment possible.
An effective programme of treatment should include medical, psychological and
sociological approaches. Psychological preventive measures need attention in public


--- PAGE 268 ---
248 Counselling and Guidance
education, concerning the detection and correction of pathological tendencies at the
earliest stage. Rehabilitation of the weaned drug addicts is of vital importance.
Psychological and sociological measures have to play an important role in this
regard.

INTRODUCnON
Evaluation is the assessment of the relative effectiveness with which goals or
objectives are attained in relation to specified standards. It is an important step in
the implementation of any programme and has several goals to fiilfil. Firstly, through
a systematic and dependable evaluation, the appropriateness of the programme can
be judged. Secondly, it can help locate the weaknesses or limitations of the
programme, if any, such that suitable remedial steps can be taken to correct the
shortcomings well in time. Thirdly, it can help discover effective measures to
improve the programme. Fourthly, it can indicate to the subjects the nature of
progress made and help motivate them towards more effective results. Fifthly, it
can help the administration or management to make the necessary personnel and
material resources available to the programme to improve its effectiveness. Lastly,
evaluation can be an effective means of demonstrating to the society or county at
large, the meaningfulness as well' as the utiliQ' of the programme.
Counselling is concerned with effecting desirable changes in client behaviour
and experience. The counsellor may choose whatever theoretical orientation he
wishes but he is ultimately concerned with client improvement
The effectiveness of counselling can be evaluated by determining to what extent
the counselling goals have been achieved through a programme of counselling.
According to Shertzer and Stone (1968), the aim of evaluation is to ascertain the
current status of the counselling service within some frame of reference and on the
basis of this knowledge, to improve its quality and efficacy. Evaluation is thus
concerned with an assessment of the outcomes of counselling. Are the results real
or imaginary? Are they permanent or temporary? Are they objective or subjective?
If counselling has been effective, the results must be demonstrable. We may explain
this with the help of an analogy. For example, a class of students should profit from
a teacher's lessons. But if the class does not show any obvious change after being
taught, it is either construed that the teacher has failed or viewed that the pupils
lack motivation. Similarly, when a physician treats his patient it is expected that the
condition of the patient will improve. If the patient does not improve it could mean
that either the physician or the system of therapy used by him has failed. Or it could
even imply that the patient was beyond improvement In counselling we face a
similar situation. When the client does not experience the desirable change, must
it be inferred that either the counsellor or the process of counselling has failed? Or
should it be interpreted that the client was not amenable to the desirable change?

Evaluation of Counselling 251
comparatively difficult to find trained personnel who are well versed with
the techniques of evaluation.
Evaluation, even if concerned with validation, is always with reference to a set
of criteria. The choice of appropriate criteria has been an unsurmountable problem.
In a strict logical sense any criterion has certain built-in Umitadons. These limitadons
would nauirally affect evaluadon. The counselling outcomes can be evaluated in
terms of (1) subjecdve criterion, namely, client sadsfacdon or experience, (2)
counsellor judgement or (3) objecdve criterion, which is independent of both the
counsellor and the client. An independent criterion could be defined as the judgement
of the community. Assessment by a device like a psychological test could also be
used as an objecdve criterion.
Subjecdve criterion, on the face of it, is the most relevant criterion for evaluating
the counselling outcomes. Who else but the client could best judge whether or not
he has profited or improved from counselling? However, a closer examinadon
shows the limitadons of this subjecdve criterion. It is a universally acclaimed fact
that the individual is not the best judge of himself. More often than not, the individual
beleives that 'he knows', but in actuality he is ignorant of himself. Freud's
'unconscious* amply demonstrates this position. It could, therefore, be argued that
the individual can never be the best judge of himself. His responses could be
merely imaginary or at best be auto-suggestions. Th^ is also a false sense of well-
being experienced by patients in physical therapy or clients in counselling*
Consequently, it is argued that the outcome of counselling needs to be evaluated
by some other criterion and not by the client himself.
The counsellor's judgement or appraisal of the client is suggested as a proper
criterion of counselling outcomes. It is argued that the counsellor is best suited to
judge because he alone has knowledge of the initial state of the client before
counselling and the present state of the client after counselling and he has the
necessary professional training to make the proper assessment This argument appears
to be reasonable on the analogy of the physician-padent relationship. The physician
is the best judge of his patient's progress and has the necessary clinical training and
experience. Hie counsellor, it is argued, stands in a similar relation to his client as
the physician to his patient. However, there are many instances in which physicians
as well as counsellors have gone wrong in their judgements. There is another
ticklish problem that comes into the picbire. No counsellor would normally accept
his failures because it would affect his professional status. Therefore, there is a sort
of compelling tendency for the counsellors to claim that their efforts have been
successful. The counselled' may claim success where there is none or exaggerate his
success out of all ]doportions. Naturally, there are serious res^ations about accepting
counsellor judgements as a dependable criterion.
The critics of the subjective criterion of the client judgement and the counsellor
judgement suggest an objective criterion to evaluate and validate counselling gain&
There are certain situations in which objective evaluation is not only practicable but
also the best means of evaluation. But this is not always possible in counselling*
For example, we cannot objectively test the dismissal of an obsession, for it is
purely a psycholo^cal phenomenon. Reports from family members and/or frien^regarding their judgement of a change in behaviour and measures of changes in
I'}; 1,

beyond doubt No psychological lest is valid for all times, for all situations and for
all persons^ The v^dity of every psychological test is specific to the situation for
which it is designed and specific to the class or category of subjects for whom or
with whom it is designed. Therefore, the evaluation of counselling outcomes on the
basis of psychological tests has obvious limitations.
APPROACHES TO EVALUATION
There may be different approaches to the evaluation of counselling outcomes. All
approaches must satisfy three requisites, namely (1) the objectives or goals should
be stated in operaUonal terms such that they can be observed and objecrivelyassessed, (2) the methods sought to be used to assess the objectives must have
demonstrable vahdity and (3) the procedures employed in evaluaUon must be reliable.
In short, any apprwch to evaluaUon should saUsfy the preliminary requirements ofobjectivity, reliabihty and validity.

changes that take place in him as a result of his exposure to counselling. The
advantage of tliis approach lies in its emphasis on the individual and his growth.
It is considered to be a more reliable approach. The drawback of this approach is
that, by its very nature, it is a time-consuming method. Also, since each individual
is unique, gencralizadons from individual data are open to serious limitations. The
massing of data pertaining to different individuals may obliterate the unique features
of the individual approach.
However, evaluation has to be made by either using the subjective criterion,
namely, the client's judgements regarding his own progress or improvement, or the
counsellor's judgement of the client's progress or improvemenL We have already
alluded to the limitations of both the criteria.
1
Experimental Approach
The experimental approach in the counselling situation is fraught with serious
problems, for an experiment involves controls. In the counselling situation control
is very difficult. However, in a limited sense the experimental approach could be
employed to evaluate the counselling outcomes. The basic requirements of this
approach are: (1) determining the objectives, (2) choosing appropriate methods, (3)
selecting two or more groups of subjects who are comparable with one another, (4)
applying counselling techniques which could be measured or scaled and (5)
measuring or assessing the fmal outcomes. The vital step in this approach is the
study of two or more comparable groups. This is a tall order, for with all the.
ingenuity at our disposal it would not be possible for us to assemble groups of
subjects who are comparable with one another to control several variables such that
the independent variable of the counselling process could be related to the outcome
of it (dependent variable).
The evaluation of counselling outconies differs from one area to another, as for
example, the evaluation of counselling outcomes in the scholastic field would differ
from that in the field of vocational choice or vocational adjustment or job satisfacdon
and so on. Depending on the field in which counselling is employed, the criteria
for evaluation have to be determined. For example, in the field of educadon a
problem that is commonly encountered is one of study skills. Counselling in this
area has specific goals like improving comprehension, vocabulary, speed of reading,
memory, etc. Criteria concerning the specific problems, as above, can easily be
defined with a certain amount of objecdvity. The evaluation of a pupil's progress
in learning could be assessed on the basis of such objectively defined criteria as the
number of items recalled or marks obtained and the like.
In the field of vocational choice the problem of evaluation is not so simple
because vocational choice has several repercussions. Client satisfaction depends on
several aspects of occupational life.
In the area of personal counselling, the problem of evaluation assumes more
serious dimensions of a problematic nature than the ones considered in educational
and vocational counselling.
