PROBUM OF MEASURING CHANGE
Of the several problems the one that stands out as the most significant is the
problem of measuring change. In counselling the objective is to bring about
personality change through personality development This phenomenon of change,
or more specifically, personality change, is not comparable to a physical condition
or state or thing, ^en one is concerned with a non-physical phenomenon, or more
sp^ifically, with a process, measurement is not easy. It assumes greater difficulty
if the rate of change is not uniform. And in counselling we cannot conceive of a
uniform rate of change. Therefore, measurement is extremely difficult. The pre-
counselling and post-counselling states of the client are not easily amenable to
objective evaluation. The same psychological instruments cannot be administered
successively to the client for obvious reasons, such as familiarity, knowledge of
content, memory, etc.
The value or usefulness of counselling and psychotherapy has been disputed. In
a shidy published in 1952, Eysenck made a surprising finding that a group of
patients who did not receive any psychotherapy were none the worse as compared
to a comparable group of patients who received some kind of psychotherapy. At the
end of a certain period of time it was found that those who did not receive any
therapeutic a^istance made startling recoveries and a proportion of such recoveries
was not owing to any chance fxtors. According to Eysenck (1952), "roughly two-
thirds of a group of neurotic patients will recover or improve to a marked extent
within about two years of the onset of their illness, whether they are treated by
means of psychotherapy or not". Levitt's (1957) findings with children tended to
cc^cur with that of Eysenck's. Patients and clients do get better if left to themselves.
It may be argued that if clients get better with time there is no sensible purpose in
investing heavily in time, resources and personnel to provide counselling services.
USEFULNESS OF COUNSELLING
The foregoing unmistakably points to the need for demonstrating beyond all doubt
the validity of counselling. Counsellors have to demonstrate the utility of their
services to the community. We mentioned Eysenck's s&idy that tends to discount
the claims of psychotherapy. Eysenck stated the views of such therapists as Glover,
Mowrer and Malan among others who hold that there is no conclusive evidence to
substantiate the claims of the usefulness of psychotherapy. Bixler (1963) too questions
the claims of counselling efficacy. He holds that routine care will improve the
condition of the client to the same extent as does counselling. But Rosenzweig
(1954) criticizes the validity of Eysenck's investigation and his conclusion. He
holds that the criteria of therapeutic success employed by Eysenck differed from
the criteria used by the different therapies. Gonyea (1963) reported negative
relatimiship between the ideal therapeutic relationship and the client's judgement of
his own Improvement. Strupp (1963) appears to be more practic^ in that he
acknowledges the difficulties of measuring the success or outcome of counselling.
Responding to Strupp's (1963) report Eysenck (1964) reiterated his earlier views


--- PAGE 275 ---
EvaJuatSon of Counselling 255
published in 1952. Silverman (1962) considers psychotherapy as an attempt to
teach the individual to develop more constructive concepts of himself. The word
'cure' has unfortunately been used in the counselling context Here it actually
means that the client fmds some relief from his current difficulties.Understood in
this sense, a 'cure' cannot be permanent If this criterion is accepted counselling
outcomes become more meaningful.
The most provocative statement about the effectiveness of client-centered
counselling was made by Rogers (1951). "The careful evaluation of the research
fmdings enables us to draw certain conclusions such as these: That profound changes
occur in the perceived self of the client during and alter therapy; that there is
construcdve change in the client's personally characteristics and personality struchire;
changes which bring him closer to the personality characteristics of the well
funcdoning person; that there is a change in direcdons defmed as personal integradon
and adjustment; that there are changes in the maturity of the client's behaviour as
observed by friends".
Edgar (1966) outlines four assumpdons underlying counselling research: (1)
counselling is lawful and orderly, (2) a cause-and-effect relationship exists within
counselling, (3) the counselling relationship is only a part of the client's experi^ce
in life, and (4) predicted outcomes of counselling can be veritied by conceivable
operations.
Rogers (1961) stressed that change occurs during therapy and it can be measured.
Hie Willoughby Emotional Maturity Scale was employed to measure the observable
change. Rogers contends, "The ove^ conclusions appear justified that where client-
centered therapy is judged to be successful, an observable change in the direction
of maturity of behaviour takes place in the client. Where therapy is judged not to
have occurred in significant degree some deterioration of behaviour is observed".
Notwithstanding the problems such as the ones alluded to in the previous section,
counselling has come to stay and this is proof enough of its utility. But this should
not lead to a complacent attitude. What appears important is the need for empirical
studies in this field. They could be made along two directions,- namely, 'process
research' in which the focus is upon what takes place in counselling and 'outcome
research' which evaluates the results or the final product of cotinselling.
The client-centred q^proach primarily focusses on the counselling process. It
does not concern itself with outcomes, apart fiom the changes that take plaee in the
individual client who is able to experience his self and progressively overcome the
not-self. If the client is able to experience the not-self, that is, widen the self to
include the not-self the client has improved. He is progressing towards self-
actualization which becomes possible when he is able to act as a fully-functioniiig
personality. Rogers and his student Dymond (1954) have made sever^ evaluations
of client-centred therapy. Using pre- and post-therapy states and the clients as their
own control group they found that the client's every-day behaviour does change
and this change is in the desirable direction. They employed the Willoughby
Emotional Maturity Scale to measure behavioural change. The conclusions of this
study were based on the client's self-ratings obtained at four stages, namely (1) pre-
wait stage six months prior to the commencement of counselling, (2) pre-therapy,
(3) during therapy and (4) six months after the conclusion of therapy. Rogers stated


--- PAGE 276 ---
7'^ CoimselUng and Guidance
that there were significant changes in the client's behaviour and there was a
significant increase in maturity in the day-to-day behaviour of the client. This
finding suggests that the client-centred therapy was successful to the extent that
there was an increase in the maiurity of behaviour as judged by the client himself
and by his peers. Dymond (1954) made a simUar study using the same design and
described the results employing the Q-sort technique. The Q-sorts revealed that the
adjustment scores of clients were significantly higher than their initial scores (scores
before the therapy began). A number of criticisms were levelled against Rogers'
experimental design (own control design). Frank (1958), for example, was an
outspoken critic of this approach. Other evaluative studies have been made by
investigators like Cartwright, Kirtner and Fiske (1963). They reported a measurable
change in the subjects' evaluation of themselves. The client tended to be generally
less critical and more acceptant of themselves after therapy. They also judged
themselves to be more adequate. When specific personality changes were investigated
the results obtained were not very significant. This suggests that counselling leads
to an all comprehensive and total change in the clients which on fragmentation for
examination ceases to be significant. Cartwright and Vogel (1960) enquired into the
interesting issue of the amount of change in the clients and they found that (1) there
was a significant change during therapy as assessed by the Q-sort adjustment score.
(2) longer periods of therapy generally tended to be associated with more
improvement, (3) the subjects who had a long pre-wait improved more than the
spontaneous remission group and (4) the amount of change or improvement was
related to the amount of experience of the counsellor or therapist. Another study
was made by Snyder (1953) at the Pennsylvania State College employing instruments,
such as MMPI, Mooney Problem Check List, a client post-therapy scale and a
counsellor post-therapy rating scale. The significant outcome of the study was that
when phenomenological measures of change were used there was an obvious
indication of client change as a result of counselling. But when specific measures,
such as a measure of change in one trait or another were used to assess the counselling
outcomes the results appeared to be somewhat disappointing.
It is now evident that more research studies need to be made employing relevant
experimental designs, instruments and criteria. It is desirable that counsellors invest
more time and energy in research and help improve counselling techniques.
CRITEItIA FOR EVALUATION
Jensen, Coles and Nestor (1955) define a criterion as "a behaviour or a condition
which is or can be described in terms of an ideal and which is a goal". The
counselling process is studied against this criterion. The common goals which the
counsellors try to accomplish are improved adjusunent, a sensible vocational choice,
a realistic self-concept, behavioural change, etc. But all counsellors do not accept
these criteria.
A good criterion must, firstly, be relevant to the problem which has ben posed
for the study, and secondly, it must be measurable. These two attributes must be
considered in the selection of a criterion. We shall discuss some of the criteria
employed in counselling research.


--- PAGE 277 ---
■1
Evaluation of Counselling 2S7
Internal vs External Criteria
There arc two types of criteria based upon data obtained from within and data
obtained from outside the counselling setting.
Internal criteria include (1) the content of the client's communications and
indications of improvement of the client and (2) the counsellor's judgement of the
client's status (improvement).
Internal criteria have the advantage of being directly observable by the client
and the counsellor.
External criteria include client changes which are not subjective and hence are
objective.
Objective vs Subjective Criteria
Objective criteria are quantifiable and do not depend on the judgement of someone
connected with the counselling process. Examples of objective criteria are grades
in school, job tenure, job ratings by supervisors and so on.
Most of the counsellors consider objective criteria as superficial. This perhaps
led to the increased use of subjective criteria. Subjective criteria rely on the judgement
of either the counsellor or the client to determine if the client has attained something
of value through counselling. The client's report of satisfaction with counselling is
the most commonly employed and controversial subjective criterion. Another
subjective criterion is the self-report of the client regarding his degree of personal
adjustment and self-concept.
Reports from family members and friends could also help evaluate counselling
gains. But these are open to errors of subjective assessment and biases. Also, the
measurement of change in selected overt behaviour can be of value in evaluating
limited counselling outcomes.
Lewis (1970) suggests that the combining of several criteria into multiple measures
can lead to the enhancement or improvement of counselling evaluation.
CONTROL OF EXTRANEOUS VARIANCE
The use of control groups is essential in research studies. The evaluation of the
effectiveness of counselling must be made on the basis of individuals essentially
interested in seeking counselling. The effectiveness of counselling can be
demonstrated by providing counselling to some persons who seek counselling
assistance and denying it to others who are equally keen to receive it, then keeping
the latter (the control group) wailing for a period of time (pre-wait) and finally
comparing the two groups for measuring change, using relevant criteria.
In order to maintain the group as a 'tme' control, its members should be
engaged in some activity which is apparently, but not actually, counselling. Patterson
(1964) suggests that what is considered a placebo in counselling may actually be
the specific remedy. Much of counselling gain can be dismissed as simply imaginary
and a demonstration of the placebo effect. A placebo, owiiig to its indistinguishability
from the real drug, sets up an expectation of relief in the patient/client Religious


--- PAGE 278 ---
w
258 Q)un5eJ//;^and Guidance
healers and others, including counsellors, could unintentionally be essentially se
up a placebo effect. For this reason Bixler (1963) demands that "the therapist mdemonstrate that his treaunent is better than doing nothing at all".

Twenty-five years later Campbell (1965) compared the same two groups. The
differences between the two groups were slight but the counselled group repcMted
higher incomes and made greater contributions to society. No difference was found
between the groups on measures of anxiety and self-confidence.
On reviewing the above studies Lewis (1970) arrived at the following conclusions:
1. The effectiveness of counselling stated in general and vague terms is not
researchable. It has not been and probably can never be fumly proved.
2. Motivated clients usually benefit ffom counselling, no matter what criterion
is employed. It is likely that motivation plays an important role—but then
it is difficult to conceive of counselling with an unmotivated client anyway.
3. The effectiveness of counselling can be more easily demonstrated with the
use of objective, but perfiaps superficial, criteria. For example, counselling
with college students clearly helps improve their grades and their probability
of graduation. These could of course have been influenced by other factors
outside the counselling situation.
4. No theoretical appro^h to counselling has been proved sup^or to others.
SUMMARY
Evaluation Is Important for determlrrfng whether counselling goals have been
achieved as a result of tiie Implementation of. the counselling programme. In a
way It Is a method of validating counselling. While the need for evaluation
cannot be overemphasized. It poses serious problems which are not ea^ to
dicumvent. One of the problems Is the problem of devising meaningful criteria.
It Is not easy to Identity valid alteila. In the absence of suitable criteria evaluation
becomes Impractical. The related problem Is: Who should evaluate—the
counsellee, the counsellor or an outside agency? There are arguments for and
against accepting any of them as evaluating Judges.
Notwithstanding all the difficulties and practical problems we cannot do
away with evaluation. It Is essential In all sclentlflc endeavours. It Is hoped that
In future a sufficiently large number of research studies will be undertaken to
obtain objective data for the evaluation of counselling outcomes.

Professional Preparation and Training for Counselling 261
COUNSELLOR PREPARATION AND PROFESSIONAL ISSUES
The nature of preparation for an individual to satisfactorily perform any job will
obviously depend on the nature of the job. Job analysis usually helps in understanding
the job requirements. If the job is simple and requires the performance of routine
activities, the training and preparation will be relatively simple and of shorter
duration. As the job l^omes more complex, the preparadon and training required
become correspondingly elaborate and lengthened. In professional areas, the entering
individuals are expected to funcdon at a higher level than technicians who are
elaborately trained to attend to roudne maintenance problems and funcdons. The
work of a professional individual is not roudne. It is often challenging, requiring
a considerable amount of inidative involving the funcdons of analysis, synthesis,
evaluaUon and cridcal appraisal. So at any dme a given amount of preparadon can
never be complete and final. The individual professional worker, therefore, has to
constantly up-date his knowledge and skills. He could be called upon to deal with
novel siluadons which his specific training may not have equipped him for. He has
to be ingenious and creadve in his outlook. He has to generalize from his experience
to take responsible decisions.
Society is being increasingly operated in ways designed to maximize control,
predictability and flexible adjustment to changing condidons. An important
consequence for counselling is the growing demand for the early selecdon and
training of personnel. There is more need to help people deal with the increasing
complexity of modern living and the consequent frustradons. The social complexity
and rapid rate of social change increase the need for raising the level of competence
in counselling.
During the last two decades, there has been a trend to define every kind of
failure as mental illness. Such disparate behaviour and outcomes as, learning blocks,
under-achievement, school phobias, and delinquency have been uncritically assumed
to be deviations from the norm requiring specialized attention and treatment. Szasz
(1964) has criticized the mental health approach based on an over-generalized
medical model of illness to problems which are essentially educational or vocational.
ACADEMIC PREPARATION
What should a counsellor know? The counsellors functions are not clearly defined.
There is no clearly understood and widely accepted role description of the counsellor.
Some educated people even do not know who a counsellor is or what he doesl
It would do well to state at the outset the goals and objectives of counselling.
This will help to define the areas of counsellor education and counsellor training.
Here it will be useful to distinguish 'education' from 'training'. In some quarters
there is a certain amount of displeasure in the use of the term 'counsellor training*.
It is argued that 'counsellor education' would be a better concept. A well educated
person may not necessarily be efficient in professional skills and practices. Counsellor
education refers to the academic training and broad-based knowledge and
understanding concerning the nature of human development, motivation, learning.

personality and the like. It also includes a thorough understanding and appreciation
of the philosophy and the principles of counselling and other useful and essential
information. Counselling, like other scientific disciplines, comprises a body of
tested knowledge, theories, postulates and assumptions. The potential counsellor
would have to necessarily equip himself with this knowledge so as to gain critical
insights through understanding, analysis, synthesis and evaluation.

Professional Preparation andTialnlngfbrCounselHng 263
ebullient enthusiasm which marked the counselling movement tended to emphasize
the need for appropriate methods from a pragmatic standpoint, to the neglect of the
development of conceptual models which could form a sound theoretical basis for
practice. The counselling movement grew out of the vocational guidance movement
which explains why it did not have a clear theoretical bias. Therefore, it largely
tended to be technique oriented and was less concerned with theory building.
Attention was focuss^ on helping the client, without understanding the integrated
nature of the human organism and the dynamics of problem appraisal. The resolution
of the problem from a psychological point of view did not receive sufficirat attention.
This relatively unsophisticated approach to counselling has undergone several
decisive changes over the years leading to the emergence of counselling as a
professional service.
Individuals who are engaged in professional activities have to face three basic
issues concerning (1) the procedures of selection and the training of prospective
entrants, (2) academic preparation to reach a level of professional standing with
regard to the necessary knowledge and the understanding of the principles and
dynamics of human growth, motivation, adjustment and coping mechanisms and
(3) methods of analysis and synthesis and the appropriate application of the acquired
skills.
The first and foremost of the professional considerations, therefore, concerns
equipping prospective counsellors with the necessary skills and adequate knowledge.
With the progressive growth of knowledge and an increasing understanding of
natural phenomena, what is known and acclaimed as the latest is likely to become
obsolescent as soon as new knowledge and techniques are known. Professional
training and skills by their very nature arc in need of constant revision and updating.
This brings home the related issue, namely, the question of differential service
or different kinds of services to be provided to clients who differ in age, sex,
experience occupation, etc. Similarly, clients could differ with regard to the type
of problems they have and the kind of service they apparently require. Consideration
of these issues suggests that training should not be of an omnibus type. Perhaps
there could be different levels of training:
1. A basic or general type, of training.
2 Training for different specializations depending on the areas or groups or
' situations in which the trainees will be called upon to serve.
ETHICAL STANDARDS
The second problem concerns ethical behaviour which invariably accompanies thedevelopment of a profession. As Wrenn (1952) explains, a profession impUes
•profe^ional* relations with the members of the society and since the counseUingrelationship is a highly personal one, there is a danger of its abuse. It is true thatfew counsellors would deUberately misuse the counseUor-counsellee relationship.
But we cannot be complacent and content with speaking in general terms and about
some or most counsellors. A profession is greater and wider than most of its
members either taken individually or collectively. It is, therefore, essential that
1
■'i¥. y riUk. ^


--- PAGE 284 ---
264 Counsellingand Guidance
professional rules or ethics be laid out or spelled out in no ambiguous terms. This
will create public trust and confidence in the profession.
Though the distinction between ethical and unethical practice is undoubtedly
obvious, in actual practice, there are many complications and the reasons are not
far to seek. Life situations are complex and the causes of unethictd behaviour
naturally are varied and multiple. Schwebel (1955) explains unethical practice to
arise from (1) ignorance, (2) inadequate training and (3) self-interest. For example,
a physician may err in the treatment of his patiwit owing to his ignorance of the
nature of the ailment He may also fail owing to lack of proper training, "^e
consequences of the two situations may be serious in themselves, but if the physician
were to act out of some self-interest and withhold proper treatment, his behaviour
would be unethical and would warrant the harshest punishment. Similarly, a
counsellor may fail owing to his ignorance or lack of appropriate skills resulting
from inadequate training. He may also.act out of self-interesL This last instance
would be viewed as unethical behaviour. However, society cannot be at the mercy
of ignorant and ill-trained professionals. The public has to be protected against the
possible harm done by such persons. This is secured by a system of certification
or licensing. Individuals are granted professional status and permitted to enter the
'occupation' only when the training is adjudged to meet the standards laid down
and the prospective entrants qualify by passing the standards set for them.
Lewis (1970) slates that to determine whether or not a given behaviour is ethical,
a profession should first have general principles to guide its members in their day-
to-day professional activities. A statement of such principles is of utmost importance
and most professional bodies devote considerable attention to such vital issues. For
example, the Medical Council, the Bar Council and other such bodies have spelled
out rules of conduct for their members. Likewise, in the field of counselling,
professional organizations like the American Psychological Association (APA, 1968)
and the American Personnel Guidance Association (APGA, 1968) have each
published a code of ethics to which the members are required to conform (excerpts
of the professional code are presented in the appendix). The code provides guidelines
for the entrant into the professional field and he cannot claim ignorance as a
legitimate defense for his perversion or non-compliance. The codes of conduct
formulated by professional bodies can only be recommendatory and not mandatory.
For strict enforcement of the code of ethics, they should have legal force, that is,
they should be made statutory either1>y an Act of the Parliament or by an Act of
the State Legislature. The former is preferable to secure uniformity throughout the
country.
A code of ethics is not enough. The exigencies of practice may bring up many
dilemmas and delicate issues of implied ethical concern. There is need for arousing
the ethical sense in the professional practitioner. It should become a part of his
professional self-concept. In the field of counselling the counsellor has his primary
responsibility to his client This may sometimes clash with the interest of the
institution which employs the client or clash with the interests of the client's family
or thoes of another individual. Yet the counsellor's responsibility cannot be
compromised. His responsibility is to his client. The second is the counsellor's
responsibility to the society. For that matter, all citizens are responsible to the


--- PAGE 285 ---
Profissslonal Preparation and Training for Counselling Z65
society to which they belong and in a wider sense to humanity as a whole. As a
professional practitioner, the counsellor's responsibility is greater than the
responsibility of a non-professional individual. The professional person has to take
such action as would contribute to the welfare and commonweal of tbe society. The
counsellor has a responsibility to his profession. He should work for the progress
of his profession and strive at all times and in all situations to further its interests.
Next, the counsellor has a responsibility to himself as an individual, as a member
of his family and as a member of this community.
Usually the several responsibilities and most of the life situations are compatible
with one another. Occasionally there may arise situations in which the counsellor
is confronted with dilemmas and conflicting situations. In such situations the ethical
codes may not be of much value to the counsellor. He has to fall back upon his
'own sense of values' or value system, his self-concept and his sense of self-regard.
This would help him in arriving at and relying on his own judgement
The most important area of ethical concern in counselling is confidentiality. This
concerns the information shared by the client with the counsellor which may be
very sensitive in nature. Even a slighdy careless handling of the information may
prove not only to be quite embarrassing for the client but also positively harmful
to his interests. The ethical Codes of most helping professions include an unequivocal
statement regarding confidentiality. The American Psychological Association (1968)
observes, "safeguarding information about an individual that has been obtained by
a psychologist... is a primary obligation of the psychologist... information received
in confidence is revealed only after most careful deliberation and when there is
clear and imminent danger to an individual or to society and then only to appropriate
professional workers or public authorides."
Lewis (1970) lists the following relating to ethical practice:
1. It is unethical to discuss a client with other persons. While this is plausible,
what about consulting with another professional person? In so far as this is
done (as in a case conference) to help the counsellor deal with his clients
better, discussing information about a client with professional persons is not
unethical. There is the question of intention. If it is to help the client, there
is nothing unethical about the matter. However, if the intention is
questionable, then a discussion of the client's information borders on the
unethical.
2. Frequently councilors are approached for information by other persons
(parents, relatives, friends, etc.) and institutions (schools or employers).
Except in circumstances which clearly warrant such sharing of information,
the counsellor is not expected to divulge any part of it without first seeking
the client's unconditional permission. A counsellor should not violate the
principle of confidentiality, even if he were to believe that a discussion of
the client with his/her parent, teacher or boss as the case may be, would be
helpful in understanding the client better.
3. Should the counsellor give information to the government or to the
employers? Here again the counsellor is not bound to please them for any
reason and he has no business to violate the principle of confidentiality. His
first and foremost obligation is to the client.


--- PAGE 286 ---
266 Counsellingand CuldancB
However, the situation is different when the client is an applicant for a job and'
his prospective employer (government or a private institution) would want
information to conrider the client for employment. Eyen in this situation, the
counsellor is not obliged to divulge any information unless he is specifically permitted
by the client to give the necessary information to the prospective employers.
Frequently the counsellor may administer psychological tests to his client After
he is counselled, what should be done with the data? Who should have access to
the data? The client and the counsellor or some other person or agency? Once again
there is no room for ambiguity at all and any information including test data
obtained from the client in connection with counselling is to be treated as confidential
material and should not be transmitted to others without the client's express
permission. Test data are also often obtained in non-counselling contexts, such as
vocational guidance, educational guidance, etc. However, in such situations, testing
is not the direct responsibility of the counsellor and, therefore, must be treated
differently.
In counselling sessions the interview may be taped. Could such taped material
be used in training counsellors? Yes. if prior permission is obtained from clients for
uring the material in a harmless way for constructive purposes. If there is no
concurrence on the part of the concerned clients, it is specifically unethical to use
the tapes for any purpose whatsoever.
It should be emphasized that any infonnaiion obtained ffom the client by the
counsellor is a private communication and that it cannot be violated under any
circumstances or at any time without the specific permission of the client
Another very, important ethical issue concerns the competence of the counsellor
to provide the appropriate service. This is a very tricky question. Who outght to be
the judge? Once the counsellor obtains his certificate after training (and obtains his
licence or a certificate of practice where such regulation is statutory), he is firee to
accq>t any client. He himself is under an obligation to determine and judge whetho^
or not he can provide the necessary help and service to the client. The counsellor
may honestly ^lieve that he can, but it may be only his misconception. An outsider
caimot judge the matter. It is entirely for the counsellor to take the responsibility.
It should be specifically understood that the counsellor must make every effort to
correct any false impressions which the client may derive concerning his
qualificadons and competence. Ik should, if necessary, make a referral. Occasionally
a client may refuse to accept a referral (such situations are very common and
frequent in the field of medick practice). Should the counsellor continue to counsel
or should he terminate the relationship? It is necessary that the counsellor should
help the client make a realistic assessment of the situation and act in accordance
wiA his (counsellor's) professional advice. If this is not heeded, there appears to
be no alternative but to terminate the relationship.
hi considering the counsellor's functions in the counselling relationship, we
have focussed on the counsellor as a practitioner. A counsellor has also to be a
researcher and this poses certain subtle problems. Should the human subject be
treated as a guinea-pig? Can the counsellor delve into the innermost experiences of
human individt^ for purposes other than the amelioration of suffering? Sometimes
the purposes or objectives of specific research have to be kept away from the


--- PAGE 287 ---
Professional Prepamtlon and Training for Counselling 267
subjects. In such situations are we justified in keeping the subjects in the dark? Tbe
ethics of research is too complex and intricate an issue to be discussed in g^t
detail in the present context
LEGAL CONSIDERATIONS
Licensing and certification are used as the basis for legally controlling the practice
of several professional areas. In the USA, statutes are in force in most States to
ensure proper supervision through licensing and cerdfication. In India this has not
attracted the attention of either the central or the state governments. As a profession
reaches maturity, it becomes necessary that legally it be recognized through licensing
and certification. The major intention for such measures is to prevent pseudo-
practitioners from entering the freld. When statutes are made counsellors have to
be largely involved in the process of drafting them and no real purpose will be
served to treat them as mere legal matters.
The statutes should be broad-based and should involve almost all kinds and
types of counsellors—child,-school, vocational, parent, marital, etc.
SELECTION AND TRAINING OF COUNSELLORS
Counsellors vary in the quality of help they can provide. Those who are highly
competent and skilled are able to produce better results. Therefore, it is the primary
obligation of the profession to provide the expertise to produce desirable results in
the clients.
All professional fields attach considerable importance to the selection of suitable
persons to be trained to become members of a profession, for example, medicine,
engineering, etc. For proper criteria to be laid out it is necessary for the different
functions of counsellors to be identified. Primarily counselling is a helping function.
Therefore, it is closely related to the needs and characteristics of the social system
in which it is to function and operate, and also to the resources,—^personnel and
material—, available to the system. For exmple, counselling services are
comparatively highly developed in the USA. They are almost non-existent in India.
With rapid industrialization and urbanization, the traditional modes of functioning
and the charateristics of the Indian society are fast breaking down, necessitating the
increasing provision of counselling services. Demographic growth, income
distribution, educational access, etc., go to det^mine the nature of services required
by the society.
In the developing countries the following limitations have prevented and
sometimes distorted the development of counselling:
1. Lack of proper understanding of what counselling is, leading to confusion
and false expectations.
2. Lack of financial support owing to the general poverty of the developing
countries.
3a. Introduction of unrealistic models of functioning. For instance, imitaiion


--- PAGE 288 ---
268 Counsellingand Culdan^
and emulation of the kind of services available on the campuses of US
universities, such as student personnel services, by the Indian universities.
Such services are too expensive to be of value in the Indian context,
b. Emphasis on models of help unsuited to the milieu. For example, the average
Indian, or for that matter the Oriental, is largely conventional in his outlook,
while in the West, and more especially in USA, people are unconventional
and individualistic.
4. Lack of proper coordination between the available agencies of assistance
leading to wastefulness and duplication of effort.
5. Absence of educational and employment avenues to serve as the primary
source for counselling activi^.
6. Social and economic means of a large part of the population lying below the
poverty line, making counselling an unrealistic exercise.
Most social systems are committed to achieving human well-being. The leaders
of such systems recognize the need for counselling but do not give it the kind of
priority it deserves owing to lack of personnel and material resources.
CONCEPnON OF A PROPESSIONAL WORKER
Counselling in education is not an instrument for economic development but an
instrument for the development of human resources. Counsellors have to help
individuals think for themselves, make decisions for themselves, and if necessary,
reorient their lives. Therefore, counselling should never be narrowed down to
counselling for a job, it has to be counselling for life, a life prepared for facing
challenging changes. Thus counselling is an integral part of learning.
A pragmatic programme would mm at preparing professionals to function at
different levels and activities in counselling programmes. The competencies required
for counselling individixals would differ from those required for working with
groups. Counselling in community situations transcends the 'cubicle relationship*.
PREPARATION OF COUNSEUORS
A balanced and sound training programme should include:
1. Basic theoretical ineparation—^Understanding of motivation, psychodynamics
of human adjustment, learning of principles and other concepts that underlie
counselling.
2. Technical and applied knowledge—Knowledge of test use and interpretation,
interviewing skills and competencies in speciaSzed procedures of intervention.3. A broad-based practicum and training for enabling the counsellors to meet
any exigencies.
4. Practical training.
There is no finality with regard to training. But it can be stated without any
hesitatioii that the counsellor moat kaaw


--- PAGE 289 ---
Professional PrepamaonandTralnlngfyrComselllng 269
cultural background of the clients. The programme could comprise a four-semester
Master's course in counselling psychology, augmented by a year's professional
training programme.
Counsellors need to have sound knowledge and critical understanding of individual
differences and their significance. The improtance of the study of culture arises
from its impact on man's development of his unique personality through imbibing
the surrounding values and developing his own individual set of values. It is now
recognized that cultural di^erences have far-reaching effects on individual values
and personality development
The earlier medical model emphasized ^the importance of remediation. With a
greater appreciation of the significance of the cultural background and its influence
on human development, the limited concept of remediation is fast yielding place to
the perspective of developing positive values in the client.
IMPORTANT ISSUES
The coimseDor Prerequisites
Should counsellors have teaching experience? Some tend to think that teaching
experience is necessary since it is believed to provide useful insights. Further,
teaching experience is supposed to give a basic understanding and appreciation of
the role of teachers. Teaching experience is expected to provide counsellors with
opportunities and experiences to observe pupils in classroom situations and the
conditions that could facilitate or inhibit learning. These reasons suggest that teaching
experience is useful for counselling. However, some administrators believe that
teaching experience for a counsellor is unnecessary. It is argued that counselling
and teaching are different activities and that teaching experience can result in
undesirable attitudes like authoritarianism. It is suggested that by providing suitable
internship experience, the prospective counsellors could be helped to gain the
necessary understanding of the school environment, common pupil needs, parental
expectations, etc.
^Mcialists or General CoimseUors
Opinion is also sharply divided with regard to the question of whether the counsellor
should be a generalist or a specialist The advocates of the generalist role hold that
it is often necessary for a counsellor to perform a host of administrative functions.
In addition to the administrative duties, the counsellors may be often required to
coordinate the several services and find the necessary resources for their
implementation. As opposed to this view, it is vehemently argued that the counsellor
should be a specialist. It is held that the counsellor performs specific functions of
counselling at the professional level. It would be a sheer waste of his training, time
and energy, if he were to devote himself to non-counselling activities. Teachers can
perform many of the functions which counsellors usually do, thus enabling the
counsellor to devote his time and energy to counselling work. The specialist versus
generalist controversy is overlooked by a few people. But it cannot be over-


--- PAGE 290 ---
270 CounseilingandGiidance
emphasized thai the purpose of specialization is to provide expert service. The
genetalist is often found to take on the responsibilities usually discharged by the
teachers. In this context, the issue whether a school counsellor should be treated as
a technician or as a professional worker comes to the fore. It is held that the school
counsellor is no more than a technician on the ground that he is employed in the
schools essentially to assist teachers. Therefore, counselling is viewed as a subsidiary
function to be performed by personnel other than teachers. The view that the school
counsellor is essentially responsible for professional service is held on the ground
that the judgements he m^es concern the fundamental and vital issues of the
personalities of the pupils. Therefore, this kind of work which is of a complex
nature cannot be fit^ into the daily routine of the school.
A related question usually posed concerns the scope of the activities of school
counsellors, "^e idea that the preparation of school counsellors is mostly directed
towards educational and vocational decision-making activities is not justified.
Teachers, parents and the students themselves expect the school/college counsellor
to assist young men and women with their curricular, educational and vocational
planning. As against this view, it is often pointed out that most educational problems
involve emotional factors and it is unrealistic and dangerous to neglect the emotional
issues. In addition, those who apparently seek educational or vocational assistance
may actually need help in the area of personal adjustment also. Most competent
school teachers are seized with this problem of emotional blocks and take pains to
get them resolved.
The importance of the need for providing counselling assistance is increasingly
being recognized by teachers, administrators and the community. The counsellor,
therefore, is recognized as a person who provides specialist and professional service
to the pupils vyho need such help. However, since the number of pupils who need
such assistance is large, the counsellors find it impracticable to reach them all.
Hence, a new counsellor role has emerged. This is consultancy. Counsellors can
serve a larger numWr of students by consulting teachers, headmasters, principals
and parents.
In view of the specialist role of the counsellor, increasing attention is being paid
to such issues as the criteria for selection and standards of counsellor preparation.
Interdisciplinary studies are being recommended for enlarging counsellors'
a|q)reciation of the cultural heritage and value systems and to provide a wider scopefor the perception and understanding of human behaviour. The extent of preparation
of counsellors has direct,relevance, to the length of the training programme. The
complexity of a counsellor's job requires preparation of a high order for working
effectively with children, youth and adults in a variety of situations. The exact
nature of the training programme would naturally be based on the job requirements
of the counsellors which depend on the situations in which the counsellors work.
But to base the training programmes on a counsellor's current duties and functions
may not be very useful. Counsellors need to be equipped and prepared, for meeting
unexpected demands in novel situations. Therefore, there is need for stressing
creativity and originality. This is best done by integrating didactic instruction with
an imaginatively designed practicum (comprising laboratory, field study and work
experience). The practicum experience should provide self-analytical and self-


--- PAGE 291 ---
PfoPesstonal Preparation and Training Ibr Counselling Z71
evaluative insights which should be spread across the entire period of training to
enable the counselling student to take on progressively increasing responsibilities.
Counsellors can not only help in the educational vocational choice process but also
in choices concerned with the day-to-day life situations by helping the counsellees
gain self-understanding and become increasingly self-directed and self-dependent
Other issues may surface in the course of the counsellor's professional work which
are not easy to anticipate. Counsellors will be able to resolve the issues, professional
or otherwise, with ease if they are trained to be tactful and rational and have an
abiding faith in human worth and capabilities.
SUMMARY
Counselling as a professional field of service is yet to emerge in India. This is
because firstly, there are no employment opportunities for trained counsellors
and secondly, there are no qualified or trained personnel. This Is a vicious circle
which needs to be broken IF we want to progress. The counselling profession Is
a service profession and. therefore, the selection of the right people ceinnot be
over-emphasized. The prospective entrant to the Held of counselling, It has been
found, would make a success ifhe were to have the necessary personality traits.
The characteristics of a successful counsellor cannot be Inventoried with success
because such a venture would Irtvoive the listing ofail the desirable characteristics
which Is not obviously practicable. A few characteristics, however, may be
listed. A counsellor must be interested In helping people, must be kind, sincere,
emotionally mature, understanding, ^rmpadietlc. knowledgeable, able, InteUlgent
and have a sense of commitment to his profession. One of the Important
characteristics that marks a good counsellor Is his helping attitude.
Counsellor training Involves providing academic and practical training. While
no training programme can ever be complete and final, it has been found that a
desirable counsellor tr«iinlng programme must involve the following: (1)
understanding the process of development tmd the determinants and dynamics
of personality, (2) personality theories,_(3) learning theories. (4) psydiodlagnostic
principles and procedures, (5) psychopathology; (6) social ptychology, (7)
principles and process of counselling and (8) counselling theory. And for
specialization a desirable counsellor training programme must Involve: educational
counselling, vocational counselling, group approaches to counselling and
cowselllng special groups. The counsellor-trainee must have a good practlcum
and supervised counselling experience. The programme envisaged Is a two-year
or four-semester Master's level programme find this may be supplemented by a
one-year professional training programme.

14
odem Tirends in
INlHODUCnON
Counselling as a fast growing dynamic movement has rapidly progressed from its
modest beginnings in the early part of the present century to its current dynamic
Status in a brief period of six decades. In the rapidity of its growth, counselling has
overlooked many issues, causing apparent confusion with psychotherapy,
psychoanalysis, behaviour conditioning, guidance, advising, etc. Yet it is all these
things in one way or the other. The counselling function is claimed to be performed
also by ministers, physicians, social workers, teachers and many others whose
number is ever on the increase. Though counselling, like any other science, is based
on scientific principles of objectivity and verifiability it cannot proceed in the
absence of subjective aspects, such as rapport, warmth and trust
Counselling has earned recognition through its service in enhancing and preserving
human happiness. It is found to be of service by different organizations for increasing
their efficiency and productivity. In the history of its growth, as a science and as
a profession, it has changed its emphasis, aims and roles as can be seen firom its
expanding range of activities in diverse sellings.
What are the dominant trends in the counselling movement? Humanistic
psychology is coming into prominence. Modem counselling clearly shows its cant
to existential views with a significant stress on meanings and personal values in
life. Traditionally, psychology in general, and counselling in particular, tended to
emphasize behaviour—^its pre^ction and control. Their concerns were, for example,
the screening of students for admission to schools and colleges, the selection of
suitable candidates for specific occupations and the increase in personal efficiency
of individuals through narrowly defined diagnoses and psychotherapeutic measures
based on them. There is increasing evidence today that counselling has outgrown
this stage and is becoming increasingly concerned with values and value systems.
CCHINSELUNG AND PSYCHOTHERAPY
The terms 'counselling' and 'psychotherapy' were generally used as disparate terms.
However, an increasingly large number of writers are tending to use them


--- PAGE 293 ---
Modem Trends In Counselling 273
interchangeably. Also the terms, advising, guidance and counselling, have been for
some time used rather loosely. But with increasing specialization and
professionalization, some amount of clarification of the terms is made. Clarification
of the inter-relationship between the terms, namely, advising and guidance, clears
the ground for a discussion of the terms, counselling and psychotherapy. Advising
has now come to be understood as academic advising provided by faculty members
to students who seek assistance concerning their curricular choices. Guidance is
used mostly in educational settings with vocational import. It also involves the
provision of educational and vocational information to enable students to make a
proper choice of courses leading to appropriate vocational goals. Guidance services
understood in this sense have been increasingly found to operate in high-school
settings.
Chronologically speaking, psychotherapy existed long before the emergence of
counselling as a helping service. Psychotherapy can be said to have had its origin
in the work of Mesmer. However, sound and scientific foundations for it were laid
by Freud. Psychoanalysis was acclaimed as psychotherapy par excellence. In the
years that followed, many other techniques were introduced into psychotherapy.
Counselling emerged as a rield of psychotherapy. Both counselling and psychotherapy
aim at changing individuals rather than institutions. Social reform movements are
specifically concerned with the latter. Further, the kind of change sought to be
brought about is different from the change a salesman or an executive or a priest
seeks. Counselling intends to make individuals more self-directed and autonomous.
Thus, the function of counselling is to facilitate the development of self-actualization
in persons. Counselling and psychotherapy are often distinguished in terms of the
siuiations they tackle. In the case of psychotherapy there is an element of pathology
.present in the client
Hie distinction between counselling and psychotherapy was sought to be made
in terms of the nature of the clientele catered to by them. It was argued that
counselling concerns itself with normal individuals and intends to prevent the
occurrence of emotional breakdowns. On the other hand, psychotherapy, it was
claimed, deals with individuals who are not normal. Some element of
psychopathology was involved and clinical treatment was indicated to remedy the
situation. But this distinction was considered unacceptable as abnormality could not
be defined in irrefutable terms. The problem of distinguishing the terms became so
involved that the American Psychological Association (APA) felt it necessary to
entrust the problem to its Committee on Definition, Division of Counselling
Psychology. Counselling, it is pointed out, is essentially concerned with the
psychological development of the individual and it contributes to the total
development of personality.
Counselling is not, it is claimed, an emergency treaunent Psychotherapy, on the
other hand, is concerned with the individual whose emotional growth has become
severely distorted. Bordin makes a quantitative rather than a qualitative distinction
between the terms. According to him, counselling is concerned with emotional
cases of less intensity and he emphasizes cognitive and rational factors in their
treatmenL In cases requiring psychotherapy, however, there is a greater distortion
of reality and cognitive and rational factors may not be of much avail. Sanderson

The distinction between counselling and psychotherapy has unnecessarily crea^confusion. What is important to bear in mind is that counselling is one type or kind

ROU OF A COUNSELLOR
The counsellor's role has been redefined and expanded from that of an expert or
specialist who deals with his clients exclusively on a one-to-one basis to that of a
staff-consultant and agent of institutional change. This is a very significant
developmenL The counsellor can be seen in the role of a counsellor-consultant and
he is increasingly involved with consulting academic staff and teaching them skills
ancillary to counselling. The consultant, counsellor attempts to:
1. Enhance teachers' sensitivi^ to student problems of personal growth (Rao,
1967).
2. Demonstrate the application of psychological principles of learning to human
problem solving.
3. Improve the effectiveness of the academic facul^ in institutions of higher
learning.
Another welcome trend is the extension of counselling services to new areas.
The early counselling services were primarily concem^ with younger people,
especiall>L-Studenl&Jn-schools. and_collegM^.The interesting feature of modem
demographic trends is the increase in the proportion of the population in the older
age groups in almost all countries and this poses several pertinent problems which
have not been sufficiently researched. While counselling does not underestim^
4he importance of its service to growing people it is now also looking towards
assisting middle-aged and older people. There is another group of clients whom
counsellors are getting actively interested in. This group comprises women, especially
young and middle-aged ones. Tim high risk students, ttet is, those who are not
likely to make good grades^are ^so^towing tiie counsellor's attention. The^
a^^ to be in greater need of intensive academic counselling. Similarly," familycouns^ing and counselling of minority people and imihigi^t populations are also
promising areas in which counselling is branching out.
A couple of decades back there was a dramatic rise in the use of behavioural
counselling whose nature has been discussed earlier. Notwithstanding the enormous
experimental research using the principles of reinforcement, shaping, desensitization,
aversive conditioning, etc., behavioural counselling has not been found quite
acceptable and applicable in all situations. This has given rise to a lively controversy
which centres on behavioural counselling and appears less related to its ability to
produce changes in people than to the moral and ethical questions involved.
Humanistically-oriented counsellors are distressed by the notion of the control of
behaviour and they frequently make the charge that advocates of behaviour
modification are not sufficiently sensitive to needs, such as personal goals and
f^om of growth of the clients. Behavioural counsellors maintain that their methods
do not entail any threat to individual freedom of choice. However, the limitations
of behavioural counselling,* such as failure to demonstrate' the durability of the
changes produced, amelioration of the self-defeating behaviour of such groups as
alcoholics, drug addicts and the like, have dampened their enthusiasm and there is
revived interest in the humanistic-oriented approach.

THE MODEL OF COUNSELLING
Even before the emergence of counselling as a professional movement, a wide
variety of approaches and orientations were in vogue. Such intervention concepts
as prevention, remediation, outreach, normal development, use of paraprofession^s,
etc., had gained currency. In the contemporary scene counsellors are found to be
working in different situations—individual, group, community—and in such
institutions as schools, vocational bureaux, child guidance centres, etc. This reveals
that neither these new concepts, such as group-counselling, micro-counselling, etc.,
nor the new functions of the counsellors, such as vocational counselling, career-
counselling, employment-counselling, etc., have been brought under and unified
within a single conceptual framework.
There is no theoretical model conceived to provide for the integration of the
expanding activities of the increasing number of counsellors within a single
conceptual framework. Such a model or conceptual frame would be useful for
practitioners, researchers and theoreticians. In this context, the work of the Western
Inter-State Commission for Higher Education (WICHE) assumes great significance.
The Three Dimensional Model
A team of counsellors who were working for WICHE, led by Clyde Parker (1974),
proposed a three dimensional model of counsellor functions. This model was
recognized to be of both practical as well as heuristic value.
For a long time the counselling relationship was described as a face-to-face and
one-to-one relationship between the counsellor and counsellee. But this view has
lost much of its force under the mounting pressure of the need for economizing
effort and maximizing effect This has led to. outreach intervention, in the form of
group counselling. Thus the intervention earlier believed to be only at the individual
level has now widened progressively to deal with (1) the individual, (2) the primary
group, (3) the associational group and (4) the institution or community. The target
of intervention could be any one of the four. The counsellor may work with the
individual, trying to alleviate his personal suffering, or he may work with a primary
group, such as the family or a small group comprising less than ten members,
helping to clarify goals and objectives or helping to improve communication channds
and the like. Sometimes a counsellor may be called upon to work with a largw
group, such as a class in a school. In this context the counsellor may be a participant
observer or may help the group apply itself to finding practicable solutions to
problems involving team work. It may also be necessary for the counsellor to woric
with an institution or a community.
The purpose of intervention at any one of the four levels described above may
be for (1) remediation, (2) prevention, (3) acquisition or learning and (4) development
This comprises the second dimension. Remediation may involve overcoming a
behavioural problem or a habit, such as drug addiction or alcoholism or an
adjustmental problem. Prevention may comprise prophylactic action involving a
programme of mental hygiene or mental health. Such action may not be concerned
with the present situation but with future outcomes so that undesirable behaviour
likely to appear in the. future is prevented. The purpose of intervention may not be


--- PAGE 298 ---
CounselUngand Guidance
sss I— >»development of new attitudes m the members of a communily.
The tlurd dimension of counseUor action concerns the method of miervenuon.
This could be W conventional or traditional direct-service, (2) consultatioii andtrmiting and (.3) media-approach. The objective of counseUing could be the alleviation
of individual suffering, the choice of a vocational career, etc. The method ofintervention could be one of assisting the individual (client) (hrectly by discussing
with turn, by giving him necessary information or counselling him in a face-io-fac®
situation. This is direct-service traditionally practised by counsellors. In recent
times another method of intervention through consultation and training has com®
to be recognized as a practical method. In this method of intervention the counsellor
may be consulting a small group of individuals and training them, who would in
their turn implement the intervention programme to wider or larger groups ofindividuals. For example, the counsellor may trmn a ^oup of school teachers who
would provide guidance services to a large number of pupils. The third method ofintervention is aimed at a much wider section of the community through different
media, such as newspaper articles, brochures, books, radio talks, film shows and
television.
The three dimensions of counsellor functioning, therefore, concem (1) the target-
individual, primary group, associational group and institution or community (2)
intervention (the goal or objective of assistancej-remediaUon, prevention,
acquismon and development (learning) and (3) the methods of intervention-direct
service, consultauon and trairang and media-approach

--- PAGE 299 ---
Modem Trends In Counseillns 279
The earlier method of catering individually to clients had serious limitations.
These are (1) the cost in terms of time and money spent, and (2) the inability to
deal with a large number of clients, all of whom may need assistance urgently. This
leads to a modification of the intervention methods. For example, it is not feasible
for a single school counsellor to meet ail the pupils in the school but it is possible
for him to meet all the teachers a number of times and train them to render assistance
to all the pupils. This mode of approach, namely, consultation and training is now
becoming more popular.
But mass me^a has to be resorted to intervene in an effective manner in the
community for such programmes as family planning, eradication of drug abuse,
smoking, alcoholism, etc.
Thus the three-dimensional model of counsellor functions auempts to embrace
the activities of counsellors in a variety of situations and for achieving different
goals.
In addition, it may be useful if other recognized dimensions of counselling are
briefly described. One of the questions concerns its duration. The early therapies
of the psychoanalytic school were all long-term in nature. The disadvantages of this
approach were too serious to be ignored. Modified psychoanalytic therapies were
introduced with some success. But while counselling should not be too time-
consuming, it may also not be effective if it is too brief. Howevw, the duration of
therapy is largely determined by the counsellee's response.
An important dimension of therapy concerns its depth. It may be contrasted with
the supportive form of therapy which involves reassuring the counsellee by providing
the necessary guidance and by reinforcing existing coping mechanisms. Depth
therapy, on the other hand, helps the individual to' overcome deep-rooted conflicts
and traumatic experiences. The goal of depth therapy is to secure personality
integration and effective coping pattans. While depth therapy is usually long-term
in nature, supportive therapy is comparatively brief.
Another interesting aspect of counselling practice is the use of two different
strategies of segregated versus total push coimselling. In the segregated therapy a
counsellor helps the client with a single problem at a time and no attempt is made
to relate it to the life situation of the clienL This is a kind of minimum therapy. In
the total push abroach the counsellor is concerned with the client's overall life
situation. This may naturally concern several problems and may involve working
with other members of the family and community agencies, both professional and
non-professional. Therefore, the total push approach is also designated as 'milieu
therrgty'.
A distinction is also drawn between crisis intervention therapy and personal
growth. As can be readily understood the former is directed at aspects ofimmediate
stress and their removal to provide quick and immediate relief. Such relief could
be of a short-term duration. In contrast, a personal growth-centred approach primarily
focuses on the problem of increased self-understanding and development ofnntendalitles for the fulfilment of the inftivirtnol'e »rnai Tt.« . jpotentialities for the fulfilment of the individual's goal. The crisis intervention and
growth approaches could be used more effectively with normal individuals though
their use with maladjusted persons cannot be underestimated.
The preceding approach is very closely related to eliminating maladaptive patterns


--- PAGE 300 ---
of behaviour and developing coping techniques and competencies. The former may
involve a strategy of short-term intervention involving a segregated type of crisis
intervention. This is achieved by adopting behaviour modification techniques. The
developing competencies approach corresponds to the personal growth approach.
This can be secured by either the inner control or the outer control of the behaviour
of the counsellee. The aim of therapy or counselling in this case is to control the
individual's (client's) behaviour through establishing environmental controls. The
external controls can at best be emergency measures and may not have lasting
effects. Therefore, inner controls have to be developed in the client which could
change his value assumptions.
It will be seen from the above that counselling has to be broad in its approach
and expectations. The three-dimensional model of counsellor functions briefly
described in the first part of this chapter and the different innovative approaches of
counselling outlined in the latter part adumbrate the present status and scope of
counselling. It is rapidly working towards the goal of freeing the individual of his
•conditioned' habits, modes of thought, coping mechanisms, interests, attitudes and
values, thus enabling him to confidently face the 'future shock' of a super-
industrialized society where values have no permanency.
VALUES IN COUNSULING

--- PAGE 301 ---
Modem Trends In Counselling 281
technological modes of living. Many aspects of this movement are of considerable
concern to the counsellor. What are the effects of this thrust? Is it true that the
effects of rapid industrialization are the disruption of inter-personal relations, an
increase in crime, alienation of the youth, disrespect for elders, sharp increase in
delinquent behaviour and other maladjustments? How should the counsellor deal
with this situation?
With advances in the field of medicine, environmental hygiene and better nutrition,
man's longevity has increased. What is the role and status of these older people in
society? Retirement from positions of authority and prestige can be a very devastating
experience. How can the 'retirement-shock'be assuaged? The counsellor's role should
be to assist the 'senior citizens' to make optimum adjusunent
The tremendous technological progress may create problems of obsolescence or
unemployment where the government could suggest two approaches—'recyclage',
that is, using adult members for new tasks by putting them through well-planned
and designed refresher-courses, or 'encyclage*, that is, providing training to
individuals in occupations different from those they are engaged in to enable them
to enter new careers, if it becomes necessary. The counsellor will, therefore, have
to play the role of a cultural mediator and help individuals adjust themselves to the
new conditions of living. This has implications for value-orientations in counseUing.
Should the counsellor impose his values on the clients? It is agreed in all circles
that he should not, but he inevitably does. He must inculcate the development of
healthy and desirable attitudes.
By establishing warm and friendly relations, the counsellor has to help clients
overcome their inhibitions about discussing their problems freely and openly with
him. The next issue concerns decision-making. In the western culture this comprises
a very important aspect of the counselling of young people. But in oriental cultures
in general, and India in particular, decision-making is to a certain extent culturally
determined. A young man or a woman is expected to consult the adult members of
the family even in matters such as choosing a course 'of study, entering a specific
occupation or choosing a life partner. Hence, autonomy, independence and the
ability to stand on one's own feet and make one's own decisions are not stressed
upon. In western cultures, however, these are considered positive attributes.
In India we are passing through an unenviable phase of transition. There is a
tendency to cling to past values and simultaneously crave for things which are not
consonant with the past values. This has resulted in an identity crisis, particularly
of the youth. The counsellor has to be mature enough to strike an appropriate
balance and help the youth to have sound values. The counsellor could have problems
with his counsellees who may be struggling with the new values and trying to cling
to the past values. This may lead to a clash between loyalty to old values and the
desire to pursue new values. The counsellee's value structures are thus of a crucial
nature and the counsellor has to. work in terms of his own value structure which
may not be similar to that of the counsellees. In this context the counsellor isconcerned with the question of whether or not to impose his own values upon his
clients. The basic admonition is that the counsellor should not impose his values.
But he invariably does so either unknowingly or unwittingly.
In the contemporary Indian context several basic values, traditionaUy heia


--- PAGE 302 ---
282 CounselUngand Guidance
sacrosanr-t, are increasingly being questioned. One of the major values concerns the
attitude to authori^. Youth is becoming increasingly resentful of authority and the
implications of this for counselling are obvious. The closer the counsellor is to
administrative authority the farther he will be fixim his counsellee. In the words of
Wrenn, the counsellor should "bd a person who does not represent authority per se,
but who represen^ the concem/for the individual per se".
The 'generation gap' also affects counselling. The importance of past experiences
for solving present problems is becoming questionable. The counsellor too must be
on his guard not to reason firom his past experience for this may not always give
him a clue to understanding the counsellee's problems.
As has been mentioned earlier, the attitude towards women has undergone a
considerable change. They are no longer confined to their homes but are taking up
careers which earlier were exclusive only to men. The counsellor, therefore, should
not look askance at a.female counsellee who does not propose to enter into matrimony
or one who proposes to enter such fields as mountaineering, forestry and the like.
The counsellor would do well to present the facts in full and not try to influence
the counsellee. The Indian attitude towards sex has been different from that of the
OccidenL Sex is looked upon as something intimate, precious and sacred. Sex is not
identified with the fplfilment of carnal desire. Women are not expected to freely
mix with men and they are expected to maintain a certain distance. In contemporary
life when women and men work together in offices and factories side by side it
becomes impractical for women to observe the 'safe distance' dictum. Questions
such as what should be done about pre-inarital sex, sex outside marriage, bigamous
relations, etc. loom large. The masculine altitudes towards these are obviously
biased in their favour. Different standards for men and women create avoidable
confusion, conflict and also crisis. There are several other values of equal importance
but it is not practical to discuss them here for reasons of space.
The counsellor must of necessity widen his field of work to include the new
problems which are surfacing as a result of rapid change. If the counsellor is
understood to be a culture-interpreter, culture-mediator and an agent for culture-
change, he must of necessity move into a wider area (of human Ufe) and make it
the canvas for his work.

INTRODUCnON
Counselling is not a novel institution in the Indian context The first counsellor was
Lord Krishna himself and the Bhagavad Gita embodies the finest principles of
counselling for people of all lands, all ages and of all limes. The Gifa or the Song
Celestial explains how Aijuna, whose mind was in great conflict, was helped to
overcome this conflict through an insight into himself. Aijuna's conflict was one
of 'mine and thine', that is, between Svo and Para. The conflict was resolved throughself-understanding or through self-realization. One has to act in accordance with his
Swadharma. Man should act in accordance with the demands of his station and his
duties in life. Self-realization, understood in the context of the Gita, is not the same
as what we understand by the term in the Rogerian or existential sense. Man has
to realize his inner nature, that is, his spirituality which reveals oneness with the
ultimate. This helps to overcome the illusory distinction between the Atma and the
Paramatama. In the pursuit of the higher spirit, man is concerned with freedom
freedom to obtain self-realization. In modem times the word 'freedom* is used in
a different sense. Its connotation is limited to freedom of xtion, speech, religious
faith as well as freedom to find the fullest expression for one's potential. In this
sense of the term, we are immediately concemed with material existence and the
psysical world.
In the ancient world of the Orient, the pupil has the choice or freedom to seek
his own guru (teacher). The guru, in his turn, was free to give the kind of education
that he thought best suited the pupU and was free in the choice of the method ofinstruction. However, this gurukula system of education could not survive the
onslaughts of repeated foreign invasions. It disappeared and was replaced by aUen
models of education. The element of freedom that was present in the ancienteducational system came to be substituted by regimentation. Pupils had to learn
from a fixed curriculum and teachers were bound to teach along the lines of this
fixed curriculum. Thus freedom disa^ed from the scene of Indian educationIndian society came to be much maligned by the Varnashrama dharma The socie^


--- PAGE 305 ---
The Status ofthe CounsellingMovementIn India 285
ly, century after century, became moreri^d in its dogged and dogmatic adherence
to it. There was no opportunity for social mobiliQ'. Indian society consequently
became highly traditionalistic and conventional. The Vedic prayer
Asato ma Sadgamaya Lead me from the unreal to the real
Taraaso ma Jyotirgamaya Lead me from darkness to light
Mrityor md Amruiamgamaya ... Lead me from death to immortality
has lost its significance in the degenerate society of colonial India. Freedom and
independence have been substituted by dependence. The youth in India today is
dependent on adult members for such important decisions as the choice of residence,
choice of a job and choice of a marital parmer, to mention but a few. What relevaiice
does counselling, therefore, have for ^e Indian situation? The important forces of
social change, namely, industrialization, urbanization, mass media of communication
and the like, have battered the traditional, social conventions and institutions and
have made several dents in them. Compared with the nineteenth century Western
society, contemporary Indian society is more radical and provides enormous
opportunities for individual choice of action. The zeii geist of contemporary Indian
society is quite hospitable to counselling; in fact it makes counselling essential.
The kind of counselling assistance sought for and provided in the western world
need not necessarily be applicable to the Indian society. However, counselling is
as much necessary in India today as it is elsewhere in the world.

started, in 1941, a private agency known as the Batliboy Vocational Guidance

GUIDANCE MOVEMENT AFTER INDEPENDENCE
The major step in the guidance movement was marked by the establishment of the
Vocational Guidance Bureau by the trustees of the Parsi Panchayat. a voluntary
organization in Bombay. The Batliboy Bureau bequeathed its materials to this
bureau. The bureau was primarily meant to help the youth of the Parsi community.
Being a denominational institution run by private philanthropists, the bureau had
inadequate resources. Serious problems owing to lack of funds developed leading
to its closure in the early 1950s. Notwithstanding the several handicaps, the director
of the bureau. Dr. H.P. Mehta, rendered meritorious service to the public of Bombay
in general, and to the Parsi community in particular. Dr. Mehta organized severaltraining courses for career masters at the bureau. The bureau was closed down for
want of adequate financial support in the early 1950s (Chothia and Mehta 1955)
It has been reported that the bureau was again started in the 1960s
The next important and perhaps the most far-reaching step was the apoointment
of the Acharya Narendra Dev Committee by the Government of Uuar Pradesh toexamine the issue of proving guid^ce ^schools. Accepting the recommendations
of the committee, the Uttar Pradesh Government established the Bureau ofPsychology in Allahabad. This was the fust time that a Stale Government had taken
interest in the subject of rendering vocational and educational guidance to school
going pupUs. Dr. C.M. BhaUa, a renowned psychologist and author of Bhatia's
Battery of Performance Tests, was appointed as its fust Director The work done
by this bureau was gready acclaimed. Acceding to the demand to extend the «rvire.
to more pupils, the Government of Uttar Pradesh established five regional hnre^Trat Varanasi. Lucknow, Kanpur, Meerut and BareUly. After about a decaS theGovernment of Bombay (now Maharashtra) set up a vocational EuidauSTnl^
