In 1954 the Government of India set up the Central Bureau of Educational and
Vocational Guidance in New Delhi and the Central Government came forward with
programmes of financial assistance to various States either to start or to expand
llieir existing guidance bureaux. By 1955, 11 State bureaux were established and
there was a steady growth in various other States as well (Gorkal, 1962),
The M.S. University, Baroda, set up counselling services and appointed a full-
thne counsellor in 1958 with the assistance of the University Grants Commission.
Centre did creditable work and it branched off into test developing work which
roust have seriously affected the counselling work proper. The Centre also offered
a two-year part-time course for school teachers, where classes were held on Satur^ys
and Sundays. However, such part-time arrangements could not do much in
professionally equipping the teachers for guidance work in any significant manner.
During the period of the Second and Third Five-Year Plans there was a
tremendous growth in the guidance movement in India resulting in the opening ofnew universities and hundreds of training colleges to meet the demand for trained
teachers for the several thousand secondary schools which came to be opened in
consonance with the Directive Principles of Universal EducaUon, namely. Article
45 of the Constitution. The guidance bureaux came to be attached to the State
Directorates of Education.
The end of the Second World War in 1945 brought in its wake serious problems
of rehabilitating the retrenched defence personnel. To render assistance to these ex-
defence pesonnel (ex-servicemen) the Government of India established employment
exchanges These have grown and become knit into the National EmploymentServices Organization under the Directorate General of Employment and Triiining,
Government of India. Vocational guidance secuons were attached to employinent
exchanges with the implementation of the recommendations of the Shiva Rao
Committee TTie Government of India gave generow assistant to State Governments
to set up Directorates of Employment and Training. In due course, vocationalguidance cells were created in most of the Directorates of Employment and TrainingSt the State Government levels.

The Status of the Counselling Movement In India 269
In 1961, the Allahabad University started a counselling centre for its students
with the assistance of the United States Educational Foundation in India (USEFI).
The reason for its failure, perhaps, was due to its dependence on professors from
American universities, research scholars and students who were brought to India on
the Fulbright Educational Programme. The work at the counselling centre was more
in the nature of a student personnel services centre with a dean of student welfare.
The experiment was not a success and the centre was closed down in 1966.
St. Xavier's College, Bombay, has provided counselling service to its students
since 1955 and the counselling was done by pastors in the beginning. But from
1960, it has tended to become psychologically oriented. The college has a full-time
counsellor. The college provides training facilities for school counsellors at St
Xavier's Institute of Education.
The Wilson College of Bombay set up a counselling centre for its students in
1963 with a counsellor. The Delhi University planned to organize a counselling
centre in 1965 with the assistance of the University Grants Commission (UGC).
The Department of Psychology took the initiative and started the centre which had
a lecturer of psychology in charge. At the Annamalai University also, counselling
services were set up during 1965-66 with the help of a Fulbright Professor. But this
did not succeed as the administration could not decide whether the-counselling
centre should be placed in the Department of Education, or Psychology or Philosophy.
The SNDT Women's University, Bombay, has appointed a dean of students and
they are providing student personnel services on a modest scale.
The overall picture of counselling in India is dismal as far as organized work
and provision of professional services are concerned. Much of what passes for
counselling is of a doubtful nature since few qualified personnel are available. The
University of Baroda, St. Xavier's College, Bombay, and other such instiludons
claim to have offered courses for the training of counsellors.
The most important reason why the status of counselling in India is unenviable
is the lack of employment opportunities. Counselling is presumably done by teachers
drawn from different disciplines who do not have the knowledge, understanding,
enlhusiasm, responsibility or commitment to rentier coimseiling. What usually pKses
as counselling service is a kintl of stuiient service started by a few colleges whose
principals and a few staff members perhaps have pamcipated in student sev.ceLinL organised in India and USA under the auspices of USEFI. It is essennalto recOEuiae that student personnel services are not the same as counselling.Counsellins Is psychotherapeutlc assistance mquinng academic preparation,"  . g P supervised internship. Two professional bodies in the field are the All India Vocational Guidance
Association started in 1954 and the National Vocational and Educational Guidance

The latter organization is more homogeneous and its membership is open to
individuals with a master's degree in psychology or education. This body is reported
to have an active membership of 60 life members and 300 ordinary members.

SECTION A
GENERAL
1. The member sincerely and deliberately strives to foster the development and
Improvement of tiie prof^lon.
2. The member has an obligation to Improve himself continuously by gaining
knowledge and acquiring skills to grow professionally throughout his career.
3. The member has a responsibility to the Institution which he serves. Therefore,
his professional acuities have to be In accord with the objectives of me
Institution.
4. The member must expect ethical behaviour among his professional associates
in NVEGA at all times. He Is under obligation to draw attention to any lapses
of members, and to attempt to rectl^ such conditions.
5. The member Is obliged to acquaint himself with the personnel functions of
non-members whose work Is expected to be competent and conform to.the
ethical standards. Where his Information raises serious doubt as to the ethical
behaviour of such persons. It Is his responsibility to attempt to recH^ sudi
conditions.
6. The member must not seek self-enhancement through expressing evaluation
or comparisons damaging to other professional workers.
7. The member should not claim professional qualifications exceeding those
possessed and Is responsible for correcting any misrepresentations oif hisqualifications by others.
8 The member providing services for personal remuneration shall. In. charging
fees for such services, take careful account of the charges made for comparable
services ty other professional persons.
9 The member who provides Information to the public or to his subordinates,
peers, or superiors has a dear responslblUly-to see that both the content andttw rnanner of presentation are accurate and appropriate.
10 The member has an obligation to ensure that evaluative Infonnatlon about■ persons, such as dlents. students, and applicants shall be shared only vrith
^ose persons who will use such Information for sWctly professional purposesand that their confidentiality Is not Impinged.. 1 The member shall offer professional services only ttuough the context of a
orofesslonal relationship. Thus testing, counselling and other services are not
to be provided through the mall 1^ means of newspaper, magazine artldes.public performances or through any other media.

SECHON B
COUNSELLING
This section refers to practices InvoMitg a counselling relationship wldi a counsellee
or client and Is not Interxled to be applicable to practices Involving administrative
relationships with the persons being helped.
A counselling relationship denotes that the person seeking help retains full freedom
of choice ar)d dedslw and that the helping poson has tio authorl^ or responsibility
to ^prove or disapprove of the choices or decisions of the counsellee or client.
"Counsellee" or "client" Is used here to Indicate the person for whom ttie member has
assumed a professional responsibility. The counsellee or client Is the Individual with
whom the member has direct and primary contact.
1. The member's primary obligation Is to respect die Integrity and promote die
wellare of the client with vdwm he Is worMng.
Z. The counselling reladonshlp and Informadon resulting therefrom must be kept
conBdentlal, consistent wldi the obligations of die member as a professlorial
person.
3. CounselUiig materials, such as records of counselling lncludlr\g Interview notes,
test data, correspondence, tape recordings, and odier documents are to be
considered profeulonal Information for use In counselling. Research and teaching
of counsellors empl^ng the above materials shall be always with foil protection
of the Idend^ of the client and ^th precaution so that no harm is done or
arises to adversely afliect the client.
4. The client should have complete and full knowledge of the conditions under
vAlch he mey receive counselling assistance at or before the time he enters
die counselling relationship.
5. The member reserves the right to consult ar^ other professionally competent
petson(s) about his client. In choodng his professional consultants} the member
must avoid pladt^g the consultant(s) In any embarrassing situadon.
6. The member shall terminate a counselling relationship when he cannot be of
professional assistance to the client because of lack of competence or personal
liinltadon. In such instances the member shall refer his counsellee or client to
an appr^rlate specialist. In the event die client declines the suggested referral,
die member Is not obligated to continue die counselling relationship.
7. When die member leams from the counselling relationship of conditions which
are Ukely to harm others over whom his institution or agency has responsibility,
he Is expected to.report die condition to die appropriate responsible authority,
but In such a manner as not to reveal the Identity of his counsellee.
8. In the event that the counsellee's condition is such as to require others to
assume responslbllify for him, or when diere Is clear and Imminent danger to
die counsellee or to odiers, die member Is expected to report the fact to an
appropriate responsible authority, and/or take such other emergent measures
as the situadon demands.
9. Should the member be engaged In a work-setting which calls for any vartadon
from the above statements, die member Is obliged to ascertain that such
variations are Justifiable under the conditions and that such vailadons are
clearly specified Jind made known to all concerned with such counselling
service.

SECTION E
CONSULTING AND PRIVATC PRACTICE
Consulting refers to a voluntaiy reladonshlp between a professlor^ helper and help-
needing Instltudon (Industry, business, school, college, etc.) In which the consultant
Is attempting to give help to the client In the solution of some current or potential
problem.
1. The member acting as a consultant must have a high degree of self-awareness
of his own values and needs In entering a helping relationship which involves
charge In a social Institution.
2. There should be understanding and agreement between corrsultant and client
as to the direction and goals of the attempted change.
3. The consultant must be reasonably certain that he or his organization has die
necessary skills and resources for giving die kind of help which Is needed.
4. The consulting relationship must be one In which client adaptablll^ and growth
toward self-direction are encouraged and cultivated. The consultant must
consistently maintain his role as a consultant and not become a decision
maker for die client.
5. The consultant. In announcing his avallablll^ for service as a consultant, follows
prof^lonal ladier than commercial standards In describing his services with
accuracy, dignity and caution.

SECTION F
PERSONNEL ADMINISTRATION
1. The member Is responsible for establishing working agreements with supertvlsors
and with subordinates especially regarding counselling relationships,
confidentiality, distinction between public and private material, and a mutiia]
respect for the positions of parties Involved In such Issues.
Such working agreements may vary from one Insltutlonal setHng to another.
What should be die case In each Instance, however. Is that agreements should
have been specified, made known to those concerned, and whenever possible,
the agreements should reflect Institutional policy rather than personal Judgement.
2. The member's responsibility to his superiors requires that he keeps them
Informed of the conditions aflectlrrg the Institution, particularly those which
may be potentially disrupting or damaglrrg to the Institution.
3. The memt»r fias the responslblll^ to select competent persons for assigned
responsibilities and to see that his personnel are used maximally In the skills
and experlene tfiey possess.
4. The member has the responsibility of constantly stimulating his staff for their
and his own continued growth and Improvement. He must see that staff
members are adequately supervised as to the quality of their functioning and
for purposes of profosslonal development.
SECTION G
PREPARATION FOR PROFESSIONAL WORK
1. The member In charge of the training provides a sound programme of academic
study and supervised practice In order to prepare die trainees for their future
